item.title: Board notes - October 2022
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Oct. 11, 2022

Welcoming new faculty
Four new faculty members were introduced. They are: Kamron Geiger, assistant professor and clinical coordinator, Radiography Program; Carrie Hale, assistant professor and program director, Paramedic Program; Kim Libby, assistant professor and clinical coordinator, Physical Therapist Assistant program; and Mark Mitchell, assistant professor and program coordinator, Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice programs.
 
Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Supplemental tax provision
  • Planning for use of Protection, Health and Safety funds
  • Tuition and course reimbursement

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • The UV-C lighting project started during COVID-19 is complete. UV-C lighting within air handlers is an effective way of improving air quality and killing viruses.
  • A peer reviewer from KCC's accreditor, the Higher Learning Commission, will be making a Multi-Location Visit on Nov. 2 and 3. The review will include the Manufacturing & Industrial Technology Center, and North Extension Center.
  • The renovation of the North Patio to make it more accessible for the disabled remains in the planning stage. It is expected to be several months until completion.

There was no Illinois Community College Trustees Association report from Bill Orr.

Student Trustee's Report. Morgan Fisher said …

  • It is Domestic Violence Awareness month. A "Red flag" campaign is being held on the Riverfront Campus.
  • Recent activities have included Nothing Bundt Cakes fundraiser (Oct. 11); Constitution Bingo (Sept. 15); a Versiti Blood Drive with 39 donors (Sept. 27); STEM Club rocket launch (Oct. 4); and Horticulture Club fall mum sale (Sept. 14). All but two sports teams were in action at KCC on a recent Saturday (Sept. 17).
  • Underway now is the presale of the Veteran's Club Krispy Kreme doughnut sale. On Oct. 20, Tropicante will have a performance at KCC as part of Latinx Heritage Month. A Halloween caricature artist is coming as well.
  • She attended the Illinois Community College Board Student Advisory Council meeting to represent KCC. She was appointed as the secretary for the group.
  • It has been great to see the college alive with activity this fall.
Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 10/13/2022
Expires: 10/28/2022
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

Phi Theta Kappa will have their 5th annual sleep-out this Friday, October 14th at the fire pit near the pavilion. 

This is a service project that began in 2018 to bring awareness and donations to the homeless in our community. Each participant commits to raising $50 for Fortitude Community Outreach and sleeping in a box for one night.

If you would like to donate, please make your check payable to Fortitude Community Outreach and bring it to Frances Hebert or Jackie Montemayer.

item.title: Annuitants Chapter meeting
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

KCC SUAA Members (and other employees),

Registration opened Monday, October 10, 2022 for our upcoming KCC SUAA Chapter Meeting on October 24, 2022, at Chicago Dough Company, 545 S. Main St., Bourbonnais, Il. The cost is $15 per person. Menu includes salad bar, pizza buffet (vegetarian, sausage, pepperoni, etc), soft drink, (tax and gratuity included). SUAA is the State Universities Annuitants Association.

Registration with payment must be received by Thursday, October 20, 2022! No payments will be taken at the meeting itself. No exceptions. If you are on campus, you can register by dropping off your payment to Mary Posing at the KCC Welcome Center. If you are not on campus, mail your payment to Mary Posing, 1520 Amhurst Way, Bourbonnais, Il 60914. Checks should be made out to KCC SUAA Chapter. 

Come hear Executive Director Linda Brookhart speak about the latest legislation in Springfield that could affect KCC employees/retirees. Linda will also be available after the meeting to talk with you and answer questions. 

 

  • 5:30    Check in
  • 5:50    Dinner - pizza buffet, salad bar, soft drink
  • 6:20    SUAAction Report
  • 6:30    Business Meeting
  • 7:00    Election of Officers
  • 7:10    Speaker: Executive Director Linda Brookhart 
  • 7:30    Adjournment

Registration is open to KCC employees, chapter members and their guests. Bring a potential new member with you! New members are always welcome!


Author: Linda Guinn, KCCAA President
Article Date: 10/12/2022
Expires: 10/24/2022
item.author: Stephanie Pizzoferrato

item.title: Topic - Phishing
item.description:
Article Description: By now most of you are familiar with the social engineering attack known as phishing as you have undoubtedly heard about it numerous times.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

By now most of you are familiar with the social engineering attack known as phishing as you have undoubtedly heard about it numerous times. But even today phishing is still the most common method bad actors use to compromise networks and organizations. As such, it cannot be discussed enough when it comes to security awareness training.

So far, the phishing attempts that I have highlighted have all been centered around e-mail; however, there are various methods of phishing involving text, instant messaging, and even just picking up the phone to call the target.

For this week's topic, I've included various links that delve into more details on phishing and the steps you can take to "stay safe online"

Lastly, if you are enjoying the content being presented during Cybersecurity Awareness month, would like to offer up a suggestion, or have a question, please feel free to e-mail me at moconnor@kcc.edu.

Interactive Training Module: Phishing - Don't Get Reeled In

Video: Credential Harvesting (Phone Phish)

Study Guide: Uncovering and Reviewing Links

Author: Michael OConnor
Article Date: 10/12/2022
Expires: 10/18/2022
item.author: Michael OConnor

item.title: Flu Clinic is Coming Today
item.description:
Article Description: October 12, 2022 from 1:30-3pm in room M130
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:


Today is the day! On Wednesday, October 12 from 1:30-3:00pm, faculty and staff can receive a flu shot here on the Riverfront (main) campus in room M130. 

If you are interested, please email Breanna Heimberger (bheimberger@kcc.edu)  and she will send you the consent form to complete ahead of time.  Please bring this completed consent form, along with your insurance card and they will bill the insurance directly, without you having to pay a co-pay.

The pharmacist will also have COVID-19 vaccines, pneumonia shots, shingles shots and tetanus shots if anyone is also interested. If you are interested in receving a COVID-19 booster, please bring your vaccination card with you to be updated. 

If you have any questions, please call Breanna at ext. 8146.


Author: Breanna Heimberger
Article Date: 10/12/2022

item.title: Proposals now being taken for spring 2023 faculty in-service
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Proposals are now being taken for the Spring 2023 Faculty In-Service.

As we begin to plan and prepare for the next Faculty In-Service event in January, we are now inviting session proposals from all areas of the college.

  • If you are a faculty member at KCC, please do consider sharing any teaching and learning topic with peers.  This type of collegial sharing is so vitally important as a resource to other attending faculty.
  • If you lead a division, department, office, or committee.. do you have important updates and/or initiatives underway for which you would like time at the next in-service?

Please respond by Oct. 31 with:

  • Session Topic/Title:
  • Amount of time requested (i.e. 15 minutes, 30 minutes, 1 hour, other?):
  • Preferred format (whole group, breakout, either):
  • Other comments?:

Thank you for taking time to help us gather and collect great ideas for our next event program!

Craig Keigher (ckeigher@kcc.edu)

item.title: Social Engineering: Anatomy of an Attack
item.description:
Article Description: It’s hard not to be intrigued, and even impressed, by the nature of some of these social engineering attacks.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

It's hard not to be intrigued, and even impressed, by the nature of some of these social engineering attacks.

About two weeks ago someone reached out to me share a social engineering/phishing attempt that was targeted towards them. It involved PayPal.

The individual had received an e-mail for a PayPal money request. They were suspicious because they did not recognize the name of the requestor, so they launched the PayPal app on their phone and sure enough there was the money request. So far things are matching up and they are thinking this might be legitimate.

But what caught their attention next was this. There was a note in the money request that said …

"We've detected that your PayPal account has been accessed fraudulently. If you did not make this transaction, please call us at toll free number +1 (888) 993-xxxx to cancel and claim a refund. If this is not the case, you will be charged $500. 00 today. Within the automated deduction of the amount, this transaction will reflect on PayPal activity after 24 hours. Our Service Hours: (07:00 a. m. to 06:00 p. m. Pacific Time, Monday through Friday)."

The question for the user was "Did PayPal security insert this message in the money request, and do I need to call the toll-free number OR was this placed by the attacker?"

After further review, the individual decided this was a scam and that message in the money request was from the attacker.

So what happened here? How can something like this happen? What if the individual had called the number? What can be done to protect yourself? There's a myriad of questions that come to mind and I'll try and answer them with this article.

First, this hack can be accomplished by anyone. It requires no special training or skills. The attacker simply goes to PayPal and makes a money request, usually by sending it to an individual's e-mail. As part of the money request process, the requestor can elect to insert a note. It is within this field where the "… account has been accessed fraudulently" message is inserted. The attacker then hits [Send Request] and waits, hoping that the recipient will see it as a valid request and call the toll-free number.

So what is the attacker hoping to accomplish? In this case it is to gain access to the target's personal financial information. That could be credit card number, expiration, card security code, bank account, bank routing information, etc..

This attack is possible because the PayPal money request application allows a requestor to insert a note. This field does not appear to be validated by PayPal so any message can be inserted.

But what makes it really clever is that the "red flags" we would normally use to detect a fraudulent message all either check out, i.e. email sent address was service@paypal.com, amount requested from the e-mail and phone app matched OR can be substantiated by the "call PayPal because this request is fraudulent" message, which we might do because we don't recognize the sender's name and do not want to lose $500 dollars.

So what action could you take if you had received this message and were still uncertain whether it was a legitimate? The best course of action would be to go to PayPal.com and use the contact information from the website to contact them to determine the legitimacy of the message.

I hope you found this little tale interesting as well as informative. Social Engineering prays on people's behavior and in this case, they are praying on the individual's fear of losing money. So until next time, "stay safe online" out there!


Author: Michael OConnor
Article Date: 10/7/2022
Expires: 10/14/2022
item.author: Michael OConnor

item.title: Media preferences survey underway
item.description:
Article Description: Facebook or Instagram?
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC's Marketing department always wants to know more about our students' attitudes, opinions, and media consumption habits. 

Partnering with Interact Communications, we are encouraging students to complete the Media Prefs survey. The survey will remain open through Nov. 13.

Faculty, if you could please announce the survey in class encouraging students to look for the link in coming emails and posts on KCC social media channels.

Staff, if you could please encourage the momentum by sharing with students when appropriate and directing them to their email for more information, we would certainly appreciate it. 

To take the survey, students should go to:
www.mediaprefs.com/illinois
survey code: Illinois
password: Illinois

The more students who participate, the stronger our data will be. As you know, these types of questions can provide critical information for marketing and communication at our college. They can additionally help target recruitment efforts for your programs.

Other important information to note:

  • It is voluntary
  • It is anonymous
  • It takes approximately 20-30 minutes to complete depending on their computer skills
  • It can be taken from a computer, tablet, or smartphone
  • It is intended to be taken by currently enrolled students only, please
  • All information entered will be kept confidential and non-identifiable
  • Participating students can choose to enter a drawing at the conclusion of the survey to win a prize put together by the college

This is an opportunity to gather some very helpful information from our students that assists with more effective marketing and planning. Having accurate, fresh data is more important than ever.

If you have any questions, contact me at knugent@kcc.edu.


Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 10/5/2022
Expires: 11/4/2022
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Seizure Guidelines for the Classroom
item.description:
Article Description: Any KCC employee witnessing a medical emergency, including a seizure, call 911 immediately.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Any KCC employee witnessing a medical emergency, including seizure, call 911 immediately.

Medical management of a seizure disorder is not always totally effective. Students who have disclosed their medical condition to the Office of Disability Services (ODS) are encouraged to communicate with their professors about what to expect in the event of a medical episode. ODS will notify instructors of which classes a student with a history of seizures are enrolled in order to be prepared, but because students are not required to disclose any disability, ODS has created this information as a resource in the event a student experiences a seizure in your class. Since most staff and faculty are not medical personnel, it is KCCs procedure to immediately call 911.


What is a Seizure?

A seizure is a sudden surge of electrical activity in the brain that usually affects how a person feels or acts for a short time. The three most common seizure disorders are Generalized Tonic-Clonic (Grand Mal), The Absence (Petit Mal), and Complex Partial (Psychomotor or Temporal Lobe).  Each type has different effects on different individuals.  Not all seizures are as evident as the Grand Mal.  Some are undetectable except to the trained observer. Some seizures can hardly be noticed, while others are totally disabling. Students may be aware when a seizure with convulsions is coming on. The seizures may last from 1 to 3 minutes, and consciousness returns slowly. Students may be drowsy, confused, agitated, or depressed when it's over. Some students have seizures that are difficult to notice. They may "zone out" anywhere from a few seconds to 20 seconds at a time. During the seizure, the students won't be able to hear you, may blink repetitively, make chewing movements, or just stare. They may be completely alert following this kind of seizure. Here are some common questions you may have and hopefully answers that are helpful.


What should I do if a student discloses, they have seizures?

  • Listen carefully to the information that the student shares.
  • Ask questions. "What happens during your seizures?" "How long are your seizures?" "Do you know when you might experience a seizure?" "Are there any 'triggers' that might induce a seizure, such as flicking lights, moving patterns, high stress, sleep deprivation?" "What do you experience after a seizure?"
  • Identify a place where the student could rest after a seizure if one occurs.
  • If you and the student choose to notify the class in advance, inform them that someone in the class may have a seizure, without identifying the student.
  • Ask if the student needs preferential seating (near the door?).
  • Recommend the student register with ODS if they haven't done so, to take advantage of full accommodations under federal law.
  • Look into scheduling an alternative classroom nearby to resume class once first responders arrive and have taken over the situation.

What should I do if an actual seizure occurs? (This information is adapted from the CDC, Center for Disease Control and Prevention.)

For tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizures:

  • While the CDC states, "Seizures do not usually require emergency medical attention." it is KCCs policy to dial 911 when a student is experiencing an active grand mal seizure.
  • Stay calm.
  • Ease the person to the floor.
  • Turn the person gently onto one side. This will help the person breathe.
  • Clear the area around the person of anything hard or sharp. This can prevent injury.
  • Put something soft and flat, like a folded jacket, under his or her head.
  • Remove eyeglasses.
  • Loosen ties or anything around the neck that may make it hard to breathe.
  • Time the seizure, if possible.
  • Stay with the student until first responders arrive.
  • Ask other students to leave the room.
    - Look into scheduling an alternative classroom nearby to resume class once first responders arrive and have taken over the situation.

    What should I NOT DO?

    • Do not hold the person down or try to stop his or her movements.
    • Do not put anything in the person's mouth. This can injure teeth or the jaw. A person having a seizure cannot swallow his or her tongue.
    • Do not try to give mouth-to-mouth breaths (like CPR). People usually start breathing again on their own after a seizure.
    • Do not offer the person water or food until he or she is fully alert. 

    For petite mal or complex seizures, 911 may not be necessary unless:

    • You notice there is difficulty breathing or waking after the seizure.
    • The seizure lasts more than 5 minutes.
    • The person has another seizure soon after the first one.
    • The person is hurt.
    • The seizure happens in water.
    • The person has other health conditions like diabetes, heart disease, or is pregnant.

    What can I expect after a seizure?

    • A student may experience significant disorientation, memory loss, loss of concentration, and alternations in behavior as well as fatigue and headaches which can last several days depending on the intensity of the seizure and where the seizure occurs in the brain.
    • You can expect the student to go home to recover.

    What types of accommodations are in place for a student who experiences seizures?

    Seizure disorders are difficult to deal with academically because of the time element lost (particularly during in-class assignments, tests, and other classroom activities). The following information and suggested accommodations will assure that the student with a seizure disorder is afforded every opportunity to succeed academically:

    • The student should not be penalized for a missed class, even if an attendance policy is in place (there are program exceptions).
    • Have backup assignments prepared for the student to complete for missed in-class activities.
    • Permit the student to tape classes and/or assist in securing a volunteer note taker to assure that s/he will have a record of lectures, assignments, class discussions, and announcements.
    • Please be patient if a student with a seizure disorder asks or repeats questions previously discussed or answered during class.
    • Allow the student additional time for tests and examinations in a separate location with reduced distractions.  Oral testing may be appropriate.
    • Allow students extra out-of-class time (within reason) to catch up or reorient themselves to class notes and/or assignments.
    • Look into scheduling an alternative classroom nearby to resume class once first responders arrive and have taken over the situation.
    Author: Sherry Kinzler
    Article Date: 10/4/2022
    Expires: 10/25/2022
item.author: Stephanie Pizzoferrato

item.title: Topic - Social Engineering
item.description:
Article Description: Social engineering is the art of manipulating, influencing, or deceiving a person in order to get them to divulge confidential information.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Social engineering is the art of manipulating, influencing, or deceiving a person in order to get them to divulge confidential information. The hacker might use the phone, email, snail mail or direct contact to gain illegal access. Phishing, spear phishing, and CEO fraud (aka "whaling") are all examples of social engineering attacks.

Those of you may remember a story I shared about how a hacker was able to successfully gain access to an employee's e-mail through a phishing attack and then attempted to contact KCC's payroll department to have that employee's paycheck deposited into an account that the hacker controlled. Both the successful access to the employee's e-mail, as well as the attempt to trick KCC's payroll clerk, involved social engineering.

For this topic, I've included various links that delve into more details about social engineering and the steps you can take to "stay safe online"

Interactive Training Module: Social Engineering Red Flags

Video: Understanding URLs

Study Guide: Social Engineering


Author: Michael OConnor
Article Date: 10/3/2022
Expires: 10/11/2022
item.author: Michael OConnor

item.title: October is Cybersecurity Awareness Month
item.description:
Article Description: October is Cybersecurity Awareness Month, a global effort to help everyone stay safe and protected when using technology whenever and however you connect.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

It's Easy to Stay Safe Online

October is Cybersecurity Awareness Month, a global effort to help everyone stay safe and protected when using technology whenever and however you connect. The theme for the month is "It's easy to stay safe online" and Kankakee Community College is happy to support this online safety and education initiative for the first time. 

Cybersecurity has become one of the largest, most focused topics, both inside and outside, of technology circles over the last several years. From securing learning devices due to a rise in digital learning and remote work, increase of phishing attacks targeting higher education, to coping with the fallout of high‑profile breaches. Some people have a misperception that cybersecurity is beyond everyday people and that it should be left to the professionals. Some people believe that breaches are simply a fact of life and that we should just learn to deal with them. But nothing could be further from the truth.

As everyday technology users, we have a key role to play in cybersecurity threat prevention, detection, and remediation.  

Throughout October, KCC will raise awareness on key best practices that we can implement today to enhance our own cybersecurity and create a more secure environment for everyone.

item.title: KCC Common Read Program Kick-Off and Jeans Day
item.description:
Article Description: Join us on Sept. 27 for the kick-off program and read more for an opportunity to wear jeans that day!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​2022-2023 KCC Common Read - American Like Me, edited by America Ferrera

Article Content:

The inaugural KCC Common Read program will begin on Tuesday, September 27th with a kick-off celebration in the College Center from 11 a.m. – 1 p.m., and comments at 12:15.

The title selected for this year's campus and community KCC Common Read is American Like Me, Reflections of Life Between Cultures, edited by America Ferrera, whose acting you may be familiar with from Ugly Betty, Sisterhood of the Travelling Pants, or Superstore.  It features chapters from Issa Rae, Jeremy Lin, Lin-Manuel Miranda, and Padma Lakshmi, among others, discussing their experiences navigating their connections to more than one culture and their struggles in finding connection and belonging.

The KCC Common Read, jointly sponsored by the Miner Memorial Library and the Center for Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion, will run through April, with at least one event per month, and is open to anyone who would like to participate – students, faculty, staff, and members of the community.  Reading schedules and event information will be available at the kick-off event – no reading needs to be done prior to the 27th.  Program information will also be shared to the campus through multiple communication channels after the 27th.  We hope staff and faculty will read the book and participate in the programming through the remainder of this academic year.

Donate a book, Wear Jeans

The book is available in paperback on Amazon for $12.49.  We would like to provide copies for students who many want to participate but can't afford a copy.  If you would like to buy an extra copy for a student, or provide the funding needed for one copy, you can wear jeans on Tuesday, September 27th.  Drop off the book or cash at the library and receive a sticker to proclaim your support of this initiative.

item.description:
Article Description: Student Affairs retains trophy and bragging rights for another year
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

Student Affairs Prevails

Article Content:


The questions were asked earlier, "Can the Student Affairs team win for the fourth time in four years? Or, will they be dethroned by the Business Affairs team?"  Not only could they, they did.

The Student Affairs team won in two straight games by scores of 1-0, and 3-1.  Bryce Shafer was selected as the Most Valuable Player for his stellar defensive plays, as well as his strategic kicks.  

Congrats to Coach Megan Ponton and her team of: Melany Duax, Mya Eason, Quante Grant, Hassel Hernandez, Adam Lee, Kriston Love, Rylee Mann, Todd Post, Jason Rodriguez, and Bryce Shafer.  


The Business Affairs team consisted of Genesis Carino Crespo, Jake Fansler, Lilli Fitzpatrick, Amanda Hubert, Braedon MacDonald, Brady McCue, Alex Smith, and Keion Whitaker, coached by David Cagle.

Special thanks to Todd Post for lining the field, George Mateja and his crew for providing picnic tables, Tyler Wheeler and Shaun McSparin for scorekeeping/timekeeping, Ellen Schmidt, Cesar Avalos, and Vern Turner for officiating, Joe Martin for serving as photographer, and Janet Fager, Toni Hundley, Breanna Heimberger, & Sheri Cagle for serving refreshments to the players and fans.

item.title: Board Notes - September 2022
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Sept. 12, 2022

 
Action Items. The Board approved the following:
Recommendation to accept grant awards for Talent Search and Upward Bound
Bid award to purchase a RV, which will be used as a recruitment tool and mobile classroom unit
Lease agreement with Illinois Network of Child Care Resource and Referral Birth to Five program
Lease agreement for the KCC South Extension Center in Watseka
Resolutions honoring retirees

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • The Census Day Enrollment report revealed an increased 3% in headcount and 5.9% in credit hours for Fall 2022 as compared to Fall 2021. Early analyses showed additional international students enrolled this fall, more students enrolled in the programs that reside in renovated area of the Technology building, and an increased number of high school students in the Early College program. Increases may also be attributed to enhanced Strategic Enrollment Management activities.
  • The Highway Construction Career Training Program cohort of Pembroke residents recently completed projects in that area.
  • The KCC Police Department has achieved the highest recognition level for policy management from Lexipol, a police/public safety and training provider.
  • Gap Year program begins Sept. 19 and is intended to help potential students explore career and program options before the spring semester.

 
Student Trustee's Report. Morgan Fisher said …

  • Trio took students on college visits at Governors State University and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
  • The office of Student Life and SAC expanded Welcome Week from one to two weeks. During the first week of classes, SAC members and others focused on greeting students and helping them get to the right classrooms. Events and activities were offered during the second week of classes.

item.title: Let's rebuild the picture library
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The marketing department could use your help as we rebuild our photo library.

Our main need is photos from classes that can be featured on the web site, in recruitment materials and in other college publications. 

So, if you have a class that is doing something visually interesting, please contact me (Ellen Schmidt, eschmidt@kcc.edu or ext. 8279). Include the day, time, location and what we'll be seeing. I'll let you know if we can get a photographer to be there.

A few parameters

  • We do our best to get names and permission from students in pictures. We'll either do that as the pictures are taken (potentially a class disruption) or will send you thumbnails to get identifications and permission slips (extra time for you). At each class, we check with the professor to see which of those options is preferred.
  • If we can't make it to the suggested, we can talk more to see if there any other dates.
  • Once we have enough pictures covering any given program area, we might decide to wait for next semester to get more.

Upcoming professional photo sessions

The college's contract photographer from The Image Group will be here Sept. 21, 5:30-8:30 p.m.; Sept. 29, 9 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.; and Oct. 13, 8:30-10 a.m.

During those times, we'll go to a variety of classes. I'll send notes to professors who have classes we plan to visit on those days.

If you have any questions about photos featuring our students, please let me know.

item.title: Best Practices for Meetings that we Learned during Covid
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Best Practices to follow 

Article Content:

We have all learned a great deal from Covid these past 2.5 years.  But what have we learned when it comes to hosting or attending meetings?  Here are some best practices to follow: 

  • If you are hosting a meeting, please offer a hybrid option where people can attend in person, or virtually through WebEx or Zoom.  We have employees who work at three other locations besides the Riverfront campus, as well as some employees who might be working remotely that day.  By offering a virtual option, participation in meetings should hopefully increase.
  • Hosts should keep meetings concise and focused on the agenda - virtual meetings need to be less about the host and more about finding ways to keep all participants engaged.
  • Hosts need to reserve a room location that allows for hosting virtual meetings.  A list of rooms has been identified in 25Live (KCC's scheduling software).
  • Hosts will need to launch the virtual meeting software from the in-room computer, which allows the camera/microphone to be available for the meeting.
  • Hosts should log on at least 15 minutes before the scheduled time of the meeting just in case any technical difficulties arise.
  • Host should use the virtual meeting tools that are appropriate to the virtual meeting platform. For example, use a virtual meeting whiteboard vs an actual whiteboard so that all participants are engaged.

So what if you are not hosting a meeting, but are attending a virtual meeting?  Here are some best practices to follow as well:

  • Please contact ITS prior to attending a virtual meeting to ensure you have adequate technology.
  • Test your virtual meeting platform connection 30 minutes prior to the start of your meeting – this will ensure the functionality of your equipment and that your setup is ready to go.
  • Focus on the meeting at hand – attending meetings virtually requires a greater level of discipline as you are subject to many outside distractions during the meeting.
    • Move to a location where distractions are less likely to occur
    • If attending from your campus office, set your desk phone to Do Not Disturb, close your door, and consider posting an "in-meeting" sign on your door
    • Reduce/Close applications to minimize distractions on your computer
    • Run the meeting software in full screen and turn your video on
    • Remove any pets away from your virtual meeting space
    • Be sure to MUTE your microphone if you are not speaking, and unmute your microphone when speaking
  • Use a professional/business appropriate background. If your background is not suitable (e.g. bedroom, messy office) it is recommended that you either move to another location, blur your background, or switch to one of the KCC provided virtual backgrounds. https://www.kcc.edu/about/#social-media-at-kcc
  • No audio or video not related to the meeting should be in the background
  • Avoid eating or smoking/vaping on camera
  • Wear normal business casual attire during your virtual meeting
  • Be engaged and participate in the meeting – avoid multi-tasking and give your full attention to the meeting as if you were meeting face to face 

Should you have any questions on any of these best practices to follow, please contact David at ext. 8128.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 9/8/2022
Expires: 9/30/2022
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Free counseling services available to students
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Reminder: 4 FREE counseling sessions are available for enrolled KCC students this fall.

Students can get help if they are experiencing:

  • Anxiety
  • Depression
  • Relationship conflicts
  • Lack of motivation 
  • LBGTQ+
  • And more....

Support is also available related to:

  • Domestic abuse
  • Transportation issues
  • Stress management
  • Homelessness
  • Single parents/childcare
  • And more....

Please refer them to Michelle Thorpe, counseling psychologist (pictured).

For students in crisis or needing immediate help, Michelle's direct line is: 312-588-9437 or email michelle@transformativegrowth.org 

For general inquiries about services or students wanting to set up an initial appointment--and it is not a crisis--please have them contact the main line at 630-423-6010 or email contact@transformativegrowth.org 

Remind students when calling the main line to tell the secretary that they are a KCC student so they can get their free services!

Information is also available from Jeremy Kingery, director of student success, at 815-802-8524 or jkingery@kcc.edu.

Counseling is confidential and the first four sessions are FREE. For long-term treatment, payments are accepted including insurance, self-pay, and a sliding scale.

item.title: Best Book Tournament
item.description:
Article Description: KCC's English Department is hosting a tournament!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The English Department is hosting a tournament for the best book among KCC faculty favorites. The bracket is made up of book titles nominated by faculty members. Everyone is invited to participate in the tournament by voting! You can vote even if you haven't read all of the books. We recommend reading a description or synopsis of each of the books and deciding which one you'd prefer to read — and then vote accordingly! Perhaps you will find some great titles to add to your reading list by participating. 😊

Every week until the end of the tournament, at least two books will go head-to-head. Your votes will help determine the winner!

When you vote each week, you may also provide your email address to be added to a raffle sponsored by the English department. The grand prize includes a copy of the winning book from the tournament as well as a booklight. Other prizes include book-related stickers, bookmarks, and more! Each week you vote and share your email is another entry in the raffle.

Vote by going to https://tinyurl.com/2p9yh62h!

Voting begins on Monday, September 5. Each round of voting lasts for one week, with a new round beginning on the following Monday until the end of the tournament. The winning title will be announced on Monday, October 31 and the winners of the raffle will be contacted via the email addresses they provided.

To see which books are winning their rounds each week, please visit the English Department's bulletin board in the D-wing of the third floor.

item.title: Save the Date - Flu Clinic Coming
item.description:
Article Description: 10/12/22 from 1:30-3pm
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​On Wednesday, October 12 from 1:30-3:00pm, faculty and staff can receive a flu shot here on the Riverfront (main) campus. 

If you are interested, please email Breanna Heimberger (bheimberger@kcc.edu)  and she will send you the consent form to complete ahead of time.  Please bring this completed consent form, along with your insurance card and they will bill the insurance directly, without you having to pay a co-pay.

item.title: ​Insights from the RISC Survey
item.description:
Article Description: Sometimes, connection makes all the difference.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

(originally posted July 28)

The introduction to the survey results provides the best description of what the RISC survey is all about: "The Revealing institutional Strengths and Challenges (RISC) survey provides detailed, actionable data about student success."  More specifically, the survey looks at the challenges students face, interactions with campus offices, and overall perceptions of the college.  For many years, KCC had administered the Noel Levitz Student Satisfaction Indicators (SSI) survey; however, we felt we needed a fresh approach to understanding the student experience at KCC, so we opted to administer the RISC survey in Spring 2022.  The results are now available and reveal a number of important insights we should consider.

When selecting among 80 unique challenges presented on the survey, 60% of KCC's respondents selected one or more major challenges in the category of "work and personal issues."  Even more specifically, many of the students who selected this challenge indicated that "work hours do not leave me enough time to study."  Anecdotally, we've always known that our students' need to work while they study has been a complicating factor in their pursuit of excellence in the classroom, and the data confirm this to be a central challenge facing the students we serve here at KCC.

Students also provided information about interactions with KCC offices, and the results were mostly positive.  For example, KCC's performance exceeded benchmarks for financial aid, academic advising, student activities, and the EDI Center.  This is great news because it means that our students find support in these offices to be available, concerned, and effective.  We'll need to continue working hard to sustain this level of performance, but we'll also need to be intentional about improving in the one area where we underperformed in relation to the benchmark – counseling services.  As we move into the new academic year, it is going to be so important for all of us to make students aware of the counseling service we have on campus and to reassure our students that it's okay to ask for help.

Reviewing students' perceptions of KCC gave me a feeling of pride to be a part of this college.  Our students are much more likely than students at other colleges to recommend KCC to a friend.  I can't think of a better compliment one of our students could give us besides making a recommendation to enroll here.  Overall, the RISC survey data show that KCC's students have a great experience here at the college. 

"I love KCC and all it stands for.  Great way to achieve my dreams that works with my life."  That's what one student chose to write into the RISC survey.  What an inspiration it is to know that we've played such an important role in helping someone achieve their dreams.  Not every student feels this way, of course, but shouldn't we strive every day to create a student experience like the one this student described? Make it a personal goal to connect with students. A small gesture or interaction can have a real impact.

Editor's note: To access RISC results in the my.kcc.edu portal: Menu (top left) > Employees > Institutional Effectiveness > Surveys (under Data Book) > Revealing Institutional Strengths and Concerns (RISC)

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 8/17/2022
Expires: 9/9/2022

The Martinez family is having a chicken BBQ to help raise money for Crystal's medical bills. The dinners include chicken, rice, beans, a slice of bread and jalapeños.

Each plate is $10.

Deadline to order is 6 p.m. on Friday, July 15.

To purchase, text Herman at 815-823-9574. Include your name and number of dinners. You can also order on Herman's facebook page by putting a comment into his post about the dinner before 6 p.m. Friday.

Pick-up dinners on Saturday, July 16, between noon and 3 p.m. at the parking lot for Todd Arseneau's State Farm office, 1250 N. Convent in Bourbonnais.

Donate directly to the family

Venmo: @mary-martinez-249 (will ask for last 4 digits of Mary's phone number - 9576)

PayPal: @marymartinez4228

Herman said, "Most importantly, keep the prayers coming, as she will soon start her treatment. Thank you for everyone's generosity!"

Herman has worked for KCC since October 2004, and is currently manager of offsite buildings and services for Physical Plant Department. Crystal is a 2016 KCC graduate.

item.title: Proper Dress
item.description:
Article Description: "Business Casual" is appropriate
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Greetings everyone!  I was asked to create a portal post reminding everyone on what "Proper Dress" looks like.  We do have a policy on Proper Dress, which is listed below: 

9.11     Proper Dress

Employees should recognize that as representatives of the College they are judged not only by the service they render and their actions toward students and the public, but also by their personal appearance. In order to help make a positive impression, the College requests that employees dress appropriately for the position in which they work, and that their attire be neat and clean.  Generally speaking, all employees of the college are expected to wear business casual attire, except on approved "Spirit/Casual Days" in which jeans may be worn if accompanied by a KCC shirt/sweatshirt, or a Cavaliers spirit wear t-shirt.

Employees of the Physical Plant Department are required to wear uniforms, and certain employees of the ITS department are required to wear KCC collared shirts. Procedures for obtaining and maintaining required uniform apparel can be obtained from the Director of each unit.

The immediate supervisor or the Human Resources officer may provide guidance or clarification regarding proper dress.

So what does "business casual" attire look like?  Here are a few examples: 

  • Pants that are either cotton, khaki, twill, corduroy, or gabardine fabric (no blue jeans, shorts, or leggings worn as pants)
  • Dress/skirt, if desired
  • A cotton dress shirt/blouse that buttons down the front, or a knit polo shirt with a collar, or a cardigan, or sweater (no hoodies)
  • Dress casual shoes, such as Oxfords, loafer, leather slip-ons, or short boots (no sneakers or crocs)
  • Belt
  • Tie, if desired

    If anyone has any questions on what is and what isn't appropriate, please contact me directly at ext. 8128.  Thanks in advance for your cooperation.  
Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 7/12/2022
Expires: 8/5/2022
item.author: David Cagle

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Effective July 12, Kari Nugent will become KCC's vice president for advancement, marketing, and public relations.  

Kari is currently serving as KCC's director of marketing & public relations. In her expanded role as vice president, Kari will maintain supervision and oversight of her current responsibilities while also assuming oversight and responsibility for the college's Foundation office. In this new role at the college, Kari will provide strategic direction and operational leadership for college advancement, marketing, and communications. 

This role includes cultivating donors and developing gifts to the KCC Foundation; assisting the president with communication with elected officials, as well as federal and state agencies; overseeing the planning, development and execution of the college's website, marketing, advertising, public relations, brand initiatives, printing/production, and internal as well as external communication; and assisting the college in developing and integrating strategic plans and in coordinating resource development.

I'm confident in Kari's ability to step into this expanded role at KCC.

item.title: Shield Covid Testing Continues
item.description:
Article Description: Unvaccinated employees must continue to test weekly - testing on campus is available July 6th, 11th and 13th
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Executive Order extended until further notice

Article Content:

As of right now, the Executive Order to get fully vaccinated or continue to get tested weekly for COVID-19 has been extended until further notice.  As such, the college will continue offering Shield Testing on Wed 7/6, Mon 7/11, and Wed 7/13/22, from 7:30 am to 12:30 pm. Testing is being conducted on the second floor of the D building, in the hallway East of the Student Services entrance (D222) and immediately east of the stairs and elevator.  The process requires you to deposit a small amount of saliva in a vial, which usually takes less than five minutes. Results are usually provided within 24 hours of samples reaching a SHIELD Illinois lab. 

Testing instructions

You should not eat, drink (including water), chew gum, smoke, or use tobacco products within 60 minutes of providing a saliva sample. Doing any of these things within 60 minutes of providing a sample could produce an inconclusive result and require the individual to re-test. Test results will be posted in the patient portal after the lab results are completed.

You will need to create a SHIELD IL Portal account

In order to schedule an appointment or view your lab test results you must create an account on the SHIELD IL portal. Please use the URL and Agency Code below to create your portal. 

It will ask you to create a user name and password. Once created, you will then need to enter your biographical information. Please use your home address not KCC's address. You MUST complete all of the biographical/demographical information, including gender, race, and ethnicity – it is a IDPH requirement. They will email you a 6-digit code to use. Once the code is entered on the site, you will be able to schedule an appointment. 

Note: Shield lists appointments from 7 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. Monday – Friday, but KCC will only be testing our employees from 7:30 am to 12:30 pm Monday and Wednesday, so please make your appointment during these times.

Website: https://shieldillinoisportal.pointnclick.com/login_login.aspx

Agency Code: c55ykhjn

If you have any questions, please contact David at ext. 8128.   

Author: David W Cagle
Article Date: 6/30/2022
Expires: 7/14/2022
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Changes for Academic Affairs
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Colleagues,

Each new academic year brings with it changes, and this year is no different.  Below, I've described the changes to KCC's organizational structure which will ensure we have a successful start to the next academic year.  Please don't hesitate to contact me directly if you have questions.

  • Effective July 1st and extending through the duration of the 2022-2023 academic year, Sheri Cagle is appointed vice president for academic affairs.  Sheri will assume all authority and responsibility for credit division instructional services, MITC oversight, faculty development & instructional technology, Miner Memorial Library, tutoring services, and Perkins grant management.
  • Effective August 1st, Chris Gibson will assume the role of Dean for Health Careers.  Chris had already been identified as KCC's next Dean for Health Careers, and this change simply moves forward the timeline for his start date.  
  • Effective July 1st and extending through the duration of the 2022-2023 academic year, Mary Posing will report directly to the president.  Mary's title and job description will not change, and she will retain direct authority and responsibility for Continuing Education & Career Services, North Extension Center Oversight, Welcome Center, Workforce Services, and Adult Education.
  • Effective July 1st, Gregg Beglau will report directly to Mary Posing.  Gregg's title and job description will remain the same, and he will retain authority and responsibility for Adult Education which includes Literacy, ABE/GED, and ESL.
  • Effective immediately, Dr. Lesley Cooper will report directly to the college president.  Dr. Cooper’s title will remain Director of Institutional Effectiveness and Assessment, and her responsibilities will remain the same.  Going forward, this position will be a cabinet-level position with authority and direct responsibility for strategic planning, Institutional accreditation & quality improvement, curriculum development, and assessment.   

Please enjoy the remainder of your summer so that we can all return in the fall refreshed and reinvigorated.

 

Best,

MB


Author: Dr. Michael Boyd

Expires: 7/8/2022

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)

Article Content:

​It is that time of year again that the college has to perform its annual one hour power curtailment test.  This test is to be sure we are able to reduce our energy consumption to the level provided to us by our energy supplier.  As you recall, the college has received significant monitary rebate checks for reaching the established goal.  This test is for one hour and will begin on Thursday June 23th, starting at 1:00 P.M. and will conclude at 2:00 P.M.

I am requesting your help in achieving our goal.  As you are able, without affecting your normal operations, please turn off all unused electrical equipment; lights and computers, in your area.  Your help and cooperation is greatly appreciated.  

As an incentive (and thank you), please come to the college center at 1 pm to receive a complimentary DQ Dilly Bar.  

If you have any questions, please contact Rob Kenney (8194) or Todd Jenkins (8185). - Thank you

item.title: Internal Search for 2022-23 VP Academic Affairs
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Colleagues,

As a result of Dr. Battle's unexpected departure, KCC will identify and appoint an internal candidate to serve as vice president for academic affairs for the 2022-2023 academic year. Qualified candidates are invited to express interest by sending an email directly to me no later than Wednesday, June 22, by the close of business.  

Minimum qualifications include the following: 

  • Completed master's degree required, doctoral degree preferred  
  • Three years of successful educational administrative experience required; community college experience at the dean's level (or equivalent) or higher required
  • 5 years of teaching experience required, preferably at the community college level 

Upon expressing interest, qualified internal applicants will be invited to discuss the opportunity. The target date for selection of the vice president is Monday, June 27.

If you have questions about this opportunity, please contact me soon to discuss.  

MB

item.title: Approval of Revised Personnel Policies
item.description:
Article Description: BOT approved revisions to two policies, effective 7/1/22
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Approval of Revised Personnel Policies

In consultation with the Robbins Schwartz legal firm, the administration has prepared two revised policies for the Board's approval. These policies went to the Board as a first reading at the May 9, 2022 board meeting and were approved by the BOT on June 13, 2022.  These revised policies are effective July 1, 2022. The two revised policies are: 3.5 Selection Process and 16.3 Reduction in Force. 

3.5 Selection Process

For supportive staff and professional/technical positions, the search committee is composed of three to five employees, including a supervisor/administrator, staff coworker, allied staff member, and a professional/technical or supportive staff member if relative to the position. Any qualified application received in the Human Resources Office will be considered by the search committee until the position is filled. Equal Employment Opportunity practices will be followed in the choices and procedures.

The search committee meets, discusses the applicants, and selects persons to be invited for an on-campus interview. Applicants' current residential distance from KCC should not be a factor in screening.

Before contacting applicants for interviews, the search committee chairperson contacts the Director of Human Resources to evaluate the proposed interview pool. If needed, the Director of Human Resources may expand the number of qualified applicants who will be interviewed.

The search committee will develop questions, all of which will be asked at each interview in the same order by the same persons and using a common procedure which will be followed for each interview. The questions are given to the Director of Human Resources to check for EEO conformity before the interviews are scheduled.

The interviews are scheduled by the Human Resources staff. The search committee is encouraged to hold each interview in the same, accessible location unless a reasonable accommodation is needed.

For full-time Faculty and Administrative level positions the following search process applies:

The supervisor submits a request to advertise a vacancy to the appropriate vice president with the recommended deadline to begin the review of applicants. 

  1. The search committee chairperson and a Human Resources Office representative will identify strategies to encourage diverse candidates to apply for the position.
     
  2. After the search committee has identified the qualified candidates, the committee will select candidates for telephone interviews to be held in a predetermined common location.
     
  3. After the telephone interviews, the committee identifies the candidates to invite for an on-campus interview. With the candidates' permission, reference checks should be made at this stage of the process.
     
  4. Upon completion of the reference checks, up to five candidates may be invited for on-campus interviews. 

Each candidate will be reimbursed up to $500 for reasonable expenses associated with their travel to Kankakee for the on-campus interview. Receipts of expenditures must be provided and may include food, travel, and lodging only. Additional reimbursement will be provided to candidates at the sole discretion of the college. 

The telephone interview process above may be waived if the candidates selected for the on-campus interviews are in the KCC District area, and as long as no one in the pool of applicants is interviewed by telephone for any reason other than to reasonably accommodate an applicant in accordance with state and federal laws. 

Any evaluative tests necessary to establish qualification for the position are administered by the Human Resources staff as part of the interviewing process. 

During the interview process, the applicant will receive a position description. The search committee is to provide the same interview conditions and questions for all candidates. After all interviews are conducted, the following procedures are followed based on the category of position to be filled: 

Part-time and full-time supportive staff and professional/technical staff – Following the interview, the search committee identifies leading candidates. The search committee chairperson submits the top recommendations to the immediate supervisor, who consults with the work area Vice President regarding the pros and cons of the candidates. The final choice's application is submitted to the Vice President for Business Affairs and/or the Director of Human Resources to calculate salary and starting dates, based on approved salary charts and procedures. Next the Employment Recommendation Form with reference checks is prepared by the search committee chairperson, recommending the candidate to the supervisor. The form is forwarded to the Director of Human Resources. The position offer is then made to the chosen candidate by the Director of Human Resources, who will offer the salary and establish the starting date, contingent upon successful completion of a background check. If the candidate declines the position offer, the second and third selection candidates may be offered the position, pending the work area Vice President's approval. 

Full-time faculty and Administrator positions – Following the interviews, the search committee selects the three to five leading candidates. Next, the committee's chairperson submits the top candidates' applications to the immediate supervisor, who consults with the work area Vice President, and/or President, regarding the final choice. The final choice's application is submitted to the Vice President for Business Affairs and/or the Director of Human Resources to calculate salary and starting dates, based on approved salary charts and procedures. Next, the Employment Recommendation Form with the reference checks is prepared by the search committee chairperson recommending the candidate to the supervisor. The form is forwarded to the Director of Human Resources. The position offer is then made to the chosen candidate by the Director of Human Resources, who will offer the salary and establish a starting date. If the candidate declines the position offer, the second and third selection candidates may be offered the position, pending VP and/or President's approval. 

The Director of Human Resources will prepare an employment agenda item for the Board of Trustees' meeting and arranges for the employee's first day. 

Full-time faculty and administrators may begin the day after Board approval, except for special action by the Board authorizing earlier employment, pending Board approval. All other employees, including supportive staff, and professional/technical staff may begin working, pending Board approval. 

Notification of employment is sent to each new employee by the Human Resources Office staff and letters of regret are also sent by the Human Resources Office staff to all unsuccessful applicants. As a courtesy, the search committee chairperson contacts the on-campus interviewed candidates to notify them that another candidate has been selected. 

16.3 Reduction in Force (RIF)

Kankakee Community College is committed to maintain, wherever possible, the employment of every employee who is performing satisfactorily. However, changing funding levels and patterns and changing community needs may, on occasion, present situations where lack of funding, lack of work, or lack of need for a particular service require a reduction of the number of staff. 

Reduction in the force of staff may occur at any time throughout the year as the need arises. Reduction in the force of instructional employees and recall of faculty is subject to compliance with the Illinois Public Community Colleges Act. The Board of Trustees shall approve any proposed position reductions before they become effective. 

After the college has determined that a RIF is the best way to meet the needs of the institution, an analysis should be conducted by the administration to determine the employees who will be laid off. Nondiscriminatory employee selection criteria will be developed and used to select the employees who will be laid off. Common factors used as criteria for reductions may include performance (based on current and previous performance appraisals and other performance documentation, such as warnings or any type of disciplinary actions), redundant roles, skills-based criteria, and longevity.

Each person occupying a position which is eliminated will receive by personal delivery or Certified Mail, a notice of impending layoff not less than two (2) weeks prior to the effective date of the layoff. If, subsequent to notice being given, but prior to the effective date of the layoff, or within 90 days of the day of layoff, an opening should occur or a new position be created, that position shall be offered to a qualified person on layoff. Qualifications shall be determined by the College. 

The position will be filled from among those laid off or due to be laid off (who express an interest in the position) through the same interview and selection process used to select new employees. If an individual on layoff is offered a position and refuses, no further obligations shall exist to offer that individual any other positions that may become open during the 90-day recall window. 

Regardless of any other provision of this policy, no person may be placed in a position for which the employee does not meet the basic qualifications, or the employee does not meet a legal or regulatory requirement. 

Grant-Funded Employees 

Persons in positions which are funded by grant monies (defined as non-operational funds and auxiliary funds), in whole or in part, may be laid off at any time with or without advance notice. Persons laid off from grant-funded positions shall not have recall rights or any other right to future or continued employment with Kankakee Community College. 

Accumulated vacation and compensatory time are paid out to each person on layoff. For purposes of any other fringe benefits, a person on layoff shall be treated the same as a person who has been terminated from employment, except that if a person is re-employed by the College within a period of one (1) year, unused accumulated sick leave from previous KCC employment shall be restored. 

If anyone has any questions, comments, or concerns, please contact David at ext. 8128.

item.title: Juneteenth Holiday
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

In recognition of the Juneteenth holiday, Friday June 17 is being added on this year's KCC's calendar.

Because it is a summer Friday, the college will be closed as planned. Due to the holiday, employees will work eight-hour days Monday-Thursday (June 13-16) and June 17 will be a holiday.   

For the academic calendar in 2023 and beyond, the college will continue to include a Juneteenth holiday observance.

Several Juneteenth activities are planned in the community, and the celebration culminates on Sunday, June 19.

KCC is also having a coloring contest, sponsored by the Center for Equity, Diversity and Inclusion. Information will be added to the EDI webpage when it becomes finalized.

June 19 is the federal Juneteenth holiday. It commemorates the end of slavery in the United States. Juneteenth became a national holiday last year.

item.title: Supporting Students with Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
item.description:
Article Description: Part of a series on supporting students with chronic health conditions
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The Office of Disability Services has seen a significant rise in invisible disabilities in recent years. Diagnosis can be emotional, psychological, neurological, and physical in nature and include diagnosis such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, Seizures, Autism, Lupus, Krones Disease, Bi-Polar, Anxiety to name a few. The Americans with Disabilities Act and Title II of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 require post-secondary institutions to accommodate these disabilities, but this is not always easy to do as sometime these diagnoses can be sporadic or episodic in nature and require accommodations that go beyond the "traditional" accommodations instructors may be accustom to providing. Due to this rise in hidden disabilities, the Office of Disability Services will be offering information articles related to Autism, Traumatic Brain Injury, and Chronic Health Conditions in the upcoming weeks. The goal is to provide some basic facts about these diagnoses and offer suggestions faculty can use to support these students in the classroom.

Supporting Students with Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)


Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is an invisible disability that may have significant impact on college students educationally, emotionally, and socially. Type of injury sustained (i.e., fall, blow to the head, traffic accident, combat related, or medical condition) can result in a varying symptom such as personality changes, cognitive changes, loss of vision, or physical limitation. These barriers often require individuals with TBI's to take longer to complete a program than their peers which can be demoralizing.


IMPACT OF A TBI

  • Inability to sustain attention on tasks
  • Struggle to comprehension, retain or recall information
  • Executive functioning skills such as organization skills
  • Impulsivity
  • Difficulty seeing, speaking, or hearing
  • Reduced social interactions
  • Problem solving
  • Information processing

TEACHING STRATEGIES

  • Simplify. Kim Collins, PhD, Director of Rehabilitation Education Center at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign suggests assisting students in breaking down larger assignments and projects into smaller chunks aids in better retention and recall and ultimately success.
  • Provide clear oral and written instructions.
  • Adapting content with technology. The Colorado Department of Education provides various technology resources educators can use for specific types of learning barriers. Check it out HERE.
  • Project IDEAL (Informing and Designing Education for All Leaners) online offer the following teaching strategies:
    • Provide repetition and consistency
    • Demonstrate new tasks, state instructions, and provide examples to illustrate ideas and concepts.
    • Avoid figurative language
    • Have consistent routines
    • Probe skill acquisition frequently and provided repeated practice
  • Encourage use of accommodations. Encourage students to utilize accommodations which may include the use of a note taker, recorder, extended time for quizzes and exams as well as testing in a reduced distraction environment.
  • Nurture self-advocacy. Encourage students to seek out outside resources such as clinician that specialize in TBI, tutoring services such as West Side Tutoring out of Ohio that customizes tutoring for students with TBI at the college level, and working with the campus Office of Disability Services for goal setting and organizational support.
  • Be available. It may be very difficult for the student with a TBI to come to you, but they want to learn and be successful and live a productive life. Being available review course content can play an important role in a student's success.

RESOURCES:

Bush, E., Hux, K., Zickefoose, S., Simanek, G., Holmberg, M., & Henderson, A. (n.d.). Learning and Study Strategies of Students with Traumatic Brain Injury: A Mixed Method Study. Journal of Postsecondary Education and Disability, 24(3), 231–250. 

Returning to School After Traumatic Brain Injury. Returning to School After Traumatic Brain Injury | Model Systems Knowledge Translation Center (MSKTC). (n.d.). 

Strategies. Strategies | Disability Resources & Educational Services - University of Illinois. (n.d.). 

Traumatic Brain Injury. Project IDEAL. (n.d.). 

University, Graduate & Professional School Tutors: Westside Tutoring. Westside Tutoring & Testing Services. (2015, April 14). 




Author: Sherry Kinzler

item.title: Password Change Coming May 13th
item.description:
Article Description: For the past few weeks ITS has been evangelizing that in order to meet the requirements placed on the College by the payment card industry (PCI), as well as meeting cybersecurity best practices, that we would need to begin changing our passwords every 90 days.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

For the past few weeks ITS has been evangelizing that in order to meet the requirements placed on the College by the payment card industry (PCI), as well as meeting cybersecurity best practices, that we would need to begin changing our passwords every 90 days.

On May 13th all users will receive a password change notification upon login requiring them to change their password and the new passwords will need to meet the following requirements:

  • 8 character minimum length
  • Must contain at least one upper case character, one lower case character, a number, and a special character
  • Cannot exceed two consecutive characters
  • Cannot contain the user's account name or parts of the user's full name

The following rules will also apply to passwords:

  • Required change every 90 days
  • Cannot use the last (5) previous passwords
  • Account will lockout after (5) failed attempts for one hour

Some of you may already be using complex passwords in your daily lives as well as having to change passwords every so often for the various online services you use. ITS offers the following recommendations to assist in keeping your KCC account secure.

  • Use a phrase for your password. This can help make your password easier to recall but at the same time add security (length)
  • Use a unique password for each account you own. This prevents the "chaining" of accounts by attackers
  • Avoid words that can be found in the dictionary
  • Avoid appending numbers onto the end of your password and incrementing that number for password changes

Cybersecurity is the responsibility of all users of KCC's computing resources and having a secure, strong, password is fundamental in ensuring that our computing environment remains safe.

Questions or concerns regarding this change can be directed to the ITS Help Desk at x.8900 or (815) 802‑8900.


Author: Michael OConnor
Article Date: 5/11/2022
Expires: 5/20/2022
