item.title: A Report from AACC
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

This week, I had the opportunity to attend the annual conference of the American Association of Community Colleges (AACC).  As the primary advocate for community colleges in the nation, AACC represents 1100 member organizations.  That means it's a big conference and includes numerous presentations from the most innovative and successful community colleges in the United States.  I've been to AACC twice in my career, and I've left each time feeling more committed than ever to the community college mission.  I also leave these conferences feeling motivated to bring back to KCC the many great ideas that our colleagues across the nation are discussing.

In the list below, I'm sharing some of the most significant themes that emerged among the various presentations and in the dynamic conversations they evoked in the hallways and in the informal evening gatherings. 

In other words, here's what I learned at AACC.

Community colleges are abandoning the 16-week model. 

This theme was pervasive throughout the duration of the conference.  Odessa College in Texas was well ahead of the curve when they "went all in" with 8-week terms in lieu of 16-week semesters.  They felt so strongly about this model that they implemented without a pilot or a phased approach.   As their president said, "we're not toe-dippers."  Since making this wholesale change, Odessa reports double-digit enrollment growth and dramatically increased retention rates.  They were also surprised to discover that 8-week terms have led to increased degree and certificate completion for part-time students who find these shorter classes easier to access and complete.  While Odessa College is an early adopter of such a dramatic redesign of their semester's length, so many of the colleges represented at the conference are actively working to move away from the 16-week semester.  Here at KCC, we certainly offer more 8-week course sessions than we had 5 or 10 years ago; however, we have not made the dramatic move away from the 16-week model that other colleges are making.  Do shorter terms create more opportunities for students to stop and start?  Does the shorter timeline make it easier for students to complete courses?  The early results from colleges like Odessa seem to suggest the answer to these questions may be "yes."

Colleges are abandoning a "student deficit" model by intentionally fostering a "student asset" mindset which focuses on "cultural wealth." 

As we rethink community college approaches to onboarding new students, it's been a challenge to let go of some of the long-standing practices which were results of a "student deficit" mindset about student success.  For a large part of our history, students' first experience at college has been placement testing.  Upon testing, we've tended to place students into pre-college courses hoping that they'll use this opportunity to become more college ready.  Many of the initiatives discussed at AACC included intentional strategies to move their college culture away from thinking about what students cannot do or do not know.   Instead, they are adopting a "cultural wealth" mindset intended to focus first on what students can do and the cultural knowledge they bring with them to campus.  To achieve this aim, colleges are creating internal campaigns to learn more about what it means to think about student assets and cultural wealth.  These campaigns focus on stated "commitments" from faculty, staff, and students.  Even more colleges are implementing multiple measures for placement, eliminating developmental education altogether, and removing all barriers to registration and enrollment.  Here at KCC, we've begun the process of using multiple measures for placement, and we've made incredible progress in how we deliver developmental education.  We're headed in the right direction.  Still, I left AACC today wondering if KCC's approaches to student success are informed by a student deficit model or a cultural wealth model.  Perhaps that's a question we can all be asking.

Retention is a higher priority than ever. 

It's always been important for us to retain the students we attract.  This is why we've always measured fall-to-spring and fall-to-fall retention statistics.  As much priority as we place on retention, though, our conversations on campus always seem to move away from retention efforts to focus on recruitment of new students.  Across the nation, colleges are expressing more and more concern that we've not done a good enough job of ensuring that our current students have such a great experience that they return each semester until completion.  The leading colleges in this conversation express similar challenges to what we are facing here at KCC.  There are fewer traditional-aged students in local high schools.  Students are choosing to complete degrees and certificates in non-traditional ways, often moving back and forth between multiple colleges or training providers.  Many people are even losing faith in the value of a college degree or certificate (more on this below), and even more are seeking credentials through non-academic training providers.  Because the market for new students is shrinking and exceedingly difficult to reach, colleges are noting the value of investing time and energy into retaining current students as a way of mitigating enrollment declines.  Are we doing all we can here at KCC to ensure that our students stick with us until they finish?

We must answer the question about the return on investment of a college education.

 Of all the themes and trends emerging from the many presentations and discussions at AACC's conference, this one was the most prominent and unsettling one.  Colleges across the nation are sensing among their communities a loss of faith in the higher education system.  Potential students no longer take for granted the value of a degree or credential from a community college.  Given the increasing cost of college, we shouldn't be surprised that students refuse to enroll if they are not convinced that a college credential will be useful, valuable, or will lead to enhanced quality of life and a family-sustaining income.  As community college educators, we feel strongly about the value of KCC's credentials in our local workforce, and we know that KCC graduates have the skills and knowledge to transfer successfully and enter a career pathway.  We get it, but have we successfully told this story in our community?  In my previous blog, I noted that we need to highlight the "tangible assets" of a community college education if we hope to attract and retain students.  Are we doing enough to help our community know that very real and substantial return on investment they will gain from completing a KCC degree or certificate?

There was a palpable sense of impending change at AACC this year as the nation's community colleges, like KCC, face continued enrollment declines.  We all know, I hope, that what comes next for community colleges looks very different from what came before.  More specifically, there was a sense that only those colleges that are willing to innovate, change, and adapt will be able to survive this thing that Arthur Levine and Scott Van Pelt are calling The Great Upheaval.  As we conclude this academic year, my call to action for KCC is to face our future with a bold willingness to embrace change, participate in innovation, and be comfortable serving students in a different way than we ever have.  If we can move forward with this attitude, I am confident that KCC will be a leader among Illinois' colleges as we shift the model for higher education in our community. 

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 5/5/2022

item.author: Karen Richards

item.title: The Tangible Advantages of Community College
item.description:
Article Description: Our Future Story
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Even if you aren't spending time each day reading and researching current events impacting higher education, you are likely aware that America's colleges and universities are confronting a time of extraordinary change.  Colleges are struggling financially as enrollments have declined, and some have even been forced to close their doors permanently.  Across the nation, the most effective colleges are taking proactive steps to explore the innovations that will drive success into the future, and they are working to implement these new strategies efficiently and sustainably.

While it's proven uncomfortable if not difficult to embrace many of these changes, it's been almost too easy for us to blame them on a global pandemic.  The truth is that higher education was already on the precipice of a sea change well before we knew about the widespread proliferation of a virus called COVID-19.  As an example, community colleges in Illinois had already suffered a decade-long enrollment decline when we were forced to implement emergency operations planning in March of 2020 which resulted in the temporary closure of campus facilities and a whole-sale shift toward virtual teaching, learning, and support. 

Even at that time, we had already spent countless hours designing short-term credentials, expanding hybrid and online courses, contemplating competency-based education, and fretting about the impact of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs).  To be sure, we aren't yet fully free from the pandemic, but we've finally obtained enough intellectual and emotional distance from the urgency it required to understand that a virus didn't cause the need for paradigmatic change in higher education; rather, it made the need for change more complex and, perhaps, more immediately necessary.

In the recent past, I've referenced one such transformation in progress here at Kankakee Community College. Even as I write this column, a cross-functional team of colleagues is working out the final details of implementing KCC's first competency-based education program.  Unlike traditional models which base completion on "seat time" or the number of hours, weeks, and months students are enrolled in a class, this new approach will give students the flexibility to complete their course of study and move on as soon as they are able to demonstrate the skills required.  We're also making our course schedule increasingly more flexible by including a variety of start dates and shorter-term classes stacked intentionally to help students get short term credentials quickly and efficiently.  Why should students wait months before starting a program?  We're even planning a winter term, perfectly designed for students to complete a course during the holiday season if that's a choice that works for them.  Perhaps the most exciting development in the past few years has been the expansion of apprenticeships at KCC so that students can work while they learn. 

As KCC recovers from these last few tumultuous years, we're asking ourselves the question, "where do we go from here?"  It's our hope that such a question may help us write our "future story."  We are ready to embrace the need for continued change.  That's exactly what authors Arthur Levine and Scott Van Pelt have done in their book The Great Upheaval: Higher Education's Past, Present, and Uncertain Future.  In this research, the authors look to the past for models of transformational change in higher education.  As they document this history, they also build a predictive framework for what we may expect to happen in higher education.  Perhaps not surprisingly, the comparative models they identify are the music industry, the film industry, and the newspaper industry.

It's a compelling argument that Levine and Van Pelt make, an argument which has captured the collective attention of the higher education community and so many others across the nation who are both concerned about the current state of higher education and, at the same time, eager to experience sorely needed innovation.  Perhaps higher education is truly in the beginning stages of a sea change.  What will our programs, classes, and services become as we design new models to serve students in the age of a knowledge economy?  In the final pages of their book, Levine and Van Pelt predict that the "disruption faced by regional universities and community colleges will be a matter of attrition" as students choose alternative providers for "cheaper, more convenient, unbundled, and in some cases higher-quality instruction."  For those among us who recognize the value of the community college mission, this is a dire prediction.  However, a few sentences later, they suggest an alternative path for those colleges who are committed to remaining relevant: "To hold onto their students and escape disruption, these institutions will have to offer some tangible advantage that alternative providers cannot."

Here at KCC, we're working hard to develop and refine these "tangible advantages" which will cement KCC as this community's college and the best post-secondary option available in this region we serve.  As this community's college, it's our responsibility and our mission to enhance quality of life by connecting students with family sustaining careers.  This mission will be at the core of all our efforts to transform the strategies and tactics we use to get it done.       

If you've read this far, I suspect you'll find Levine and Van Pelt's argument insightful and engaging.  I hope you'll choose to read it.  Further, I'm extending a formal invitation to join me this summer in a book study of The Great Upheaval.

We'll coordinate our book study with the summer semester, starting on June 6th and concluding on July 28th.  Our study will be asynchronous, so you can respond and interact with others on your own time, but you will need to "keep up" with the entire group so that our conversations are timely and engaging.  We'll use the Canvas learning management system to discuss the book and explore ways that we can apply insights gained to how we achieve our mission here at KCC.  One last thing – there will be "work" to do, so be prepared to read, write, and think. 

Still interested?  If so, send me a note at mboyd@kcc.edu telling me why you'd like to be in the first cohort to read and study The Great Upheaval.  Participants will be selected by May 13th at which time you'll need to source your own copy of the book and start reading.

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 4/29/2022

item.title: 2022 Performance Appraisals
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

It is that time again -- time for annual performance appraisals of administrators, professional/technical and supportive staff.

Completed appraisals are to be submitted to the Human Resources Office by June 1st for non-supervisory staff (full and part-time) and June 15th for supervisory personnel.

 

Evaluation process:

The process includes reflection on your accomplishments, how you met/exceeded last year's goals, and what specific goals/objectives await you in the coming fiscal year.

Please note below KCC's Strategic goals for FY20 – FY22:

  • Improve student success through increased enrollment, retention, transfer, and completion rates.
  • Create diverse, inclusive, and equitable teaching, learning, and work environments.
  • Improve physical and virtual teaching and learning spaces.
  • Increase visibility and value in community.
  • Provide development opportunities to enhance KCC employee skills and knowledge. 

     
    You should consult with your immediate supervisor for his/her deadline which allows time for all levels of supervision to review evaluations before the appropriate Human Resources deadline.  Electronic evaluation forms are located on the HR Portal page under Documents.

    As part of this process, if the position description is not accurate, your supervisor should make proposed revisions and submit them to Human Resources with the evaluation.  A copy of your current description may be obtained by contacting Janet in HR at ext. 8124.  A "Specific responsibilities" section should also be included.

    The process will be as follows:

    1.  Complete a self-evaluation.

    2.  Submit it as a Word document to your immediate supervisor. Schedule a meeting with him/her to discuss performance, review the completed tasks, establish new goals through March 2022 and complete the final evaluation. Note: Input/support from department directors should be solicited prior to this meeting.

    3.  Sign the completed evaluation, get your immediate supervisor's signature, plus the appropriate department director's.  Keep a copy (or save it electronically). Your supervisor should do the same (for use during next year's evaluation process).

    4.  Deliver a paper copy to Human Resources by the appropriate due date.

Please contact David Cagle at dcagle@kcc.edu or 815-802-8128 if you have any questions regarding this process.


Author: Human Resources
Article Date: 4/28/2022
Expires: 6/20/2022

item.title: Summer work schedules begin May 16
item.description:
Article Description: Work 40 or 32 hours a week during summer
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Beginning May 16, KCC will be switching to a summer hour work schedule. Staff will be allowed to work a compressed work week by working a four day, (Mon-Thurs) 10-hour schedule.  Or, in response to many of your requests, staff could work a four day, 8-hour schedule totaling 32 hours of work for the week without having to use a vacation day.  Of course, one's pay would be paid accordingly.  If this option is of interest to you, please discuss this with your immediate supervisor for approval.  

The 10-hour day could begin as early as 6:30 am, and end at 10 pm. Here are some examples of a 10-hour workday:

* 6:30 am - 4:30 pm

* 7:00 am - 5:00 pm

* 7:30 am - 5:30 pm

* 8:00 am - 6:00 pm

* 8:30 am - 6:30 pm 

Staff will NOT need to punch in and out for lunch - KCC is GIFTING you the time so that your 10-hour day includes a paid 30-minute lunch period.  

The college will be closed on Fridays from May 20-July 29, except for June 3 and July 8 due to Memorial Day and Independence Day holidays. Those weeks the college will be open Tuesday-Friday, and full-time staff would work four 8-hr days.  KCC will still gift you a paid 30-minute lunch during these two weeks :)

If you have any questions, please contact me at ext. 8128.  

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 4/26/2022

item.title: Take-Your-Child-To-Work Day – April 28
item.description:
Article Description: Goal: Introduce your child to a range of jobs so that they will have a better idea of what to expect from the workforce when they eventually join it.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Take Your Child to Work Day is an internationally recognized day for children to go to work with their parents. It was originally called Take Your Daughter to Work Day to guide more girls and women into the workforce when it was instated in 1993. While this day was created for U.S. children, it is now celebrated in countries all over the world. Take Your Child to Work Day is held on the fourth Thursday in April annually.

The current goal of Take Your Child to Work Day is to introduce young children to a range of jobs throughout their childhood so that they will have a better idea of what to expect from the workforce when they eventually join it.

Take Your Child to Work Day benefits both kids and adults. Bringing your child into work can help humanize you to your colleagues. If your child gets sick, for example, your boss or coworkers may be more understanding if they have met your child. Additionally, it allows your colleagues to see another aspect of your personality and life. The same applies to children. They will see you in a different role than they do at home, and hopefully, gain some understanding about what you do all day at work.

Do's for Take Your Child to Work Day

To make Take Your Child to Work Day the best possible experience for both you and your child, please follow this list of do's:

  • Research the Programming: know what to expect from the day so both you and your child will be prepared and ready.
  • Know the age recommendations:  we don't recommend bringing in kids under 5 years old; additionally, if you work in a location with heavy machinery or other potentially dangerous equipment, consider saving your child's visit until they are in middle or high school.
  • Assess your schedule: keep important or lengthy meetings off of your calendar on Take Your Child to Work Day. You may not get as much work done as you normally do, so prepare ahead of time to meet any goals.
  • Provide expectations: your child should know how they are to behave at the college. Set clear expectations and consequences.
  • Have a backup plan: younger children may not be able to make it through the whole day. Have a caregiver ready to pick up your child if needed.
  • Check with your immediate supervisor: be sure to check in with your boss and immediate colleagues before bringing your child in for the day.
  • Inform your child's school: call your child's school and let them know their student will be with you for the day rather than in the classroom. Arrange make-up work ahead of time if needed.
  • Introduce your child: present your child to your coworkers when you arrive. Model for your child how to meet someone new in a professional setting.
  • Reflect on the day afterwards: on the drive home or at dinner that evening, debrief about the day with your child. Ask them what they thought of your workplace, your position and the program.

Don'ts for Take Your Child to Work Day

There are some behaviors you will want to avoid to have the most successful Take Your Child to Work Day. Please follow this list of don'ts as well:

  • Force your child: if your child does not want to go to work with you, do not force them to. It will only lead to a challenging day for you and your child.
  • Overstimulate: know your child's limits. If they are getting overtired or seem to be losing focus, give your child a chance to decompress.
  • Bore your child: kids have shorter attention spans than adults. While you may be able to focus on a spreadsheet for several hours, your child may not. Bring something for them to do while you work if needed.
  • Ignore your child: don't expect to come into work and leave your child on their own. Make sure you are with them or know where they are at all times.
  • Have a bad attitude: if there are parts of your job you do not like or colleagues who are difficult to get along with, try to put that aside for your child. Keep a positive attitude at work with your child present.
  • Pretend your job is different: your child will be impressed by whatever it is you do. There is no need to pretend you do something you don't.
  • Bring in more than one child: although you may have more than one child, please only bring one child with you each year; then next year, you can bring another child to work.
In support of the families participating in Take Your Child To Work Day, the EDI Center and the Student Success Center are partnering to have snacks, picture books, coloring sheets and other activities available for children on April 28. Because the EDI center is a lounge space, we will be operating as a "Kid's Breakroom" that day. If younger children are getting restless and parents want to accompany them to the EDI center for a while to have a snack and a little bit of fun, this space is open to them. Please let Whiteny know if there are any additional questions.

Should you have any other questions pertaining to Take Your Child to Work Day, please contact David at ext. 8128.

item.title: Supporting Students with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD)
item.description:
Article Description: Part of a series on supporting students with chronic health conditions
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The Office of Disability Services has seen a significant rise in invisible disabilities in recent years. Diagnosis can be emotional, psychological, neurological, and physical in nature and include diagnosis such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, Seizures, Autism, Lupus, Krones Disease, Bi-Polar, Anxiety to name a few. The Americans with Disabilities Act and Title II of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 require post-secondary institutions to accommodate these disabilities, but this is not always easy to do as sometime these diagnoses can be sporadic or episodic in nature and require accommodations that go beyond the "traditional" accommodations instructors may be accustom to providing. Due to this rise in hidden disabilities, the Office of Disability Services will be offering information articles related to Autism, Traumatic Brain Injury, and Chronic Health Conditions in the upcoming weeks. The goal is to provide some basic facts about these diagnoses and offer suggestions faculty can use to support these students in the classroom.

Supporting Students with Autism Spectrum Disorders

The Center of Disease Control (CDC) defines autism as a developmental disability that can cause social, communication and behavioral challenges. Autism affects 1 in 54 individuals and is 4 times more likely to be identified in males compared to females (2020). Often autism is accompanied with secondary and tertiary diagnosis such as epilepsy, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and/or anxiety disorders to name a few (Furfaro, 2018).

Many hear the word "spectrum" and think of a horizontal line that runs from "low-functioning" to "high-functioning" and everybody is supposed to fit neatly in their own dot on the spectrum (Birch, 2020). However, those in the autism community argue the spectrum is not linear at all.


The spectrum is actually circular in shape, broken into various categories (see example below). Through observation and self-identification, medical professionals can determine what areas in the brain are impacted and to what extent. It is unknown why autism can impact functioning in some areas and not in others (Birch, 2020).


As with any diagnosis or disability there is no one-size fits all and this is true with Autism as well. However, in the college setting, there are some common characteristics that may be observed along with strategies to appropriately and successfully interact and work with students with ASD.

LANGUAGE/COMMUNICATION

  • Verbal Communication
    • Inability to initiate and sustain appropriate conversation
    • Use of inappropriate responses
    • Repetitive language
    • Lack of inflection
  • Nonverbal Communication
    • Lack of facial expression
    • Inability to "read" facial expression of others
    • Lack of eye contact

Classroom strategies

  • Do not assume there is limited cognitive ability and address the student as you would any other adult or student.
  • Avoid using words of phrases that are too familiar or personal. For example, words like "honey" or "sweetie", or "cutie", can come across as demeaning or disrespectful.
  • Say what you mean. When interacting with an adult with ASD, be literal, clear, and concise. Avoid the use of slang, nuance, and sarcasm.
  • Take time to listen. Being an active listener and taking the time to listen lets them know that you care about what they have to say.
  • If you ask a question, wait for a response. Individuals with autism or other special needs sometimes need a little more time to absorb and process information before giving you their response.
  • Provide meaningful feedback. Some adults with ASD may unknowingly communicate inappropriately. Be prepared to provide specific feedback about what in the conversation was inappropriate. Providing feedback that is honest, non-judgmental, and clear can help someone with ASD learn to safely navigate complex social interactions (Walsh, 2010).

MOTOR SKILLS

  • Possible observations
    • Unusual gait, toe-walking, slower walking speed
    • Difficulty with fine motor skills
    • Clumsiness
    • Toe-walking (Deweerdt, 2017)
    • Repetitive behaviors or Stimming - self-stimulatory behavior (Deweerdt, 2020)
Classroom Strategies:
  • Provide ample time to complete kinesthetic activities i.e., lab experiments or in class written/typed assignments.
  • Recognize that stimming (repetitive actions or movements) may be an anxiety calming function and do not bring attention to the behavior as long as it is not harmful to the student, others, or impacts class learning.

PERCEPTION

  • Executive Function
    • Organizing, planning, paying attention, inhibited and/or inappropriate responses (Autism Speaks, n.a.)
SENSORY - How "hyper- or hypo- responsive to stimuli a person is (Milne, et, al., 2017).
  • Abrupt, seemingly inappropriate, or rude comments may come from not having enough time to process the information and formulate an appropriate response.
    • Tend to function in a literal sense, innuendos, sarcasm, and satire can be difficult.
    • Difficulty speaking in class (social anxiety) or being over chatty or seeming like a know-it-all.
    • Asking for Help
Classroom Strategies:
  • UDL: Universal Design for Learning inculdes:
    • Multiple means of access to information
    • Multiple means of presentation of information
  • Using the white board for key words
  • Adding color in text material to highlight important concepts
  • Incorporating images to PowerPoints
  • Showing a video clip or an animation that reinforces an idea
    • Multiple means of engagement
  • Group Work
    • Be thoughtful in creating groups
    • Let the student know, in advance, of group work so the student can prepare
    • Introduce the student to group members prior to the activity
    • Use a "speed dating" system where students rate their compatibility with others in the class through the use of a quick survey tool and use this to establish groups.

The most important thing an instructor can do is establish a rapport with the student. Provide a respectful, trusting environment.

RESOURCES
  • Birch, N. (2021, June 10). This Graphic Shows What the Autism Spectrum Really Looks Like. The Mighty.
  • Browne, Ken, director. Supporting College Students with Autism Spectrum Disorders. YouTube, 15 Mar. 2012.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2020, September 25). Data & Statistics on Autism Spectrum Disorder. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
  • "Comic Redesigns the Autism Spectrum to Crush Stereotypes." The Mighty, 23 May 2016.
  • Deweerdt, S. (2017, November 14). Motor problems in autism persist into adulthood. Spectrum. 
  • Furfaro, H. (2020, May 7). Conditions that accompany autism, explained. Spectrum. 
  • Milne, E., Dickinson, A., & Smith, R. (2017). Adults with autism spectrum conditions experience increased levels of anomalous perception. Spectrum.
  • Walsh, M. (2010, June 1). Tips for Talking to Adults on the Autism Spectrum. May Institute.
  • Why is Autism called Autism Spectrum Disorder? The Carmen B. Pingree Autism Center of Learning. (2021, May 25).

item.title: Board Notes - April 2022
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, April 11, 2022

 
Recognition and Honored Guests. The Board received the following guests:

  • Outstanding Full-time Faculty Award recipient – Anne Reilly, Nursing
  • Outstanding Adjunct Faculty Award recipient – Dr. Dawn Muhammad, Psychology
  • Distinguished Alumnus Award recipient – The Honorable Mike Kick
  • Student Board of Trustees Representative for 2022-23 – Quante Grant
  • Phi Theta Kappa Officers; Phi Theta Kappa Advisors Frances Hebert and Jaclyn Montemayer
 
Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Grant awards
  • Request to bid service counters and doors
  • Computers for staff and computer lab upgrades
  • Architectural services to relocate the bookstore
  • Installation of a solar array on campus and a power purchase agreement

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Welcome Quante Grant, Student Trustee for the 2022-23 academic year.
  • Reminder that Economic Interest forms are available from the Kankakee County Clerk's Office and due May 1.
  • The High School Art Show featured some very talented high school students. More than 150 people attended the reception. Thanks to all those whose planned the event.
  • KCC is the recipient of the Daily Journal Reader's Choice Award for Education and Progress Award for the EDI Center.
  • This spring George Mateja and his crew will be planting 30 trees that he started in a tree nursery on the KCC golf course around Riverfront Campus. These trees were planted and have been developing for three to four years as whips that were 4-6 ft. tall. The crew will add to the tree nursery next spring with new whips that KCC will grow and plant in the future.
  • Several special events are coming up, including a celebration for KCC's Military Friendly designation, the Technology building grand opening, Veteran's Stole Ceremony, Nursing Pinning, commencement and more

Trustee's Report. Bill Orr said….

  • ICCTA meeting was held at South Suburban College in South Holland. Topics included Governor's budget for higher education and additional MAP grant funding. Prairie State and South Suburban talked about their programs and spaces for diversity, equity and inclusion.   

Student Trustee's Report. Samaria Rosenthal said …

  • Welcome to the new Student Trustee Quante Grant.  
  • Spill the Tea with the Trustee went well.
  • Student Life events included a financial literacy presentation, Open Mic Night, and the Save a Life tour were successes.
  • The Psychology Club held a career exploration event.

item.title: Reilly and Muhammad named as 2022 Outstanding Faculty Award recipients
item.description:
Article Description: Announcement of 2022 Outstanding Faculty Awards
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The Outstanding Full-Time Faculty Member recipient is Anne Reilly, MSN, RN, nursing professor in the Health Careers Division.

By her own admission, Anne was initially reluctant to move into teaching. Encouraged by a nursing colleague, she made the leap to the classroom in 2012. A truly gifted educator, Anne is often the first college professor nursing students encounter in the Certified Nursing Assistant course. She is caring, kind, and an excellent professional role model for them. Both as a nurse and an instructor, Anne never stops learning. She shares that knowledge and expertise with her students, preparing them to become future caregivers. Anne has said before that nothing gives her a greater sense of accomplishment than when she sees a prior student in a health care setting, and they refer to her as Mrs. Reilly. She likes to respond, "Call me Anne, because we are now colleagues." Outside of KCC, Anne frequently volunteers with Relay for Life and the Alzheimer's Association of Kankakee.

 







The Outstanding Part-Time Faculty Member recipient is Dawn Muhammad, PhD, who teaches psychology courses in the Liberal Arts and Sciences Division.

Dawn is a lifelong learner. She has a passion for learning and shares that passion with her students. An adjunct instructor since 2016, Dr. M, as her students call her, strives to make her classes engaging, dynamic and relevant to all students. Her classroom environment is described as comfortable, inclusive, and conducive to learning. She is currently pursuing a post-doctoral Master of Science in psychopharmacology. Additionally, Dawn works in behavioral health, which affords a symbiotic relationship of theory and real-world experience which she shares in the classroom. Even when a student may not be majoring in psychology, it is her contribution to cultivate empathy and understanding of mental health and other psychological disorders. When she is not teaching or taking a class, Dawn finds time to act on shows such as: The Chi and Chicago Med.

Anne and Dawn will be KCC's nominees for the annual Illinois Community College Trustees Association outstanding faculty awards presented in June.

Author: Teaching and Learning Center / Faculty Development Committee

item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Where Do We Go From Here?
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Where do we go from here?

In recent months we've confronted the challenging reality that enrollment rates at Kankakee Community College are the lowest they have been since 1984.  Solving the challenges associated with this trend will require us to develop creative solutions and adopt innovative practices.  We have leaned into this challenge and are beginning to realize an opportunity to think differently about many of our programs and services and to consider enhancing them in a way that resonates with so many potential students who have not yet found in KCC's programming an accessible, attractive, or flexible enough pathway to achieve their goals.  

We're also working strategically to enhance KCC's capacity and ability to innovate and address problems with creative solutions.  As an example of this strategic approach, Dr. Battle recently led a team of KCC employees through a competency-based education "bootcamp" experience.  The team she led participated in a series of training sessions during the summer of 2021 and obtained the knowledge and expertise they needed to design competency-based educational programming here at KCC. 

Competency-based education, or CBE, is one "model-shift" occurring in higher education.  Unlike more traditional approaches to designing college courses in which students must meet "seat-time" requirements by being in class for a specified number of hours, days, and weeks, a competency-based model allows students to advance at their own pace based upon demonstration that they have met or exceeded expectations outlined in the course materials.  This approach to academic and career programs has potential to enhance flexibility and accessibility.  Because students can work on skills at their own pace, there is an opportunity to fit a KCC education into their complex lives and schedules.   

Professor Lamanda Baade, Professor and Program Director of Medical Laboratory Technology here at KCC, heard the call to action and accepted Dr. Battle's invitation to participate in the bootcamp experience.  Professor Baade knew that a competency-based approach may be the strategic and innovative solution KCC needs to embrace as a way of positioning the phlebotomy program to attract and retain more students in future semesters.  Along with the other members of Dr. Battle's CBE bootcamp, Professor Baade has significantly redesigned the phlebotomy program which is now poised to become KCC's first competency-based education program.

This is great news, of course, because it represents strategic and innovative efforts to make KCC's programs and services more accessible.  It's also great news because it helps us learn more about what it takes to be innovative and entrepreneurial as a college.   It starts with an attitude, of course, and I appreciate the willingness of the participants in the CBE bootcamp who were brave enough to recognize a problem and committed enough to seek a creative solution.  This team also understood that collaboration was a key to their early success, and the bootcamp team knew that successful implementation would require knowledge and resources from all corners of the college.  The early successes and achievements gained as a result of this project have inspired confidence in KCC's capacity for developing creative solutions and innovations.      

Future results and outcomes of this newly designed phlebotomy pathway will teach us more about flexible program design for our academic and career programs, and we'll all be waiting with eager anticipation to see how students respond to the opportunity.  Further, I hope that the successful implementation of a competency-based education approach in our medical laboratory technology program is just the beginning of the next phase in KCC's history.  Perhaps this strategic innovation is a leading indicator that KCC is ready to embrace a call to action and become a truly entrepreneurial community college. 

As for my own personal response to this strategic initiative, I am encouraged by the achievements the CBE Bootcamp team has already made since convening for the first time last summer.  I hope others feel just as encouraged and join me in expressing gratitude for our colleagues' efforts on this initiative.  Led by Dr. Kiana Battle, the team includes Lamanda Baade, Sheri Cagle, Paul Carlson, Lesley Cooper, Michelle Hasik, Meredith Purcell, and Mark Schnoor. 

Reflecting upon my gratitude for their work, though, I'm left with a lingering questions…

Where do we go from here?  What innovations will follow?  What transformative work lies ahead for us here at KCC? 

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 3/23/2022
Expires: 4/1/2022
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Supporting Students with Chronic Health Conditions
item.description:
Article Description: Part of a series on Supporting Students with Invisible Disabilities
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​The Office of Disability Services has seen a significant rise in invisible disabilities in recent years. Diagnoses can be emotional, psychological, neurological, and physical in nature and include diagnoses such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, Seizures, Autism, Lupus, Chron's Disease, Bi-Polar, Anxiety to name a few. The Americans with Disabilities Act and Title II of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 require post-secondary institutions to accommodate these disabilities, but this is not always easy to do as sometime these diagnoses can be sporadic or episodic in nature and require accommodations that go beyond the “traditional” accommodations instructors may be accustom to providing. Due to this rise in hidden disabilities, the Office of Disability Services will be offering information articles related to Autism, Traumatic Brain Injury, and Chronic Health Conditions in the upcoming weeks. The goal is to provide some basic facts about these diagnoses and offer suggestions faculty can use to support these students in the classroom. 

Supporting Students with Chronic Health Conditions

According to the CDC (Center for Disease Control) 60% of adults in the US have a chronic disease and 40% have two or more (2021) so it stands to reason that KCC serves a number of students with chronic health conditions. In the last 5 years the Office of Disability Services have served students with chronic conditions such as sickle cell anemia, lupus, cystic fibrosis, multiple sclerosis, Crohn’s Disease, cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, seizure disorders and heart disease to name a few. Symptoms related to these conditions can be sporadic in nature and occur unexpectedly. When a student experiences an exacerbation of an invisible and chronic disability, one of the common side-effects is missing class. While this can be challenging from an instructor’s perspective, keep in mind the following.

  • The student didn’t ask for this disease and would give anything to not have the condition.

  • Not only are these students battling a chronic illness, but often a psychological/emotional struggle as well. One student reported, “I just graduated high school and I want to go to college the same as my peers even with this condition. Is that too much to ask?” Another student states, “I just want to have as ‘normal’ a life as I can.”

  • In many cases, students with chronic illness are still coming to class even when they don’t feel like and in some cases probably should be home.

  • Some students need to go to larger cities or even other states to find the medical support and treatments needed for their disease. KCC’s ODS served a 19-year-old student whose specialist for a certain type of brain cancer was in California.

  • Many students report feelings of embarrassment, shame, and guilt. “I don’t like having to ask my professor extensions, but I don’t have a choice when I get sick,” reports one student. Another student comments, “I worry the teacher will look down on me when I have to leave the classroom a couple of times [during lecture] due to my illness.” 

  • Some flare-ups require hospitalization or extended recovery time. A student with sickle cell anemia may spend days in the hospital to mange the pain from the disease. The student reports, “I am living in a haze from the pain medication and have tried to attend Zoom classes.” Another student with a seizure disorder reports, “After having a grand-mal seizure, I am often unsure of where I am and am foggy for hours afterwards.”

  • Students with a chronic illness often do not take attending classes for granted. One student reported, “I love going to class and hate missing, but sometimes I simply can’t go.”

As a faculty member having to accommodate these invisible disabilities, please keep in mind that students have provided documentation of the diagnosis from a qualified medical professional and are legally entitled to the accommodations articulated in the Accommodation Letter. Be careful to keep biases in check and consider the following:

  • Punitive consequences can exasperate the issues these students face by increasing their stress levels and create more issues for them.” (Curtis, 2020)

  • For many students with chronic illnesses, even courses with more flexible attendance policies become daunting. (West, 2018)

Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Title II protects students with chronic illnesses and upon completing the Office of Disability Services registration process that includes providing documentation of the diagnosis, a student must be granted reasonable accommodations which may included deadline extensions and assignments, waiver on attendance policies. Naturally, the next question is “How can I make my class more universally designed so the impact of such an accommodation request doesn’t become such a hardship to me?”

  • Take the student’s word for it. Be willing to accept the student’s word for the absences after the accommodation letter is received. 

  • Utilize CANVAS. Post as much information and materials in CANVAS as possible, so the student having to miss class can access course information.

  • Consider recording lecture. Most of our classrooms now have Hyflex technology. Record and post lecture so the student is up to speed with the information.

  • Be approachable. Students with chronic illnesses often feel they are a burden and don’t want to cause you more work, but the reality is sometimes they must. Being approachable reduces a student’s anxiety and can ultimately reduce flare-ups from their illness.

  • Class and exam breaks. Realize that some students may need to step out of the class or even take breaks during exams due to their condition. ODS encourages students to communicate this need to you and recommends the student sit near the door to reduce distraction to other students. If your class runs for an extended period of time, consider having a brief 5-minute break.

  • Be reasonable when adjusting assignment deadlines. There are no governing statutes regarding how much time a student should be given to make up work when a student experiences an exacerbation of their disability. Work with the student to set reasonable deadlines to submit work. 

  • Makeup exams should not be punitive in nature. If a student misses an exam due to the disability-related condition, the instructor should allow the student to make up the exam as taken by the other students. Put exams in CANVAS and decide if a time limit is necessary.

  • Follow the golden rule. Treat the student as you would like to be treated. 

Resources:

  • Cdc.gov. 2021. About Chronic Diseases | CDC. [online] [Accessed 4 March 2022].

  • Curtis, K. (2020, July 21). College students with Chronic Health Conditions: Rights, Resources & Scholarships. EduMed. Retrieved March 4, 2022. 

  • Royster, L., & Marshall, O. (2008). The Chronic Illness Initiative: Supporting College Students with Chronic Illness Needs at DePaul University. Journal of Postsecondary Education and Disability, 20(2), 120–125.

  • Tulkin, A. (2020, November 17). 5 FAQs About Requesting Health-Related Accommodations on Campus. Accessible College. Retrieved March 4, 2022 

  • West, J. (2018, September 3). Navigating the university’s attendance policy with chronic illness. The Review. Retrieved March 4, 2022.

item.title: Days of Learning
item.description:
Article Description: Please join us
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Days of Learning begins next week.  Informative and engaging sessions are being offered for Monday and Tuesday (March 7 & 8) from 9-noon, and 1-4 pm. each day.  Please accept two of the four calendar appointments that were sent -- one for each day.
 
Here are the agendas:

Monday, March 7, 9-noon & 1-4 p.m.

  • CQI: Internal Communications Gate Review, by Dr. Boyd, Kari Nugent, Jen Zimmerman (45 mins)
  • Stress in the Workplace, by Melanie Duax, KCC Health Careers Navigator; M.S. (45 mins)
  • Financial Literacy- Helping you prepare for a more fit retirement journey, by Nick Boney, Financial Advisor, AIG Retirement Services (30 mins)
  • Cybersecurity Annual Update by Michael OConnor, KCC Director of ITS (30 mins)
  • Calendar Creep/July 1 Pay date by David Cagle, Director of HR (15 mins)


Tuesday, March 8, 9-noon & 1-4 p.m. 

How to Navigate the Post-Pandemic Workplace with Mindfulness, by Chris George, a former Student Life professional at Harper College and now a Mindfulness and Compassion Facilitator and Coach.

This informative, interactive workshop provides employees with a foundational understanding of what mindfulness is, the proven health and business benefits, and an experiential understanding of what it means to be mindful.

Participants will learn how mindfulness can transform the challenges of the workplace into valuable opportunities for personal and professional growth and enhanced effectiveness. Through discussion and practice, we learn how mindfulness can help us develop balance, concentration, resilience, communication, connection with others, integrity, compassion, and meaning - characteristics that allow us to thrive in the workplace.

Participants will learn how mindfulness can transform the annoyances, conflicts, and anxieties of the workplace into valuable opportunities for professional and personal growth.

Through discussion and practice, we learn how mindfulness can help us develop honesty, agility, openness, courage, maturity, respect, and authenticity – characteristics that allow us to thrive in the workplace.

Lunch will be provided both days, from Noon - 1 p.m.  (baked potato and pasta bar)


In addition, we welcome you to join us for an update on KCC's Classification and Compensation Study.  This program will be offered two times (10 am and 2 pm) on both Wednesday (March 9) and Thursday (March 10) in the Auditorium.  You can attend in person, or you can participate virtually. Please accept one of the four calendar appointments that were emailed to you by Janet Fager.

Jim Fox, Managing Partner with Arthur J. Gallagher, will be the presenter.

item.title: Casual Days
item.description:
Article Description: Staff may wear jeans during spring break week
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
Casual Days
During spring break week, staff will have the option to follow the casual day guidelines:

  • Participation is optional.
  • Jeans may be worn if accompanied by a collared shirt with "Kankakee Community College" on it or if accompanied by a business casual shirt and a KCC name badge or staff ID. KCC shirts are sold at the Hammes Bookstore and a limited selection is available in marketing and public relations. 
  • Staff are asked to use their good judgment in choosing appropriate jeans. Inappropriate jeans include those with patches, fraying, excessive length, low-rise cut and/or very faded.
  • Those who choose not to wear jeans should wear their normal work attire; or they can choose to wear a KCC collared shirt along with their normal attire.
  • All employee groups can participate.
  • Please use good judgment in choosing whether to wear jeans. Depending on what is scheduled for a particular day, jeans may or may not be appropriate. Professional appearance is important, and all employees share the responsibility of representing the college.
Questions regarding casual days should be directed to David Cagle, director of human resources.

As you should already know, on Feb. 9, Gov. Pritzker announced that mask requirements are being lifted in most public places by Feb. 28. As such, KCC is removing its mask requirements, effective Feb. 28. As the mandate is lifted, face coverings will be optional.

Some people might find that continuing to wear a mask is the best option for them.  If that is your preference, and you want a new mask, please visit Alison in PPD between the hours of 8 am to 4:30 pm, Monday-Friday  She just received an order of 500 Hanes white knit cotton masks supplied free of charge by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency (IEMA).

item.title: Workshop Week
item.description:
Article Description: The library is hosting our second Workshop Week of the semester, February 28 through March 4.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​The library is hosting our second Workshop Week of the semester February 28 through March 4.

Workshop topics include advising and registration information, MLA and APA citation, stress management and anxiety, financial literacy, study strategies, test-taking skills, and research tips.

All workshops are being held in a hybrid format. In-person participants are welcome to attend in room L162 in the lower level of the library, and online attendees can join via Zoom.  Registration is required in order to be sent the Zoom connection information.

The full schedule details along with all registration links can be found through our library website or on our workshop page.

If faculty or staff would like to offer extra credit or program participation points for students who attend workshops, there is a spot on the registration form where a student can list one or more names of people they would like to notify of their attendance.  We will send out that attendance information in the following week via email.

We are planning on one final workshop week in the second half of April in the lead-up to finals week.  If you are interested in contributing a workshop to our schedule, or have any other questions about Workshop Week, please let me know!

item.description:
Article Description: Requirements are changing Feb. 28
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​On Feb. 9, Gov. Pritzker outlined the next phase of mask mandates for Illinois. Mask requirements are being lifted in most public places by Feb. 28.

KCC will remove its mask requirements, effective Feb. 28. This applies to all indoor and outdoor college spaces. As the mandate is lifted, face coverings will be optional. Some people might find that continuing to wear a mask is the best option for them.

The vaccination policy and certify.kcc.edu requirements are unchanged. View KCC's protocols and policies related to COVID-19 on the coronavirus response website.

We will keep you posted on any future developments. If you have any questions, please use the KCC COVID-19 contact us form.

item.title: KCC mitigation strategies remain in place
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Colleagues,


On February 4th, a Sangamon County judge issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting specifically named school districts from requiring students to wear masks as a mitigation strategy to slow the spread of COVID-19 in school settings.  The restraining order on these specific schools also addresses exclusion and testing protocols.  Governor Pritzker's office and Attorney General Raoul have called for an expedited appeal of the ruling.  

While some local school districts already responded by adjusting mitigation protocols for their schools, this restraining order does not include Kankakee Community College.  KCC's administration is watching closely to determine what impact the ruling and subsequent appeal may have on KCC's mitigation strategies.  At this time, students and employees will continue adhering to the COVID-19 protocols described on the college's COVID-19 website.  If changes to KCC's COVID-19 mitigation strategies are warranted or required, we will get this information to you as quickly as possible.

I also want to thank you, in advance, for demonstrating flexibility and empathy as we address the ever-changing nature of this pandemic and our collective response to mitigation strategies.  I anticipate that students and employees will arrive on campus today with a great number of questions regarding this development.  Some may also arrive on campus with pre-conceptions regarding what this ruling means for community colleges and KCC, specifically.  Please know that we are actively working to determine answers to these questions and set future direction for our college community.

Thanks,

MB

item.title: Stay focused and spring into action
item.description:
Article Description: Continued decline in enrollment must be a "call to action" for all of us.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

As we enter a new calendar year, we have an opportunity to face our challenges with a new outlook and a new perspective. 

At my all-college address to open the spring 2022 term, I mentioned that enrollment trends during the registration cycle signaled another enrollment decline this term.  Indeed, this prediction was accurate as census day numbers show the college to be nearly -9% down in headcount and nearly -8% down in credit hours.  This decline follows what we saw in the fall of 2021.  It would be irresponsible for us, as a college community, if we did not confront the basic fact that credit hour enrollment at KCC has declined by 25% since the fall of 2016.  Additionally, we can't afford to ignore the reality that our college's revenue is tied directly to credit hour enrollment.  Certainly, we are experiencing a time of great change in our college's history.

I also mentioned in my all-college address that these factors should not lead us to panic, despair, or even complacency.  I believe strongly in our institutional mission to enhance quality of life through learning, and the commitment I've made to our students' success drives me to give all of my professional energy to Kankakee Community College and the work we do.  I know that so many of you feel the same way that I do.  I know this because I sense in our college culture right now a spirit of optimism about our future, an energized approach to changing the way we offer our services, and a willingness to think outside the box in creating access to our academic programs.

We're on the precipice of a new era for KCC, and I'm finding it very exciting to be here for this part of our story.  I hope you do as well.  One of the things that encourages me about our future is the spirt of innovation I am hearing in the conversations we are having about our shared future.  Consider all the initiatives we are pursuing at present time:

·       Guided Pathways
·       Enhancing Retention and Early Alert using Technology
·       Enabling access to instruction with HyFlex modality
·       Work-based learning
·       Competency-based instruction

There are other initiatives we can add to the list as well, and I hope we'll continue to innovate and design new solutions to the challenges we face as we pursue our mission.   

What I also see in this list is an insight I hope you see as well.  Achieving the goals at the core of each of these initiatives will certainly make us a better college at this moment in our history, but they also will bring us "back to the basics" of what we are doing here at KCC.  Consider that these projects are helping us to refresh and reenergize our approaches to the fundamentals of what we need to do in order to be a great college. 

·       Engage and recruit potential students.
·       Connect them to high quality, accessible courses and programs.
·       Coach them to completion.

These fundamental concepts that guide our efforts haven't changed.  Perhaps what has changed is our communities' and our students' expectations for how we do these things. 

Continued decline in enrollment at KCC must be a "call to action" for all of us.  It's time for us to develop a sense of urgency related to our current initiatives.  Robust discussion and debate are essential, but we must also be prepared to ideate, prototype, test, and implement quickly.  It's time for risk-taking and stepping out of the box even if doing so pushes against the systems and processes which we have in place currently.  This is what will be required to develop a culture of design thinking and entrepreneurialism at KCC.

In order for this to work, we'll also need to avoid dissent and distrust.  In working with each other, we must set our default mode to collaboration, trust, encouragement, and empowerment.  Let's direct our energy toward building supportive professional networks and away from tearing others down.  If you haven't been or aren't currently actively engaged in an improvement initiative, please talk with your supervisor to find ways to contribute.

We need to realize that we are now a smaller college today than we were as far back as 1984; however, one of our strengths right now is our size.  As an organization which understands the need for change, we can be nimble and agile as we build best practices for post-pandemic success.  Because we are a small college, we have a very flat organizational structure which means we have capacity to communicate efficiently and clearly across divisions and units.

The most important strength we have right now is the people who are KCC.  With so many of us new to the college or new to our roles at the college, we are poised to invent and design new ways to reach students who haven't considered KCC and to retain those we've lost in the past.      

We are facing another substantial enrollment decline, and we'll now begin to address the challenges this decline will present us.  Despite this setback, I remain encouraged about our future as a college.  I hope you share my enthusiasm and accept this call to action. 

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 1/25/2022
Expires: 2/4/2022

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Jan. 10, 2021

 
Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Bid solicitations for West Campus improvements
  • Award of bid for a grounds tractor
  • Adoption of KCC Board of Trustees policy manual revisions
  • Adoption of KCC Foundation Board bylaws
  • Architectural services for the Arts and Sciences building

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) shortened quarantine time to 5 days from 10 days. The college updated its procedures to follow the recommendations, which were also endorsed by the Illinois Department of Public Health and Kankakee County Health Department.
  • OSHA compliance with the vaccine mandate requires the college to track vaccine dates.
  • KCC received an extension to spend its American Rescue Plan dollars through 2023.
  • Twenty-five percent of college employees are new or new to their roles. This creates an exciting time for the culture of the college and a chance for new ideas to emerge. It's a good time to reintroduce the Leadership Development Program, and plans are underway to begin a new cohort for the program this May.
 
Student Trustee's Report. Samaria Rosenthal said …
  • Spill the Tea with the Trustee results will be shared with the President's Cabinet.
  • Welcome Week is happening this week and kicked off with the Student Involvement Fair. SAC and the Psychology Club two of the top interests.
  • February activities will include airbrush tattoos, a blood drive, and Black History month programs.

item.title: Employee Covid Testing
item.description:
Article Description: Agency code is c55ykhjn
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Employee COVID Testing

If any employee has been exposed to someone who has tested positive for COVID and wants to get tested here on campus, here is the information you will need to set up an appointment:  

Shield Testing is being conducted on the second floor of the D building, in the hallway East of the Student Services entrance (D222) and immediately east of the stairs and elevator.  

Testing hours are:  

Mondays: 7:30 am – 12:30 pm

Tuesdays: 7:30 am – 12:30 pm

Wednesdays: 7:30 am – 12:30 pm

The process requires you to deposit a small amount of saliva in a vial, which usually takes less than five minutes. Results are usually provided within 24 hours of samples reaching a SHIELD Illinois lab. 

Testing instructions

You should not eat, drink (including water), chew gum, smoke, or use tobacco products within 60 minutes of providing a saliva sample. Doing any of these things within 60 minutes of providing a sample could produce an inconclusive result and require the individual to re-test. Test results will be posted in the patient portal after the lab results are completed.

You will need to create a SHIELD IL Portal account

In order to schedule an appointment or view your lab test results you must create an account on the SHIELD IL portal. Please use the URL and Agency Code below to create your portal. 

It will ask you to create a user name and password. Once created, you will then need to enter your biographical information. Please use your home address not KCC's address. You MUST complete all of the biographical/demographical information, including gender, race, and ethnicity – it is a IDPH requirement. They will email you a 6-digit code to use. Once the code is entered on the site, you will be able to schedule an appointment. 

Note: Shield lists appointments from 7 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. Monday – Friday, but due to staffing, we will only be testing our employees from 7:30 am to 12:30 pm Monday – Wednesday, so please make your appointment during these times.

Website: https://shieldillinoisportal.pointnclick.com/login_login.aspx

Agency Code: c55ykhjn

If you have any questions, please contact me at ext. 8128.   

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 1/5/2022
Expires: 1/31/2022

Here are the answers

Holiday Traditions

Match the country/staff member to the tradition

__J___AustriaA.   Eat Kentucky Fried Chicken on Christmas
___T__DenmarkB.   Roads are closed so people can roller skate to church
___P__EgyptC.  Hide the brooms on Christmas Eve to ward off evil spirits
___O__EnglandD.  Fondue party on Christmas Eve
__V___FinlandE.   Presents opened from youngest to oldest
__S__FranceF.   Places a tall red candle in the window
__Y___GermanyG.  Eat a fried Christmas caterpillar with colorful toppings
__F___IcelandH.  Villages compete in the Great Lantern Festival
__W___IrelandI.     Eat pizza or waffles for dinner on Christmas Eve
___A__JapanJ.    Beware of Krampus (half man and half goat) hunts naughty children
__X___LatviaK.   An extra place is set at the table for an uninvited guest
__L___New ZealandL.   Cookout with seafood, meat and seasonal vegetables
__C___NorwayM.  Concert with family members
__H___PhilippinesN.  Fireworks in the town square
__K___PolandO.  Polar Bear plunge on Christmas morning
__N___PortugalP.   Fruitcake originated here
__G___South AfricaQ.  Celebrates the new year in a cabin
__U___SwedenR.  Skating in Rockefeller Center
__B___VenezuelaS.   Burn a log at home from Christmas Eve to New Year's Day
__R___United StatesT.   Homes are decorated with superstitious characters to provide protection
---D----Lynne UtterU.  A 3-ton Yule goat is constructed out of straw
---I----Ellen SchmidtV.   Go to a sauna on Christmas Eve
---Q---Brandi CastilloW. Shoes placed by window for Yule Lad visit
--M----Faith KellerX.   First decorated Christmas Tree in 1510
---E---Liz BecvarY.   Outdoor markets with handcrafted goods and holiday treats

Happy Holidays to all!

item.description:
Article Description: During Emergeny Closings - Faciliites Will Close
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)

Article Image:
Article Content:

As we approach the winter season, the college administration has re-evaluated what would happen in the event of inclement weather, and has decided that the college would indeed close for the day (as opposed to switching to a virtual work environment) in order to ensure everyone's safety.  

For those who submit time sheets, please indicate 8 hours of "Emergency Closing" in the appropriate column.  In the event facilities close due to the weather, employees and students will receive a phone call, email and text message informing them of the decision. Announcements will also be posted on www.kcc.edu.

If you have any questions, please contact David Cagle at ext. 8128.

item.title: Board Notes - December 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Dec. 14, 2021.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Grant awards
  • Tuition and course reimbursement
  • Contract awards for abatement work
  • Bid for a grounds tractor
  • Renewal of the property, casualty, liability insurance programs
  • Adoption of the tax levy
  • 2022-23 academic calendar
  • First reading for KCC Board of Trustees policy manual revisions
  • First reading for KCC Foundation Board bylaws
  • Resolutions honoring full-time retirees Elizabeth Becvar, Ralph Flores, Glenda Forneris, Carol Hubert, Darla Jepson, Dave Massey and Dana Washington

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • PJ Thompson, executive director for the KCC Foundation has a few highlights to share, including that Judge Mike Kick is being recognized as the 2021 Distinguished Alumnus and employee giving raised nearly $20,000 for student needs.
  • End of the semester is upon us and we're wrapping up for break.
  • Ceremonies were held this week for RN pinning, respiratory graduation, and nursing honors society induction.
  • UV-C lighting was installed in the campus air handling systems. UV-C light kills mold, bacteria, and viruses, including the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes COVID 19.
  • Commencement plans are underway for three ceremonies again this year at 9 am, 11 am and 1 pm.
  • ITS instituted multi-factor authentication for our computer users. This simple step keeps our systems safer from cyber security threats.

Trustee's Report. Bill Orr said….

  • The ICCTA legislative agenda was shared with trustees, and we are communicating with our elected officials when appropriate. Priorities include baccalaureate degrees at community colleges among other items.
 
Student Trustee's Report. Samaria Rosenthal said …
  • The roller-skating experience was well attended.
  • Spill the Tea with the Trustee was a success.
  • SAC members attended the Student Government Summit virtually in November. Members learned about best practices in student government.
  • SAC hosted a Pack-the-Place event for the KCC basketball team and Kankakee High School's football team attended and was recognized.
  • Relaxation Week during finals included an oxygen bar and massages for students so they could destress and unwind.
  • Welcome Week is scheduled when we return in the spring.

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Our men's basketball team is off to a good start to their season. 

They are nice young men that are working hard in the classroom as well as on the basketball court. We anticipate (the coach has his fingers crossed) a team GPA of above 3.0! Their current record sits at 9-4 against one of the most competitive schedules in the Midwest. Three of the four losses are by 6 points or less. The 6-point loss was against the no. 11 ranked team in country. One of the victories was against a nationally ranked opponent. 

We have a virtual fundraiser set up with Double Good Gourmet Popcorn. It is 100% contactless and it will be shipped directly to your home. 

I participated in this program last month and received my order within two weeks. The popcorn is good. Please click the link and purchase what you can. Feel free to share the link as well (popup.doublegood.com/s/795a3ppl)

The fundraiser ends Friday, Dec. 17 at noon. 

Happy holidays, and THANK YOU!

item.title: Leadership Development Program
item.description:
Article Description: Soliciting Cohort 4 Applications
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Applications are now being accepted for the two-year Leadership Development Program (LDP).  Cohort 4 will begin with Year One scheduled for May 17 and 18, 2022 at Starved Rock Lodge in Utica, Illinois.

The Leadership Development Program is an investment in developing talent within the college to assist with current and future roles at Kankakee Community College.  Participation in the program is a commitment to attend two years of a two-day program and actively participate in the follow-up sessions held on and off campus.  Upon completion of Years One and Two of the LDP, participants will be recognized as graduates from the program.

This program is designed for those interested in making the investment of their time and efforts with the college's support to enhance leadership skills that will serve the college community for years to come.  Graduates of the LDP will be given projects by the president.  Opportunities for professional development will be shared with all LDP participants.

If you are up to this challenge to contribute to the advancement of Kankakee Community College as an institution of higher learning, please click on this link to complete the application for consideration.  Please make sure you save it on your desktop or in your own folder, then email it to David Cagle at dcagle@kcc.edu by 5 pm December 20, 2021. Applicants will be notified of their acceptance as part of Cohort 4 of the Leadership Development Program by January 31, 2022.

If you have any questions, please contact David Cagle at ext. 8128 or dcagle@kcc.edu. 

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 12/6/2021

Article Image Caption:

​Winter break begins at noon on Dec 21

Article Content:

As you should already know, the college will officially close at noon on Dec 21, and our employees will be free to leave for winter break at that time.  Anyone requesting that full day off will only have to account for four hours of vacation (or GIVE, personal day, or floating holiday) and will receive the gift of four hours of holiday pay.  Any part time employee will be paid their normally scheduled hours that day. 

But before leaving for winter break, please join us for an all employee holiday breakfast on Tuesday, Dec 21 from 7:30-9 am in the College Center.  

As always, we thank each and every one of you for all of your contributions to our students and one another this past year.  We wish you and yours a happy holiday season!

item.title: Life insurance benefits more than $50,000 are taxable
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

subject to SURS and reflected in Dec 31 check

Life insurance benefits more than $50,000 are taxable and must be included on the W-2 form. The college is required to withhold SURS funds on this amount. Due to this SURS withholding requirement, the SURS deduction will be taken out on the last paycheck of the year. Employees will see a stipend payment with an offsetting benefit deduction on the Dec. 31 paycheck. Please note that income taxes have been taken out automatically over the course of the year. Anyone with questions is invited to call Breanna Heimberger in HR at 815-802-8146.

item.description:
Article Description: Now available on HR portal page
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Human Resources has just added an electronic version of the Tuition-Transcript Waiver form to the HR portal page.  It is best to use Google Chrome when accessing this document which is located under Documents>HR Forms>Tuition-Transcript Waiver for Employees and Retirees.  It is a fillable form that may be completed online (or printed out) and taken to Enrollment Services when registering for classes.  A paper form is still available at the Enrollment Services desk.

This benefit allows for a tuition reduction and transcript waiver for an employee's or retiree's spouse and dependent children (under age 24).  It is required that the waiver be completed every semester.

Please stop by the Enrollment Services desk or contact Human Resources if you have any questions.

item.title: New security measures for KCC accounts
item.description:
Article Description: Coming soon
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Starting next week (before Dec. 10), KCC employees will be required to use multi-factor authentication (MFA) to access email and resources connected to it.

For the new process, employees verify themselves using another device, commonly a mobile phone, when logging in to their email accounts. 

The change follows recent updates to KCC's systems security protocols. The process has been tested with a pilot group, including members of the President's Cabinet. 

"MFA is an extra layer of security designed to ensure that you're the only person who can access your KCC account, even if your password is stolen," said Michael OConnor, director of Information Technology Services. "Given today's current cybersecurity landscape, KCC's online services and accounts are high-priority targets for hackers. MFA will improve KCC's overall cybersecurity resulting in better data protection for the college."

ITS will send detailed information and instructions next Monday (Dec. 6) to help everyone understand and use the new authentication system.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 12/2/2021
Expires: 12/10/2021
