item.title: Manufacturing jobs are on the rise
item.description:
Article Description: KCC is the path to family-sustaining careers
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

My family and I love the neighborhood where we live. We love the whole community, but it's our neighborhood that is really special. I frequently tell my neighbors, "Don't wait for the invite, come on over." It's that kind of place.

If you've paid any attention to the local media in recent months, you may have learned that recent census data shows a population decline in most of our communities across the Kankakee region. These are curious statistics given the incredible opportunity and growth of business and industry happening right now. 

Did you know that Kankakee County ranks #5 among small manufacturing economies in the U.S. according to AdvisorSmith? Currently, there are 7,558 jobs available here which is 104% above the national average. The future looks even better for us, and EMSI Labor Market Analytics predict a positive growth in manufacturing jobs of +16% for our region between 2021-2031. What's even more exciting is that the average earnings in these jobs is $96,622.00.

Family-sustaining career opportunities are abundant in our community right now, and we can expect even more opportunities in the near future. At Kankakee Community College, we see it as our mission to help anyone find the pathway to these family-sustaining careers. In early October, the Daily Journal broke the news about Northern Illinois University's recent Economic Impact Study of Kankakee Community College. That study determined that KCC's graduates can expect an extra $741,997.00 in lifetime earnings in comparison to others who choose not to attend college.    

NIU's study confirms the value of a KCC degree, and the return on investment is substantial. We didn't need the data scientists at NIU to tell us, but it sure is nice to have the proof.

With so much opportunity, it's hard not to be optimistic about our future which is why the population decline we are witnessing is so confusing. Here at Kankakee Community College, we know we have a role to play in reversing this trend. We are on a mission to connect local residents with really great careers, the kind of careers that sustain strong and healthy families. We also know that strong and healthy families create strong and healthy communities, and we believe in the power of community.

I mentioned above how much I love my neighborhood and the community where my family and I live. It's warm, welcoming, friendly, and supportive. I feel like I belong here. It's my hope that we are creating a similar environment at Kankakee Community College. So, I hope no one waits for the invite. Tell everyone you know to come on over! We'd love to see you on campus very soon, and we hope you'll bring a friend along with you.

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 11/8/2021
Expires: 11/19/2021
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Open forum this week: VP for student affairs
item.description:
Article Description: Meet the candidates!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Students and college employees are invited to attend open forum sessions with finalists for the position of vice president for student affairs.

Employee forums will be 10:15-11:30 a.m. and Student forums will be 1:30 – 2 p.m. in the rooms indicated below:
    
October 26 – D152 - Dr. Jo Ann Jenkins, Dean, Student Success, Moraine Valley Community College
October 27 – D140 - Dr. David Volpe, Dean, Enrollment Management and Student Services, Community College of Baltimore County, Baltimore, MD
November 3 – D152 - Meredith Purcell, Director, Student Success, Kankakee Community College

Each finalist will begin the Open Forum with a brief 3 to 5-minute bio incorporating what attracted you to this position at KCC and how does it fit into your overall career plans. 

Additionally, a 15-minute presentation to faculty and staff will be made on this topic: "Given the decline in enrollments across the region and most parts of the country, please provide a presentation for the Board of Trustees with your recommendations for strategic institutional enrollment management.  Please include how the various departments within Student Affairs contribute to the success of recruitment and retention strategies."

At the conclusion of their presentations, finalists will participate in an Open Forum where students, faculty, and staff will present them with questions relevant to their candidacy for VPSA at KCC.

Hope to see you there in person (practicing social distancing of course).  


Author: Human Resources

item.title: 14th Annual KCC Halloween Competition is Underway
item.description:
Article Description: Today is KCC's 14th Annual Halloween Competition between campus departments.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Today, Friday, October 29, is KCC's 14th Annual Halloween Competition between campus departments.

Take a walk around the campus and check out all the participants. Then stop by the Security Desk near the library and place your vote for your favorite theme and your favorite individual costume. Voting continues until 2 p.m.

If you are part of a theme, you cannot vote for favorite theme. But definitely vote for your favorite individual costume. Your favorite individual does not have to be part of a theme.

Staff and student workers are able to visit all areas of the campus, please use the orange ballots.

A prize is also given for the student choice. Students cannot go to all areas of the campus so that is why there is a separate green ballot for the student vote. We want to be fair to all areas.

The following departments are participating in this year's competition:

  • Adult Education-3rd floor
  • Hammes Bookstore-1st floor
  • Con Ed/HR 1st floor
  • Financial Aid-2nd floor
  • Library-1st floor
  • Marketing-2nd floor

Mobile Document Destruction will be at KCC on Tuesday, December 7 to shred KCC department documents.  The approved application for authority to dispose of records along with the certificate for disposal are located on the Business Office Portal site.  Please remember you are only authorized to dispose of the records listed on the certificate for disposal.  Although the application for authority may indicate a record could be disposed of after a certain timeframe, the certificate for disposal indicates which records may be disposed of at this time.  The business office has acquired approval from the State of IL for the current certificate of disposal.    

Pease email Juli Gereg by November 23 with how many copy paper size boxes your department will have to shred and the location of the boxes.  Please remove all binder clips, paper clips and rubber bands from the documents.

 

If you have any questions please contact Juli Gereg at ext. 8122 or Michelle Weishaar at ext. 8123

 

Shredding of personal documents offered to employees

As an added benefit, employees also can bring personal documents to be shredded. The limit is one box of documents (a copier box up to 11 inches x 17 inches x 9 inches).

Please email Juli Gereg by November 23 to have your personal documents shredded. Bring personal documents at 11 a.m. December 7 to the circle drive (near the west end of the Health Careers Center for Excellence and Arts & Science Building).

​Planning is underway for the 2021 Recognition Event. It will be Friday, Nov. 5 at the Quality Inn and Suites, 800 N. Kinzie Ave. in Bradley.

Social hour will be at 5 p.m.
Dinner will begin at 6 p.m. 
Program will begin around 7 p.m.

This year will be a "Team KCC" theme.

Our emcees are Patrick Klette and Margaret Wolf!

Invitations were sent via email to all full-time employees and some part-time employees. Retirees received invitations by mail. Please reply by Oct. 21.

Dinner and soft drinks are included for employees and guests. It will be a fun way to spend a social evening together while celebrating the service of employees. We hope you can come!

Thirty-one employees will be recognized for service anniversaries ranging from five to 20 years. The honorees are ...

5 years: Gregg Beglau, Dawn Graveline, Marlana Hunter, John Shivers, Clay Sterling, and Jennifer Zimmerman

10 years: Erica Billington, Michael Caparula, Kelly Edwards, Laura Ryan, Amy Harwood, Craig Keigher, Beth Nunley, Amy Porter, Anne Reilly, Jenny Rogers, Diane Soltis, and Kendra Souligne

item.title: Safety precautions for the Recognition event
item.description:
Article Description: Staying healthy is a priority
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Some have asked the planning team what COVID-19 precautions will be incorporated into the event. Quality Inn's guidelines are much like those at local restaurants. 

  • Face masks are encouraged in common areas inside the building. 
  • Staff and servers are required to wear face masks. 
  • While we are in the event room, masks are optional for attendees, and will likely not be worn while guests are eating. 
  • Tables will be placed with ample room between them.
  • You choose your own seats and can determine who to sit with ahead of time (each table will have a max of 8 seats).
  • Plated meals will be served tableside (no buffet). 
  • Of course, if you or your guest don't feel well or are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms, please do not attend. 

We understand that the future is unpredictable. If you feel uncomfortable attending, we completely understand. Keep us updated if there is anything we can do to be more accommodating.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 10/12/2021
Expires: 11/5/2021
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Media preferences survey underway
item.description:
Article Description: Tik Tok, Facebook, Insta? We want to know.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC's Marketing department always wants to know more about our students' attitudes, opinions, and media consumption habits. 

Partnering with Interact Communications, we are encouraging students to complete the Media Prefs survey. The survey will remain open through November 14.

Faculty, to gain awareness of the survey, it would be especially helpful if you could announce in class encouraging students to look for the survey link in coming emails and posts on KCC social media channels.

Staff, if you could encourage the momentum by sharing with students when appropriate and directing them to their email for more information, we would certainly appreciate it. 

To take the survey, students should go to:
www.mediaprefs.com/illinois
survey code: Illinois.

The more students who participate, the stronger our data will be. As you know, these types of questions can provide critical information for marketing and communication at our college. They can additionally help target recruitment efforts for your programs.

Other important information to note:

  • It is voluntary
  • It is anonymous
  • It takes approximately 20-30 minutes to complete depending on their computer skills
  • It can be taken from a computer, tablet, or smartphone
  • It is intended to be taken by currently enrolled students only, please
  • All information entered will be kept confidential and non-identifiable
  • Participating students can choose to enter a drawing at the conclusion of the survey to win a prize put together by the college

This is a wonderful, timely opportunity to gather some very helpful information from our students that will assist with more effective marketing and planning for our college's future. Having accurate, fresh data is more important than ever.

If you have any questions, contact me at knugent@kcc.edu.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 10/7/2021
Expires: 10/22/2021

item.title: Upload your proof of vaccination by Sept. 19
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​In my first blog post, I promised future entries providing more analysis of the recent employee satisfaction survey. While I do plan to revisit those survey data sometime soon, it's more urgent for me to write some words about KCC's response to recent vaccination mandates. 

Let me start by stating my own thoughts on this issue. The best way to end the COVID-19 pandemic is for as many people as possible to become fully vaccinated against the virus. Vaccines are widely available, free, effective, and safe. If you are already vaccinated, thank you. If you are not, I hope you'll make that choice very soon.

As of yesterday morning, just 52% of all KCC employees have submitted proof of vaccination. I hope we can improve this percentage by the deadline of September 19th. Even more discouraging, though, is the fact that only 17% of KCC students have submitted their proof of vaccination. We can do better than this; in fact, we need to do better than this if we hope to move forward and achieve our mission of enhancing quality of life through learning.

I'm so proud of how this college has endured the challenges of COVID-19. From the early days, we met these challenges with resolve. Though we closed our doors for a short time, we refused to let the virus become a barrier to accessing the instruction, training, support, coaching, mentoring, and guidance we provide. We adapted our behaviors to meet students' needs. We went above and beyond to provide flexible service and instruction. We took extraordinary measures to make our campus environments healthy because we knew it was important for students to continue their education and for employees to thrive in our careers.

I'm not only proud, but I'm also grateful. I'm grateful for the work you've all done in the last two years. As grateful as I am, though, I need to ask you to face another COVID-19 challenge with bravery.

If you aren't already, please make an appointment to receive a COVID-19 vaccination. If you are already vaccinated, please take the opportunity to share with others how safe and painless the process really is. Be a kind, gentle, and empathetic influence in others' lives. That's our role as educators isn't it?   

There are now state and federal mandates in place for employers including Kankakee Community College. Illinois' mandate goes into full effect on September 19th, and KCC will be required to comply with these executive orders. While Illinois' order provides some allowance for weekly testing as an alternative to vaccination, this allowance stops short of providing exemptions due to convenience or availability of testing supplies. So many of us at the college are working hard to provide on-site testing as an amenity to employees or students; however, we will likely be required to comply with the mandate even when testing is not readily available on our campus locations. 

This isn't going away! 

By this, I mean to say that the vaccination mandate isn't going away, and KCC's compliance with the mandate will be under close scrutiny. As we move ahead toward the deadline, KCC will enhance our efforts to ensure that everyone is vaccinated. This begins today, with outreach to employees and students. We'll make every effort in the coming weeks to provide information, education, and opportunities to become vaccinated. If these efforts are not successful, KCC will be faced with the choice of taking additional steps to ensure that KCC maintains its recognition as a community college in Illinois by complying with the executive orders in place at this time. 

By saying "this isn't going away," I also mean that this pandemic and the illness caused by this virus, isn't going away until as many people as possible become fully vaccinated.

As our community's college, KCC has an important role to play in this region we serve. For our students and clients, we are a lifeline to important knowledge, to valuable training, to enhanced quality of life, to the liberation that comes from education. We can only achieve our mission if we can remain open to our community. 

Individually, you play an important role in how this college operates. I hope you are proud of that, and I hope you are proud to tell everyone you know that you are a part of KCC and you are an essential part of making this college what it is. Most importantly, I hope you see a future for yourself here…working on our important mission together.    

Our future, the future of our college, depends upon finding a way to move beyond COVID-19 and the horrible impact it's already had on our community. The best path to that future is vaccination. We've already fought through so many challenges together, and now I'm asking that you fight through this one as well.

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 9/14/2021
Expires: 9/24/2021
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Higher Education vax/testing requirements
item.description:
Article Description: Goes in to effect Sept. 19
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Editor's note: The following reflects new information as of Sept. 3. Where needed, information on the linked pages has also been updated.

​On Aug. 26, Illinois Gov. Pritzker announced new vaccine requirements for higher education students and employees, including KCC.

To comply with this mandate, KCC needs to institute the following changes:

  • If you are already vaccinated, complete KCC's verification form online. This is a one-time verification. Please submit verification by Sept. 19, 2021.
  • If you are not already vaccinated, consider making plans to receive the first dose of a two-dose COVID-19 vaccination series or a single-dose vaccination by Sept. 19, 2021. Second doses of the vaccine must be received within 30 days after the first dose.
  • If you do not receive the vaccine, you must be tested for COVID-19 once per week when testing becomes available at KCC.  The college is working to implement testing as soon as possible. Testing will later expand to extension centers. That information will be communicated to students and employees as it becomes available.
    • KCC is contracting with a third party vendor to provide saliva-based PCR tests.
    • Details of how to follow the weekly testing protocol are in the works and will be communicated as information becomes available.
  • Most KCC students who are vaccinated qualify for a free class from KCC. This is up to a $495 value. Full details are here. 

  • Access to campus will not be limited while we get our testing process in place. Students can come to campus and should continue to certify, social distance and wear masks.
We realize this may not be a simple change for many of you. Thank you for your understanding as we implement these required processes. 

Information will be kept up-to-date on the coronavirus.kcc.edu website. Please send questions using the KCC Coronavirus contact us form. 
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 8/30/2021
Expires: 9/10/2021
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: TED Talk Tuesdays
item.description:
Article Description: New library program takes place every Tuesday in September.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Please join us for TED Talk Tuesdays every Tuesday in September.  Each week, students, faculty, and staff will gather in the library to watch a short TED Talk and take part in a discussion and Q&A session moderated by a KCC instructor.  If you enjoy learning about a wide variety of topics and discussing interesting things, these programs are for you!


The line up for September is:

  • Tuesday, September 7, 12:30 PM:  Amy Porter discusses the TED Talk "The Opportunity Gap in U.S. Public Education - and How to Close It" by Anindya Kundu.
  • Tuesday, September 14, 1:00 PM:  Joshua Riley moderates a discussion about the TED Talk "The Physical Side of the Internet" by Andrew Blum.
  • Tuesday, September 21, 10:00 AM:  Trisha Dandurand leads the conversation after viewing the TED Talk "The Infinite Alchemy of Storytelling" by Zahra Al-Mahdi.
  • Tuesday, September 28, 11:00 AM:  Robert Babich examines the issues raised in the TED Talk "How Great Leaders Inspire Action" by Simon Sinek.


TED Talks, discussion questions, and additional resources are posted on our TED Talk Tuesday guide, along with the program flyer.  The talks will be shown at the beginning of each program, so no need to prepare in advance, just come on in and join the conversation!


If you are interested in moderating during the next round of TED Talk Tuesdays (tentitively planned for February), contact Tracy Conner for more information.

Author: Tracy Conner
Article Date: 8/31/2021
Expires: 9/29/2021

Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC Connect, the system students and employees once used to check information like grades, class schedules, pay advices and leave balances, will not be available after Sept. 30. The software manufacturer will no longer support it.

All of the information from KCC Connect, and more, can now be accessed through Self-Service on the portal.

"Self-Service offers a more user-friendly experience than KCC Connect," said Josh Gregoire, coordinator of administrative information systems. "And, it has all the functionality you're expecting."

"For example, employees can use Self-Service to check earning statements, leave balances and other HR related information," Josh continued. "Budget managers can also use Self-Service to monitor department budgets. Faculty can use it to submit grades and view/email class rosters. Students can view their schedule, plan and register for classes, pay their bill and see their KCC financial statements through the tool. Overall, it's a much better solution."

Anyone with questions can contact the Help Desk at ext. 8900.


Use Self Service to view, monitor and plan:

  • Earnings statements
  • Leave balances
  • HR information
  • Department budgets
  • Class rosters
  • Class schedules
  • Grades
  • Registration
  • Student financial statements

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Aug. 9, 2021

 
Presentations. Honored and distinguished guests…
Kiana Battle shared the strategic plan update.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Grant awards
  • Tuition and course reimbursement
  • Board of Trustees meeting calendar
  • Tentative budget for FY22

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…
Mask requirements are in effect for college facilities. Everyone is expected to wear face covering regardless of vaccination status, and we'll continue with the practice until such time that our area is deemed as low or moderate risk for transmission of Covid-19. KCC is still conducting contact tracing and will recommend quarantine for those known to be exposed.
KCC is purchasing UV light technology for the HVAC system. The UV will clean the air moving through the system and protect against viruses, including Covid-19.
Inservice begins Wednesday, Aug. 11, and classes begin Monday, Aug. 16.
NIU conducted an Economic Impact Study with the ICCB and results will be shared with the community in September.
Health Honors program begins this semester at the North Extension Center. Twelve students are enrolled in the cohort group.

SAC's Welcome Week is planned and will provide events and activities for students.
SAC is participating in the next Equity, Diversity and Inclusion council meeting in August.

item.title: Greenspace plan is always evolving
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​KCC's campus started as farm ground, with very few trees. 

Under retired KCC President Dr. L.H. Horton Jr., a concerted effort began to plant trees and cultivate other green spaces on the 176.6 acre (more or less) campus.

After Horton retired in 1987, efforts to beautify KCC and keep plentiful greenspaces continued. 

Coming soon, KCC's website will have a page dedicated to our greenspaces--with reflections on the past, details on the present, and thoughts on the future.

The content has nuggets including:

  • The estimated number of trees that were planted by teenagers during summer programs.
  • The new college acreage.
  • How much of KCC's acreage is dedicated to farmland.
  • Why some trees have ribbons.
  • Past and current collaborators, including the Morton Arboretum, University of Illinois students and University of Illinois Extension Office.
  • A burgeoning fruit tree orchard.
  • Current considerations for cutting down, cutting back, pruning or removing trees and plantings.

The page will also have pictures of KCC trees and open spaces through the years.

Another Update article will be posted when the page goes live -- hopefully within the next few weeks.

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 8/23/2021
Expires: 9/10/2021

Counseling is confidential and the first 5 sessions are FREE. For long-term treatment, payments are accepted including insurance, self-pay, and sliding scale.

item.title: What's it like to work here?
item.description:
Article Description: Depends on who you ask
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Dear KCC Community,

This is the first of a series of blogs that I will post on a regular basis as a KCC Update article. The goal of this project is to enhance communication by finding new ways to share information and generate productive dialogue at KCC. My vision is that these posts will be brief but timely discussions of relevant topics.

The impulse for starting this blog series came from my first reading of results from our recent administration of the Noel Levitz Employee Satisfaction Survey. You may recall that we administered this survey while we were in a very challenging stage of the covid-19 pandemic, yet it revealed some very encouraging things about employee satisfaction at KCC. These survey results, overall, are incredibly positive. You can read more on this update article. If you were at my all-college address in August or watched the recording of it, you already know that KCC's satisfaction scores surpass those of other colleges across the nation. You also heard me mention that I'd be sharing more information from the qualitative portion of the survey in which employees write candid responses in their own words.     

Whenever the entire employee group from a large organization is surveyed, the results are incredibly varied. For example, this same survey administered at the same time elicited responses like those which follow and share very different perceptions of our college climate.  

  • "KCC is a second home for me. It has welcomed me with open arm and I have become a part of KCC and its culture.  We are not only co workers we are friends and family.  KCC is a safe place for faculty, staff, and students.  I truly believe it is a great place and I would recommend highly for anyone to take classes or work here!" 
  • "miserable, our department is listening to people that are rarely there and have no clue as to what is actually going on, who is doing the work"
  • "I feel valued and my work is personally fulfilling and recognized by my immediate supervisor, students, and colleagues."
  • "I would rate KCC as the worst college I have had the opportunity to be [sic]employed."
  • "Work environment is one of the best I have worked in my entire working career.  We all work as a team here at KCC."

In my next article, I will share a bit more analysis from this portion of the survey. I hope, though, the quoted feedback I've provided here show you how challenging it is to completely understand the results of our recent Employee Satisfaction Survey. There's a lot of passion expressed here, and that passion is often aimed in opposite directions. 

Finally, thanks for reading this first blog-style update to the college community.  Stay tuned.

Best,
MB

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 8/19/2021

Article Content:

We hosted just over 180 students at Thursday night's First Year Experience Kickoff Event! 180! 

The goal of the event was to welcome our students to campus and to connect them with their instructors and resources and one another. All students enrolled in a fall section of ORIN 1541 - Foundations for Student Success were invited. We accomplished all that and more. It was a huge success!

This event could not have happened without everyone's help and your passion for our students and this program. I wanted to take a minute to tell you how much I appreciate all each and every one of you did to make this event a success and to make our students feel welcome and that they belong.  You know who you are!

This Fall is our largest FYE cohort since the course's inception with 446 students registered as of today, Wednesday, August 18.

A drawing for prizes concluded the evening.  Winners were:

Baylee Anderson - $100 Bookstore gift card and a digital notebook.

Jacqueline Annes - certificate for a 3-credit-hour course.

Kloey Greenwood-Schubbe - certificate for a 3-credit- hour course.

Arely Manzur Cruz - KCC gift basket of swag.

Quiana Morris - certificate for a 3-credit-hour course.

Kaylie Warpet - Air Pods.

Thank you again to everyone for making this inaugural event a success!

Jen Huggins

item.title: Employee satisfaction survey results
item.description:
Article Description: We gave it 4 out of 5
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Thank you to everyone who participated in the Noel Levitz Employee Satisfaction Survey. In total, 339 KCC employees received the survey and 141 responded to it.

Overall, respondents ranked their satisfaction with the workplace at a 4.02 out of 5.0.  This is higher than the average comparison group of institutions score of 3.84.

"KCC conducts this survey so that we can continue to improve, even in areas where we are already outperforming other employers," said Dr. Boyd. "KCC, as it has in each year of the survey's administration, outperformed similar institutions in overall satisfaction which means that employees at KCC are generally more satisfied than employees at other colleges. This is great news and an indicator that Kankakee Community College remains a great place to work. A quick review of those items where KCC improved since the last survey are great reminders of the pride employees have in this college's mission and our impact in the community."

 
Strengths
Employees feel:

  • Proud to work at this institution, feel their work is personally rewarding, and feel appreciated by their supervisor.
  • The institution treats students as its top priority and promotes excellent employee-student relationships.
  • The institution treats students as its top priority and promotes excellent employee-student relationships.
  • Themselves personally, and the institution are committed to advocating for equality and inclusion for all groups,
    particularly LGBTQ, Multicultural, women, veterans, first generations students, and students with disabilities.
  • The institution has done an effective job making them aware of its policies, procedures, and available resources.
  • The benefits available to them are valuable.

 

On the upswing
Areas which showed significant improvement compared to the 2018 survey:

  • The institution is committed to advocating for equality and inclusion for all groups.
  • The institution is committed for fostering a community of inclusion that promotes equality and acceptance for all students and all employees.
  • Faculty take pride in their work.
  • The institution is well-respected in the community.
  • There are effective lines of communication between departments.
  • There is good communication between the faculty and the administration at this institution.
  • Efforts to improve quality are paying off at this institution.
  • The leadership of this institution has a clear sense of purpose. 

Opportunities for Improvement
Employees feel the institution could improve by:

  • Exploring ways to retain the most highly qualified employees and providing additional opportunities for advancement.
  • Increasing effective lines of communication between departments and using employee suggestions to improve the institution.
  • Increasing efforts to promote positive employee morale.
  • Consistently following clear processes for the selection of new employees.
  • Ensuring that departments have the staff necessary to do their jobs well.

Aspirations
Employees ranked the following as the top five strategic priorities the institution should pursue:
1. Increase the enrollment of new students.
2. Retain more of its current students to graduation.
3. Improve employee morale.
4. Improve marketing and outreach efforts.
5. Improve the quality of existing academic programs.
 

Anyone with questions about results from the satisfaction survey is invited to contact Lesley Cooper at ext. 8370 or lcooper@kcc.edu.

item.title: Board Notes - July 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, July 12, 2021

 
Presentations. Honored and distinguished guests…

ICCTA Executive Director Jim Reed presented Jerry Hoekstra with the ICCTA 30-year Trustee Award. (see photo, left)

Whitney Mittons discussed the new EDI Center and the equity, diversity and inclusion training she is conducting with Riverside staff.

Jen Huggins and Meredith Purcell shared that retention is the focus of KCC's quality improvement project and educated the board about a retention software option.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Next steps in sale of funding bonds
  • Grant award for Perkins Reserve funding
  • Bid requests to construct a police and public safety office
  • Bid approvals to proceed with Phase 2 of the Technology Building renovation
  • Bid approvals for science supplies

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…
Thanks to the July 4 planning team for assisting the Kankakee Valley Symphony Orchestra with their annual fundraiser on our lawn. It was a great way to welcome our community back to campus grounds.

Former Cavaliers baseball player Dylan Dodd was drafted by the Atlanta Braves. Dylan was the 96th draft pick and will join the Braves as a left-hand pitcher. Dylan played first base and left-hand pitcher for the Cavaliers' 2017 and 2018 seasons and helped lead the Cavaliers to a National Tournament Championship in 2017.

Dr. Kiana Battle and Mary Posing joined the County Board's Workforce Team to guide how the county will spend Covid relief dollars to improve Kankakee County.

North Patio renovation project planning is underway with the Capital Development Board. The process can be lengthy, but state funds pay for much of the project cost.

The Health Careers Honors program begins this fall at the North Extension Center. Ten students have been admitted, and they will progress through the program as a cohort group.

Financial assistance packages are available for students.

  • The college has received $3.2 million in American Rescue plan funds, in addition to the Higher Education Emergency Relief Funds (HEERF II) its already received under the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act (CRRSAA). These awards do not impact a student's eligibility for other federal student aid, such as the Pell grant. They do not have to be paid back. (editor's note: Students who enroll for Fall 2021 at KCC can apply for this financial assistance and find additional Information at https://www.kcc.edu/tuition-and-aid. Requests will be evaluated based on need and verification of enrollment.)
  • KCC received a federal grant from the Dept. of Labor that pays for tuition, fees, books and more for students in KCC's manufacturing, welding and electrical engineering technology degree and certificate programs. To be eligible, students must be out of high school, reside in Northwest Indiana or Northeast Illinois and be unemployed or underemployed. (editor's note: Interested people can contact Mark Anderson at manderson@kcc.edu.)

Student Trustee's Report. Somaria Rosenthal said …

  • SAC's July 4 table was a success. Representatives handed out items and cotton candy.
  • SAC has three potential new members this summer.
  • Members are working on the student life calendar for fall and spring, and activities will include hiking, canoeing, fishing, frisbee golf and chess.
  • Trio members recently went on an architectural boat tour in Chicago.
  • SAC is participating in the next Equity, Diversity and Inclusion council meeting in August.

Author: Kari Nugent

item.title: "1 Kick Wonders" 3-Peat
item.description:
Article Description: Student Affairs wins kickball tourney for the third time
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Four teams entered the 3rd annual double-elimination Kickball Tournament on July 22, and for the third time, the team from Student Affairs - the "1 Kick Wonders" were crowned the champions.    

In the first round of action, "The BAD Team" (Business Affairs Division) defeated "The Marketing Team" while "The Guardians" (PPD) defeated the "1 Kick Wonders" sending the two-time defending champs into the loser's bracket.  

In the second round, the "1 Kick Wonders" defeated "The Marketing Team, knocking them out of the tournament while "The BAD Team" defeated "The Guardians."  

In the third round, with the score tied after three innings, the "1 Kick Wonders" sneaked past "The Guardians" in sudden death, which featured one player from each team kicking the ball closest to second base.  

This set up the Championship Match pitting the undefeated "The BAD Team" vs. the "1 Kick Wonders." After three innings of play, the score was tied, setting up once again a sudden death one-kick, closest to second base contest.  Nick Sotello beat out Sean Hogan forcing the two teams to play one final game. The "1 Kick Wonders" then knocked out "The BAD Team" to win the tournament and to have bragging rights for yet another year. 

Congratulations to Kendra Souligne (captain) and her "1 Kick Wonders" team members: Michael Brown, Taylor Fox, Sherry Kinzler, Sergio Parks, Megan Ponton, Michelle Rodriquez, Nick Sotello (named tournament MVP), Amanda Stosiek, Abigail Tilley, and Kate Wachtor.










The other teams - BAD, Marketing, The Guardians

  

Author: David Cagle

item.title: Kickball tournament begins at 12:15 pm, 7/22
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Four teams have entered the 3rd annual double elimination Kickball Tournament, scheduled for this Thursday, July 22 on the north lawn.

By virtue of a random draw, "The BAD Team" (Business Affairs Division) will face "The Marketing Team" at 12:15 pm.  The second game will begin at 12:45 pm between "The Guardians" (PPD) vs. the two-time defending champs, "The 1-Kick Wonders" (Student Affairs).  

Each game will consist of three innings or a 30-minute time limit, with the Championship Match slotted for 2:45 pm.  The "Traveling Championship Trophy" and the "Traveling Most Valuable Player Trophy" (solely chosen from the winning team) will be presented immediately afterwards. 

If the action on the field isn't enough attraction for you, come on out at 12:15 pm for hotdogs, chips, cookies, bottled water, etc.  Employees may wear jeans that day if worn with a KCC shirt. 

So, come on out and cheer for your favorite team, and have a little "summer fun."  

A special thanks to fellow Culture of Caring Committee members for hosting/coordinating this event:  Kendra Souligne, Liz Becvar, Janet Fager, Kelsey Hart, Kim Cross, Katie Henry, Abigail Tilley, and Dana Washington.

item.title: Unemployment Fraud
item.description:
Article Description: Press Release from IDES on Unemployment Fraud
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
Identity Theft-Related Unemployment Fraud

The following is a press release from the Illinois Department of Employment Security (IDES).

IDES is urging Illinoisans to be on high alert for phishing schemes that may be leading to identity theft as international bad actors continue to attempt to exploit unemployment systems across the country. Fraudulent text messages, emails, and social media messages, posing as IDES and other state agencies and constitutional offices, are being sent to individuals in an attempt to phish for personally identifiable information (PII) and other data. This is a continued, organized attempt to defraud state unemployment insurance systems until the expiration of the federal unemployment programs on September 4, 2021.

It is imperative that claimants and the public at large remain vigilant to detect fraudulent correspondence. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has provided steps individuals should follow to recognize and avoid phishing schemes. Individuals should also take steps to strengthen and protect online account information. IDES claimants should maintain strong, unique passwords to their accounts, and never share personal account information with untrustworthy sources.

Since March 2020, IDES has shut down more than 1.7 million claims filed with the Department in the names of identity theft victims. Throughout the pandemic, these organized and sophisticated crime syndicates have continued to adapt and evolve their attempts to access the unemployment insurance system. IDES has worked tirelessly to enhance internal analytic tools, fraud detection and prevention methods, and identity verification measures to increase protections around fraudsters accessing the system and filing fraudulent claims. Last week alone, the State of Illinois and IDES networks blocked nearly 450 million nefarious attempts to access the Department’s benefit system, either to file a fraudulent unemployment insurance claim or to compromise an existing claimant account to redirect payment.

Illinois is among the states who have committed to administering the federal unemployment insurance programs until their expiration in September to ensure those who are struggling receive the benefits they eligible for under federal law. These programs include Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA), Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation (FPUC), and Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation (PEUC). As expected, fraudsters are increasing their attempts to access the unemployment insurance systems in states who have not opted out of administering these programs early. This is being done through continued data mining via phishing schemes to attempt to file claims in the names of identity theft victims or steal benefits from existing claimants.

Identity theft-related unemployment insurance fraud has been rampant nationwide since the onset of the pandemic as a result of the wide-scale availability of PII and the creation and extensions of the federal unemployment insurance programs – PUA, FPUC, and PEUC. Large corporate data breaches and cyber hacks (e.g. Equifax data breach in 2017 which compromised the PII of nearly 150 million; Yahoo data breach in 2014 which compromised the PII of nearly 3 billion; Target data breach in 2013 which compromised the PII of nearly 110 million) have exposed and compromised the PII of millions of victims, resulting in organized fraudsters taking advantage of this information and using it to capitalize monetarily during a time of crisis.

If you have been the victim of identity theft-related unemployment insurance fraud, visit the IDES fraud webpage for information about how to report the claim.
Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 6/22/2021
Expires: 7/3/2021
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Board Notes - June 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, June 14, 2021.

Presentations. Honored and distinguished guests…

Dick Frey resigned from the board of trustees after 20 years of service. During the meeting, Chairman Brad Hove honored Frey with a resolution, and each member shared their gratitude for his commitment. The college will host a reception in August. Michael Proctor from Bourbonnais was appointed to complete Frey's term on the board. You can read more about Dick Frey in KCC's Newsroom.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Resolutions honoring retirees Karen Bayston, Bridget Bertrand-Essington, Helen Streicher and John Willard, and outgoing trustee Dick Frey.
  • Recommendation to appoint Michael Proctor as trustee
  • Recommendation to operate within the budget draft
  • Revised 2021-22 academic calendar
  • Grant award for Governor's Emergency Education Relief Grant (GEER)
  • Debt certificate resolution
  • Bid approvals for cybersecurity software, VM Ware and instructional equipment
  • Bid requests for science supplies
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Welcome to our new Student Trustee Samaria Rosenthal.
  • KCC Foundation update to the board included highlights from the Scholarship Signing Day event, Give Day planning and donor stewardship efforts.
  • Summer enrollment fell by 2.8% over last summer. As the pandemic subsides the college is looking forward to increasing enrollment numbers in the coming semesters.
  • Women's soccer completed their inaugural year and finished sixth in the region. The men's soccer and women's volleyball teams were named 2021 NJCAA All-Academic Teams.

 
Student Trustee's Report. Samaria Rosenthal said …

  • Thank you for the opportunity to be the voice of the student body.
  • Student Advisory Council (SAC) elected new officers, but who will fulfill the vice president's role is still to be determined.
  • SAC is planning activities for the year.
  • SAC typically sells glow items at the July 4 event, but this year those items will be given away at no cost.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 6/15/2021
Expires: 7/2/2021

item.title: Updated Mask Requirement
item.description:
Article Description: June 11 masks will not be required for fully vaccinated people.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following guidance from the Centers for Disease Control, the governor’s office and the Illinois Department of Public Health, KCC is revising its mask requirement.  

Beginning Friday, June 11, individuals who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 will no longer be required to wear a mask while at college facilities, both indoors and outside. This adjustment follows announcements from the CDC and IDPH which indicate that the COVID-19 vaccine provides effective protection against the virus. Therefore, those vaccinated can remove their masks in most settings. 

This change does not extend to unvaccinated individuals, who should continue to wear a mask while on college property. 

KCC will depend on the integrity of students and staff to follow the requirements based on their individual vaccine status. 

For those who have not done so already, the college also recommends getting a COVID-19 vaccine – for both the health benefits and the flexibility it now provides while at the college and in the community.

Please note: Also on June 11, the requirement to complete a self-assessment before entering a KCC facility is being removed for everyone. Social distancing guidelines and cleaning protocols are still in place in college facilities.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 6/8/2021

item.title: 2021 Performance Appraisals
item.description:
Article Description: Due dates are in June
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

 

 

It is that time again -- time for annual performance appraisals of administrators, professional/technical and supportive staff.

Completed appraisals are to be submitted to the Human Resources Office by June 1st for non-supervisory staff (full and part-time) and June 15th for supervisory personnel.

 

Evaluation process:

The process includes reflection on your accomplishments, how you met/exceeded last year's goals, and what specific goals/objectives await you in the coming fiscal year.

Please note below the new KCC Strategic goals for FY20 – FY22:

  • Improve student success through increased enrollment, retention, transfer, and completion rates.
  • Create diverse, inclusive, and equitable teaching, learning, and work environments.
  • Improve physical and virtual teaching and learning spaces.
  • Increase visibility and value in community.
  • Provide development opportunities to enhance KCC employee skills and knowledge. 

     
    You should consult with your immediate supervisor for his/her deadline which allows time for all levels of supervision to review evaluations before the appropriate Human Resources deadline.  Electronic evaluation forms are located on the HR Portal page under Documents.

    As part of this process, if the position description is not accurate, your supervisor should make proposed revisions and submit them to Human Resources with the evaluation.  A copy of your current description may be obtained by contacting Janet in HR at ext. 8124.  A "Specific responsibilities" section should also be included.

    The process will be as follows:

    1.  Complete a self-evaluation.

    2.  Submit it as a Word document to your immediate supervisor. Schedule a meeting with him/her to discuss performance, review the completed tasks, establish new goals through March 2022 and complete the final evaluation. Note: Input/support from department directors should be solicited prior to this meeting.

    3.  Sign the completed evaluation, get your immediate supervisor's signature, plus the appropriate department director's.  Keep a copy (or save it electronically). Your supervisor should do the same (for use during next year's evaluation process).

    4.  Deliver a paper copy to Human Resources by the appropriate due date.

Please contact David Cagle at dcagle@kcc.edu or 815-802-8128 if you have any questions regarding this process.

Author: Human Resources
Article Date: 6/1/2021
Expires: 6/21/2021
item.author: Janet Fager

item.title: Masks still required on campus for now
item.description:
Article Description: Please continue wearing masks in public spaces
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) recently announced that those who are vaccinated can remove their masks in most indoor settings.  

While many are excited about the news, we are still awaiting additional guidance from Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) that will allow for the college to reevaluate its campus mask policy. KCC has been following CDC, IDPH and Illinois Board of Higher Education guidance throughout the pandemic.

For the time being, our plan is to maintain the current mask requirements indoors until we can receive and interpret this new guidance. The reopening task force will communicate any changes in practice. Until then, thank you for wearing masks in public spaces on campus.

item.title: Construction work - L Building exterior
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Beginning Monday, May 17, we will have contractors on site to begin work on the south face of the L bldg over the main entrance.  

The area of work will include the 3rd floor overhang of the main entrance and over the ITS roof. The work at the 3rd floor overhang will have noise issues which will be audible at the offices in the back hall and classroom L344.  It will include cutting and grinding, repair/replacement of the steel lintels and replacement of any damaged brick.  

The contractors plan on constructing a scaffold that will span the front of the building. This shouldn’t affect ingress of the building much as these doors have been closed for the last year. There will be signage and barricades at the doors from the inside, indicating they’re closed.  

The doors that will be affected are the main entrance doors, east door by the police vehicle, and the two west doors by Hammes Café and the stairwell.

Author: Rob Kenney

Expires: 6/4/2021

item.description:
Article Description: Employees no longer need to self-assess
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)

Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Students must still self-assess daily

Article Content:

Effective May 17, employees are no longer required to complete the self-assessment form prior to coming to work. This only applies to employees – students will still need to continue this process.  Although this is no longer a requirement for employees, faculty and staff still need to follow the previous safety measures, meaning do not come to campus if you have: 

  • a fever or a measured temperature above 100.3 degrees
  • a cough or trouble breathing within the past 24 hours
  • had close contact with an individual diagnosed with COVID-19 within the past 14 days (unless you have been fully inoculated with the COVID vaccine)
  • have not been asked to self-isolate or quarantine by your doctor or a local public heath official 

If you are unsure about your ability to come to campus, or if you aren't well enough to come to campus because of the above safety measures, you must contact David Cagle at ext. 8128.

item.title: Submit Work Orders Using Schooldude
item.description:
Article Description: Use computer-based software to request and monitor PPD requests.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​Physical Plant Department uses a work order system called Schooldude to request and monitor work orders throughout the college.  Each department has a person designated as the work order initiator.  Employees should bring PPD requests to that person to create the work order.  Contact your supervisor to find out who your initiator is.  

Work order requests can include anything from hanging pictures, changing light bulbs, moving furniture, painting spaces, and even larger-scale work like adding electrical circuits.  Think of Schooldude as your one-stop shop for all service and maintenance requests.

Please note:  If you see an issue that needs immediate attention, like a toilet overflowing or water dripping from the ceiling, please contact PPD at ext 8170 as soon as possible.

item.title: SURS Deferred Compensation Plan available 7/1
item.description:
Article Description: another way to save towards your retirement goals
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
Effective July 1, 2021, full-time KCC employees will be able to participate in the SURS Deferred Compensation Plan (the SURS Plan). 

The SURS Plan is a governmental plan under Section 457(b) of the Internal Revenue Code that allows employees to make tax-deferred contributions toward retirement. The College's participation in the SURS Plan is required to facilitate compliance with Section 15202 of the Illinois Pension Code, which mandates that employees participating in SURS be offered an optional defined contribution benefit. 

Employees' participation in the SURS Plan will be voluntary. The College will play a limited role in coordinating payroll deductions for participating employees and monitoring compliance with contribution limits under the Internal Revenue Code for participating employees. The College has elected not to make any matching or discretionary nonelective contributions based upon the mandatory nature of the College's participation.

For additional information concerning the SURS Plan and its administration, please refer to the SURS website (https://www.surs.org/welcome-surs-deferred-compensation-plan). SURS will also be sending direct postcards to employees' home addresses in the coming weeks to promote the SURS Plan. 

If you have any questions or concerns regarding the College's required participation in the SURS Plan or the new benefit being offered to employees, please contact me at ext, 8128.  
Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 4/19/2021
Expires: 5/14/2021

item.title: Board Notes - April 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, April 12, 2021

 

Presentations. Honored and distinguished guests…
Mike Proctor from CSL Behring acknowledged the apprenticeship program partnership between CSL and KCC. This May four students will graduate with Associate in Applied Science degrees in Manufacturing Technology. They completed the program while working full-time with CSL, and as a result they will take on more responsibilities in the workplace.

Dr. Kiana Battle presented the new tenured faculty: Jaclyn Cruz, Radiography; Chris Gibson, Paramedic; Sarah Gowler, Early Childhood Education; Rebecca Murphy, Radiography; Jessica Oladapo, Sociology, Mark Schnoor, Economics/Statistics

Craig Keigher presented the KCC Outstanding Faculty of the Year award recipients Jennifer Pecora Kettley and Josh Riley to the Board. Both are English professors in the Liberal Arts and Sciences division.

Dr. Jose Da Silva introduced Samaria Rosenthal as the 2021-22 Student Board of Trustee member. She will begin her term at the June meeting.

 
Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Grant awards
  • Athletic letters of intent
  • SURS deferred compensation plan options
  • Bid solicitation for computer switch refresh
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Congratulations to Bill Orr and Jerry Hoekstra on their reelection to the KCC Board of Trustees.
  • Bridge to Illinois' Phase 5 reopening plan is moving forward. KCC is safely managing the campus environment.
  • Kudos to Rob Kenney, Katie Henry, Kari Nugent, Karen Slager, Micheal Stoltz and their staff who planned and coordinated the vaccination event on April 6 and 7.
  • KCC is planning three commencement ceremonies on May 15 at 9 am, noon and 3 pm.
  • Funds from the American Rescue Plan will be used to on campus to mitigate effects from coronavirus related expenditures.
  • State Representative Jackie Haas visited campus to tour the Technology hallway renovation. Her office was instrumental in releasing state funds to the college for the project.
  • The food pantry is moving to the first floor thanks to sponsorship dollars from Iroquois Federal. It will expand offerings to include refrigerated and frozen foods.
  • The police station is moving from under the stairs to another first-floor location.
  • KCC's heating and cooling system could get an upgrade to improve air circulation and virus mitigation.
  • KCC is exploring how it fits with a small business incubator being developed in downtown Kankakee.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • ICCTA met in Schaumburg. The focus was cyber security and legislation for MAP grant funding.

 
Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • Volunteering at the vaccine event was an important and rewarding experience.
  • SAC officers attended a student leadership exchange about time management.
  • Sexual assault awareness week is underway – the exhibit "What They Were Wearing" is on display in the College Center. Other activities are planned, including Candlelight Yoga, and Wear Teal Day on April 15.
  • Club activities are being planned for fall.
  • Student clubs held a virtual recognition event.
  • PTK virtual convention happening June 4 and 5.

item.title: Pecora Kettley and Riley named as 2021 Outstanding Faculty Award recipients
item.description:
Article Description: Announcement of 2021 Outstanding Faculty Awards
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The Outstanding Full-Time Faculty Member recipient is Jenny Pecora Kettley, English professor in the Liberal Arts and Sciences Division.

​
Since Jenny began her career as a community college English professor in 2010, she has shared her love of learning with her students and colleagues in a variety of ways. Her highly engaging, scaffolded methods of instruction have consistently provided strong and positive feedback from her students for more than a decade. Her passion for learning and self-improvement has led her to pursue ongoing educational opportunities, for which she has earned multiple professional certificates related to online instruction, writing instruction, and digital accessibility. In turn, she readily and enthusiastically shares her knowledge with her colleagues through many in-service sessions, conference presentations, committee work, and participation in other college initiatives.​

The Outstanding Part-Time Faculty Member recipient is Joshua Riley, who teaches English I and English II courses in the Liberal Arts and Sciences Division.

​
​Joshua joined KCC as an adjunct professor in Fall 2019, and is the lead tutor to the student athletes. Students have expressed appreciation for his kind and welcoming approach in the classroom. Outside the classroom, Professor Riley further serves students through his role in Tutoring. The tutoring program he developed for student athletes establishes a culture of group accountability and growth through expectation setting, planning, resource referral, and direct tutoring.

Beyond his work at KCC, Riley has written a weekly column for a local newspaper and other publications about craft beer, he hosts a podcast about retro video games, and he hosts a YouTube channel about classic literature.

Jenny and Joshua will be KCC's nominees for the annual Illinois Community College Trustees Association outstanding faculty awards presented in June.


Author: Teaching and Learning Center / Faculty Development Committee
Article Date: 3/26/2021
Expires: 4/17/2021
item.author: Craig Keigher

item.title: KCC selected to offer COVID-19 vaccinations
item.description:
Article Description: Plans are moving ahead
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC's Riverfront campus has been selected as a Point of Distribution (POD) for the COVID-19 vaccine.

Johnson and Johnson vaccines will be administered at KCC's Ryan Gymnasium for those who qualify to receive it under Phase 1a, 1b and 1c guidelines. Appointments are required. Dates, times and the sign-up process isn't available to us yet. We'll communicate it as soon as we know.

Plans are in place to administer 700 vaccinations per day for up to 2 days at KCC. Illinois National Guard personnel will be on site to support processing, paperwork, vaccinations and observations.

"Up until late last night we didn't think that KCC would be able to offer vaccinations," said Mike Boyd, KCC president. "But all that quickly changed and now we're ready to move ahead. This will be an event for community members who are qualified to receive the vaccine, which includes KCC faculty and staff. It will include KCC employees and our community. While we do have clear direction from the Governor's office, plans like this are subject to change."

The moment we knew that vaccinations were available we offered our campus as a distribution site," said Dr. Boyd. "KCC is a familiar place for so many residents and that's why it was a great place to host a vaccination site. It's our hope is that all residents in Kankakee County who qualify for the vaccine can receive it. It is a privilege to serve our community during the COVID-19 recovery process."

A preparation team is working on the details, including the set-up, signage and communication. Appointments will be handled through a website managed by the Illinois National Guard.

When the time comes, those with appointments should come to KCC's Riverfront campus, follow directional signs to park and enter the building. Masks and social distancing guidelines are in place, and areas will be routinely sanitized.

The Illinois Department of Public Health guidelines, vaccination plan, and FAQs are provided at https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/vaccination-plan

Author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Advisors' titles are changing
item.description:
Article Description: From Academic Advisors to Student Success Advisors
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Advisors titles are changing from Academic Advisor to Student Success Advisors. 

"Over time, advisors roles have expanded to include more than planning student's schedules and registering them for classes," said Meredith Purcell, director of advising. "We also connect students to campus resources like tutoring, counseling and social work services, plan events and contribute to student success initiatives."

Advisors plan and oversee events that help students during their educational journey, including Cav Days, New Student Orientation, career exploration workshops and the Spring/Fall transfer fairs. Advisors also participate in Proactive Advising (CANVAS observer) and early alert, provide course planning, transfer planning, and guidance with health careers applications and appeal processes. 

"The title Student Success Advisors captures all these responsibilities that contribute to KCC student's success and retention," said Meredith. "The change will help students navigate their educational process."

Advisors titles will formally change in April. Questions about the change can be directed to Meredith at ext. 8514.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 3/23/2021
Expires: 4/2/2021
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Higher Ed now eligible for the vaccine
item.description:
Article Description: Group 1C announced
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Higher education employees are now eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. 

Gov. Pritzker announced that higher education employees and other groups are eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine effective Monday, March 22. KCC employees who want to receive the vaccine are encouraged to seek it from community distribution sites. The CDC website www.vaccinefinder.org can help you find a site nearby to schedule an appointment.

"All employees are encouraged to make plans to get the vaccine," said Beth Nunley, chair of KCC's reopening task force. "We will not be able to offer the vaccine at the college, so it's important to make plans using other community resources." 
  
Beginning Monday, April 12, vaccines will be widely available to Illinois residents who are ages 16 years and older. Once 50% of residents 16 and older have received their first dose of the vaccine and no increase in COVID-19 metrics is recorded, the state could move into Phase 5. 

Phase 5 of the Restore Illinois plan, which removes capacity limits on the settings such as dining, office and retail. You might be wondering about mask requirements. Restore Illinois says "While regulations are rolled back gradually, Illinoisans should continue following the public health guidelines that have kept us safe during the pandemic, like wearing a mask in public and social distancing."  

Author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Office Supply Exchange
item.description:
Article Description: An Office Supply Exchange room has been set up in Room L251.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Office Supply Exchange

An Office Supply Exchange room has been set up in Room L251.

With many new employees and employees fully returning to campus, office supply needs may be changing.

This in-house exchange has items that one department no longer needs and is offering to others for KCC work use. All departments and employees are invited to bring items for drop off, and to come get supplies they might be able to use for KCC work. Items can be gently worn, but still need to be usable.

Many new items have been recently added, including artwork by the late Willie Dixon. Already available: desk trays, binders or file folders (letter and legal size available) and some other assorted items. Please check it out before you purchase new items.

Room L251 is on the second floor, near the center of the L Building. It is to the east of the Media Department and West of Admin Hall.

The room will be open every day. If the room is closed, feel free to contact security or someone from Physical Plant Department to open the door.

After each semester, any items still remaining and not deemed for future use, will be moved to storage for auction.

And, one last time, please remember that you should only take items that are going to be used for KCC work.

Article Date: 3/15/2021

item.title: Pro tips to help you transition back to campus
item.description:
Article Description: Hey, team! We're back!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Now that we're all working together in person five days a week, take a look at a few reminders to help with the transition.

When you arrive on campus:

  • Complete the daily self-assessment at certify.kcc.edu.  
  • Enter through one of the designated entrances on the Riverfront Campus:
    • Welcome Center (south entrance)
    • Entrance near circle drive (west side)
  • Use main building entrances at:
    • Manufacturing Industrial Technology Center, Kankakee
    • North Extension Center, Bradley
    • South Extension Center, Watseka

While you're inside:

  • Wear a face covering
  • Maintain social distancing
  • Gather with 50 people or less in any area (masks and social distancing are still a must).
  • Clean high-touch surfaces in classrooms and meeting rooms before you leave the rooms.

Pro tips:

  • Change email signatures and voicemails that mention remote work.
  • Remember that business casual attire is expected.

Anyone with questions can ask a member of the reopening task force: David Cagle, Paul Carlson, Jill Christy, April Frye, Ryan Hale, Rob Kenney, Beth Nunley, Mike O'Connor, Mary Posing, Eric Springer, Kate Wachtor and Michelle Weishaar.

item.title: Board Notes - March 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Introduction of Guests. 

Theodis Pace, president of the NAACP, shared information about the Kankakee County Crisis Response Team. The team works to prevent or respond to incidents of civil unrest locally. It is a collaboration among law enforcement, community leaders, business owners, school administrators/counselors/coaches, churches and others.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Grant awards
  • Tuition and fees for FY22 – remaining at $165 per credit hour
  • Servers from Dell Direct
  • Bid award for a police vehicle
  • Architectural services for Phase 2 of Technology building renovations
  • Resolution honoring retiree April Frye
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

 President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • College employees are undergoing National Incident Management training as part of the campus emergency operations training. 
  • We have no indication that KCC will be provided with vaccines in the near future. While we remain hopeful, employees should pursue every other option to be vaccinated.
  • Student Life and SAC are celebrating Women's History Month and recognizing five female leaders from KCC – Trustee Cathy Boicken, Vice Presidents Kiana Battle and Beth Nunley, The Honorable J. Imani Drew, and Student Trustee Ariana Ramirez. 
  • TRiO Student Support services submitted a proposal to renew the Talent Search grant. Dr. Jose da Silva and the Talent Search team worked hard on the renewal. 
  • Plans for a winter term are under consideration, which means a four-week term would be offered between mid-December and mid-January. This would not affect holiday break, but it could attract more students.
  • Kudos to Paul Carlson and his team on the virtual Career Pathways Day. The virtual event is pre-recorded and available to view all month. 
  • The college's website transformation is complete. Take a look at the new concept. 
  • The college auctioned surplus items through GovDeals.com. 
  • A property in downtown Kankakee is under development as a business incubator. Conversations are underway about how the college can be involved. 
  • A professional development opportunity is happening this week for staff and administrators. It builds on the Clifton Strengths Finder program put in place in 2019.  

 Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • ICCTA will meet Friday and Saturday in Schaumburg. The focus is cyber security and legislation for MAP grant funding. 
  • Lobby Day is not happening in person this year.   

 Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • Using the Career Coach software helped me figure out what major to pursue. It's been one of the best experiences I've had at KCC.
  • Women's History Month is under way and SAC is recognizing five local women leaders. 
  • Clubs are active through virtual events, including a trivia night. 
  • Spill the Tea with the Student Trustee was a success, and so was a Women Empowering Women forum. 
  • The Student Leader Exchange Series focused on inequality around gender and race.
  • Student Leadership trip with team building activities is planned.

item.title: Employee Satisfaction Survey deadline ends Friday
item.description:
Article Description: final deadline is 5 pm March 12
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Your feedback is valued and requested!  

Article Content:

Update:  So far, 134 employees have already completed the survey and another 49 are in the process of completing the survey.  

As you know, KCC is once again encouraging all full-time employees, current adjunct instructors, and part-time employees averaging 16 hours or more of work per week to complete an employee satisfaction survey.  The deadine has been extended to allow those 47 employees who have started the survey additional time to complete it.  And  If you haven't started it as of yet, you also have additonal time to start and finish it.  

Here is the link:  https://ruffalonl.sjc1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_0lAec83V98Umvci

It should take about 20 minutes to complete. Ruffalo Noel Levitz is administering the survey and--as a third-party--helps assure that answers will be confidential. Information pertaining to individual identities will not be shared. The survey will be available until 5 pm, March 12. 

This is the eighth year we have used Noel Levitz to administer the survey. It allows for comparison between years to see how we are doing, as well as a comparison to approximately 30 other community colleges across the nation. We hope to have the survey results compiled and distributed sometime in April.

Here are questions and answers related to the survey, which have been asked before:

   Q: Can the survey be saved and restarted if I am interrupted?

    A: Yes, as long as you use the same computer when returning to the survey.    

    Q: Can we offer some type of incentives to employees for completing the survey in order to increase participation?

    A: KCC is offering an incentive for the completion of THIS survey only (not to be precedent setting for other surveys). Upon completion of the survey, you will be given the opportunity to print off a coupon for a medium size coffee or a bottled soda pop (Approx. $2.00 value) redeemable at Arena Food Services.  Additionally, if you put your name on the bottom of the coupon, you will be entered into a second incentive where we will draw four names with each person winning a $25 Wal-Mart gift certificate. 

As always, thank you in advance for your cooperation and honest/constructive feedback.

item.title: Coming soon: Website makeover
item.description:
Article Description: The final stages of the website software migration will go live at kcc.edu the week of March 8.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The final stages of the website software migration will go live at kcc.edu the week of March 8.

The changes include a new homepage and updated Student Affairs site. The rest of the site is now also part of a new web management system. The implementation has been a collaboration between the Marketing Department and Information Technology Services since 2018.

"The software we were using is no longer supported, and we knew we had to make a move." said Kari Nugent, director of marketing and public relations. 

After researching the options, the team chose powerful, low-cost, open-source products for web management, instead of typical content management software.

"What we did was truly innovative," Kari said. "Not many other colleges or universities are doing this yet, but they want to. These products are flexible and scalable, so they will grow as we do. We were also able to update our content, navigation and design. It's not often that a college significantly alters all of these at once."

The team used research to refine navigation and tested the results with KCC students.

Here are some highlights of the site:

  • The focus is on the visitor's experience
  • It takes fewer clicks to find important information about the programs KCC offers, the cost to attend, and how to apply for financial aid.
  • Inquiry information funnels directly to Student Affairs, where recruiters and advisors follow up.
  • Bigger and bolder pictures/banners
  • For the most part, the site is now organized by topic instead of audience.
  • The look and feel is more modern.

Several sub-sites within kcc.edu launched between May 2018 and now. Those sites include Athletics, news and events, KCC Foundation, Adult and Community Education, Library, Workforce Investment and Opportunity Act and Corporate and Continuing Education.

Anyone with questions about the process is invited to phone or email me at ext. 8256 or knugent@kcc.edu.
