item.title: CTE Faculty Recognition
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

February is Career and Technical Education month.  ICCB is highlighting Career and Technical Education Faculty in Illinois. Kankakee Community College's has 5 CTE faculty members who were recognized.  

Committed to Continual Growth- Patrick Klette, Kankakee Community College

Patrick Klette, a professor of Electrical Engineering Technology, has continued a long tradition of Electrical training for not only traditional students studying for certificates and degrees but also our area stakeholders and businesses. Professor Klette has also been influential in growing aspects of the Electrical Engineering Technology curriculum, ensuring the most up-to-date equipment and technologies are available for student use. His expansion of hydraulics and pneumatics, as well as PLC programming and functionality has become a valued element of continuing training for area businesses sending their employees to KCC. Pat is also a well-known textbook author in the focused discipline of Hydraulics and Pneumatics. His influence on the new Advanced Technology Education Center, ATEC includes classrooms and labs for renewable energies programming, including a roof-top Solar Photo Voltaic array used for installation and maintenance for students.

Professor John Bordeau, Computer Graphic Technologies 

"Professor Bordeau has been influential in the growth of KCC's Innovation Lab, which while utilized with his computer design programming has also grown into a space with over ten 3D printers, laser engravers, plotters and advanced printers. Professor Bordeau's long held desire to create an Innovation Space that is highlighted within the Technology area at KCC is under planning phases to hold a very prominent location and view ability. One of the major extra's that Professor Bordeau brings are his YouTube videos that have served a worldwide audience with nearly a million views in total, for students learning more about AutoCAD and other design software."

Professor Mark Stevenson, Welding Technology

"Professor Stevenson has been responsible for growing and sustaining a sought after Welding program for area business and employers. His ability to envision the Manufacturing and Industrial Training Center, MITC, as the home for Welding, Machine Tool, Fabrication and Millwright programming. As a local business owner within the same arena Professor Stevenson has firsthand knowledge of the needs and hurdles that local manufacturers face. It is widely known that walking through any local manufacturing plant with Mark, you will hear his name shouted by employees as they see him walking through the plants. His support of continuing education opportunities is also sought and looked forward to."

Professor Charlie Cooke, Heating and Air Conditioning

"Professor Cooke continues to expand the HVAC curriculum, most recently moving his entire lab space to the Manufacturing and Industrial Training Center. This expansive shift to a new space, and ability to customize based on his long standing experience as instructor and at the same time a technician for an HVAC contractor over the summer months. Given this insight to on-the-job understanding and able to apply this knowledge into first rate classroom delivery of the on-the-job elements for students."

Katelynn Ohrt, Agri-Hort Technologies

"Katelynn remains a strong contributor to the KCC District 520 agriculture and horticulture culture through her delivery of a wide array of Agri-Hort courses, her support of FFA and 4-H programs and clubs in the area, her continued focus on agriculture growing technologies aa well as maintenance of greenhouse, aquaculture and hydroponics lab spaces. Stepping into the virtual delivery of course content through Facebook Live, Youtube and Instagram, she has become a sought after leader in the community for course expansion. A little known fact of Katelynn's value and support of KCC is her leadership of Perkins Grants at KCC. Katelynn has grown a team approach into a valued and sought after partnership at KCC and with local leaders."

item.title: Technology corridor renovation gets underway.
item.description:
Article Description: West end will be closed Feb. 15
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Renovations at the west end of the Technology building will begin Monday, Feb. 15. The hallway will be closed and the entrance at the west end will not be accessible. Those entering from the west parking lot should enter the facilities at Health Careers. 

The work is Phase 1 of the two-phase project. In total, the work will expand and modernize instruction areas, upgrade equipment, and renovate student training and workspaces.

Phase 1 includes renovating lab space that will enhance the Electrical Engineering Technology program. The total project will benefit all of KCC’s Technology Division programs.

Funding for the project comes from Protection, Health and Safety funds, state grants, and a donation from Nucor in Kankakee. 

“Training qualified workers is our mission, and these programs are a big part of it,” said KCC’s president, Michael Boyd. “Strengthening our programs now helps our residents find family-sustaining jobs in the future. KCC looks forward to training the next generation of technology workers with the help of new teaching and learning spaces. We certainly appreciate the support from the state in making it possible.”

“The update to the Technology hallway at KCC will allow expansion and upgrading of current programming that has been needed for some time,” said Paul Carlson, KCC’s dean of Business, Technology and Human Services programs. “This most current renovation is a credit to the program faculty, as well as senior leadership at KCC supporting the changing needs of the students within these programs.”

See the news article for more details https://news.kcc.edu/

First floor: The Hammes Bookstore is open and accessible. 
Second floor: The Veteran's Center, Upward Bound and Talent Search offices can best be accessed from the east-end stairs near the Bookstore. The best alternate route to Student Affairs, Financial Aid and Business Affairs offices is the WDC elevator or stairwell.
Third floor: Adult Education is accessible from the L Building hallway.

Repairs are underway and the areas affected will be back in service as quickly as possible.

item.title: Interested in becoming an ACT/SAT worker?
item.description:
Article Description: We are looking for additional people interested in working upcoming ACT or SAT exams
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Interested in becoming an ACT/SAT worker?

We are looking for additional people interested in working upcoming ACT or SAT exams. All tests happen on occasional Saturday mornings from 7AM-1 or 2PM throughout the year. Interested staff or faculty will be placed on an list of possible workers and contacted about availability around 3-4 weeks before the test.  

To qualify, you must:

  • Be a high school graduate or have your GED
  • Not have a family member taking the ACT or SAT you're assigned to
  • Be comfortable with a computer or smartphone

Workers will be compensated directly by the test provider. Social distancing, frequent cleaning, and mask policies will be in place for all participants.

For more information or to be placed on the staff list, please contact Michelle Argento at margento@kcc.edu or Dwayne Musick at dmusick@kcc.edu

item.title: It's electric (boogie woogie)
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

 ​ 

KCC has a new electric car charger.

Made by ChargePoint, the charger has two plugs (called a two-point charger), so two cars can "juice up" at once.

Other information:

  • It is rated as a level two, as a reference to the charging speed. It adds 10-20 miles of range for every hour it is plugged in..
  • There is no fee to use the charger.
  • It is located in Parking Lot P6, south and west of the Advanced Technology Education Center.

Though the station was installed in May, it was not programmed--and usable--until recently.

The ChargePoint charger was acquired by KCC through a grant from the Illinois Green Economy Network.

item.title: Coach Donnie Denson reaches 500 career wins
item.description:
Article Description: Congratulations! It's a well-deserved honor.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Congratulations to KCC's Women's Basketball Coach Donnie Denson on reaching 500 career wins! Below is an article and photo reprinted from the Daily Journal. 


Women's College Basketball: Denson gets career win No. 500 with KCC's win over Bethel
Cody Smith | csmith@daily-journal.com
Jan. 27, 2021

KANKAKEE — Kankakee Community College women’s basketball coach Donnie Denson came into the season knowing the Cavaliers’ first win would be a monumental one, as he entered the season with 499 career wins.

It didn’t take long for Denson to reach his milestone.

Thanks to a gigantic run to close out the fourth quarter, KCC defeated Bethel University JV 89-68 in the Cavaliers’ home opener to give Denson his 500th college victory and improve the team to 1-1 on the year.

“It’s been a journey,” Denson said. “I think about all the players who went through our program and what they went on to do … it kind of makes you think of all the relationships I’ve built with players over the years.”

In Denson’s 21 years of coaching at KCC, he has recorded an official college coaching record of 500-150, a .770 win percentage, with 16 of those seasons netting at least 20 wins.

“I haven’t really slowed down enough to really think about No. 500,” Denson said. “I guess it’s just going to take some time for it all to soak in.”

The reason Denson was able to achieve this new career milestone was in part because of the brilliant offensive performance by sophomore guard Brandi Hudson.

Hudson poured in 23 of her team-high 25 points in the first half, which helped KCC take a comfortable 14-point lead into halftime. From there, Hudson forced Bethel to make stopping her a focal point, which in turn allowed Hudson to become more of a playmaker for her teammates in the second half.

“To be honest the defense was kind of open, especially in the first half,” Hudson said. “I’m so used to reading the defense so I can break through it easily. And that’s what teams fail to realize.”

Between Hudson’s offensive onslaught and KCC’s ability to force 20+ turnovers off its full-court press during the contest, KCC managed to avoid a Bethel comeback, which was sparked by an 18-5 Bethel run to close out the third quarter.

KCC then opened things up again in the fourth quarter with tenacity. The Cavaliers went back to their full-court press, which forced a pair of Bethel turnovers to open the frame. The Cavaliers were able to get easy scores on the offensive end, which helped them build a 66-56 lead with just eight minutes left in the game.

“Our energy just went back from being negative and down to, boom, creating three to four positive plays in a row, and that just gave us energy the rest of the way,” Denson said.

The defensive energy helped KCC close out the fourth quarter on a gigantic 23-12 run to close things out.

“Tonight’s game we stayed in a press because we feel it provides us the best opportunity to take away possessions and gain,” Denson said. “It also keeps us engaged and keeps our energy up.”

Aside from Hudson’s big contribution, KCC got additional support from starters Madison Allen (19 points), Jaida Sherrod (14 points) and T’Laizha Morris (9 points).

“We saw great positives tonight compared to last Friday’s game, but we still had little bit of segments where we have corrections to make,” Denson said.

Author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Former student coping with family crisis
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Former KCC student Adam Beedle is handling a family crisis no one would want to face.

Beedle attended KCC from 2000 to 2005, and was also a Physical Plant Department student worker. He earned an AGS in 2005.

Beedle and his wife, Amanda, have two daughters, and both girls were recently diagnosed with Batten's disease (CLN2). "Batten's disease is a terminal disease of the nervous system, a brain degenerative disease in which there is no cure," according to the gofundme page set up on the family's behalf. 

More information about the family and their situation is in a Daily Journal article published Jan. 12.

Anyone interested in helping the family financially is invited to their gofundme page "Please Help the Beedle Family."

item.title: Board Notes - Jan. 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Jan. 11, 2021

Introduction of Guests.

The Board heard an audit summary from Dale Gerretse, partner at the accounting firm Groskreutz Abraham Eshleman & Gerretse.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition/course reimbursements
  • FY20 financial audit
  • Farm lease agreement
  • Revisions of the board policy manual

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Today is the first day of the spring semester, and it is good to see students on campus.
  • Faculty in-service was delivered virtually last week. It's a refreshing and re-energizing time in higher education.
  • Senator Patrick Joyce was on campus last week to talk through education items in advance of the legislative session. Through a co-written note with Sen. Joyce, KCC was able to thank Gov. Pritzker for the state's support of the Technology Hallway renovations.
  • Plans for campus emergency operations training are underway.  
  • KCC is partnering with the Kankakee County State's Attorney's office to offer the "I Can Go To College" program aimed at troubled youth before they enter the corrections system. Eight students are enrolled this semester as a result of the partnership.
  • Winter sports schedules are being planned for men's and women's basketball and volleyball. No spectators will be allowed at the games because of Covid restrictions. Games will be live-streamed when they can, and basketball games will be broadcasted on WGFA 94.1 FM.
  • Commencement planning is the early stages and we are considering ways to offer a ceremony safely.
  • KCC's Cash Bash will happen virtually on Feb. 20. Tickets are available from athletics.

 Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • ICCTA will meet online Jan. 30.

Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • Classes resumed today and SAC members are assisting students at Welcome Week tables. They are sharing information about campus resources, tutoring, library services, and clubs and activities.
  • SAC continues to review its constitution.

item.title: PHASED IN RETURN TO KCC CAMPUS 2021
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

Staff report to campus at least 3 days a week ​beginning Jan 19

Article Content:

The re-opening task force recognizes that the current positivity rate for COVID-19 in our district is alarming.  The task force also recognizes the strong desire from students and community members for KCC employees to fully return to campus to work and provide services to our students and district residents in 2021.  In an effort to plan accordingly and allow staff sufficient time to make the transition back to campus, it is the recommendation of the re-opening task force that KCC implement a phased in approach to fully return to campus in 2021.   

The phased in plan is as follows:

  • Beginning Tuesday, January 19, 2021, (after the Martin Luther King Holiday on Jan 18) all staff will be expected to report to their respective campus locations three days per week (days will be determined by their immediate supervisor and essential employees will continue reporting all five days).
  • Beginning Monday, February 15, 2021, all staff will be expected to report to their respective campus locations four days per week (days will be determined by their immediate supervisor and essential employees will continue reporting all five days).
  • Beginning Monday, March 15, 2021, all staff will be expected to report to their respective campus locations all five business days of the week.

Notes:

  • Campus extension centers will operate under modified schedules based on human resources and student needs. 
  • Departmental leaders will work through their office areas to ensure all employee workstations are properly social distanced by at least six feet. 
  • All campus entrances will remain the same and those entering the building will continue completing daily self-assessments. 
  • Any medical requests for an accommodation must be submitted to David Cagle in Human Resources at least one week prior to the dates identified above. 
  • This phased in plan assumes the Governor's guidelines allow for the full return of employees to respective campus locations dependent on the positivity rate across region 7.  The college may modify the plans to return to campus at any time based on COVID-19 developments at that point in time.

Anyone with questions can contact David Cagle at 815-802-8128.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 1/12/2021

item.title: Cleaning products available in shared spaces
item.description:
Article Description: Clean up to maintain a healthy environment on campus.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The Reopening Task Force needs your help to maintain a clean and healthy environment. 

Faculty and staff are asked to please wipe down high-touch surfaces in shared classrooms and meeting rooms at the conclusion of the class or meeting.

You can view a short video about it featuring Paul Carlson and Rob Kenney.

Personal protection equipment and cleaning products are available in the rooms and a cleaning checklist is provided. The dispensers, spray bottles and wipe buckets are refillable, so please do not discard the containers. 

Vendors are prioritizing products for healthcare and childcare facilities. So, while products are available to the college, we ask that you use them responsibly so that we can maintain a supply. 

Physical Plant and ITS personnel adopted more rigorous cleaning schedules during the summer and fall 2020 semesters. Now that we are anticipating more students and employees on campus for spring 2021, we need and appreciate your assistance to keep our rooms clean. PPD and ITS will continue to complete normal cleaning activities, as well as more frequent cleaning of high traffic areas.

Thank you so much for your dedication to maintaining a clean and safe environment for all students and staff.

If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to any of one of the task force members listed below.

The KCC Re-opening Task Force

Beth Nunley, April Frye, David Cagle, Chief Eric Springer, Jill Christy, Kate Wachtor, Mary Posing, Mike O'Connor, Michelle Weishaar, Paul Carlson, Rob Kenney, and Ryan Hale

item.title: TODAY is the DEADLINE to APPLY for VOLUNTARY RETIREMENT PROGRAM
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

today (1/5) is the last day to submit an application 

Article Content:

With ongoing budget challenges, and uncertainty over state and federal funding levels, the College has been attempting to reduce costs in order to maintain as much continuity as possible in our services and programs.  We are continuing to explore ways to achieve cost reductions through voluntary measures in order to avoid, or at least to minimize, the need for any involuntary reductions. As part of these efforts, a One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program is being offered for eligible employees. The eligibility requirements, participation conditions, and separation incentive are outlined below. This one-time offering will expire today, January 5, 2021. 

Eligibility Requirements

In order to be eligible to participate in the One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program, the following conditions must be met:

  1. The employee shall have a minimum of ten (10) years of continuous, full-time service at the College by the intended date of retirement; and
  2. The employee must have an effective separation date sometime between March 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021; and
  3. The employee must be eligible to retire under the rules and regulations of the State Universities Retirement System (SURS) without any additional costs to the College as a result of excess earnings increases (over 6%) in any academic year used by SURS to determine the employee's final rate of earnings. 

One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program Incentive 

An employee approved for the program shall receive:

1) a one-time retirement payment of $8,100 to the retiree on their final paycheck (the approximate equivalent of 18 months of premium) for personal health insurance through the College Insurance Program provided through SURS or through another insurance provider.   

2) The employee will also be paid any other amounts owed or required by law or College policy (e.g., unused vacation days).

3) In no event shall the incentive be calculated or applied so as to cause a participant's earnings to exceed SURS limits and/or cause the College to owe any additional contributions, payments or penalties to SURS.  The College reserves the right to make adjustments to the incentive in order to avoid the assessment of any additional contributions, payments or penalties by SURS. 

Participation Conditions

In order to participate in the One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program, the following steps must be taken:

  1. By no later than January 5, 2021, the employee must complete an application (see HR to receive it) indicating interest in the program and identifying the intended separation date (which must be between March 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 and participating faculty must complete their current semester/term as not to adversely affect our students). 
  2. Once the application is received, the College will prepare a separation agreement that will include your Retirement Incentive, your separation date, and other legal conditions. The employee must execute this separation agreement and release.
  3. We will consider the needs of the College in order to minimize the disruption on College operations and to maximize the amount of savings that are generated by this One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program.  The final separation date will be set forth in the separation agreement and depending on the response to the One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program, the College reserves the right to propose a separation date beyond the December 31, 2021 deadline.
  4. The employee's participation in the One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program and the separation agreement must be approved by the Board of Trustees.  As it is impossible to gauge the level of response to this One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program before formally receiving applications, the College reserves the right to limit the number of approved participants.  The final decision as to whether a participant is approved by the Board of Trustees rests with the sole discretion of the Board. 

Please note that the ultimate decision whether to retire from the College is significant and should be carefully considered before applying for participation in this One-Time Voluntary Retirement Program.

Anyone with questions, please contact David at ext. 8128.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 1/5/2021
Expires: 1/5/2021
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Faculty: insights needed
item.description:
Article Description: Statewide marketing initiative aims to improve community college perceptions
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC has joined other Illinois community colleges to work on initiatives to transform public perception of the state's community colleges.

Lipman Hearne, a Chicago-based marketing communications firm with a special expertise in higher education, is assisting with this branding work. They would like to meet Illinois community college students who will share stories of their own community college experiences.

As part of their discovery process, a team from Lipman Hearne will be meeting with Illinois community college faculty who are willing to share their experiences working in community colleges. 

I hope you can volunteer to participate in a one hour virtual group discussion with the Lipman Hearne team: 10-11 am on Friday, Jan. 22.

If you are interested in participating, please sign up here: https://forms.gle/dZTXzURjXP6EWefK6.  

Their questions will focus on your own experiences as community college faculty—the opportunities and challenges you face, and your work with a diverse student body with varying needs and goals. No advance preparation is necessary, and I encourage you to be as candid as possible.

Please note that as we are trying to speak with faculty from across the state, only the first few respondents from our region will be able to participate.

Thank you in advance for making time for this discussion. We appreciate your help!

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 1/4/2021
Expires: 1/8/2021

item.title: Christmas Trivia - contest results
item.description:
Article Description: Thanks to those who participated in the Christmas Trivia Contest
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Thanks to the Christmas Trivia Contest participants. 13 staff member used their "Elf Encyclopedias" or maybe had help from family or Christmas websites to answer the 30 trivia questions.

Congratulations! to the top three winners:

Brandi Castillo with 29.5 correct

Erica Billington with 29 correct

Greg Mulinax with 29 correct

Here are the questions and answers to the

2020 Christmas Trivia based on the websites listed below.

1.     How many ghosts show up in A Christmas Carol?

 Four

2.    What are the two other most popular names for Santa Claus? (two part question)

Kris Kringle and Saint Nick

3.    In Home Alone, where are the McCallisters going on vacation when they leave Kevin behind?

Paris

4.    Which country did eggnog come from?

England

5.    In the classic Christmas movie, How The Grinch Stole Christmas, the Grinch was described with three words. What are they?

Stink, stank, stunk

6.    What did Frosty The Snowman do when a magic hat was place on his head? He began to dance around.

7.    In the movie It's A Wonderful Life, what happened every time a bell rang? An angel got his wings.

8.    Which one of Santa's reindeer has the same name as another holiday mascot?

Cupid

9.    In Charles Dickens' A Christmas Carol, what was the first name of Scrooge? Ebenezer

10. Which country state the tradition of putting up a Christmas tree?

Germany

11.  What is Ralphie's little brother's name in the movie A Christmas Story? Randy

12. In the song "Winter Wonderland," what do we call the snowman?

Parson Brown

13. In the movie Elf, what was the first rule of The Code of Elves?

Treat every day like Christmas

14. According to the song, what did my true love give to me on the eighth day of Christmas?

Eight maids a milking

15. What was the highest-grossing Christmas movie of all time?

Home Alone

16. What was the real name of the character Tim Allen plays in The Santa Clause?

Scott Calvin

17. Which fairy tale was the first gingerbread houses inspired by?

Hansel and Gretel

18. How many gifts in total were given in "The Twelve Days of Christmas" song? 364

19. In the movie A Christmas Story, what was the name of the neighbors whose dog at the Christmas turkey?

The Bumpuses

20.What is the best-selling Christmas song ever?

"White Christmas" by Bing Crosby

21. What is the name of the last ghost that visits Scrooge in A Christmas Carol? The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come

22.Who wrote "Christmas doesn't come from a store, maybe Christmas perhaps means a little bit more?"

Dr. Suess

23.What is the name of George Bailey's guardian angel in It's A Wonderful Life? Clarence Odbody

24.What popular Christmas song was actually written for Thanksgiving?

 "Jingle Bells"

25.In the movie, Elf, how does Buddy get to the North Pole?

He hides in Santa's sack.

26.In 1981, Bob and Doug McKenzie released their own version of a classic Christmas song. Which song is that?

"The Twelve Days of Christmas"

27.What traditional Christmas decoration is actually a parasitic plant? Mistletoe

28.Name the animatronic cassette-playing bear toy that every kid wanted for Christmas in themed 80's.

Teddy Ruxpin

29.What well-known Christmas carol became the first song ever broadcast from space in 1965?

"Jingle Bells"

30.What Christmas carol does the Peanuts gang sing at the end of "A Charlie Brown Christmas?"

"Hark! The Herald Angels Sing"

 

The questions were from the following websites

https://parade.com/943457/parade/christmas-trivia/

and

https://www.whiteelephantrules.com/christmas-trivia-questions/


Happy Holiday! to all!

 


Author: Liz Becvar
Article Date: 12/21/2020
Expires: 1/8/2021

item.title: Prep for Spring 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Reminders and helpful information
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

 

We are just a few weeks away from the Spring 2021 semester at KCC. Here are some updates and helpful pieces of information:

  • You made it through Fall 2020! Let's celebrate that for a moment. You should be proud of your persistence!
  • Looking ahead, we sincerely hope that COVID-19 does not derail your educational goals. KCC is dedicated to helping you stay on track. Spring classes begin Jan. 11. Class options are in-person, online (live online, and online "on your time"), plus classes that are a little bit of both--called hybrid. 
  • If you want to talk to your advisor about registering, it isn't too late. We've opened up more advisement appointments. Phone 815-802-8500 or email advising@kcc.edu. We can talk about the best options for you. See below for holiday hours.
  • Avoid lines and order textbooks online using the KCC Hammes Bookstore webstore. Either preorder books for pickup or have them sent directly to your home. Payment can be from your financial aid or use a credit card. 
  • KCC's offices will be closed for winter break from noon Dec. 22 -Jan. 3. The website and student portal wont' be taking a break. College offices re-open at 8 a.m. Jan. 4. 
  • On Jan. 4, KCC's service areas, including advising, Workforce Services, Counseling and Referral Services, Continuing Education & Career Services, and Career Planning will all be open and ready to help you--whether or not your education/job situation has changed due to COVID-19. Most services are free.
  • If you've already registered for Spring: That's great! We're looking forward to seeing you in-person or through a virtual-yet-still-interactive format.

Thanks for choosing KCC! If you don't see the information you need above, please let us know how we can help you be as successful as possible. Enjoy the winter break!

815-802-8500 | advising@kcc.edu  | kcc.edu

item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Dec. 15, 2020

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition/course reimbursements
  • Adoption of the tax levy
  • Academic calendar for 2021/22
  • Resolution honoring retiree Bruce Myers
  • Request to solicit bids to renovate the Technology Division hallway (phase 1)
  • WIOA on-the-job training contract
  • Bid awards for an autoclave and building renovations for an Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Center
  • First reading of new personnel policies and revisions

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Thanks to Kari Nugent, the Marketing and IT teams, and all who helped organize and host the virtual KCC Recognition Event. It was well attended with more than 70 people attending online.
  • Thanks to Midland States Bank for the office furniture donation. Many staff members around the college will benefit from the generosity.
  • KCC students received more than $244,000 in KCC Foundation scholarships this year. An increase of about $7,000 from last year.
  • The KCC Foundation raised $47,000 during its first virtual Give Day event, and KCC's employee giving campaign raised $18,000 this year. Four employees gave at the President's Circle level.
  • Four KCC scholarship recipients received Christmas toys for their children courtesy of Lisa Dugan's toy drive.
  • KCC is preparing for the potential opportunity to administer Covid-19 vaccines to faculty and staff who want to receive it.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…
No report this month.

Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • The virtual pet contest was the most successful online event yet. The event garnered 976 engagements, 936 likes, and 81 new followers on the KCC Student Life Facebook page.
  • Student Life hosted virtual yoga to provide some finals week relaxation, and shared some finals prep tips for students. Event planning is underway for spring 2021 with a mix of online and in-person options for students.
  • The Student Advisory Council is updating its constitution.
  • The Psychology Club is selling rubber bracelets for $1 that say "Don't Give Up" to promote suicide prevention.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 12/16/2020
Expires: 1/1/2021

item.title: 2021 United Way/KCC campaign
item.description:
Article Description: Pledge by 12/18 for drawings!​
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Believe it or not, the year is quickly coming to a close and so is the KCC United Way campaign.  This year has been anything but "normal" and we understand that; however, the need in our community and the needs of the United Way agencies, haven't gone away.

If you haven't had a chance yet and find it in your heart to give, there is still time to show your support to the United Way.  There are many incentives that you will be eligible for with your donation, e.g. KCC face mask, wear jeans on Fridays, time off, and drawings for gift cards.  Pledges made and received in Human Resources by this Friday, December 18th, will be included in the drawing for gift cards.  Here is a link to the form 2021 United Way Pledge form.

Let's show our "Power of Community" by giving back to the community that we live and work in. 

Any questions, please contact David Cagle or Janet Fager in Human Resources.

Thank you for your support!

item.title: Help keep shared spaces clean in 2021
item.description:
Article Description: Wipe high-touch surfaces
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The Reopening Task Force needs your help to maintain a clean and healthy environment. Starting Jan. 4, faculty and staff are asked to please wipe down high-touch surfaces in shared classrooms and meeting rooms at the conclusion of the class or meeting.

 

Personal protection equipment and cleaning products will be available in the rooms and a cleaning checklist will be provided.  If faculty choose, students can also share in the sanitization of each space at the conclusion of each class session. You can view a short video about it featuring Paul Carlson and Rob Kenney. 

 

Physical Plant and ITS personnel adopted more rigorous cleaning schedules during the summer and fall 2020 semesters. Now that we are anticipating more students and employees on campus for spring 2021, we need and appreciate your assistance to keep our rooms clean. PPD and ITS will continue to complete normal cleaning activities, as well as more frequent cleaning of high traffic areas.

 

Thank you so much for your dedication to maintaining a clean and safe environment for all students and staff.

 

If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to any of one of the task force members listed below.

 

The KCC Re-opening Task Force

Beth Nunley, April Frye, David Cagle, Chief Eric Springer, Jill Christy, Kate Wachtor, Mary Posing, Mike O'Connor, Michelle Weishaar, Paul Carlson, Rob Kenney, and Ryan Hale

 


Author: Liz Becvar for Kari Nugent
Article Date: 12/11/2020
Expires: 1/15/2021
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: New process for web edits
item.description:
Article Description: Part of change to a new software for kcc.edu sites
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC is moving to a new software solution to manage and edit the KCC website.

The project is entering the stage where content still on the "legacy" software (Sharepoint) moves to the new software (CloudCannon). This move will occur from now through Jan. 31. During this time, please use the Web Services Request form to request changes to all KCC web pages. If you have questions about it, contact Roger Ehmpke at rehmpke@kcc.edu.

As mentioned above, the bulk of the migration will occur between now and Jan. 31, 2021. While the move is underway, the web team will make critical changes and will delay the more routine updates until after Feb. 1.

The implementation of a new web software management system has been a collaboration between the Marketing Department and Information Technology Services since 2018.

"The software that we are transitioning from is outdated and no longer supported," said Kari Nugent, director of marketing and public relations. "The need to make a change gave us the opportunity to develop a new web site that focuses on the user's experience. The team has been working hard to update content, navigation and design. It's not often that a college gets the chance to impact all three at once."

The new site has a more modern look and feel. Several  sub-sites within it have already launched, including Athletics, news and events, catalog, KCC Foundation, Adult and Community Education, Library, Workforce Investment and Opportunity Act and Corporate and Continuing Education. Next, Student Affairs sites and the homepage will go live in early 2021.

Anyone with questions about the process is invited to phone or email me at ext. 8256 or knugent@kcc.edu.

item.title: KCC is following Kankakee Health Dept. recommendations
item.description:
Article Description: 14-day quarantine still the best option
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Though additional options have been made available by the Centers for Disease Control, Kankakee Community College has elected to continue requiring a 14-day quarantine following exposure to COVID-19 before an individual can return to college facilities.

"Throughout the pandemic, KCC has worked closely with the Kankakee County Health Department to ensure that our practices and policies were in line with their recommendations," said Kate Wachtor from the college's reopening taskforce. "KCC is a congregate setting and there is still a risk of residual post-quarantine transmission when the quarantine is less than 14 days. KCHD has advised the college to continue to adhere to the 14 day quarantine time frame. By maintaining a 14-day quarantine requirement, we further reduce or eliminate that risk."

Anyone with questions can reach out to Kate at ext. 8524.

Author: Kari Nugent

item.title: KCC Staff Key Verification
item.description:
Article Description: Staff verification of campus keys to correct records.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The Physical Plant Department is reviewing our campus key program and want to ensure that the keys you have been issued are the keys you need, and have.  The reason for this verification is to update our records and your card file as staff have relocated offices, or departments over time.  Please contact Aliso Sublett to find out what keys we currently have on record for you.  We will work with you to correct your records.  Going forward keys will not be transferred directly between staff members.  All keys, including file cabinet keys and equipment keys, should be returned to the PPD office and issued directly to the new holder. The deadline for key verification is December 22, 2020.

Beginning January 4, 2021, we will be making some adjustments to our key issuing program.  At that time we will assume our records are up-to-date and will charge the $5.00 per key cutting fee for any keys lost or not returned when staff members leave KCC.  Damaged keys should be reported to the PPD office immediately and a replacement will be issued at no fee.

Feel free to return any unused keys at any time and we will remove them from your record.  Please email Alison Sublett at asublett@kcc.edu or call 8174 to set up a 10-15 minute block to review and update your key card file when you're on campus and available.  We are looking forward to hearing from everyone and will do our best to make this process as simple as possible.


Author: Alison Sublett
Article Date: 12/7/2020
Expires: 12/31/2020
item.author: Alison Sublett

item.title: Outstanding Faculty Member Nominations
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Do you work with a faculty member who:

  • Demonstrates excellence in teaching, commands a strong knowledge of their discipline, and stays current in their field?
  • Uses innovative teaching techniques to help students learn?
  • Motivates and encourages students to give their best?

Each year the Faculty Growth and Development Committee collects nominations, solicits feedback, and selects one full-time and one part-time faculty member to be recognized with the KCC Outstanding Faculty Award. Those honored receive an award medallion and framed certificate at commencement, as well as a spot on the KCC Wall of Honor.

Additionally, KCC recommends the full-time and part-time outstanding faculty members to the Illinois Community College Trustees Association for the ICCTA Outstanding Faculty Member Award. They will be invited to attend an awards banquet in June for the announcement of the statewide winners.

Nominate online or printed forms are available from Craig Keigher in L293
Deadline for nomination is January 30, 2021.


Author: Faculty Growth and Development Committee
Article Date: 1/18/2021
Expires: 1/29/2021
item.author: Craig Keigher

item.title: 27 Paychecks in 2020
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

last payday of the year: 12/31/20

Article Content:

I know the year 2020 was an unprecedented year and many can’t wait to get into the new year hoping for the better.  But there is some good news to share with you this holiday season: due to the banks being closed on Friday, January 1, 2021 (with their next business day being on Monday, Jan 4, 2021) we need to pay our employees on Thursday, Dec. 31.  That means there will be a total of 27 paychecks in 2020.  With one more paycheck, our employees will be earning more in 2020.  In 2021, there will be the normal 26 payrolls, meaning your W-2 wages will actually be less next year.  The 12/31/20 paycheck will NOT have any medical, dental, additional voluntary life insurance, FLEX, or United Way & Employee Giving taken out of it, but it WILL have SURS, Medicare, FICA, buy-up long term disability, and any other normal deductions associated with earnings. 

If anyone is concerned about tax implications this year, you can always change the number of withholdings by opening the federal and state hyperlinks below and submitting the completed forms to human resources.

 

W-4 Federal tax form

 

W-4 Illinois tax form

 

If anyone has any questions, please contact David Cagle at ext. 8128.

The  Bradley Christmas Parade is Friday (Dec. 4). We need KCC employees and their families to participate!

Since we'll be in one spot, physical distancing will not be too difficult. Masks will be worn -- and they'll be doubling as nose-warmers!

Since the KCC van is part of our display, it will provide a warm spot for a brief break if anyone gets tired of waving.

Theme: "Christmas Memories"

item.description:
Article Description: An Office Supply Exchange room has been set up in Room L251
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Office Supply Exchange

An Office Supply Exchange room has been set up in Room L251.

This in-house exchange has items that one department no longer needs and is offering to others for KCC work use. All departments and employees are invited to bring items for drop off, and to come get supplies they might be able to use for KCC work. Items can be gently worn, but still need to be usable.

Already available: desk trays, binders or file folders (letter and legal size available) and some other assorted items. Please check it out before you purchase new items.

Room L251 is on the second floor, near the center of the L Building. It is to the east of the Media Department and West of Admin Hall.

The room will be open when Liz Becvar is on Riverfront Campus (at this time: three days per week). If the room is closed, feel free to contact security or someone from Physical Plant Department to open the door.

After each semester, any items still remaining will be moved to storage for auction.

And, one last time, please remember that you should only take items that are going to be used for KCC work.

Anyone with questions about the office exchange can contact Liz Becvar at x8253 or ebecvar@kcc.edu.

item.title: Holiday Hoopla is Virtual​
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Holiday Hoopla is going Virtual

November is here and the holidays are just around the corner.

In the past Holiday Hoopla was the week before Thanksgiving to give you a chance to view some talented crafters wares and do some holiday shopping.

This year because of the Covid 19 coronavirus restrictions we cannot have a Holiday Hoopla on campus. I contacted the crafters to see if they would participate in a 'virtual Hoopla'. Please contact individual crafter if interested in making a purchase.

The following are the crafters willing to offer their items 'virtually'.

Felicia St. John offers Scentsy and Color Street products. Felicia has stock onhand and available.

Color Street Nail Strips – www.befancy4life.com or email Felicia with questions (befancy4life@gmail.com)

Scentsy – www.smellfancy4life.com or email Felicia with questions (smellfancy4life@gmail.com)





Dawn Wrobel will be offering novelty leather goods, leather and crystal jewelry, drums, and classes through KCC (leather earrings, leather bracelets, leather Christmas ornaments, aromatherapy items, drumming).  A wide variety of these can also be seen and purchased at the Community Art Council Art Market in Northfield Square Mall, including jewelry, leather wine bottle carriers and the always popular leather fly swatters!  Contact Dawn for more information.





Julie Larsen of Nisse Farms has honey, soaps and other items.

Here is my product list:

4 sizes of honey - 5 oz for $5, 10 oz for $9, 1# for $12 and 2# for $24 all in glass jars.

Honey Soaps $5 each or 4 bars for $18 - honey oatmeal (my only soap without essential oil), Lemongrass, Gaia (lavender and patchouli), Stress Reliever (spearmint and eucalyptus), Orange Blossom (orange & ylang ylang), Silk Road (frankincense, clove, myrrh, cinnamon), Rich Avocado (cedarwood & lemongrass with avocado oil), Lavender, Shaving Bar and Shampoo Bar.

Also available are Lotion bars for $10, lip balms and soothing sticks are $3 each, all made with beeswax and coconut oil among other skin moisturizing ingredients.

I am happy to deliver in the Kankakee area.

Contact Julie for more information. Or you can go to the Nisse Farms Facebook page.




Liz Becvar has Cookie Bar mix in two flavors. Chocolate Chip and Peanut Butter Chocolate Chip Bars. $10 a jar. Contact Liz for more information.

Note: I will donate 25% of sales to the KCC Food Pantry.


Note: Photos are from previous Holiday Hoopla events.








Mary Martinez Independent Consultant for Paparazzi

Website to shop: https://paparazziaccessories.com/419488/

item.title: Dr. Jerry Weber passes away
item.description:
Article Description: Served as KCC president 2001-09
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The fifth president of KCC, Dr. Girard Weber, died Wednesday, Nov. 11 at the age of 70. Weber was KCC's president from July 1, 2001 to April 4, 2009.

Upon announcing his departure from KCC, Weber said "It's been a pleasure working at KCC for the past seven years. KCC is poised for the future with a philosophy of continuous quality improvement and with state leadership in sustainability and renewable energy."

He left KCC to become president at College of Lake County in Grayslake, where he served from April 2009 to June 2017. He then accepted the presidency at Bellevue College in Washington, where he worked from July 2017 to March 2020.

At KCC, Weber lead the college through many successful initiatives and fulfilled several goals set by the board of trustees, including the adoption of Academic Quality Improvement Program (AQIP) as an accreditation and planning vehicle. In 2002, the college completed a community-wide strategic planning process, which resulted in a 20-year master facilities plan for the college. While Weber was president, the college opened a Satellite Center in Watseka (2003) and the Education and Employment Center in downtown Kankakee (2007). The college's Riverfront Campus in Kankakee opened a Workforce Development Center (2003), an Arts and Sciences facility (2007), and the Health Careers Center for Excellence (2008).

"Dr. Jerry Weber was a catalyst for change and a champion for sustainability," said KCC president Dr. Michael Boyd. "Jerry started the conversation on our campus about sustainability, and our focus on sustainable and renewable energy training is part of the legacy he left here at KCC. After his departure, the college carried on with that priority. He and I spent some time together a few weeks ago. Jerry visited campus and he toured the renovated Miner Memorial Library and the new Advanced Technology Education Center, which was built to deliver KCC's renewable energy curriculum. I could tell how proud he was of ATEC, even though it occurred after his time at KCC had ended. He made a lasting impact on our campus."

Weber earned a doctorate in higher education administration and a master's degree in educational measurement and statistics from the University of Iowa. He has had two degrees from Northern Illinois University, a master's degree in linguistics and English literature, and a bachelor's degree in English.

Author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Board Notes - Nov. 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees Meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Nov. 9, 2020

Introduction of Guests. The Board heard comments from the Faculty Association regarding proposed personnel policy revisions.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition/course reimbursements
  • Grant awards
  • Request to bid an autoclave and building renovations for an Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Center.
  • First reading of new personnel policies and revisions

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Nursing reaccreditation was affirmed. Appreciation goes to Sheri Cagle and the nursing faculty for their work on it.
  • Phi Theta Kappa hosted an induction ceremony for 35 students. Keynote speech was delivered by Dr. Jose da Silva.
  • The state may reduce higher education budgets. A state budget reduction coupled with enrollment decline will be challenging for KCC. About 26% of KCC's revenue comes from the state.
  • Cybersecurity risks are elevated at Illinois community colleges, and email is a primary vulnerability. It's been KCC's long standing practice to let retirees retain their KCC email addresses, but we are changing that tradition. We are transitioning our retiree accounts away from KCC servers and migrating them to Google-based mail ending with @retiree.kcc.edu.
  • KCC may become a Covid-19 vaccine or rapid test site. We are working closely with the Kankakee Health Department to plan for the scenarios, but several details have to be determined before we would go forward with options.  
  • A one-day power outage on West Campus is planned so that ComEd can complete upgrades to the power system.
  • With the surge of Covid-19 cases nationally, faculty will begin to wrap-up in-person learning and encourage students to complete the semester remotely.
  • We are planning a phased-in reopening plan starting Jan. 19, and we are conscious of doing this safely. We will monitor the Covid-19 situation as plans continue. Our priority is to keep everyone healthy.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • The next ICCTA meeting takes place in November via Zoom.

Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • SAC's Halloween event hosted on KCC's Student Life Facebook page generated engagement, likes and shares.
  • Spill the Tea with the Trustee happened virtually and garnered positive feedback.
  • First generation college student celebration is being held this week.
  • PTK held an socially-distanced induction ceremony, conducted an "I can go to college" project, and held their 3rd annual sleep out.
  • Clubs are meeting virtually.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 11/11/2020
Expires: 11/20/2020
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Students' media preferences survey
item.description:
Article Description: I've got my Grandma on speed dial. I call it Insta-Gram.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC's Marketing department always wants to know more about our students' attitudes, opinions, and media consumption habits. 

Partnering with Interact Communications, we are encouraging students to complete the Media Prefs survey, beginning on September 21. The survey will remain open through November 1.

Faculty, to gain awareness of the survey, it would be especially helpful if you could announce in class encouraging students to look for the survey link in coming emails and posts on KCC social media channels.

Staff, if you could encourage the momentum by sharing with students when appropriate and directing them to their email for more information, we would certainly appreciate it. 

The more students who participate, the stronger our data will be. As you know, these types of questions can provide critical information for marketing and communication at our college. They can additionally help target recruitment efforts for your programs.

Other important information to note:

  • It is voluntary
  • It is anonymous
  • It takes approximately 20-30 minutes to complete depending on their computer skills
  • It can be taken from a computer, tablet, or smartphone
  • It is intended to be taken by currently enrolled students only, please
  • All information entered will be kept confidential and non-identifiable
  • Participating students can choose to enter a drawing at the conclusion of the survey to win a prize put together by the college

This is a wonderful, timely opportunity to gather some very helpful information from our students that will assist with more effective marketing and planning for our college's future. Having accurate, fresh data is more important than ever in our current situation.

If you have any questions, contact me at knugent@kcc.edu.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 9/17/2020
Expires: 11/1/2020
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: There's still time to earn a day off work and more when you give
item.description:
Article Description: Make a difference through KCC's Employee Giving Campaign
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Don't wait! Make a gift during KCC's Employee Giving campaign. If we all participate, we can make a difference for students and members of our community. Plus, you could receive a day off work with pay, and other incentives depending on your commitment level.

You understand the challenges of our students in ways that others cannot. Your giving is powerful, but it is especially meaningful this year. It is a time when students and the community need support more than ever. 

In a video, KCC President Dr. Michael Boyd said, "We'll need to continue focusing on the needs of the students we serve. Students who may be facing challenges far more complex than each of us face." Take a moment to view Dr. Boyd's message. 

You can decide how your donation is used. Choose options to impact student-focused initiatives through the KCC Foundation and community-minded support through United Way - or both. Any amount is the right size, and we have incentives for every level of giving. 

If you are new to KCC, please consider how you would like to give back. If you have been at KCC for a while, we hope you can maintain or slightly increase your gift from last year. Or, maybe it is the right time to give for the first time. Every contribution makes a difference! 

Many of us made contributions during the KCC Foundation's Give Day. That effort was fantastic! The need remains as we begin this annual employee campaign to support students and the community. 

For many students, we are their support. They don't have reliable transportation, or reliable internet, or help parenting, or a warm meal every day. They are working, studying and being parents. Your support of these campaigns makes things a bit better for them. It will definitely make a difference!  

Please give today.

Thank you!

KCC professor presents at education & technology conference

Professor John Bordeau presented at the Illinois Education & Technology Conference on Friday Nov. 6, 2020. 

The conference was sponsored by TEAI--Technology Education Association of Illinois--which is a non-profit organization promoting technology and engineering STEM Education throughout Illinois.

 John presented "Free Instructional Videos for AutoCAD, Revit, Inventor, 3ds Max and Mudbox." He provided over 3,000 free instructional videos for the high school and college instructors across Illinois.

"These recourses come at a critical time for instructors during remote learning," John said.

item.title: KCC may become a COVID-19 testing site
item.description:
Article Description: The college wll not have community testing.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC is in the process of becoming a site authorized to administer COVID-19 tests.

It is not planned that KCC will be a community test site. That means staff, students and visitors will not be able to request testing at KCC.

Here are a few other things we know, and a few things still to come.

A final approval of KCC as a test site is not complete. There are still a few confirmations and approvals which are needed. If the college becomes a test site:

  • It will follow Kankakee County Health Department procedures for reporting those who test, the results, and follow-up.
  • The type of test given will provide results within 15 minutes.
  • Criteria for receiving the test will be established.

Another unknown is the exact number of tests which will be available at KCC. 

As more details become available, they will be shared through Update or other communication.

For more information, contact Beth Nunley.

item.title: Campus entry requirements are changing
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

This KCC's requirements for in-person gatherings and visits to college facilities are changing in accordance with Centers for Disease Control and Illinois guidelines.

These changes are a result of the reopening task force monitoring information on preventing the spread of COVID-19, and changes to mandates at the state and national levels.

To visit a KCC facility, the new guideline regarding recent travel states: " Within the last 14 days I have not traveled internationally, or within the United States in places with a surge in COVID-19 cases."

Certain industries in Illinois are now allowed to have more than 50 people as long as social distancing and mask requirements are still followed.  When attending a large gathering, check with the organizer or event venue about their COVID-19 guidelines. Bring supplies to help you and others stay healthy – for example, masks, hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol, and drinking water. Be careful to maintain social distancing and limit physical contact.

KCC is a unit of higher education that is subject to the governor's guidelines of limiting gatherings in any indoor area to 50 people or less.  We are cancelling the annual recognition dinner and holiday buffet to remain aligned with the governor's guidelines and ensure safety of all KCC employees.

Author: Beth Nunley
Article Date: 10/19/2020

item.title: Records Retention for social media
item.description:
Article Description: KCC has recently learned that as part of the Government Records law, we need to meet record requirements for our social media pages
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC has recently learned that as part of the Government Records law, we need to meet record requirements for our social media pages, including KCC-affiliated Facebook page(s) managed by various departments, grants and organizations.

If you are currently managing a Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or any other page on social media on behalf of a KCC-related program, you need to follow these guidelines.

The good news: It isn't hard to document posts, comments and private message inquiries. Additionally, the documentation is a great way to see what you post throughout the year and use for future scheduling and promotional purposes. Please see the government record retention document and sample social media history log to use as a guide for documentation of your page. Please capture and maintain this information at the end of each month.

If you have questions regarding the guidelines, please contact Michelle Weishaar at mweishaar@kcc.edu  Additionally, Katie Henry cohenry@kcc.edu, is an excellent resource on setting up the document and how to capture the information.

item.title: Board Notes - October 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Oct. 13, 2020

Introduction of Guests. The Board was introduced to…

New faculty members Kristine Salmons, assistant professor in the Electical Engineering Technology and Adam Tournier, assistant professor Physics.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition/course reimbursements
  • Supplemental tax provision
  • Protection, Health and Safety projects
  • WIOA office lease in Livingston County
  • Kankakee Valley Park District property lease
  • Application for ICCB's Resource Allocation Master Plan (RAMP) program

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • The Trump administration instructed federal agencies to suspend all diversity training programs until they are deemed compliant with the president's executive order on combating race and sex stereotyping. KCC is taking a close look at the order and does not plan to make any changes until there is more clarity on how it applies to colleges.
  • Spring enrollment and marketing push is underway.
  • A reminder that KCC's campus and extension centers are open to students and visitors. Students are able to access our facilities, conduct their online classes here, or just come to study.
  • Students can register for the Spring semester beginning this week. There are four ways that classes will be delivered this spring – online, face-to-face, hybrid (both online and in-person) and online that requires virtual interaction.
  • Congratulations to KCC employees Jose da Silva, Beth Nunley and Travis Miller for being recognized as Kankakee County's 40 Under 40. KCC Board of Trustees legal counsel Claire Chaplinski also was recognized. Ten of the 40 recipients are KCC employees or alumni.
  • Beth Nunley and the Business Office team continue to receive grants and alternative funding streams for the college.
  • Eric Springer is communicating KCC's emergency response plan with ICCB.
  • Our Nursing program is preparing for an accreditation visit from ACEN.
  • The Economic Alliance is hosting their November meeting on KCC's Riverfront campus. Attendance is restricted to 50 people.
  • Election Day is now a state holiday and KCC will be closed on Nov. 3.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • Shared board education opportunities about ICCTA's equity, diversity and inclusion initiatives happening at community colleges.
  • The next ICCTA meeting takes place in November.

 Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • Constitution Day had good participation.
  • SAC celebrated Hispanic Heritage Month with a Hispanic student panel discussion.
  • Tik Tok challenge participation has been low, so SAC is looking for new ways to engage students.
  • PTK induction happens Oct. 30.
  • Psychology Club is working on scarecrow decorations.
  • Red Flag campaign is underway to bring awareness to sexual assault.
  • ICCB conference for SAC members highlighted the state-wide enrollment decline, the impact of racism on campus and the importance of equity, diversity and inclusion.
  • ASGA conference focused on how to make SAC web pages more presentable and common SAC mistakes.
  • SAC members that participated in the Vice President for Academic Affairs interviews appreciated the opportunity.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 10/14/2020
Expires: 10/23/2020

item.title: 2 employees present to statewide audience
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Dr. Francesca Catalano and Pat Klette recently presented at the Forum for Excellence, held Sept. 23 and 24.

Their topic was "Rethinking the Purpose of Gen Ed Courses in CTE Programs." The online presentation was seen by more than 80 faculty and administrators from throughout the state.

Here's a the program description (edited for clarity within this context):

"KCC Career and Technical Education leadership asked the question, 'What are the purposes of Gen Eds in CTE programs?' This led us to revise the general education CTE programmatic requirements and reconfigure them into a guided pathway to ensure students take general education course when appropriate. In particular, we redesigned the Technical Math and Technical Science courses for this cohort so they are no longer applicable as general education courses for the AA/AS degrees.

"We designed the competencies for the Technical Math and Technical Science classes so that they support and complement each other. The course objectives for Technical Math align with PWR Act. The Technical Science class was designed by science faculty with extensive collaboration from the CTE faculty and local industry. It will cover all topics that have been identified within these fields and include guest speakers and field trips to local employers."

Pat is program coordinator of Electrical Engineering Technology Programs; Francesca is associate dean of the Math, Science and Engineering Division.

The Forum for Excellence is a Career and Technical Education and Adult Education professional development event. According to the Illinois Center for Specialized Professional Support website, it "highlights educational initiatives and effective practices impacting career pathway implementatiaon and expansion."

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 10/7/2020
Expires: 11/11/2020

item.title: KCC Key Verification
item.description:
Article Description: Mandatory verification of staff's issued campus keys
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​

The Physical Plant Department is reviewing our campus key program and want to ensure that the keys you have been issued are the keys you need, and have.  The reason for this verification is to update our records and your card file as staff have relocated offices, or departments over time.  Please contact Alison Sublett to find out what keys we currently have on record for you.  I will work with you to correct your records.  Going forward keys will not be transferred directly between staff members.  All keys, including file cabinet keys and equipment keys, should be returned to the PPD office and issued directly to the new holder. The deadline for key verification is December 22, 2020.

Beginning January 4, 2021, we will be making some adjustments to our key issuing program.  At that time we will assume our records are up-to-date and will charge the $5.00 per key cutting fee for any keys lost or not returned when staff members leave KCC.  Damaged keys should be reported to the PPD office immediately and a replacement will be issued at no fee.

Feel free to return any unused keys to PPD at any time and we will remove them from your record.  Please email me at asublett@kcc.edu or call 8174 to set up a 10-15 minute block to review and update your key card file when you're on campus and available.  We am looking forward to hearing from everyone and will do my best to make this process as simple as possible.


Author: Alison Sublett
Article Date: 9/29/2020
Expires: 9/30/2020
item.author: Alison Sublett

item.title: KCC-SEC highlighted on WCIA 3
item.description:
Article Description: KCC Watseka Campus will be highlighted on WCIA 3
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

KCC Watseka Campus will be highlighted on WCIA 3

 

KCC's Miner South Extension Center will be one of the Watseka area businesses promoted on WCIA TV channel 3 of Champaign-Urbana, during their "Our Town- Watseka" celebration.

 

For the past 15 years, WCIA has put a spotlight on communities they serve with the Our Town segments. The week of Oct. 5-9 they will air inspiring , home-spun stories of the people and local business of Watseka. The South Extension Center clip  will air on WCIA channel 3, WCIX and WCIA.com before news, weather, sports or lifestyle videos on WCIA.com.

"This will be a great way to spread awareness about the programs and services available in the southern portion of the KCC district," said Nancy Schunke, coordinator of the South Extension Center.

 

 


Author: Liz Becvar for Nancy Schunke
Article Date: 9/29/2020
Expires: 10/16/2020

item.title: Flu shots available Tuesday, Sept 29th!
item.description:
Article Description: See details...
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

On Tuesday, September 29 from 11:00 AM-1:30 PM, faculty and staff can receive a flu shot here on the Riverfront (main) campus in Room M129. 

 

If you are interested, please email Amy Brouwers (abrouwers@kcc.edu)  and she will send you the consent form to complete ahead of time.  Please bring this completed consent form, along with your insurance card and they will bill the insurance directly, without you having to pay a co-pay.

 

The pharmacist also said he would have pneumonia shots, shingles shots and tetanus shots with him if anyone is also interested. 

 

If you have any questions, please call Amy at ext. 8146.

item.title: KCC's Office of Human Resources is relocating
item.description:
Article Description: New roommates for the Welcome Center staff
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC's Office of Human Resources is relocating to the Welcome Center. The move will occur on Thursday and Friday, October 1 & 2, and they will be ready to serve employees from their new offices on Monday, Oct. 5. 

David Cagle's office will be located in D-116 and his phone number will remain the same: ext. 8128. Janet Fager's office will be in D-117, and her phone number will remain the same: ext. 8124. Amy Brouwers' office will be located in D-114, and her phone number will remain the same: ext. 8146.  

 "The Welcome Center is easy for our visitors and prospective employees to find and makes a positive first impression of our college," said Beth Nunley, vice president for Business Affairs. "The new location also allows for enhanced confidentiality, and privacy."

item.title: Board Notes - September 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Sept. 14, 2020

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition/course reimbursements
  • Grant awards from the Workforce Board
  • Grant award from the US Dept. of Education for Trio Student Support Services
  • On-the-job training contracts through WIOA
  • Bid awards for building façade repairs
  • Resolutions honoring full time retirees
  • Request to proceed with phase 1 of the Technology building renovations

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • According to the Census Day enrollment report, headcount is down 9.34% and credit hours are down 6.96%. We continued to enroll students in 14-, 12- and 8-week classes after census day. Overall, enrollment is down at most community colleges in Illinois.
  • Give Day was a success and fundraising continues.
  • Congratulations to Kari Nugent. She was recognized as a Women in Business recipient.
  • KCC's Electrical Engineering Technology made international news as part of a report that aired on Al Jeezera television.
  • The Illinois Community College Board approved the Governors Emergency Education Relief Fund (GEER) funding to provide coronavirus relief.
  • The Illinois Board of Higher Education added KCC's Passport to Learning to its digital toolkit.
  • KCC is the first community college in the country to offer the CNA II course.
  • We are tracking the number of Covid cases. Information is at coronavirus.kcc.edu
  • The President's Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Council convened for the first time, and the group is off to a good start.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • The ICCTA met via Zoom and discussed equity, diversity and inclusion initiatives happening at community colleges.

Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said …

  • The virtual Club Rush was a success.
  • Student clubs are making videos that recruit new members.
  • Student Advisory Council has four new members, and helped Whitney Mittons, coordinator of Equity, Diversion and Incusion with an Anti-Blackness program.
  • Constitution Day is happening on Sept. 17.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 9/15/2020
Expires: 9/25/2020
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Michele Buikema is retiring on Sept. 30
item.description:
Article Description: Send cards and well-wishes
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

With COVID we're not able to celebrate with our retirees like we usually do. But, we still want to convey our memories, kind words and well-wishes to Michele Buikema before she retires on Sept. 30. 

There are two ways to share your well wishes and memories:

Write a personal note or card. Mail your card to Kankakee Community College, Michele Buikema c/o Katie Henry, Marketing Dept., 100 College Drive, Kankakee, IL 60901 before Sept. 30. We'll deliver the unopened, handwritten cards.

Send an email. Email your stories, comments or well-wishes for Michele to Katie Henry at cohenry@kcc.edu before Sept. 30. We will compile the emails to create a printed keepsake for each of them.

If you have any questions, contact Katie at ext. 8287 or email cohenry@kcc.edu

item.title: KCC GIVE DAY IS A SUCCESS- UPDATED TOTAL
item.description:
Article Description: Kankakee Community College (KCC) Foundation Give Day proves we are #strongtogether!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
Kankakee Community College (KCC) Foundation Give Day proves we are #strongtogether!  

On August 27, the KCC Foundation held a virtual Give Day asking KCC alumni, faculty, staff and the community to support three initiatives: 
  • The Technology Fund that helps current KCC students navigate the impact of remote learning; 
  • The Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Center Fund which fosters community-building, provides resources and a safe, inclusive and affirming space for the entire campus community; 
  • The Emergency Assistance Fund that supports KCC students experiencing an extreme financial hardship that threatens to halt their education. 
“We want to thank our generous donors who supported Give Day! Together, we raised $42,540.42. This day of giving provided essential support that will increase the success of our students. Together we really are strong!” said Kelly Myers, Executive Director of the Kankakee Community College Foundation.  Give Day is the Foundation's major fundraising initiative for 2020.  Other events, such as Employee Giving, Women's Giving Circle, and The Cavalier Fund appeal will also take place to help support the college mission and provide financial assistance to our students.

For more information, updates, events and opportunities to support our students please visit the KCC Foundation at: https://foundation.kcc.edu/.
Author: KCC Foundation
Article Date: 9/10/2020
Expires: 10/1/2020
