item.title: Records Retention Training
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The Secretary of State has approved our application for authority to dispose of local records.  The approved application will be used as a guideline to dispose of records. Records are anything made, produced, executed or received by the college in connection with the transaction of public business as evidence of the organization, function, policies, decisions, procedures, or other activities thereof, or because of the informational data contained therein.  

 

A records archivist will be providing training on campus.  The training will provide information on appropriate disposal of records and an opportunity for any questions you may have related to records retention.  The Business office will be submitting a certificate for disposal of records to the state soon.  After approval of the certificate for disposal of records and training the business office will work with departments on proper disposal of their records.  Please don’t dispose of any records at this time.  

 

Sessions will be held in the Iroquois room.  Please contact Michelle Weishaar to register for one of the training sessions below:

 

Wednesday, October 7            2:00 p.m. – 3:00 p.m.

Thursday, October 8              10:00 a.m. – 11:00a.m.

 


Author: Michelle Weishaar
Article Date: 8/27/2020
Expires: 10/8/2020
item.author: Brenda Dressler

item.title: KCC GIVE DAY IS HERE- IT'S TIME TO CHANGE LIVES!
item.description:
Article Description: Today, with your support, we are celebrating Kankakee Community College Foundation's GIVE DAY.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Today, with your support, we are celebrating Kankakee Community College Foundation's GIVE DAY.  All of you have given so generously with your time, talent, and financial support.  Your commitment to empowering students in our community with education is the driving force behind the successes the Foundation has experienced over the years.

The Foundation is so proud to present this initiative that provides friends, families, students, staff, alumni, faculty and community members to come together to support the KCC mission--to enhance the quality of life through learning.  These students will one day be our nurses, our teachers, our horticulturists, our welders, our business owners, our police officers and our future. They are choosing to persevere during this challenging time, but they need our help.  Given the unprecedented changes occurring on campus and the impact of the pandemic on our community, the Foundation is proud to stand with you and by KCC students.  They need our support now more than ever!

Please consider joining the Foundation in spreading the message of this special day with your friends, family, acquaintances and colleagues via personal phone calls, social media and email.  

Any gift, no matter what the size can change lives.

Author: Jen Zimmerman
Article Date: 8/27/2020
Expires: 8/28/2020
item.author: Jennifer Zimmerman

item.title: Interested in Becoming an ACT/SAT Worker?
item.description:
Article Description: We are looking for additional people interested in working upcoming ACT or SAT exams
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Interested in becoming an ACT/SAT worker?

We are looking for additional people interested in working upcoming ACT or SAT exams. All tests happen on occasional Saturday mornings. Interested staff will be contacted to check availability ahead of the exams.  

To qualify, you must:

  • Be a high school graduate
  • Not have a family member taking the ACT or SAT
  • Be comfortable with a computer or smartphone

Workers will be compensated directly by the test provider. Social distancing, frequent cleaning, and mask policies will be in place for all participants.

For more information or to be placed on the staff list, please contact Michelle Argento at margento@kcc.edu or 815-802-8508.

Author: Michelle Argento
Article Date: 8/20/2020
Expires: 9/18/2020
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: Library and Tutoring Information
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The physical library and tutoring space is currently open and operating from 9am to 1pm, Monday through Friday.

The previous Writing Studio and Math, Science, and Accounting tutoring labs have relocated to the SSC, and are using the name Tutoring Services.  In person tutoring is available from 9am to 1pm.

Reservations are required for space use, including computer use, a table or seat for studying, and tutoring.  The ability to make your own reservation online is coming soon.  Right now, library staff are making reservations for currently available seats as students walk in.

Online services are available as well!

Online access to articles, ebooks, videos and other material is available at all times through the library's website.

Librarians are available for research help online through Canvas and our website during most business hours.

Online tutoring is available from 9am to 8pm at kcc.tutorocean.com.

If your department or area would like a tour of the space, contact Tracy Conner (tconner@kcc.edu) to schedule a time.

Author: Tracy Conner

Expires: 10/12/2020

item.title: KCC Foundation To Host Virtual Give Day on August 27
item.description:
Article Description: The Kankakee Community College (KCC) Foundation presents GIVE DAY 2020 #strongtogether. GIVE DAY is the one day that alumni, families, students, staff, faculty, and friends unite to support one common goal: supporting the Kankakee Community College Mission—enhancing the quality of life through learning.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The Kankakee Community College (KCC) Foundation presents GIVE DAY 2020 #strongtogether. GIVE DAY is the one day that alumni, families, students, staff, faculty, and friends unite to support one common goal: supporting the Kankakee Community College Mission—enhancing the quality of life through learning.

The KCC Foundation would like to acknowledge that this year's event is happening during a very challenging time in our community.  Given the unprecedented changes occurring on campus and the impact of the pandemic on our community, it feels right to unite our college community and supporters in a common effort.  We also know that our students need our support more than ever.  100% of your gift will have a direct and immediate impact on KCC students.

We sincerely hope that you consider helping make KCC's GIVE DAY #strongtogether a success.  Any gift, no matter what the size, can change lives.  You can designate which funds you would like your donation to benefit:

Technology Fund

Helps current KCC students navigate the impact of remote learning.

Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Center Fund

Fosters community-building, provides resources and a safe , inclusive and affirming space for the entire campus community.

Emergency Assistance Fund

Supports KCC students experiencing an extreme financial hardship that threatens to halt their education.

To learn more about GIVE DAY, and to donate, visit:

https://foundation.kcc.edu/giveday

item.title: To my KCC colleagues
item.description:
Article Description: To my KCC colleagues—colleagues who are also my friends
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

To my KCC colleagues—colleagues who are also my friends:  After two-plus decades, it’s time for me to move on.  After 31 years of service to the Illinois court system and higher education, including 22 of those years here at KCC, I want to thank you for the opportunity to teach and learn with you.  When I arrived in the fall of 1998, my job was split between Continuing Education, the Business Division, and IT Services.  The scope of that job soon changed, and to work as the college’s corporate trainer allowed me to pursue areas I truly enjoy—consultation, design, development, and platform training.  So many of you joined those classes, and that was how I got to know you and to appreciate your commitment to our community’s college.  Thank you for that opportunity, for your friendship, and for your kind words as I retire today from KCC.  Our students are so incredibly fortunate to have each of you as their advocates, mentors, and supports.  Best wishes to you!  --Kris


Author: Liz Becvar for Kris Condon
Article Date: 7/31/2020
Expires: 8/14/2020
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: To my KCC colleagues
item.description:
Article Description: To my KCC colleagues—colleagues who are also my friends
Article Category: Insider Info
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

To my KCC colleagues—colleagues who are also my friends:  After two-plus decades, it’s time for me to move on.  After 31 years of service to the Illinois court system and higher education, including 22 of those years here at KCC, I want to thank you for the opportunity to teach and learn with you.  When I arrived in the fall of 1998, my job was split between Continuing Education, the Business Division, and IT Services.  The scope of that job soon changed, and to work as the college’s corporate trainer allowed me to pursue areas I truly enjoy—consultation, design, development, and platform training.  So many of you joined those classes, and that was how I got to know you and to appreciate your commitment to our community’s college.  Thank you for that opportunity, for your friendship, and for your kind words as I retire today from KCC.  Our students are so incredibly fortunate to have each of you as their advocates, mentors, and supports.  Best wishes to you!  --Kris


Author: Liz Becvar for Kris Condon
Article Date: 7/31/2020
Expires: 8/14/2020
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: Stay home if you are sick
item.description:
Article Description: Stop the spread of COVID-19
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC's administration wants to remind everyone that if you feel sick you should stay home and not go to work. If you have symptoms of COVID-19, including a fever, cough, or shortness of breath, please notify your supervisor, stay home, and follow the recommended guidelines provided by the health department and CDC. The guidelines, and more details about KCC's reopening plan, are in the information below.

"The health and safety of our employees, students and visitors is a priority," said Beth Nunley, vice president of Business Affairs. "We're following the guidelines of our reopening plan, and those directives could change as we get updated information. We appreciate everyone's cooperation to maintain a healthy campus environment."

Questions about the reopening plan can be directed to Beth at ext. 8130. To discuss time away from work because of your health or exposure to COVID-19, contact David Cagle in Human Resources at ext. 8128.


KCC Campus Reopening Plan

Except where noted:

  • This plan is effective June 26, 2020.
  • All portions of the plan apply to employees, students and community members – referred to as "everyone/anyone" in the document.

Due to the executive "Stay-at-Home" order and the COVID-19 pandemic, the college administration has planned a transition back which includes re-opening college facilities in phases with a focus on the safety of our students, faculty, staff, and community.

These guidelines align with the recommendations made by federal, state, and local officials that any reopening be achieved in a modular or progressive manner (i.e., phases). Phase Four of Illinois' re-opening plan begins on June 26. Given the changing nature of COVID-19 and Illinois' Reopening Plan, this document may be subject to change without notice.

General guidelines for Phase 4 return to KCC facilities

All open facilities are for those conducting essential appointments, business, or participating in approved classes.

  • The Main Riverfront Campus and the Manufacturing and Industrial Technology Center (MITC) are open.
  • The Fitness Center and athletic programs are open with adherence to industry guidelines. Signage communicates new procedures related to these guidelines.
  • North Extension Center opens Aug. 3, 2020. Until July 31, 2020, the NEC is only accessible for approved Riverside Medical Center employees.
  • The South Extension Center opens Aug. 3, 2020.

Before entry to any college facility, everyone must complete the self-assessment at certify.kcc.edu.

Social distancing, face covering and hand sanitizing signage to communicate those requirements will be posted at designated entrances and throughout key locations in all KCC locations.

Building entrances are:

Riverfront Campus

  • Welcome Center (south side)
  • Health Careers Center for Excellence (west side)
  • Technology Building (west side)
  • Service door at the north entrance to the gymnasium (employees only; east side).

Main entrances at

  • MITC building - (east side)
  • NEC building - (north side, effective Aug. 3, 2020)
  • SEC building - (south side, effective Aug. 3, 2020)

Rental of internal and external college facilities is available with an addendum to the rental contract that requires organizations adhere to KCC phase 4 conditions and pay an additional charge for deep cleaning and sanitization of the facilities.

Food Service and vending machines are not available until Aug. 17, 2020. "Grab and Go" options will be available beginning Aug. 17, 2020. Everyone can bring their own food and drinks. Microwaves, refrigerators, and coffee pots can be used "at your own risk."

Procedures and information for those at KCC Facilities

The college will follow ICCB and CDC guidelines.

  • Everyone is required to maintain a 6-foot social distance from others.
  • There is a maximum of 50 people in any one group.
  • A face mask must cover your nose and mouth at all times in college buildings, even when social distance is maintained. The exceptions are those in isolated, private offices; with medical documentation; and while eating in the College Center.
  • Employees will be required to complete training upon returning to work.
  • Deep cleaning and disinfecting of high touched and frequented spaces is taking place at all college facilities.

Employees may contact their supervisor with any questions, clarifications, or personal circumstances needing consideration.

For employees - Symptoms/positive COVID-19 test and travel

Employees who are sick should stay home and not go to work.

  • CDC "Isolate if you are sick" guidelines are at www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/isolation.html
  • CDC "Quarantine if you might be sick" guidelines are at https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/quarantine.html
  • An employee who exhibits recognized symptoms of COVID-19 (e.g. fever, cough, or shortness of breath) should immediately: notify their supervisor, stay home, and follow the recommended guidelines provided by the health department and/or CDC.
  • The "if you are sick" guidelines include: Self-isolate for a minimum of 10 days after symptoms first appear, and 3 days (72 hours) after recovery.
  • Recovery is defined as no fever without fever-reducing medications and improvement in respiratory symptoms (cough, shortness of breath); OR two negative COVID-19 results at least 24 hours apart.
  • Employees who are well, but another resident of their household is sick with COVID-19 or COVID-19 symptoms should notify their supervisor, stay home and follow the recommended quarantine guidelines provided by the health department and/or CDC. The employee should self-monitor for signs and symptoms of COVID-19 if they suspect exposure.

When an employee tests positive for COVID-19:

  • The county health department will conduct contact tracing and notify individuals who have had close personal contact with the employee. Contact tracing and notification involves telling others that they have been exposed and providing the date. The employee's name will not be released. For purposes of contact tracing, personal contact is contact within 6 feet for 10 minutes or longer.
  • Individuals identified as being exposed will be required to quarantine for 14 days after the most recent personal contact.
  • If the exposed individual develops COVID-19 symptoms, they should follow the guidelines for isolation.
  • If after 14 days of quarantine, the exposed individual has no COVID-19 symptoms and/or a negative COVID-19 test, they may return to work with documentation from the health department or healthcare provider.

The college will deep clean areas in which the employee worked and frequented. This may involve temporarily moving other employees to a different location or transition to working remotely, as needed.

Anyone potentially exposed to COVID-19, either through community-related exposure or travel, should follow the CDC guidelines for quarantine.

Use judgement regarding travel. Those who attended a community-related event like a concert, traveled to states with areas highly exposed with COVID, or traveled to any international destination(s) should self-quarantine for 14 days.

Employees may be able to work remotely during the quarantine period.

Questions about this plan can be directed to Beth Nunley, vice president for Business Affairs, at ext. 8130 or bnunley@kcc.edu.

item.title: Testing Center update
item.description:
Article Description: New on-line proctoring
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The Testing Center is pleased to announce that we are offering limited at-home, proctored online make-up exams for students via Zoom. To qualify, a student must have access to a computer or laptop (not a Chromebook or tablet) with internet and webcam. 

To schedule, faculty should submit their make-up exam request form as usual. They should inform the student needing an at-home proctored exam to contact testingcenter@kcc.edu or 815-802-8500 to sign-up for a time.

Please note this is only for make-up testing, we can not accomodate proctoring exams for an entire class. 

In-person paper or online/Canvas make-up testing within the Testing Center is still available by appointment only. The same process applies. The instructor should submit a make-up test form and a student will need to schedule by emailing or calling.

For both in-person and online testing, the student should schedule their exam time at least 2 business days before their exam deadline. Limited seats are available so please encourage your student to schedule ahead.  Walk-ins will not be allowed.

 

Any questions regarding this new policy can be directed to Michelle Argento at margento@kcc.edu.

item.title: Mask safety reference
item.description:
Article Description: Initiate conversations when you need it
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

As we get closer to the fall semester, we are all preparing to be as safe as we can on campus. Occasionally, we may come across someone who isn't wearing a mask. We've put together a flier with suggested phrases to help you initiate conversations with visitors, colleagues or students who are not wearing masks while in the building. 

It is college policy that masks must be worn at all times by anyone on campus even when practicing social distancing with the exception of employees working in their private offices. Anyone entering the building without a mask will be given one if they need one. 

As a reminder, if someone has a medical reason for not wearing a mask, they could receive an accommodation with proper documentation. Visitors will discuss their accommodations with campus security at the entrance, students should talk with Sherry Kinzler in Student Affairs and employees should consult with David Cagle in Human Resources.

If someone is simply refusing to wear a mask, you may ask them to put one on. If he/she refuses, they will be asked to leave the building and the incident will be reported to Meredith Purcell in Student Services and to Eric Springer in Campus Security for possible Code of Conduct violations. 

The pandemic has posed some real challenges for all of us and KCC's mask policy is  to keep everyone as safe as possible while they are on campus. If you have any questions, please contact David Cagle at ext. 8128.

 


Author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Board Notes - July 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, July 13, 2020.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Recommendation to accept grant awards
  • 2020-21 academic calendar
  • FY21 budget for public display
  • KCC's return to work plan
  • Bid awards for boiler/chiller plant renovation and VM ware
  • Resolutions honoring retirees

Honors and mentions. 

Rep. Parkhurst presented a resolution from the Illinois General Assembly to honor Dr. Kristine Condon, and delivered emotional farewell remarks for Kris' contributions to the local legal community.

Dr. Boyd and the Board members shared their gratitude for retirees Dr. Kristine Condon's and Rich Soderquist's leadership and accomplishments.


President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Thank you to Rep. Lindsey Parkhurst for assisting KCC with a $500,000 grant proposal.
  • Summer enrollment is down 14.56 percent in credit hours, and KCC's decline ranks near the "middle of the pack" among the Illinois community colleges.  
  • KCC received $248,000 grant from IGEN for the boiler and chiller replacement project. 
  • President's Equity Diversity and Inclusion Council convenes in late August. The group will share their advice as we begin an EDI center on campus.
  • The KCC Foundation's Give Day is Aug. 27. It's a virtual opportunity to make a difference for students.  
  • NJCAA Region 4 fall and winter sport seasons are postponed until spring 2021.
  • Employees are preparing for a return to campus Aug. 3 with masks, hand sanitizer, social distancing guidelines and our Phase 4 Reopening Plan.


Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

ICCTA meeting was virtual in June. Conversations were around community colleges' fall re-opening plans and the state's budget. The group will convene virtually in November. 


Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said…

SAC has a tentative student activities scheduled for fall. Planning is around virtual events and competitions, and engaging student clubs online.

item.title: Retirement recognitions
item.description:
Article Description: Send cards and notes for Rich and Yuri
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​It's hard to believe we're losing more talented people, but Police Chief Rich Soderquist and Technology Professor Dr. Yuri Starik are retiring on July 31.

With COVID we're not able to celebrate like we usually do. But, we still want to convey our memories, kind words and well-wishes with Rich and Yuri as they leave.

There are three ways to share your well wishes and memories:

Write a personal note or card. Mail your card to Kankakee Community College, (Retiree Name) c/o Katie Henry, Marketing Dept., 100 College Drive, Kankakee, IL 60901 before July 28. We'll deliver the unopened, handwritten cards.

Send an email. Email your stories, comments or well-wishes to Katie Henry at cohenry@kcc.edu before July 28. We will compile the emails to create a printed keepsake for each of them.

Post to Facebook on July 30. Look for KCC's Facebook post on July 30 and comment on the post with your favorite memories.

If you have any questions, contact Katie at ext. 8287 or email cohenry@kcc.edu

item.title: Please help with message to students
item.description:
Article Description: When it comes to face coverings, some students may need a nudge
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​As we prepare to return with some in-person options for Fall 2020 classes, we may need to help students understand the importance of wearing cloth face coverings.

Though students are required to wear face coverings to enter campus, some may become more careless about it once they are in the building, or as the semester unfolds. 

Sharing our personal messages on social media is one way we can educate students. Please consider recording a brief video—30 seconds or less—to encourage students to wear a face covering when they come to the college.

Do you need a few details to get you talking? For more information on why the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends wearing masks, the newest information on this topic is online. The page is Considerations for Wearing Cloth Face Coverings: Help Slow the Spread of COVID-19.

How to submit a video
Use the link to VidGrid below.
Include a brief introduction in your video with your name and department or title.
You can either record it, then upload the video; or wait to record until you get to the upload site.

Either way, here's what to do:

  1. Go to https://use.vg/idefwl
  2. Follow the prompts.
  3. Wait for your video to upload.
  4. Give it a name (use your name in the title).
  5. Click "Looks good" to finalize it.

It's that easy.

If you need help uploading your video, contact Craig Keigher, ckeigher@kcc.edu.

Please complete uploads by July 31.

Videos will be posted to KCC's social media channels. You are welcome to share the video on your own social media accounts as well. 

Thank you for your help!

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 7/6/2020
Expires: 8/7/2020

item.title: Webex for all KCC Employees
item.description:
Article Description: Announcing Webex for all KCC Employees
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​I am pleased to announce that KCC was able to acquire full Webex licenses, at no additional cost.  The new Webex licenses will provide single sign-on access to meetings, trainings, and webinars for up to 1000 participants without restrictions.  Licenses have now been activated for all KCC Staff/Faculty.  

There are a few important items to note as it relates to the new licensed Webex service;

  • Download any recordings that you made in the free Webex environment and take note of any upcoming scheduled meetings.
  • Sign out and back into both the Webex Client and the Outlook Productivity Plug-in to pick the new site name (kccedu.webex.com).
  • Webex is enabled for SSO.  Signing in should not require a password while on a KCC system.
  • During sign-in, (web, app, plugin, or mobile), choose the new site name "kccedu.webex.com"
  • If you need to access appointments previously scheduled on the free account, you can use the Webex website and choose the previous site name while logging in. 
    • If you already scheduled future appointments in the free tier, you may prefer to recreate those appointments once logged into the new environment.
  • The licensed Webex environment support the following attendee limits;
    • Cisco Webex Meetings service with capacity of 1000 attendees per session
    • Cisco Webex Training service with capacity of 1000 attendees per session
    • Cisco Webex Events service with capacity of 1000 attendees per session
  • There are a significant amount of training options available on the Webex site.  Here are a couple links that I found to be beneficial for use at KCC.
    • https://www.webex.com/essentials.html/
    • https://www.webex.com/webexremoteedu.html

Please contact the HelpDesk at x8900 or helpdesk@kcc.edu if you have any questions or run into any issues.

item.title: Phase 4 plan includes post-travel recommendations
item.description:
Article Description: Follow the CDC guidelines if you've travelled
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC has updated the Phase 4 reopening plan to include information on travel or community-related exposure to COVID-19

All faculty, staff, and students potentially exposed to someone with COVID-19, either through community-related exposure or travel, should follow CDC guidance to self-isolate.

"You should use your best judgement. If you attend a community-related event like a concert, or travel to states with areas highly exposed with COVID, or travel to any international destinations, you should self-isolate and stay home for a two week period," said Beth Nunley, KCC's vice president for business affairs.

Employees may be able to work remotely during the isolation period.

Nunley noted, "If the exposed individual has no COVID-19 symptoms after 14 days of quarantine or documentation from the health department or healthcare provider of a negative COVID-19 test, they may return to campus."

If you have questions about KCC's Phase 4 plan, contact Beth at ext. 8142.

item.title: Phase 4 Reopening Plan
item.description:
Article Description: The news site has an article about KCC's entry into Phase 4 of Illinois' reopening.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The news site has an article about KCC's entry into Phase 4 of Illinois' reopening. View the full article here.

All employees should also have received an email about this phase of reopening, which began June 26.

The following aspects of the re-opening are particularly important to know and/or pertain specifically to employees:

  • Beginning Aug. 1, employees will return to their normal work locations/schedules. Department supervisors may re-arrange workspaces as needed. Employees are required to complete training upon returning to work.
  • All students/visitors and employees are required to submit a self-assessment before entering a college building.
  • A face covering requirement, plus social distancing and other procedures are in place. The exception is employees in private offices and work areas where no social interaction is occurring.
  • The designated employee entrances are:
    • Service door on the east side of the Riverfront campus at the north entrance to the gymnasium; east door of the Technology Building hallway.
    • MITC building – Main building entrance (east side).
  • Food Service and vending remains unavailable. You can bring your own food. Microwaves, refrigerators and other communal appliances can be used at each person's discretion.
  • Beginning Aug. 1, 2020, The North and South extension centers will open for approved appointments, business, or classes.  

There is also more information on the coronavirus information page. Questions about these procedures can be submitted to the coronavirus information request form. Employees may also contact their supervisor with any questions, clarifications, or personal circumstances needing consideration.

As you may expect, because of the changing nature of COVID-19 and Illinois' Reopening Plan, this information may change without notice.

item.title: Riverfront campus is open on a limited basis
item.description:
Article Description: Employees should follow these guidelines.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Notes and procedures for facilities re-opening

As KCC's facilities re-open on a limited basis, please keep the following items in mind:

  • Everyone must complete a brief self-assessment before they can enter KCC's facilities. You must do this each day you enter campus. The form is at http://certify.kcc.edu
  • , or scan the QR code which will also be posted at entrances. To access the QR code without an app, open your camera and hover over the QR code. A safari link to the assessment/questionnaire will open. The self-assessments are sent to human resources and security.
  • A mask is required to enter any college building. For those who need one, it will be provided. Riverfront Campus entrances are: 
    • For employees – (east side) service door/north entrance by the gymnasium, and (west side) entrance to the Technology Building.  
    • For students/visitors conducting essential appointments or business – south entrance marked Welcome Center (Workforce Development Center Building).  
  • Complimentary bottles of hand sanitizers have been delivered to select work stations courtesy of the Culture of Care committee. 
  • Most service counters are equipped with hand sanitizer and additional cleaning solutions. Those who need cleaning products or sanitizer in additional areas should contact April Frye at ext. 8179.
  • Please clean and sanitize all shared work stations prior to use and keep all workspaces clean and sanitized.
  • Please be cautious if you choose to use any communal equipment. You are encouraged to bring your own lunch and beverages in insulated bags.
  • Food Service, vending and catering will not be available. 

Re-opening task force members are Beth Nunley, April Frye, David Cagle, Eric Springer, Jill Christy, Kate Wachtor, Mary Posing, Mike OConnor, Michelle Weishaar, Paul Carlson, Rich Soderquist, Rob Kenney, and Ryan Hale. Please reach out to any member with feedback or suggestions. Another avenue for feedback is Candid Comments.

item.title: Board Notes - June 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, June 8, 2020

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • KCC's return-to-work plan following the coronavirus pandemic
  • Recommendation to operate within the budget draft
  • Resolutions honoring full-time retirees
  • Bid awards for network switches
  • Proposal for audit services
  • Planning for Technology building renovations
  • Bid solicitations for VM Ware and building façade repairs
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Dr. Vicki Gardner's strong work ethic, strategic thinking and guidance will be missed when she retires on June 30. Dr. Boyd and the board offered their well wishes and kind words.
  • A lot of work went into coordinating the Zoom meeting platform, and that is appreciated.
  • Many people have been asking about KCC's plans for fall. Our class delivery will be hyper-flexible. When it makes sense, classes will meet online. When it's best to meet in person – for classes with labs and hands-on learning - we'll welcome students back safely.
  • Plans to update the signage at River Road and Route 45/52 are on hold.
  • College Drive is paved and in much better shape.
  • KCC is exploring how it fits in the plan to revitalize downtown Kankakee.
  • KCC athletics may return in the fall. Discussions are underway to bring back sports safely. 

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • ICCTA meeting was virtual this month. Conversations were around community colleges' fall re-opening plans and the state's budget.

Student Trustee's Report. Ariana Ramirez said…
  • Ariana told the board more about herself. She is a Gilman resident, a 2019 graduate of Iroquois West High School, is studying psychology, and plans to transfer to a 4-year college after KCC.
  • SAC organized a video challenge on Tik Tok to engage students.
  • The transition from classroom to online learning in the spring was a challenge for many students. Some had issues with technology and navigating Canvas, but everyone worked hard to resolve issues for students and faculty. Now, students are worried about class formats for fall and want more information and reassurances before they register for classes.

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

As more employees transition back to working on campus, and as the college begins to meet with students via appointments beginning Monday, June 15, it is important for us to remember our "Proper Dress" policy, which is described below: 

Proper Dress

Employees should recognize that as representatives of the College they are judged not only by the service they render and their actions toward students and the public, but also by their personal appearance. In order to help make a positive impression, the College requests that employees dress appropriately for the position in which they work, and that their attire be neat and clean.  Generally speaking, all employees of the college should be wearing professional business attire. 

Should you have any questions on the above policy, please contact David in HR at ext. 8128.

item.title: Board Notes - May 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, May 11, 2020 


Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Recommendation to approve a resolution honoring Student Trustee Daisy Solorzano
  • Recommendation to approve grant award
  • Recommendation to approve bids for a library backup equipment 
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for network switch refresh 
  • Recommendation to relocate the Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) academic program to the Manufacturing and Industrial Technology Center
  • Recommendation to temporarily amend pass/fail requirements
  • Recommendation to adopt disclosure policies and procedures
  • Recommendation to approve tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • Welcome to new Student Trustee Ariana Ramirez, and a special thank you to Daisy Solorzano for her year of service. 
  • Our faculty, staff and students showed resiliency and determination as they moved to remote learning and work environments. Everyone demonstrated flexibility as the changes occurred, and its due in part to the board's high expectations for our culture.
  • Summer classes will happen via remote learning, and we are actively planning academic continuity plans for the fall semester.
  • Enrollment is trending down, and KCC's marketing outreach is in high gear.
  • KCC's graduation will be a virtual celebration this year. Tune into KCC's Facebook page for the video premiere on May 15 at 4:30 pm. More info at commencement.kcc.edu
  • CARES Act funding is available for students, and they can request funds through our Financial Aid office. 
  • College Drive is being repaved. To access campus, please use the ice arena drive.
  • Gov. Pritzker's budget proposal is being reproached as ramifications from the coronavirus affect our state. KCC's budget development process is underway and our budget committee has some tough decisions to make. 
  • KCC received thank you letters from our local hospitals for our personal protective equipment donations.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • ICCTA hasn't met. 
  • Mr. Frey asked that we tell or community that KCC is a safety net for area students who cannot return to their college campuses this fall.  

    Student Trustee's Report. Daisy Solorzano said…
  • Relaxation Battle Royale competition is happening on Tik Tok during finals week. First place prize is a $50 gift card and the second place prize is a $25 gift card.

item.title: Listening and Learning - A Culture of Caring
item.description:
Article Description: Dr. Boyd shares his comments about George Floyd's death and the events that followed.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content: Colleagues,
In the days since the events which occurred on May 25th leading to the death of George Floyd, we have all experienced a range of emotions.  As we grieve together, each in our own way, we also make a commitment to support and care for one another.  At KCC, we are committed to nurturing and sustaining a culture of caring because we know that the learning process begins with caring deeply about others as human beings.
Right now, we need listen to each other, learn from each other, and commit to doing so peacefully.  Throughout history, peaceful protests have helped us learn more about each other, the unique challenges each of us faces, and ways to overcome those challenges together.  Racism is a very real societal problem; it is systemic and harmful to everyone.  Each one of us has an important moral obligation to do whatever we can to overcome racism and the impact it has on our communities.  Sadly, George Floyd's tragic death is not an isolated incident.  His death and the death of others serves to illuminate the physical and psychological violence caused by systemic racism and injustice.
Our mission at KCC is so important to us because we truly believe that learning enhances quality of life for everyone.  As educator Paulo Freire often wrote, education is an "instrument of freedom."  Peaceful gatherings, whether those gatherings are face to face or online, give us a unique opportunity to listen to each other and to learn.  When we make a commitment to learning, we also make a commitment to our community.  A diverse, equitable, inclusive community is a community that cares deeply about every single person regardless of the many superficial differences which feed ignorance, racism, and social injustice.
Please know that KCC is committed to providing a healthy, safe, and inclusive environment where everyone can learn.  As we work through the powerful emotions associated with physical and psychological healing, we invite everyone to turn anger and fear into peaceful action, and make this moment a turning point for real change. 

MB      
 
Dr. Michael Boyd
President

 


Author: Dr. Michael Boyd

item.title: IT'S FINALLY HERE!!!
item.description:
Article Description: It seems like just yesterday...
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​

Article Content:

​It seems like just yesterday when I started going to KCC for my Associates Degree in Computer Programming. I worked in the library under Barb Loudy's direction as a student worker and enjoyed it so much that I started full-time in the Humanities/Social Science division right after graduation.

I have had the same position for 35 years, but I have had 9 bosses in that time. (I guess I'm hard on them. LOL) My office started in L337, moved to L340, and then ended up in L355.

My time at KCC has been wonderful and I will miss everyone. I received these flowers and plaque in the mail yesterday. Thanks to Katie and Liz for arranging for these to be sent to me and for the gift left at school for me. Since we were unable to have a retirement party, I thought I would use this to say goodbye to everyone. When everyone is allowed back on campus, I will be back for a visit to say goodbye in person.

Thanks to everyone who has wished me well. I am ready for this. I plan to do some work around the house and lots of work in my 2+ acres. It has all been put on the back burner for the last 10 years or so and needs a lot of TLC. Now it is time for that TLC. I also plan to do a lot of relaxing and dancing. I do already have a part-time job mowing--and not at my house; although, I will be doing that, too.

Until we meet again...

item.author: Sheila Pfaff

item.title: College Reopening Plan in Phase 3
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

As we enter Phase 3 of Governor Pritzker’s Reopen Illinois plan, KCC now has greater flexibility to welcome employees and students onto campus.  

That said, clear restrictions remain in place, and some employees will continue to work from home until the governor determines when Illinois enters “Phase 4” of the state’s reopening plan. Supervisors will determine when employees need to access campus for essential functions and request that those employees get added to the security access list. 

Our safety measures are still in place:

  • Once at KCC, masks are required to enter a college building.
  • Make sure there are 10 or fewer people in any given area.
  • Follow social distancing guidelines of 6 ft or more. 

In keeping with the plan guidelines, we will prepare for front line staff to return to campus beginning June 8 to meet with students on an appointment basis.

Supervisors will use the Phase 3 guidelines to create work schedules to accommodate student appointments. This includes advisors, financial aid staff, Business Office staff and any others who assist with advising and registration processes.

In addition to the safety requirements above, these additional measures will also be in place:

  • In-person student appointments will be optional. Virtual or phone appointments will continue.
  • Supervisors should make staffing plans based on who is needed, look at possibilities for use of a rotating schedule, and choose which work areas will be utilized.
  • The staffing plans will be shared with Physical Plant Department/Security to help custodians know which areas have people and need to be cleaned.

Our vision statement at KCC says that we aim to be a “flexible organization where teamwork is the expectation,” and I continue to be impressed with our shared commitment to realize this bold vision.  

Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, we’ve all continued to demonstrate flexibility as we’ve encountered so many challenges. I ask you now to continue demonstrating flexibility.  We’ve never had to “re-open” our campus in this way, and I know that we may make some mistakes along the way. But also know that we are committed to working as a team to figure it out, and we are going to do just that over the next weeks and months.

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 5/29/2020
Expires: 6/26/2020

item.title: Make a difference with Facebook and Twitter
item.description:
Article Description: Consider writing a post about KCC, or sharing KCC posts, on your personal social media feeds.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content: With enrollment trending down for summer and fall, it's a great time to reach out to our family, friends and acquaintances to help increase the number of students we serve. If you choose, you can post about KCC on your personal Facebook, Instagram and Twitter feeds. 

You can use these messages below aimed at our recent high school grads and college students home for the summer, or adapt them with your own words. Or, you can share the messages from KCC's page.

Whatever you chose, the intent is to invite as many people as we can to consider KCC. 


Facebook and Instagram
College kids – don't let COVID-19 interrupt your college goals. Take classes at KCC so you don't miss a beat. Not sure if your university campus will be open this fall? You can stay local and save money. KCC costs less than 4-year colleges or universities. You can still apply for financial aid, and CARES Act funding can help with expenses, technology needs and other costs. Stay on track, stay local, save money and reach your goals!

https://register.kcc.edu

 

Twitter 
Don't let COVID-19 interrupt your college goals. Take classes at KCC. Not sure if your university campus will be open this fall? You can stay local and save money. CARES Act funding can help with technology needs and more. Stay on track!

https://register.kcc.edu

item.title: Message to all students
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​A message went out to all students this morning to share several items related to the end of thesememster and services offered at the college.

Here are the main points which were sent:

  • It's finals week. Do your best. Use common sense study tips and plan out your time ahead. Good luck! The college faculty and staff admires your willingness to stick with it!
  • You deserve a good time! Graduation Spirit Week is May 11-15. Different ways to celebrate are at commencement.kcc.edu. Please share pictures any time during the week.
  • The Virtual Graduation Program premieres at 4 p.m. May 15. View it through the commencement.kcc.edu site or Facebook®. Please join the celebration! If you can't watch at that time, the recording will be saved for later viewing.
  • You can take books for buyback and rental returns to the Riverfront Campus May 11-15, plus May 18, 9 a.m. - 3 p.m. each day. There will be a spot to return library materials, too. Road work is starting, so drive past the main college entrance to the Ice Valley Center. Wear a mask to enter the building. Other details are at kcc.edu/bookstore.
  • An application is now available for those who want to receive funds from the Federal Emergency Stimulus Funding (CARES Act) for Colleges and Universities. For information, qualifications, and to apply, visit the information site.
  • KCC's service areas, including advising, Workforce Services, Counseling and Referral Services, Continuing Education & Career Services, and Career Planning all are ready to help you—whether or not your education/job situation has changed due to COVID-19. Most services are free, and staff is ready to help.
  • Along the same lines, it's time to think of the future – and ways to stay on track to meet your goals. Registration is underway for summer and fall. Most returning students can register online, and advisors are available to help.

item.title: Webinar: 'Embracing and Planning for Online Learning'
item.description:
Article Description: You're invited to join a live webinar April 30
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Dear Kankakee Community College Partners,

Please feel free to share this with others.

You're invited to join WGU's Vice President of Design and Development, Joann Kozyrev, for the live webinar, "Embracing and Planning for Online Learning," on Thursday, April 30, at 11 am (CST). To learn more and register for the webinar, visit https://www.wgu.edu/lp/programs/academic-engagement-webinar.html.

Despite the unanticipated and rapid transition to digital learning, the goal among institutions remains the same: to keep students on track in their academic journey and ensure they continue learning with limited disruption. Embracing the unexpected shift to online instruction is key to student success and faculty preparedness, planning, and flexibility to adapt play central roles.  

The webinar will present how instructors might pivot their teaching methods and restructure their course content to align with the new digital learning landscape. Webinar attendees will receive a simple planning outline that can be quickly implemented to help support their new online courses. Key takeaways from the webinar include:

  • Learning five essential considerations that all faculty should keep in mind when moving to online instruction.
  • Receiving an action plan to move face-to-face instruction online based on how much time is allotted to plan.
  • Considering how accessibility and accommodations are altered in an online environment.

 Register now for the webinar: https://www.wgu.edu/lp/programs/academic-engagement-webinar.html. 

Can't attend our live session? Don't worry. You should still register. We will be sending out the presentation to all registrants. 

Information provided by Christy Seawall, Strategic Partnerships Manager, Chicago, Western Governors University - christy.seawall@wgu.edu

item.description:
Article Description: Presentations by finalists are available to review
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Greetings everyone! 

The screening committee has spent the past two weeks interviewing the four finalists for the Vice President for Business Affairs position, to replace Dr. Gardner upon her retirement June 30. 

Unfortunately, we are not able to have an open forum on campus with all faculty and staff to meet the candidates. Instead, we asked the candidates to submit a VidGrid presentation, providing a brief presentation (five to 10 minutes) on themselves, incorporating their bios and what attracted them to this position at KCC.  

Additionally, they were asked to provide their personal philosophy on the role that a community college plays and what the Vice President for Business Affairs can do to promote student success. 

We welcome your input and feedback! 

Here are the links to the four VidGrid presentations.  Please review and email your input and feedback to Karen Slager, kslager@kcc.edu  before noon on Monday, April 27.  If you have any questions or concerns, please contact David Cagle at ext. 8128 or dcagle@kcc.edu.

  • Beth Nunley
  • Phil Pena
  • Jake Lee
  • Michael Cornale
Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 4/22/2020

item.title: Course Prefix Changes for Fall 2020 for Humanities/Social Sciences
item.description:
Article Description: Check out this article for the HSS course prefix changes starting in Fall 2020.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The following course changes will be in effect for the Fall 2020 semester in Humanities/Social Sciences.


The following courses have been discontinued starting in fall:

ENGL 0944 – Prep for College English I

ENGL 0954 – Prep for College English II

ENGL 1413 – Fundamentals of Writing

ENGL 1422 – Accelerated Writing Instruction


The  newly added courses starting in fall are:

ENGL 0964 – Prep for College English (For students who don't score into 1423.)

ENGL 1423 – Accelerated Learning: Reading & Writing (Students who score into this class must still take ENGL 1613 in the same semester, but the sections are no longer tied together.  Students may sign up for any ENGL 1613 section that fits their schedule.  They will probably not have the same instructor for both classes.)

ORIN 1541 – Foundations for Student Success (Now a 1 credit class mandatory for all first time AA, AS, and AGS students.)


The following courses will have a COMM prefix starting in the fall. 

BSNS 1603 – Business Communication is now in the HSS Division and is COMM 1603

JOUR 1673 – Introduction to Mass Communication is now COMM 1673

SPCH 1553 – Introductory Speech is now COMM 1553


(JOUR 1653 – Introduction to Journalism will remain JOUR 1653.  This class is only offered in the spring, but we want to make sure everyone knows that this course is not changing prefixes.)


If you have any questions, please contact the HSS Division at 815-802-8700 or e-mail Jen Huggins directly.

item.title: Debra Daun uses 3D Printers to Make Mask Shields
item.description:
Article Description: We're all in this together!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Debra Daun is a adjunct instructor at KCC who is teaching ELTR2192  Build a 3D Printer.  She is also a Computer Graphic Technology tutor.  However, she also is the MakerLab Manager at Joliet Junior College.

After discussions with Professor John Bordeau and the local maker community, the decision was made to produce mask shields for the growing demand of personnel protection equipment.  

"Debra is always ready to lend a helping hand and without hesitation stepped up when we were approached with this project," said Amy Murphy, JJC dean of applied arts, workforce education and training. "I can't thank Debra enough for her efforts and sharing her expertise with the innovative technologies that are available in our JJC MakerLab."

Shields are made from PETG 3D printing filament, and each take about 40 minutes to complete. With its nine printers, the Maker Lab can make upwards of 100 shields per day. Affixed to a face mask, the shields can extend the life of the N95 masks.

As of Tuesday, "She has made 1200 mask shields that have be donated to regional health care facilities such as Manteno Veterans Home.  The demand is great and supplies in the country are sparse.    The PETG 3D printing filament has a four week wait time from the manufacturers." said Professor Bordeau.


Author: John Bordeau
Article Date: 4/8/2020
Expires: 4/24/2020
item.author: Karen Richards

item.title: Protecting Your Zoom Meeting Sessions
item.description:
Article Description: By now most of you have probably heard about various security vulnerabilities related to the Zoom virtual meeting/conferencing service. ...
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​By now most of you have probably heard about various security vulnerabilities related to the Zoom virtual meeting/conferencing service. Although, many of the stories that have been reported in the press were accurate at the time, it does appear that Zoom has worked diligently to correct the more serious vulnerabilities.

One of the issues that continues to be a serious concern is the hi-jacking of Zoom meeting sessions, better known as "Zoombombing". Zoom has released a blog post entitled "How to Keep Uninvited Guests Out of Your Zoom Event" [Link] that is worth reading to ensure that you and your participants have the best meeting/instruction experience possible.

The FBI has also provided the following tips for Zoom users …

  • Do not make meetings or classrooms public. In Zoom, there are two options to make a meeting private: require a meeting password or use the waiting room feature and control the admittance of guests.
  • Do not share a link to a teleconference or classroom on an unrestricted publicly available social media post. Provide the link directly to specific people.
  • Manage screensharing options. In Zoom, change screensharing to "Host Only."

In addition to Zoom, there are a myriad of other virtual meeting solutions that you may wish to consider…

  • Webex (free accounts available at www.webex.com)
  • Skype for Business (Available through the web on Office365 and installed on every KCC employee system)
  • Teams (Included in our Campus agreement, available through the web on Office365 and installed on every KCC staff system)
  • Google Meet (Web based service, available to all KCC users at https://meet.google.com/)
  • Canvas Conferences (services provided by BigBlueButton and available to KCC faculty and students with https://kcc.instructure.com)

As always if you have any questions or concerns, or would like additional information regarding Zoom security, please do not hesitate to reach out to the ITS Help Desk at (815) 802-8900 or helpdesk@kcc.edu.


Author: Michael OConnor
Article Date: 4/4/2020
Expires: 4/20/2020

item.title: Home office expenses
item.description:
Article Description: Reimbursement of office expenses
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

A message from the Business Office:

Since closing campus at 5 p.m. on Tuesday, March 17, 2020, many KCC employees have transitioned to a remote work environment and have established a home office.  KCC would like to reimburse employees for the following home office expenses:

  1. Printer paper
  2. Printer ink
  3. Internet service plan increases due to working from home
  4. Miscellaneous office supply expenses

For business office to process your reimbursements, please complete the staff reimbursement request form available on the portal under Employees then select the Human Resources page within the HR Forms drop down menu.  Please complete the following fields within the form: employee name, date, department, amount, description of the expense, and check the box for miscellaneous staff reimbursement.  The business office will complete the account number and obtain necessary signatures.  The business office will need receipts or proper backup documentation to support your staff reimbursement request.  Please submit your receipts or backup documentation using one of the methods described below via email to Juli Gereg at jgereg@kcc.edu:

  1. If you have an iPhone, you may scan a document through your phone.  First go to "notes" and hit the little camera button.  It will ask if you want to scan a document.  Lay out the pages you want to scan and it will save them all as a PDF file.  Please submit the PDF file via email with your staff reimbursement request form.
  2. If you do not have an iPhone, your phone may have a camera and you can take a picture of the receipt or backup documentation and submit the image via email with your staff reimbursement request form.
  3. If you prefer not to submit your backup or request electronically, please mail your request to: Kankakee Community College, Attention: Juli Gereg, 100 College Drive, Kankakee, IL  60901

With the campus closure, KCC is processing all check requests bi-weekly.  The next scheduled check runs are set for Wednesday 4/8/2020 and Wednesday 4/22/2020.  Please remit all staff reimbursement requests by Monday at 5 p.m. to Juli Gereg via jgereg@kcc.edu to ensure your requests will be processed with the scheduled check run.  If you have any questions, please contact Juli Gereg at (815)802-8122.

Thank you,

Business Office

item.author: Jessica Braddy

item.title: Employee Rights under FFCRA
item.description:
Article Description: New U.S.Department of Labor Posting Requirement
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The following is being posted in compliance with the New U.S.Department of Labor Posting Requirement.

The Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA or Act) requires certain employers (including KCC) to provide employees with paid sick leave or expanded family and medical leave for specified reasons related to COVID-19. The Department of Labor’s (Department) Wage and Hour Division (WHD) administers and enforces the new law’s paid leave requirements. These provisions will apply from the effective date of April 1 through December 31, 2020.

Generally, the Act provides that employees of covered employers are eligible for:
  • Two weeks (up to 80 hours) of paid sick leave at the employee’s regular rate of pay where the employee is unable to work because the employee is quarantined (pursuant to Federal, State, or local government order or advice of a health care provider), and/or experiencing COVID-19 symptoms and seeking a medical diagnosis; or
  • Two weeks (up to 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds the employee’s regular rate of pay because the employee is unable to work because of a bona fide need to care for an individual subject to quarantine (pursuant to Federal, State, or local government order or advice of a health care provider), or to care for a child (under 18 years of age) whose school or child care provider is closed or unavailable for reasons related to COVID-19, and/or the employee is experiencing a substantially similar condition as specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Secretaries of the Treasury and Labor; and
  • Up to an additional 10 weeks of paid expanded family and medical leave at two-thirds the employee’s regular rate of pay where an employee, who has been employed for at least 30 calendar days, is unable to work due to a bona fide need for leave to care for a child whose school or child care provider is closed or unavailable for reasons related to COVID-19.

Covered Employers: The paid sick leave and expanded family and medical leave provisions of the FFCRA apply to certain public employers, and private employers with fewer than 500 employees.

Eligible Employees: All employees of covered employers are eligible for two weeks of paid sick time for specified reasons related to COVID-19. Employees employed for at least 30 days are eligible for up to an additional 10 weeks of paid family leave to care for a child under certain circumstances related to COVID-19.

Notice: Where leave is foreseeable, an employee should provide notice of leave to the employer as is practicable. After the first workday of paid sick time, an employer may require employees to follow reasonable notice procedures in order to continue receiving paid sick time. 

Qualifying Reasons for Leave:

Under the FFCRA, an employee qualifies for paid sick time if the employee is unable to work (or unable to telework) due to a need for leave because the employee:

  1. is subject to a Federal, State, or local quarantine or isolation order related to COVID-19;
  2. has been advised by a health care provider to self-quarantine related to COVID-19;
  3. is experiencing COVID-19 symptoms and is seeking a medical diagnosis;
  4. is caring for an individual subject to an order described in (1) or self-quarantine as described in (2);
  5. is caring for a child whose school or place of care is closed (or child care provider is unavailable) for reasons related to COVID-19; or
  6. is experiencing any other substantially-similar condition specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Secretaries of Labor and Treasury.

Under the FFCRA, an employee qualifies for expanded family leave if the employee is caring for a child whose school or place of care is closed (or child care provider is unavailable) for reasons related to COVID-19.

Duration of Leave:

For reasons (1)-(4) and (6): A full-time employee is eligible for 80 hours of leave, and a part-time employee is eligible for the number of hours of leave that the employee works on average over a two-week period.

For reason (5): A full-time employee is eligible for up to 12 weeks of leave (two weeks of paid sick leave followed by up to 10 weeks of paid expanded family & medical leave) at 40 hours a week, and a part-time employee is eligible for leave for the number of hours that the employee is normally scheduled to work over that period.

Calculation of Pay:

For leave reasons (1), (2), or (3): employees taking leave are entitled to pay at either their regular rate or the applicable minimum wage, whichever is higher, up to $511 per day and $5,110 in the aggregate (over a 2-week period).

For leave reasons (4) or (6): employees taking leave are entitled to pay at 2/3 their regular rate or 2/3 the applicable minimum wage, whichever is higher, up to $200 per day and $2,000 in the aggregate (over a 2-week period).

For leave reason (5): employees taking leave are entitled to pay at 2/3 their regular rate or 2/3 the applicable minimum wage, whichever is higher, up to $200 per day and $12,000 in the aggregate (over a 12-week period).

Notes: 

  • Paid sick time provided under this Act does not carryover from one year to the next.
  • Employees are not entitled to reimbursement for unused leave upon termination, resignation, retirement, or other separation from employment.
  • An employee may elect to substitute any accrued vacation leave, personal leave, or medical or sick leave for the first two weeks of partial paid leave under this section.

Anyone with specific questions on this Act should email me at dcagle@kcc.edu or by calling me at 815-802-8128.

Author: David Cagle

item.author: Brenda Dressler

item.title: Reporting of Hours on Timesheets
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

In response to numerous questions on how to report time during facility closing, here are some guidelines to follow:

1)     Time should be recorded using the existing time sheets.  Supportive Staff should continue entering your time in and your time out, and Professional/Technical staff should continue listing the total number of hours worked, just like you do while working on campus. 

2)     Under the column "TOTAL HOURS WORKED" list the number of hours an employee actually worked each day, whether it is at home or physically on campus.

3)     Under the "EMERGENCY CLOSING" column, list the number of hours an employee was available to work, but did NOT work due to the emergency closing of campus. 

Example: employee worked from home from 8:00 am to 1:00 pm for a total of 5.00 hours - list 5 hours worked under "TOTAL HOURS WORKED" and 3 hours under "EMERGENCY CLOSING" to total 8 hours for the day.

Example: employee was available to work, but did not work from home or on campus - list 8 hours under "EMERGENCY CLOSING."

Example: employee worked from 8:00 – noon and 12:30 – 4:30 – list 8 hours under "TOTAL HOURS WORKED" and do not log any hours under "EMERGENCY CLOSING."

4)     HR is creating a new leave code for FT and PT employees to keep track of hours NOT worked but paid as a result of COVID-19. Time will be entered in as a positive rather than a negative number (counting up/not counting down), like bereavement and jury duty is now.  The new leave code is CVNW – Coronavirus Not Working.

5)     If someone is unavailable to work and is requesting a paid benefit day (vacation, personal, give, floating holiday, sick) – if that person is truly off from work (not working remotely, not answering emails, phone calls, or instant messages, nor participating in webex meetings, etc.) then that person needs to submit the appropriate number of hours not working under the respective "BENEFIT TIME USED" column.

6)     Part time employees do not need to submit time sheets going forward (unless they are actually working remotely, or on campus like our police officers) since they will be receiving stipends equivalent to their actual hours worked for the pay period ending  2/29/20.  

If anyone has any questions, please contact David at ext. 8128.  

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 3/24/2020
Expires: 4/10/2020
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Best Practices and Tips for Working Remotely
item.description:
Article Description: As KCC transitions to a virtual campus for the next few weeks, the ITS team thought it might be helpful to share some best practices about working remotely.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image Caption:

​Remote Worker

Article Content:

​As KCC transitions to a virtual campus for the next few weeks, the ITS team thought it might be helpful to share some best practices about working remotely.

  • All of the communication tools that you use when on campus at KCC are available to you remotely including e-mail, instant messaging (Skype for Business) and your phone. Use the tool that is most appropriate based on the timeliness of the response that you require.
  • Pay attention to your habits and design your day around your peak productivity.
  • Adopt a routine most days of the week. Know when you start your work day and when you should end your work day.
  • Always use video in conference calls. People tune out when it's an audio-only call.
  • Turn your camera on and be present when you're meeting with people. Try to make time for rapport-building even when you're just meeting remotely.
  • Find moments to connect as human beings across the distance, like remembering to message "good morning" or "have a nice evening". Little things create the sense of togetherness across huge leaps of time and space.
  • Stay in constant communication with your team and your manager about what you are working on.
  • Be sure to check in with your manager and if you're managing direct reports be sure to ask "Are you getting what you need from me?" This will foster a conversation around objectives and ensure both the employee and employer are getting what they need!
  • Remaining visible while working remotely is a crucial key to our overall success - whether it involves creating and following a calendar, scheduling weekly calls, or putting in extra effort to complete a project.
  • Making sure to follow up on assigned work is an important aspect when working remotely. Without following up, a project or task may be backlogged -- until you realize the deadline is tomorrow. Being consistent about notifying your coworkers and managers about your completed work allows your progress to be tracked and ensures goals will be met.
Working remotely doesn't have to be a challenge. With proper planning and an understanding that tasks may take longer than when working face-to-face, you'll be able to accomplish whatever it is you set out to do.
Author: Michael OConnor
Article Date: 3/22/2020
Expires: 4/7/2020

item.title: Message to employees about coronavirus and actions
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The following was emailed to all employees at approximately 4:40 p.m. March 12.​

Colleagues,

Kankakee Community College will extend its spring break until March 22, and most face-to-face instruction will move online March 23. This action is to reduce potential pathways for community spread of coronavirus (COVID-19).

This is not a college closure.

There will be no classes in any format from March 16-22 to allow faculty and staff involved in instruction to make the adjustment to online delivery. Beginning on March 23 through April 20 faculty will teach lecture classes online. Each professor/instructor will communicate with their students regarding how their specific classes will proceed in an online environment. Some labs will continue to meet in person. Clinicals will continue as allowed by the host site.

KCC’s Riverfront Campus and its extension sites will remain open. Student support services like tutoring, advising, registration, food pantry, computer labs, and campus resources are still available. While on campus, please practice social distancing guidelines. The Centers for Disease Control defines social distancing as "remaining out of congregate settings, avoiding mass gatherings and maintaining distance (approximately 6 feet) from others when possible."

KCC will update coronavirus.kcc.edu as the main source of information for our college’s actions and response.

The Office of Instructional Technology and Faculty Development offers Canvas support for faculty and students who need it and you can direct questions to canvashelp@kcc.edu. Information Technology Services and the ITS Help Desk provides support for online technologies.

I realize this is a major disruption of academics. I’ve made these decisions with all the current information available from the Illinois Department of Public Health, the Centers for Disease Control, and in consultation with other Illinois community college presidents, KCC’s administrative and faculty leadership teams. I feel it is the best way to minimize the risk of spreading the virus. It is my hope that temporarily moving to the online environment will minimize the spread of the virus, while still pursuing our educational mission.

Other immediate effects

  • College-sponsored student travel is suspended, with limited exceptions for intercollegiate athletics. At these events, only the athletes and coaches may be present.
  • Events at KCC with 50 or more anticipated attendees are postponed at least through April 20. All gatherings should practice social distancing guidelines.
  • Non-essential college-sponsored travel for faculty, administrators, and staff is suspended. Please consult with the President’s Office for exceptions.
  • Third-party employers will make decisions related to their employees on our sites. This pertains to Student Success Center construction and the North Extension Center, which houses some Riverside personnel and other agencies.

As we continue to monitor the situation we may need to take additional steps. On or before April 20, the college will consult with public health authorities regarding conditions, as well as resumption of face-to-face instruction. Looking forward, if significant events such as Commencement are going to be affected, we will communicate as far in advance as possible. As of today, we don’t have enough information to make those decisions.

I believe in the work ethic, dedication, and resiliency of the KCC community. We will get through this together. I would especially like to thank the faculty for the deep care they have shown in adjusting their teaching to accommodate our students' needs. As we work through this unprecedented situation, our propensity to be flexible and work together as a team has made the difference. You have put the college’s vision statement into action and you have my gratitude.

Sincerely,

Dr. Michael Boyd
KCC President

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 3/12/2020

item.title: FAQs for College Employees
item.description:
Article Description: A few things to know about student workers and more.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Communication Committee members posed a few question that are important college-related things to know in our offices and departments. We will keep adding to this list of Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) as needed, and when the information could benefit the majority of us. If you have a question, please ask your supervisor, or submit the question through the Contact Us form at coronavirus.kcc.edu. 
We will use Update in MyKCC (the portal) to post the latest FAQs for employees. The FAQs at coronavirus.kcc.edu are written with the students and community in mind. 

FAQs from College Employees 


Can student workers work 29 hours next week since classes are not in session? 
Yes, if there is work for them.  If there is not sufficient work in your area for the students, please deploy them to departments who need help. Departments that students can be redeployed to are ITS (to help keep computers clean, coordinate with TJ Hoekstra), Food pantry (coordinate with Francesca Catalano), Admissions & Records (coordinate with Kate Wachtor). On March 23 when classes resume, students should return to normal working hours.
Is there a charge for employees to be tested for COVID-19? 
Anyone who has health insurance coverage through the College will incur no cost for testing.
