item.title: Board Notes - March 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, March 9, 2020

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Resolution honoring retiree Brenda Newman
  • Recommendation to approve grant awards
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for a library backup equipment and boiler/chiller plant renovation
  • Recommendation to approve bids for network switch refresh and smart room equipment
  • Recommendation to award the furniture purchase for the Student Success Center
  • Recommendation to approve the purchase of servers from Dell Direct
  • Recommendation to approve renewal purchase of Canvas
President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • Board members toured Kankakee High School’s newly designed collaborative learning spaces, culinary arts program and fine arts additions prior to the board meeting. It was an opportunity to understand the high school learning environment and its transition to problem-based learning and real-world experiences in the classroom. 
  • Should the Coronavirus result in a facilities closure, plans are in place to provide continuity in business, student affairs and academic delivery. Classes will move to an online or flexible learning environment. Similarly, advisement and other student affairs departments could deliver services online such as answer questions, build schedules, and register students for summer and fall classes. Important business functions will also continue remotely. 
  • In Athletics news: KCC’s Lady Cavaliers took home the NJCAA regional title and will compete in the national tournament in Port Huron, Michigan. Coach Denson’s next win will put him at 500 career wins! Both basketball teams achieved 20-plus wins this season, and baseball and softball seasons are both underway.
  • Days of Learning is happening for staff while students and faculty are on spring break. Today’s presentation was about emotional intelligence. Wednesday we’ll hear about equity, diversity and inclusion from our new EDI coordinator, Whitney Mittons.
  • Illinois State Scholars dinner happened recently and it was a great event.
  • Administration received results from a new survey tool SENSE, Survey of Entering Student Engagement, and will use the data to improve the student experience.
  • Lt. Governor Julianna Stratton visited campus and enjoyed hearing from our students. She cleared her calendar to stay longer that afternoon.
  • Gov. Pritzker’s budget proposal is generous to community colleges, with at $50 million commitment for MAP funding and specific MAP dollars identified for Community College students. 
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • ICCCP and ICCTA joint meeting will take place on March 13. Campus safety and security is the focus of the meeting. Lobby Day is coming up on April 29.
Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said…
  • Student government is in the planning stages for next academic year. This year, the SAC is educating students about the changes.
  • Maurices clothing store is organizing a food drive to benefit the KCC Food Pantry.
  • ICCB’s SAC will meet at Lincoln Land Community College on March 20 to plan Student Advocacy Day.
  • Spill the Tea with the Student Trustee was a success in part because we offered walking tacos in exchange for survey feedback.

item.title: IMPORTANT: Error Accessing my.kcc.edu in Chrome
item.description:
Article Description: IMPORTANT: Error Accessing my.kcc.edu in Chrome
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

Users are reporting an error when attempting to access my.kcc.edu through Google Chrome.  The error appears to be due to a recent change in the latest version of Chrome and does not impact other browsers such as IE or Edge.  We are in the process of testing methods to mitigate this error.  For most users, this error can be resolved by closing out of Google Chrome completely and then reopening Chrome.  If this does not resolve the issue, we recommend that you clear your browser cache.  The following are the steps to clear the browser cache and cookies in Google Chrome;

  1. At the top right, click More (three dots).
  2. Click More tools and then Clear browsing data.
  3. At the top, choose a time range. To delete everything, select All time.
  4. Next to "Cookies and other site data" and "Cached images and files," check the boxes.
  5. Click Clear data.

If you continue to receive this error or have any other questions/concerns, please contact the ITS Helpdesk at x8900.

item.title: KCC FOUNDATION SEEKS SCHOLARSHIP READERS
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Looking for a way to impact current and future KCC students? Here's your chance! The KCC Foundation is seeking scholarship readers/ evaluators for the 2020-2021 Foundation Scholarship Application. Nearly four hundred students have completed the Foundation Scholarship Application for the chance at 206 unique awards ranging from $250-$5000 for the year. For some students, receiving these scholarships is the deciding factor in choosing to attend KCC. A scholarship reader/ evaluator will review the application and score the applicant, helping to determine if they receive a scholarship. We understand that your time is valuable, so if you volunteer to read, you evaluate as many applications as you would like.  There is no maximum or minimum to complete. All reading and evaluating is done anonymously and online! Application review takes place from March 18-April 27. You can read from the privacy of your own home or anywhere else you choose. Your input is so important in selecting the 2020-2021 scholarship recipients.  

If you have any questions or to volunteer, contact Jen Zimmerman in the Foundation Office at jzimmerman@kcc.edu or x8251. If you are already a scholarship reader/ evaluator, we thank you for your continued participation. You can expect an email with instructions to log in on March 18. Instructions will be provided to all volunteers.

item.title: Stop the spread of germs
item.description:
Article Description: Some common-sense actions can keep you healthy.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

News outlets everywhere are sharing stories about the coronavirus outbreak. Amid the worry and concern, please use common-sense preventive actions. 

They include: 

  • Stay home if you’re sick, 
  • Cover coughs and sneezes, 
  • Clean frequently touched surfaces, and 
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Employees with health benefits can use the BlueCross BlueShield virtual visit option. This elimintates an office visit for those concerned with exposure to other viruses. 

The Centers for Disease Control recommends washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or using a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available. More resources are on the CDC website.

item.title: Jeans week for the United Way March 9-13
item.description:
Article Description: Wear jeans, help United Way, maybe win a big prize (3/9 - 3/13)
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Denim Week
Wear jeans, help United Way, maybe win a big prize (3/9 - 3/13)

KCC employees are invited to help United Way of Kankakee County reach its goal and continue services for those in need.

The week of March 9 to 13, employees can wear jeans every day for a $20 donation to United Way of Kankakee County.

The $20 donation will include a 1 in 5 chance to win a "Wheels and More" raffle ticket. Therefore, if 40 people pay $20, eight (8) $100 chance tickets will be given away.

Only 1,000 tickets will be sold before the drawing on April 9, so you have great odds to win a $30,000 car (like Sheri and David Cagle did three years ago).  With each raffle ticket, you'll receive a coupon book full of local deals valued over $700! You'll also have the chance to win one of their great secondary raffle prizes. You don't want to miss your chance to win!

To participate in Denim Week, or for more information, bring a $20 donation to David Cagle in the Human Resources Office. You can also increase your odds in winning by purchasing your own Wheels & More ticket for $100. See David to purchase.

Notes: The Denim Week opportunity is separate from the Friday Denim Days associated with the Employee Giving Campaign and United Way fund drive. The drawing for Wheels and More raffle prizes will be on April 9 during the United Way Annual Meeting. Winners need not be present.

item.title: KCC Alumni Association Announces 2020 John M. Fulton Distinguished Alumni
item.description:
Article Description: The KCC Alumni Association has selected Dr. Vicki Gardner to receive the 2020 Kankakee Community College John M. Fulton Distinguished Alumni Award.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Please join the Kankakee Community College (KCC) Alumni Association in congratulating Dr. Vicki Gardner on being selected as the recipient of The John M. Fulton Distinguished Alumni Award.  Dr. Gardner's career at KCC has spanned more than thirty five years.  As vice president for finance and administration since 2001, she oversees college operations including finance, human resources, institutional technology, police and security, physical plant, and environmental and institutional sustainability.  Dr. Gardner is the past president of the Illinois Community College Chief Financial Officers and a member of the Illinois Community College Board Finance Advisory Committee.  She serves on the board of the Kankakee County Training Center for the Disabled Foundation, and is president of her church's Parish Council and finance committee.  She is a past president of the United Way of Kankakee County Board.  

Dr. Vicki Gardner embodies the Distinguished Alumni Award.  After earning her degree from Kankakee Community College she went on to achieve two degrees from Olivet Nazarene University and a doctorate in community college leadership from Ferris State University. She embodies the positive role model of a Kankakee Community College graduate.  Dr. Gardner continues to work hard to attain professional success, while inspiring others to give back to their community.  She is a leader, a mentor, a role model and we are pleased to recognize her as the 2020 John M. Fulton Distinguished Alumni.

​Condolences to Alison Nakaerts and her family on the death of Alison’s brother-in-law, David Fritz. He passed away Tuesday, Feb. 11 at his home. David was a 1997 graduate of the KCC Nursing Program. His wife, Brenda Nakaerts Fritz, is a 1996 graduate of the KCC X-ray Program. Their eldest son, Ethan Fritz, will graduate from KCC this semester with an associates in engineering science and will be transferring to a university in the fall. Their middle son, Connor Fritz, will graduate from Central High school and start at KCC in the fall. Their youngest son, Logan Fritz, will be entering Central High School in the fall.

Visitation will be from 9 a.m.-12 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 22, at the Knapp Funeral Home in Clifton, 415 North Main Street, Clifton.  A memorial service will follow at 12:15 p.m. For more info, https://www.knappfuneralhomes.com/obituaries/David-Fritz-4/.

In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to his boys' college funds. Donations can be dropped off in L355 to Sheila Pfaff or Janet Rosenbrock.

Everyone is invited to wear Cubs, Bears or patriotic attire for the visitation and memorial service.

Alison is an administrative assistant II in the Math, Science, & Engineering Division.

item.title: Phone Etiquette & Transfer Protocols
item.description:
Article Description: Proper telephone etiquette can leave either a positive or negative phone experience for callers and potential customers.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Proper telephone etiquette can leave either a positive or negative phone experience for callers and potential customers.  Sometimes you may have to transfer a caller to another person or department, and unfortunately, this often irritates the caller.  To ensure a positive experience, apply these strategies:

 

  1. State what you can do, not what you cannot do.  You might say, "I can help by letting you talk to Jerry in Finance."  "Should we be disconnected, his extension is 267."  "May I connect you now?"

 

  1. Avoid using the word transfer.  The term transfer can often be irritating to a caller, especially if they have talked to several people.  "Let me connect you to …" or "I'll let you talk with …" provide a positive experience.  Be sure to give them your coworker's extension number.

 

  1. When connecting a call to another department or coworker, share with them the customer's name and any facts you obtained.  The customer will feel they are making progress because they do not have to repeat the information again.  The key is to have just enough facts for your coworker to be prepared to talk with the caller.  You might say, "Debbie, Jerry would like to send a transcript.  When I hang up, he will be on the line."

 

  1. Ask the customer if you can connect their call.  The customer may tell you they have already spoken to multiple people and do not want to talk with anyone else.  Learn as much as you can about the situation, gather the information they seek, and call the customer back.

Then again, they may no longer have time available to talk, but because they have the name and number of the person they need to speak with, they can call them directly when time is available.

 

 

Adapted for Kankakee Community College from, The World of Customer Service, 2012.


Author: Communications Committee
Article Date: 2/13/2020
Expires: 2/28/2020

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Feb. 10, 2020.

Action Items. The board approved the following:

  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for smart room equipment and switch refresh
  • Recommendation to approve bids for a college car, two buses and a fire alarm system

President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • There were no compliance findings in the Schedule of Expenditures of Federal Awards audit. 
  • KCC has been designated as a Military Friendly School for 2020-21.
  • KCC’s Office of Business Affairs was recognized for “Best-in-Class Performance for Healthcare Cost Control” from Gallagher, a risk management services firm.
  • Dr. Kris Condon has been nominated for a Chicago Women’s Conference/South Suburban College Business & Career Institute Star Award. The awards will be presented at South Suburban College on March 13.
  • KCC’s Phi Theta Kappa Chapter has earned 5-star status.
  • The Nursing Department had a 100% pass rate of 2019 RN and LPN graduates.
  • Area chiefs of police and NAACP representatives will have a ceremonial signing of shared principles on Feb. 20 at 11 a.m. in the Iroquois Room. All are welcome to attend.

  • Lt. Gov. Stratton will be on campus Feb. 11 as part of a community college tour.
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…

Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said…

  • Student Life is working to get the new Student Government Association up and running.
  • The Food Pantry will host a second-year anniversary event on Feb. 14.
  • State’s Attorney Jim Rowe is working with KCC's Phi Theta Kappa chapter to bring individuals in the juvenile detention system to campus for tours.
  • She will lead a student panel discussion during the Lt. Governor's campus visit.
  • The ICCB SAC met recently at Parkland Community College to discuss campus activities and pending legislation.

item.title: Stars among us
item.description:
Article Description: Dr. Kristine Condon nominated for a Stars Award
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Dr. Kristine Condon is nominated for a Chicago Women’s Conference/South Suburban College Business & Career Institute Star Award. Two awards will be given to recognize women for their outstanding leadership in business, community activities and education. 

“STAR awardees are role models because they not only focus on achieving their own goals, but through their inspiring actions they profoundly motivate others to do the same,” said Pat Rush, director of Marketing and Communications at South Suburban College.  

Kris’ experiences as a history and social studies educator, paralegal, corporate trainer and community college faculty member contributed to her nomination.  

The nominator wrote about Kris’ commitment to education and her ability to inspire students and others. “It is an honor to nominate Dr. Condon for a STAR Award because it was her first teaching experience at South Suburban College that set the stage for her career in community college education. During her 22-year tenure with KCC, her program and her students have been recognized on a statewide and a national level for their commitment to academic excellence.”

The awards will be presented at the Chicago Women’s Conference at South Suburban College on March 13, 2020.

item.title: Get Fit in February
item.description:
Article Description: Only $25/month per person; enrollment fee waived in February
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

How many of you made a new year's resolution to get in better shape this year?  How many of you have kept this resolution six weeks into the new year? 

To aid you in your fitness goals, KCC is pleased to announce a new "Well on Target" Fitness Program (available through Blue Cross Blue Shield membership).  If you have enrolled in KCC's BCBC health insurance program, you qualify for this program!

The cost of the program is only $25 a month per person, you can go to any of the 10,000+ participating fitness locations near your home or work, and there is no contract or long term commitment.  Normally, there is a one-time $25 enrollment fee, but for the month of FEBRUARY, BCBS will waive this fee – you have to enroll prior to Feb 29, 2020 though.

You will need to enter this coupon code fit4feb at checkout to qualify for the waived fee.

In Kankakee, there are two participating fitness centers: the YMCA, and Planet Fitness. You can "Search Locations" to see what other gyms and fitness centers are located near you. 

There are two ways to enroll: 

  1. Online, go to this link: https://www.bcbsil.com
    1. click on "Register Now" (if you are a new user) or simply click "Log In" and type your user name and password (you can reset your password if you have forgotten it)
    2. you will need your ID number, which is listed below the Subscriber Name on your BCBS insurance card
    3. Click on "View My Plans" located in the top right hand corner
    4. Click on PPO+ under the Column "Plan Type"
    5. Click on "Fitness Program" under "Quick Links"
    6. Click "Search Locations" to see which gyms and fitness centers are located near you
    7. Click "Enroll Now!" to enroll located in the top right corner; or
  2. Simply call 1-888-762-BLUE (2583) Monday through Friday, from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m.  to speak to a dedicated customer service team member who will gladly answer all of your questions and redeem your coupon code of fit4feb

If you have any questions, please contact David at ext, 8128.

item.description:
Article Description: The KCC Veterans Resource Center will be featuring different student and staff veterans each month.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
The KCC Veterans Resource Center will be featuring different student and staff veterans each month. Please feel free to contact Kendra Souligne at ksouligne@kcc.edu or stop by the Veterans Resource Center (room L20A) to share your story with the KCC veteran community.


Veteran Spotlight

 

Name: Dustin Blaylock

Area of study: Associate Degree of Nursing (4th Semester Woot!)

How higher education has impacted my life, goals, and future:  Higher education is allowing me to reach my goal of becoming a Registered Nurse.  Becoming a RN will help secure my financial future and allow me to navigate many different jobs within the nursing field. 

Branch of service: U.S. Army

Military Occupation Code:  

13M-Multiple Launch Rocket System Crewmember (96-99) active,

68W-Combat Medic (2010-18) active,

68W-Combat Medic (2018-present) Reserves

Location of service:  Fort Sill, OK (1996-99), Fort Hood, TX (2010-14), Fort Sam Houston, TX (2014-18), Hobart, IN (2018-present)

Hobbies/Interests: Procrastination, video games, concerts, grilling out, movies, shooting range.  Helping and making people feel better, advocating for and educating Veterans.

Advice for fellow student veterans: I, You, We are not alone!  Let's get to know one another at the Veteran's Center.  We have coffee, soda, and snacks. 

When do you usually hang out in the KCC Vet Center?:

Mondays-0800-0900, after 1200

Tuesdays-possibly all day

Wednesday-possibly all day

Thursdays-after 1200

Fridays-probably not

Favorite Quote:  "As a man changes his own nature, so does the attitude of the world change towards him"

item.description:
Article Description: Business Office receives recognition
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

KCC’s Office of Business Affairs is recognized for “Best-in-Class Performance for Healthcare Cost Control” from Gallagher, a risk management services firm. 
The college was selected because Dr. Vicki Gardner and the Business Affairs team smartly manage our health insurance program. 
Based on data from Gallagher’s 2019 Benefits Strategy & Benchmarking Survey, more than 4,000 organizations responded nationally, and KCC is one of the 408 employers that received the best-in-class recognition. 
Two key themes emerged for KCC and other the best-in-class employers: making insurance plans affordable, and providing related programs that support wellness and access to care.
Congratulations!

Pictured above: Dr. Vicki Gardner, vice president for Business Affairs and David Cagle, director of Human Resources accept the award from the insurance representatives.

item.title: Congratulations to Todd Post
item.description:
Article Description: Coach Post named Daily Journal Male Sports Citizen of the Year
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Congratuations to Todd Post on receiving the Daily Journal's award for Male Sports Citizen of the Year! The following news article is reprinted from The Daily Journal.

Male Sports Citizen of the Year: KCC's Post a baseball lifer
Mason Schweizer | mschweizer@daily-journal.com | 815-937-3300
Jan 29, 2020

When Todd Post began his college basketball career at Danville Community College in 1984, he did so with baseball still as his primary love.
“Baseball was always my first love, but I had an opportunity to play basketball,” Post said of the decision he made after graduating from Crescent-Iroquois High School. “I chose that opportunity and stay close to basketball as a fan.”
After graduating from Danville in 1987, Post returned to his love of baseball when he hit the diamond for a year at Kankakee Community College in 1988 and then two more years at Benedictine University.
Ever since then, baseball has been what Post is most known for. He’s been a coach at KCC since 1993, taking the reins as head coach in 2001. Since he took over, Post has piled up 791 wins, 16 sectional and two regional championships and made a pair of National Junior College Athletic Association Division II World Series appearances, winning it all in 2017.
Because of his excellence as a coach, Post was inducted into the NJCAA Region IV Hall of Fame. That excellence, as well as a career dedicated to various roles at KCC he also has held since becoming a coach, serving as an academic advisor before being named athletic director in 2016, have helped make Post this year’s Daily Journal Male Sports Citizen of the Year.
For Post, it’s the ability to do what he’s dreamed of doing since his high school days as a Golden Eagle that has allowed his success. He spent a few brief years teaching at his alma mater before his move to KCC.
“Since my senior year of high school, I had a vision of [teaching and coaching] as an opportunity, and I can’t say it could have worked out any better,” Post said. “When I got the opportunity to come here as an assistant coach and full-time employee, I wasn’t sure how long I would be an assistant and hoped to be the head coach some day.
“That day happened in 2001 ... and since then, the success we’ve had has been from great assistant coaches, and the college and athletic department have given the program the avenues we’ve needed for that success.”
One of those assistant coaches, current assistant Bryce Shafer, said it’s the attention to detail Post pays to the small things that have added up to this sustained success on a larger scale.
“He’s doing everything right all the time,” Shafer said. “If you’ve ever walked around campus or walked around the field with Coach Post, you know he stops 50 times to pick up a piece of trash.
“He wants everything to run right; he wants the field to look nice, and he wants you to do the right thing,” he added of his current mentor. “He wants you to do what you think is the right thing all the time.”
Post said that attention to detail and urging of doing the right thing are just a few ingredients he has been able to positively implement during his time in Kankakee.
“Recruiting is a big part of that, doing things right and developing these players,” Post said. “Developing socially and athletically, but you also have to put your time in in the classroom and get that degree to give yourself an opportunity to move on at various levels academically.”
During Post’s tenure, 12 players have been drafted by a major league organization or played independent professional baseball and two players he coached, Bryce Redeker and Casey Fletcher, are a couple of the 11 total NJCAA Region IV Hall-of-Famers from KCC.
Seeing his own name added to the previous list of 10 hall-of-famers from the school, a list that features names such as former Major League Baseball player Tom Prince and basketball coaches such as Denny Lehnus and Donnie Denson, a pair of coaches Post said he has modeled himself after, has helped to give him a sense of the effect he has had on others.
“To be voted in, I think that it kind of gives you a feeling that you’ve made an impact on some people,” Post said. “And I appreciate being thought of as a hall-of-fame coach.”
The son of a teacher, Phyllis, Post was influenced by both his mother and father Robert to go down the career path he has navigated successfully. Perhaps the most beautiful part of that path came the past two seasons, when Post was able to coach his son, Dylan, at KCC.
Dylan was able to play baseball for his dad in various youth leagues along the way, culminating at the junior college level. Now a student at Illinois State University, Dylan said his dad has a tough coaching style, something that pairs well with the person he is.
“He’s got good morals; he knows a lot about the game, and he educates a lot of young people,” Dylan said of his dad. “When they play for him, they don’t always see eye to eye because he’s hard on them, but when they move on, they realize he made them a better player and better person in all aspects of life.
”He just wants everyone to succeed.”
Dylan’s athletic career saw plenty of success, as he was on Bishop McNamara’s 2015 football state championship team and the 2017 boys basketball third-place team.
Todd was able to be at both of those games, but there were times, especially during Dylan’s high school basketball and baseball days, when he wasn’t able to watch his son.
A supportive family, including wife Julianne and daughter Jordan, was able to be there while Todd was with the Cavaliers, which Post said is a representation of how vital his family has been to his success.
"You give and you take, but my wife has been very supportive,” Todd said. “She’s never missed a game.”
Just as the Post name has become part of everyday life at KCC, the Cavaliers also have become a part of the Post family. For Dylan, a memory of his dad after the Cavaliers’ 2017 World Series title perfectly symbolizes that.
”He actually slept in his uniform the night they won it, the trophy in his lap,” Dylan said. “It meant a lot to him to win it, and it meant a lot to me seeing him so happy and his hard work pay off.”

item.title: Board Notes - January 2020
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Jan. 13, 2020.
Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Recommendation to approve grant awards
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for a college car
  • Recommendation to approve board policy updates
President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • Coach Todd Post will be inducted into NJCAA Region IV Hall of Fame!
  • We have invited Lt. Governor Julianna Stratton to visit campus, and we’re working on plans with her office to coordinate a visit in the near future.
  • In keeping with recent legislation, KCC makes information about community mental health resources available to our students.
  • We recently renewed our Illinois Green Economy Network membership. Fun fact: KCC was one of IGEN’s founding colleges.
  • Less than 100 campus incidents were reported in 2019, down from more than 400 in 2012. Our public safety program and campus police force are likely responsible for the declines.
  • The KCC Foundation received a gift from Janet V. Leonard’s estate, which will be directed towards the food pantry. 
  • The new ambulance simulator is up and running.
  • The Student Success Center renovation is underway and moving along. 
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • ICCTA nominations are due soon, and legislative day is coming up on May 1.



Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 1/14/2020
Expires: 1/31/2020
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Board Notes - Dec. 2019
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Dec. 10, 2019.
Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Tuition and course reimbursement
  • Recommendation to renew property, casualty and liability insurance programs
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for two buses
  • Recommendation to approve the 2020-21 academic calendar 
  • Recommendation to adopt the tax levy
  • Recommendation to approve bids for exterior masonry repairs and window replacements
  • Recommendation to approve the first reading of board policy updates
  • Recommendation to approve resolutions honoring retirees Cathy Hughes, Delithia Love and Brian Yeoman
  • Recommendation to establish a women’s soccer team.
President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • KCC received the Business of the Year award for Innovation and Technology from the Kankakee Chamber of Commerce. The award recognizes our ATEC building. 
  • The Respiratory Therapist Assistant program held its pinning ceremony on Dec. 7.
  • The Adult Education department received an Innovation Bridge and Transition grant award from the Illinois Community College Board (ICCB) to help incarcerated individuals prepare for, and complete, the high school equivalency exam.
  • The college submitted an application for the Transitional English grant through the ICCB.
  • Senator Pat Joyce was on campus last week to learn more about the college.
  • The Nursing program will host its honor society induction on Dec. 11 and its pinning ceremony on Dec. 12. 
  • We continue to attend high school board meetings to share our partnerships and progress.
  • It is finals week, and campus reflects it as students are ending the semester. 
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • ICCTA will host a telephone meeting in January and face-to-face meeting in March.
Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said …
  • The Student Advisory Council is working to create a student government, now with the help of the new student life coordinator, Rodney Lipscomb.
  • The SAC is preparing for spring 2020 events, and hosted Finals Fuel Week to help students relieve stress prior to finals.
  • Students created a new club called FASH, which stands for Fight Against Student Hunger. Their work benefits the KCC Food Pantry.
  • Phi Theta Kappa took 7 students to its Regional Leadership Conference, and will host their new member induction ceremony in November. PTK is also hosting a Sleep Out fundraiser in November. Participants will sleep outside to experience how homelessness feels.

item.title: Professor co-writes article with tips on Vet Center formation
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

A Veterans Resource Center is among many services KCC offers to veterans.

Two representatives of KCC, Dr. Cari Stevenson and Michael Le Buhn, have written a scholarly article on the process of developing the center, "All In: Developing a Community College Veterans Resource Center with Student Veterans."

Cari is a KCC professor, and co-advisor for the Veterans Association. Le Buhn is a U.S. Army veteran and graduate of KCC and the University of Illinois. He is currently a graduate student at Vanderbilt University. 

The article details the process undertaken to have the center created, including surveying veterans, selecting those to lead the initiative, and considerations to make when selecting the environment of the center, including its location and furniture placement. Seventeen additional research references are also included.

The article was published online in December 2019 in The Journal of Continuing Higher Education, the official journal of the Association of Continuing Higher Education.

item.title: ​ITS department tips to set up out-of-office replies
item.description:
Article Description: Phone and email replies are good to have.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following are tips the Information Technology Services department is sharing to help everyone set up out of office email and phone messages.

Detailed and printable instructions are in the attached article. Or, use these steps:

Create a Rule using Outlook 2016 on campus

  • File > Info > Automatic Replies (Out of Office)
  • Click Send automatic replies; check the box for "Only send during this time range"; enter the starting and ending dates and times
  • Click the tab “Inside My Organization”; enter your away message for people at KCC in the message box; click OK.
  • Click the tab “Outside My Organization (off)”; Click Auto-reply to people outside my organization; Anyone outside my organization; enter your away message those outside the organization in the message box; click OK.

Create a rule using Outlook Web Access:
  • Open Settings (upper right); click View all Outlook settings; Setting dialog box will open
  • Click Automatic replies; Send replies only during this time period; enter the starting and ending dates and times
  • Enter your message to auto send when a new message arrives from someone at KCC
  • Click Send automatic reply messages to senders outside my organization; Send replies to all external senders
  • Enter your message to auto send when a new message arrives from outside of KCC
  • Click Save

Change your phone greeting

To change your Alternate Greeting, follow these steps:
Hint: Before you start, write down exactly what you want to say so you will be able to record it flawlessly.

  1. Press the messages button and enter your password
  2. Press 4 for Setup Options
  3. Press 1 for Greetings & Transfer
  4. Listen to the prompts, press 3 to edit other greetings
  5. Press 3 to edit your alternate greeting
  6. Listen to the prompts and press 1 to re-record your alternate greeting
  7. Record your alternate greeting and press # when you are finished.
  8. Listen to your alternate greeting and follow the prompts to exit when you are finished.
  9. Do NOT turn on unless you are ready to start using it.
When you are ready to turn on your alternate greeting:
  1. Access your voice mail
  2. Press 4 for setup options
  3. Press 1 for greetings & transfer
  4. Listen to the prompts and press 2 to turn on your alternate greeting.
  5. When you choose to turn your alternate greeting on, there will be an option to set an end date. Follow the prompts to take advantage of this option.
  6. Exit your voice mail
  7. If you did not choose an end date for the alternate greeting, remember to turn it off when you return.

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)

Article Content:

​Sen. Pat Joyce's office has an opportunity for a KCC student be be an intern in the senator's office.

The intern will learn about government, business and non-profit organizations. It is an opportunity for leadership and civic engagement at the local and state level. Joyce represents the 40th Legislative District of Illinois, which includes portions of Kankakee County.

Please share this information with KCC students. You can recommend a student, or have students inquire for details.

item.title: Life insurance benefits more than $50,000 are taxable
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​subject to SURS and reflected in Dec 20 check

Article Content:

Life insurance benefits more than $50,000 are taxable and must be included on the W-2 form. The college is required to withhold SURS funds on this amount. Due to this SURS withholding requirement, the SURS deduction will be taken out on the last paycheck of the year. Employees will see a stipend payment with an offsetting benefit deduction on the Dec. 20 paycheck. Please note that income taxes have been taken out automatically over the course of the year. Anyone with questions is invited to call Jane Clark at 815-802-8146.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 12/16/2019
Expires: 12/21/2019
item.author: David Cagle

​Who's Got the FEVER for some CAVALIER PRIDE!

Cheer on the Cavaliers at the "Pack the Place" games with the Women's and Men's Basketball Teams in the Ryan Gymnasium.

On Thursday, January 23, 2020 the Women's Team plays at 5:30 p.m. and the Men's Team plays at 7:30 p.m. The opposing teams are from Kennedy-King College.

Don't forget to show your SPIRIT and SHINE IN PRIDE by wearing KCC scarlet gear.

Also, enjoy a half time show and performance with our very own and spirited Dancing Cavs!

Admission is free with refreshments at both games, while supplies last.

For information contact Rod Lipscomb, student life coordinator, or 815-802-8628.

Sponsored by KCC Athletics, Student Advisory Council and Student Life and Development Office.

Note to KCC employees: Spirit Day/Casual Day guidelines can be followed on January 23, 2020.

item.title: Last chance to register for Holiday tournaments
item.description:
Article Description: Must sign up by 2 pm today - Holiday tournaments: Ping pong, air hockey, bags, and Connect Four
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Must sign up before 2 pm today - Holiday tournaments: Ping pong, air hockey, bags, and Connect Four.

  
Bragging rights and prizes will be on the line during four KCC holiday tournaments: ping-pong, air hockey, bags, and Connect Four.

Details

  • All KCC employees and student workers are invited to participate.
  • Register by 2 p.m., Friday, Dec 13 at the Police and Public Safety desk near the Library.
  • Matches will begin Monday, Dec 16 and will continue until champions are crowned shortly before noon on Dec. 20.
  • Brackets will be posted at the tournament sites.
  • Entry fee in each sport is a donation to KCC's Food Pantry (on your honor).

The sports

  • Ping pong - single elimination tournament.  Each game will be played to 21, and the winner must win by 2. The match is best 2 of 3. Participants can use their own paddles if they choose. Scoring will use the honor system. The top two players will receive gift cards.

  • Air hockey - single elimination tournament. Each game will be played to 7. The match is best 2 of 3. Common sense rules apply, such as players not being able to touch the puck with their hands and not crossing over the middle line. The top two players will receive gift cards.

  • Bags - double elimination tournament. Partners/teams will be randomly drawn and paired. Each game will be played to 21. The match is best 2 of 3. The top two teams will receive gift cards.

  • Connect4 - single elimination tournament.  The match is best 2 of 3. The top two players will receive gift cards.

  • For more information, contact David Cagle at 815-802-8128 or email dcagle@kcc.edu

Author: Liz Becvar for David Cagle
Article Date: 12/13/2019
Expires: 12/14/2019
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: Retirement thanks
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

I want to express my sincere thankfulness for the support everyone has given me over the past 24.11 years. This support has made working at KCC more enjoyable and more rewarding. Also, thank you for attending my retirement party, gifts, cards, phone calls, emails, flowers, cake, kind words and hugs.

As I look forward to the next chapter of my life, I will certainly miss everyone. I’m so glad I had the opportunity to share my life with KCC family (students and employees).

- Delithia Love
Author: Delithia Love
Article Date: 12/13/2019
Expires: 1/10/2020

item.title: Network Downtime This Weekend
item.description:
Article Description: ITS will be performing maintenance on the KCC network beginning 12/14 between 12 AM and 2 AM. Click the story for add'l information.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​ITS will be performing maintenance on the KCC network beginning Saturday,12/14 between the hours of 12 AM and 2 AM. Internet access for the campus will be impacted during this time.

Users who go to www.kcc.edu will be greeted with a maintenance page where they will be able to access online resources such as e-mail, online courses, etc...

PLEASE NOTE: Registration will be unavailable during this time.

This planned maintenance is part of a bigger ITS project, the upgrade of our core network switch, which will take place over the holiday break. Information regarding the specifics of this project will be reported in Update.

If you have any questions or concerns, regarding either project, please contact the ITS Help Desk at x.8900

item.author: Michael OConnor

item.title: Board of Trustees Meeting Highlights
item.description:
Article Description: Info from the Board of Trustees' December meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Dec. 10, 2019

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition and course reimbursement
  • Recommendation to renew property, casualty and liability insurance programs
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for two buses
  • Recommendation to approve the 2020-21 academic calendar
  • Recommendation to adopt the tax levy
  • Recommendation to approve bids for exterior masonry repairs and window replacements
  • Recommendation to approve the first reading of board policy updates
  • Recommendation to approve resolutions honoring retirees Cathy Hughes, Delithia Love and Brian Yeoman
  • Recommendation to establish a women's soccer team.

 President's Report. Dr. Boyd said…

  • KCC received the Business of the Year award for Innovation and Technology from the Kankakee Chamber of Commerce. The award recognizes our ATEC building.
  • The Respiratory Therapist Assistant program held its pinning ceremony on Dec. 7.
  • The Adult Education department received an Innovation Bridge and Transition grant award from the Illinois Community College Board (ICCB) to help incarcerated individuals prepare for, and complete, the high school equivalency exam.
  • The college submitted an application for the Transitional English grant through the ICCB.
  • Senator Pat Joyce was on campus last week to learn more about the college.
  • The Nursing program will host its honor society induction on Dec. 11 and its pinning ceremony on Dec. 12.
  • We continue to attend high school board meetings to share our partnerships and progress.
  • It is finals week, and campus reflects it as students are ending the semester.

 Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • ICCTA will host a telephone meeting in January and face-to-face meeting in March.

 Student Trustee's Report. Daisy Solorzano said …

  • The Student Advisory Council is working to create a student government, now with the help of the new student life coordinator, Rodney Lipscomb.
  • The SAC is preparing for spring 2020 events, and hosted Finals Fuel Week to help students relieve stress prior to finals.
  • Students created a new club called FASH, which stands for Fight Against Student Hunger. Their work benefits the KCC Food Pantry.
  • PTK is looking forward to the national Catalyst convention to be held in Texas next year.


Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 12/11/2019
Expires: 12/20/2019
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Tidings of Cheer! Here are Holiday Buffet details: 12/20/19
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

It's time to gather in the grand tradition of an all employee (faculty & staff, full- & part-time, student workers) holiday party beginning at 12:15 p.m. on Friday, Dec. 20 in the College Center.

KCC will cease operations at noon on Dec. 20. This will allow employees to gather for the celebration. Following the luncheon and party, all employees are invited to use the remaining afternoon hours to take down holiday decorations and prepare for the new year before adjourning for winter break.

Luncheon details

If you are eating lunch, please bring a dish to share so there can be enough food for everyone. Bring your covered dish to the Cavalier Room by noon.

To ensure variety, if your last name begins with…

  • A-H, please bring a dessert
  • I-Z, please bring a side dish (e.g. hot dish, salad or appetizer)

* Arena Food Service offers side dishes for purchase. 

Other procedures/info:

  • The meat, plates, napkins, plastic ware, bread and condiments will be provided.
  • Bring a drink, too; beverages will not be provided.
  • The room will be cleaned immediately afterward, so please pick up your dishes before leaving.
  • We will eat in the College Center to accommodate more people.
  • No need to line up early. Sit at numbered tables in the College Center. At 12:10 p.m., a random drawing will determine the order of tables to go through the line.
  • Food tables will have selections on both sides to speed up the line.
  • Everyone is ENCOURAGED to dress in FESTIVE (yet appropriate) HOLIDAY ATTIRE, such as Fuzzy Slippers, Crazy socks & hats, and of course your Favorite Holiday Sweater (ugly or not).  There will be an opportunity to showcase your wardrobe in a Holiday group picture.

    The luncheon will conclude with comments from KCC President Dr. Boyd.
Author: Human Resources
Article Date: 12/11/2019
Expires: 12/21/2019

item.title: KCC Food Pantry (Food for Thought) Thank you!
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The KCC Food Pantry (Food for Thought) would like to send a huge THANK YOU to so many of you who went above and beyond this holiday season to decrease food insecurity in our students:

  • The Curriculum and Academic Standards Committee (CAS) and Dr. Dave Naze for approving the addition of language to all Master Syllabi regarding the services Food for Thought provides.
  • The KCC Criminal Justice Club and Professor Bridget Bertrand-Essington for their "Stuff the Squad" food drive.
  • The KCC Horticulture Club and Professor Katelynn Ohrt for donating a portion of the proceeds of the poinsettia sale to the food pantry.
  • The Continuing Education & Career Services Department for asking employers represented at our job fair to donate food.
  • The English Department, Terese Roberson, Marketing and the Foundation for sponsoring four Thanksgiving baskets for needy students.
  • Culture of Caring Committee and Kim Schott for creating the Christmas Giving Tree for donations to Food for Thought.
  • The Division of Finance & Administration for donating to Food for Thought in lieu of Christmas gifts. 

This semester the food pantry saw on average 145 students a week; your ongoing support is so appreciated. Collectively, your generosity continues to humble and amaze me. Food for Thought will celebrate its second anniversary in February; stay tuned for news of our celebration!  


Author: Francesca Catalano
Article Date: 12/5/2019
Expires: 12/17/2019
item.author: Alison Nakaerts

Article Content:

Announcing a wonderful opportunity to help support the KCC student food pantry this holiday season!

A Christmas Giving Tree is located just outside of the KCC Welcome Center and is filled with "wish tags" of popular items for our student food pantry. Simply select a wish item from the tree and place your purchased (unwrapped) gift under the tree or inside the donation bin labeled "KCC Food Pantry." All gift items will be donated to the KCC student food pantry and will be accepted through Friday, Dec. 20.

If you have any questions, please contact Kim Schott or any member of the Culture of Caring Committee. 

We are especially grateful for your support!

- KCC Student Food Pantry & Culture of Caring Committee

item.title: Congratulations state champ!

Rogers is a sophomore at Herscher High School, and his coach is Rob Grosso.

item.title: Festive tree lights up annual display
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

KCC has a tree in the annual Gallery of Trees exhibit at the Kankakee County Historical Society.

Tree crew chief was Alison Nakaerts, who picked "Cars" from a number of options related to Disney movies. She did a fantastic job integrating "Cars" the movie with words and symbols related to the journey a KCC student takes (certificate, degree, Lifelong Learning, etc.).

"I would like to thank Diane Soltis from marketing for her collaboration and work on the ornaments, Ellen Schmidt for her support in accomplishing my vision and John Bordeau for showing me how to use his laser engraver," Alison said. "Participants must be not-for-profit, so I would also like to thank the KCC Foundation and staff for allowing us to represent KCC via the Foundation."

Over 2,000 area students as well as numerous community members visit the Gallery of Trees in December. The public can vote for a favorite tree, voting is separated into adult favorite and children's favorite. If you get a chance, visit the tree display any time from Dec. 1-30 -- and vote! 

Having the tree on display fits well with the college goal to be more visible in the community. Alison and other members of the Strategic Enrollment Management Recruitment subcommittee are among those assisting in this effort. 

The museum is at 801 S 8th Ave, Kankakee. More details and museum hours are on the Gallery of Trees page. Suggested donation for visitors to the Gallery of Trees is $2.

There's also an article in the KCC newsroom with a few more details.

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 11/25/2019
Expires: 1/1/2020

item.title: Shop With A Cop
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

From the KCC police department,

Due to a combination of many circumstances, unfortunately we are not going to be able to organize and hold our traditional shop with a cop event at the campus this year. As many of you know and for those who don't the police department has sponsored an event for a number of years where we raise money for gifts for KCC student's children in need.

 

 It took a tremendous effort from our college community with help from the nursing department, the Safety Committee members, the KCC police department, and others from all across the college to shop for and wrap the gifts, host the dinner with pizza, drinks and cookies, a fantastic volunteer Santa and Mrs. Claus, decorating the college center and all the crafts, storytelling, and pictures on Santa's lap.

 

It is with great sadness that that event will not be able to happen this year. But as an alternative the police department is still going to sponsor "Shop with a Cop". We have decided to raise money for gifts for children in need in our area. We will purchase a variety of toys,  wrap the gifts, and then deliver them to KCC students with children, and any extra gifts purchased will go to the children in various shelters in Kankakee that help  to serve our community.

 

If you wish to contribute please give your kind donations to Eric Springer or Travis miller by the end of the day on Wednesday November 27th. Also by Wednesday the 27th please share with Eric or Travis the names and contact information of KCC students with children in need. All the money donated will go to help the children. Once the gifts are ready we will be reaching out to those families to make sure the children share in the joy of the holiday season! Thanks in advance for helping bring happiness and hope to those children in need!

Author: Eric Springer and Travis Miller
Article Date: 11/21/2019
Expires: 11/27/2019
item.author: Travis Miller

item.description:
Article Description: KCC Food Pantry Student Club raffling off Thanksgiving Dinner baskets!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The KCC Food Pantry Student Club is raffling off free Thanksgiving Dinner baskets to students and would like your help! If your department would like to sponsor a basket please let Francesca know by Monday 11/18 with the completed basket delivered to the Food Pantry by Friday November 22nd.   We are aiming for three baskets but if there is more collected we will raffle out more.

Contents of each basket are up to the department; suggestions include shelf stable items like gravy, boxes of stuffing and mashed potatoes, sweet potatoes, rolls, green beans, corn, pie and whatever else you would like to include.  Currently three frozen turkeys have been donated by Terese Roberson, so we will add that to your basket.  If we have more interest we will purchase more turkeys.   

Thank you and please let me know if you have any questions!
Francesca

item.title: Retention software demonstrations
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​As I hope most of you are aware, the members of the Strategic Enrollment Management Team (faculty, administrators, and staff) have been reviewing retention software designed to improve student success by increasing the opportunity for faculty, advisor, and student interaction on behalf of the student. 

This new system will replace the current Early Alert system and will be much more interactive and effective.

Two finalists have been selected. They will be on campus for your review next week. Much like when we selected a new learning management system, we want to ensure everyone has an equal opportunity to see the products. Each vendor will give three demos. 

Again, you will most likely be consistently using this software, so your input on the products and their capabilities is invaluable!

Save these dates! Nov. 19 & Nov. 21

Nov. 19 - Aviso Retention Software, Room  **D152. Choose one:

  • 10-11:30 a.m.
  • 2-3:30 p.m.
  • 4-5:30 p.m.
Nov. 21 - Ellucian Advise Software, Room D140. Choose one:
  • 10-11:30 p.m.
  • 2-3:30 p.m.
  • 4-5:30 p.m

If you have any questions about the software and/or its capabilities and purpose, please reach out to the members of the software selection team: Jen Huggins, Josh Gregoire, Meredith Purcell, or Kate Wachtor. 

Author: Meredith Purcell

item.title: Student Success Center Update
item.description:
Article Description: Library furniture available for re-use
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​​Library furniture available for re-use

Article Content:

​The Project to convert the existing library into the new student success center is scheduled to begin late this semester. A construction barrier will be installed at the library entrance beginning December 13th, with demolition to start on December 16th. New construction will follow beginning January 13th 2020.

In preparation, all of the existing furniture will be moved out of the space not to return. This includes wooden library tables and chairs, computer tables and chairs, office furniture, soft seating furniture, and other miscellaneous pieces. In an effort to re-use as much of this as possible and to reduce storage requirements, if there are any furniture needs in your area please submit a request by email to Rich Soderquist at rsoderquist@kcc.edu . All requests will be collected. Re-use decisions will be made on optimum use and maximum benefit to the college as a whole. The items will then need to be re-assigned in the college’s capital asset inventory. Any questions please call Rich at ext. 8173.

Author: Rich Soderquist
Article Date: 11/13/2019
Expires: 1/20/2020

item.title: Halloween 2019 Follow Up
item.description:
Article Description: And the winners are...(in case you haven't seen the KCC FB post.)
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

...​Business Affairs/Human Resources/Accounting as 1st choice from the staff side. W102 won the student choice award. Also, staff chose Gregg Beglau (aka Deloris Umbridge) from Harry Potter for Best Costume. The students chose Chris Gibson (aka Bob) from Bob's Burgers for Best Costume.

I think this was one of the best competitions we have had over the last 12 years. Everyone is really getting involved and the decorations were amazing. I love seeing how this gets everyone around campus and into other departments.

The voting went as follows:

Best Theme--Staff Choice

BAHR/Accounting (Toy Story) - 24, W102 (Bob's Burgers) - 15, Adult Ed (Harry Potter) - 11, L355 (Scooby Doo) - 9, SSS/UP/TRIO Talen Search (Target) - 8, ConEd/Career Services (Bee the "I" in K_ND) - 5, Financial Aid (Alice in Wonderland) - 3, Advising (Super Store) - 1

Best Costume--Staff Choice

Gregg Beglau-13, Michelle Hasik-8, Beth Nunley-6, Lily Fitzpatrick-5, Liz Becvar & Jose de Silva-4, Kendra Souligne-3, David Cagle, Janet Fager, Michael Reising, & Janet Rosenbrock-2, Michele Buikema, Lesley Cooper, Juli Gereg, Chris Gibson, Tinker Parker, Mary Posing, & Karen Richards-1

Best Theme--Student Choice

W102-21, L355-5, Adult Ed-2, BAHR/Accounting-2, CECS-2, SSS/UB/TRIO TS-2, Advising-1, Financial Aid-0

Best Costume--Student Choice

Chris Gibson-6, Gregg Beglau-3, Jazzmyn Johnson-2, Tina, David Cagle, Joselyn Martinez, Sarah Reyling, & Janet Rosenbrock-1

(And the winner of our Scooby Doo Guess the Villains game was Amanda Hubert with 9 out of 10 right. I'll post the answers on Monday.)

         

Way to go everyone! Next year will be even better!

Sheila Pfaff, Halloween Coordinator

item.title: 12th Annual KCC Halloween Contest is Underway
item.description:
Article Description: Take a walk around campus today! You never know what you'll see!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Today is KCC's 12th annual Halloween Contest between departments. Take a walk around campus and check out all the participants.  Then stop by the Security Desk in front of the library and place your vote for your favorite theme and your favorite individual costume.

If you are part of a theme, you cannot vote for favorite theme, but definitely vote for your favorite individual costume. Your favorite individual does not have to be part of a theme.

We are giving a prize for student choice as well so make sure you use the orange ballots for all staff voting. Since student workers are staff and can go to all areas, they can vote as staff. Students cannot go to all areas so that is why there is a separate ballot. We want to be fair to all areas.

The following departments are participating: Adult Education, Advising, Business Affairs/HR/Accounting, Career Services & Continuing Education, Financial Aid, L355 Academic Office, Student Support Services/Upward Bound/TRIO Talent Search, and W102 Academic Office.

item.title: Board Notes October 2019
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Oct. 15, 2019

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Recommendation to accept grant awards
  • Recommendation to solicit bids for an ambulance simulator
  • Recommendation to purchase curriculum management software 
  • Recommendation to approve supplemental tax provision
  • Recommendation to approve the final phase of the HVAC renovation
  • Recommendation to approve the Student Success Center abatement and construction projects

President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • Dr. Larry Huffman wrote about the development of the campus grounds for the KCC archives. The piece chronicles the tree-planting initiative and campus growth through 2001.
  • Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act brings opportunity to develop education and training around the emerging cannabis industry. ICCB will select 8 community colleges as pilots for industry training, and it’s expected the applications for permits will begin Jan. 1. To prepare, the college is determining how to integrate competencies into our existing programs, and considering if we build a new certificate or degree program.

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • A key topic at the ICCTA meeting was cannabis legislation and cannabis production programs on campuses. He reinforced Dr. Boyd’s report, and together they discussed with the board how the cannabis industry’s growth could affect KCC programming.

Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said …
  • The ICCB Student Advisory Council elected Daisy its vice chair. She will be able to review policy and advise the ICCB on system-wide issues.
  • Student Advisory Council hosted a number of campus events – Constitution Day, Hispanic Heritage Month, two Pack the Place events, and the Red Flag Campaign.
  • The first Chat ‘N Chew was a chance to meet students and talk about their needs.
  • Phi Theta Kappa took 7 students to its Regional Leadership Conference, and will host their new member induction ceremony in November. PTK is also hosting a Sleep Out fundraiser in November. Participants will sleep outside to experience how homelessness feels. 


​

Author: Kari Nugent

item.description:
Article Description: Five upcoming events.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

October is LGBTQ History Month. Please join the GSA at any of the following events. A flier with information is also available. 

  • Monday, October 7th 2 PM in D-214: "Mental Health and the LGBTQ Community," a presentation by Dr. Jessica Norman of Transformative Growth Counseling, in conjunction with the Psychology Club.
  • Friday, October 11th 7 PM "Celebration of National Coming Out Day" at St. John's UCC 1045 W. River St, in conjunction with Prism from ONU.
  • Thursday, October 17th all day "Spirit Day."  Wear purple to show LGBTQ young people that you are dedicated to ensuring they are able to live authentically and without fear of bullying.
  • Thursday, October 24th 4 PM in D-140 a screening of the movie Milk, a biography of civil rights activist Harvey Milk.
  • Monday, October 28th 1 PM location TBD "Genetics and Sexuality," a presentation by Dr. Francesca Catalano.

item.title: Halloween Competition 2019 Coming Soon!!
item.description:
Article Description: ​I hope everyone is ready for some fall fun once again.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The 12th Annual KCC Halloween Competition is just around the corner! 

The annual Halloween contest will be on Thursday, Oct. 31, 2019. This will be the twelfth year that areas of the college have competed against each other for the best Halloween costumes and department theme. I hope to see everyone from last year (and maybe more) join in on the fun again this year.

The competition was very close last year. L355 has been participating for all of the past 11 years (since we started this whole thing we have to keep competing) and we were very excited to win—barely! I can't wait to see what caldron of fun everyone has come up with this year! 

Each area's theme should be kept under wraps to make the day more exciting. As an incentive, the winning department will keep the "Fabulous" Traveling Tacky Trophy and will be able to show it off until the 2020 competition.

There will also be a Traveling Tacky Trophy for best costume which can be kept on display until next year. The winner of the best costume does not have to be part of one of the office/area themes. We have had a tie for the last two years for best individual costume and one individual each year was not part of a theme.

Those who are part of a department theme cannot vote for best theme, but should definitely vote for best individual costume.

If your department or staff in your area would like to get into the spirit of the day, please contact me, spfaff@kcc.edu or 815-802-8700 by Friday, Oct. 25.

Sheila Pfaff, L355 Academic Office

item.title: Inauguration is Oct. 30!
item.description:
Article Description: Invitations are in the mail to all KCC employees.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
KCC will host an inauguration to induct Dr. Michael Boyd as 7th president of Kankakee Community College. 
The ceremony will take place Wednesday, Oct. 30 at 4 p.m. in the Harold and Jean Miner Memorial Library on KCC’s Riverfront Campus, and a reception will follow the ceremony. All faculty, staff and administrators are invited and will receive invitations to the events. Students, alumni and the community are also invited to the inauguration and celebration.
KCC faculty and administrators have the option to be members of the academic procession. Those in the procession will be dressed in academic regalia. Participating in the procession is not required. If you prefer not to, we would be honored to have you join the ceremony as a member of the audience.
KCC's ceremonial mace and a new chains-of-office medallion will be a part of the ceremony.
Colleges often host a week of activities during inauguration week. If you’re interested in hosting an event on campus for students and the community, please let me know by Sept. 27.
This is the first time KCC will host an inauguration, and we are excited to incorporate this important academic ritual into our culture and history. The community already holds the college in high regard, but an academic ceremony like this one elevates community members’ perception of the college and reinforces that academics are a priority. We hope that you will join us.
If you have questions, contact me via email or call me at ext. 8256.
Author: Kari Nugent

The entirety of the Humanities and Social Sciences Division encourages you to join us in celebrating transfer institutions during Transfer Week, September 23-27.
HSS folks (faculty, staff, and administrators) will represent their alma maters on Wednesday, September 25, the day of the Transfer Fair, by wearing their college gear (t-shirts, sweatshirts, etc). In addition, they'll be hanging pennants from their alma maters on their doors or in prominent places in their offices beginning on Monday that week. We hope you will all join us in the fun and likewise take time to talk with interested students about your alma maters and answer any questions students may have about those schools.
Thanks!

item.title: Board Notes - Sept. 2019
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the recent Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Sept. 9, 2019

Information. The Board heard the following:
Kelly Myers shared and update from the KCC Foundation.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Recommendation to approve an on-the-job training contract through WIOA.
  • Recommendation to solicit bids to remodel the library into the Student Success Center.
President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • The semester is off to a great start. 
  • Employee Giving Kickoff was a success and fundraising continues.
  • Donor engagements have expanded relationships and resulted in a new $50,000 gift to benefit the Hospitality program.  
  • We’ve made connections with our legislators Lindsay Parkhurst, Tom Bennet and Toi Hutchinson to help educate them about the college and encourage them to invest in KCC.
  • We extended the lease agreement at South Extension Center, which is home to our successful Fast Path program cohort. 
  • The KCC Foundation is offering a Planned Giving Seminar at KCC on Oct. 10. It will be facilitated by KCC Foundation board member Mark Smith.  
  • Work is underway to write a Workforce Equity Grant.

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next ICCTA meeting is Sept. 13-14 in Springfield. A key topic will be cannabis programs on campuses, expanding mental health services for students and how upcoming legislative bills could affect community colleges in the next two years.

Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said …
  • Club Rush was a success. 
  • Student Advisory Council has new members.
  • Constitution Day is happening on Sept. 17. Students can register to vote at the event. 
  • KCC’s Phi Theta Kappa chapter will attend the PTK Illinois Regional Leadership Conference 
  • Daisy is running for an officer position with the Illinois Community College Board’s Student Advisory Council.

item.title: Food for Thought
item.description:
Article Description: Food Pantry Information
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

I would like to share with you all some exciting news about the KCC Food Pantry!  Thanks to a generous staff donor, we have added a chest freezer and are providing students with ready-to-eat frozen lunches.  Additionally, one of our faculty members has pledged to donate a refrigerator. This semester the Food Pantry has been averaging 100 visits a week by students.  We have expanded hours into the evening and are now open 46 hours a week this semester.  Finally, I was invited to speak with Whitney Thompson next week at the Forum for Excellence meeting, Illinois' premier CTE and AE professional development event.  Below is a synopsis of our talk.

 

Whitney Thompson, Illinois Community College Board

Francesca Catalano, Kankakee Community College

Food insecurity among college students is growing at an alarming rate. Research has indicated as high as 56% of college students, particularly those enrolled in community colleges, are facing food scarcity on a daily basis. In early 2019, the ICCB conducted a survey on how community colleges were addressing food insecurity on their campus. This breakout will also feature the grassroots efforts that transpired at Kankakee Community College to address food insecurity. Participants will learn about research on this topic, results of the survey conducted by the ICCB, as well as resources colleges and students can tap into.


Author: Francesca Catalano
Article Date: 9/17/2019
Expires: 10/2/2019
item.author: Alison Nakaerts

item.title: Library Renovation News
item.description:
Article Description: Information about the upcoming renovation.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​As the renovation project gets underway, here are some more details about what to expect.

The library will be completely moved out of our current space by the end of the fall semester.  Demolition will begin over the winter break.

Our temporary service point for the spring and summer semesters will be in D212.  Some of our material will be available in D212, and the rest will be available upon request, and stored elsewhere on campus.  If you would like to offer input about what material needs to be readily accessible for your students, please use our feedback form.

The Student Success Center (including the library, tutoring services, and Instructional Technology & Faculty Development) is scheduled to open for the fall semester, 2020.

For more Frequently Asked Questions, renderings of the finished space, and photos and updates about the process, visit our renovation website.  You can subscribe to the Updates page to make sure that new information always lands in your inbox.

If you have more questions, please reach out so that I can add them to the FAQ section, and check back there for more information as we post updates.

As you should know, one of our new strategic goals is to "Promote development opportunities to enhance KCC employee skills and knowledge." 

In alignment with this goal, we are pleased to offer professional development opportunities, right here at KCC, free of charge to KCC employees this fall.  It is being offered through our Continuing Education and Career Services department to all full time employees, adjunct faculty currently teaching this semester, and to part time employees who work an average of 20 hours per week.  Prior to enrolling, employees must first receive supervisor approval.

item.title: Inauguration planning underway
item.description:
Article Description: Welcome Dr. Michael Boyd at KCC's 7th president on Oct. 30.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
I’m excited to share that KCC will host an inauguration to induct Dr. Michael Boyd as 7th president of Kankakee Community College. 
The ceremony will take place Wednesday, Oct. 30 at 4 p.m. in the Harold and Jean Miner Memorial Library on KCC’s Riverfront Campus.
A reception will follow the ceremony. All faculty, staff and administrators are invited and will receive invitations to the events. Students and the community are also invited to the inauguration and celebration.
KCC faculty and administrators will have the option to wear academic regalia. The event will include delegates from other academic institutions. KCC's ceremonial mace and a chains-of-office medallion, like the one pictured in this article, will be a part of the ceremony. 
Colleges often host a week of activities during inauguration week. If you’re interested in hosting an event on campus for students and the community, please let me know.
This is the first time KCC will host an inauguration, and we are excited to incorporate this important academic ritual into our culture and history. The community already holds the college in high regard, but an academic ceremony like this one elevates community members’ perception of the college and reinforces that academics are a priority. We hope that you will join us.
If you have questions, contact me via email or call me at ext. 8256.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 8/29/2019
Expires: 9/13/2019
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: SURS Presentation and KCC's SUAA Chapter Meeting
item.description:
Article Description: SURS presentation on Sept. 24 on buyouts and SMP
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

KCC's SUAA Chapter Meeting – submitted by Linda Guinn, KCCAA and SUAA President

 

On Sept 24, in the Iroquois Room, we are honored to have SURS Executive Director Martin Noven and SURS Head of Legislative Affairs Kristen Houch give a presentation on the current SURS buyouts and provide an update on the Self-Managed Plan. They will share information that is relevant to every employee, as well as retirees.   

 

Because we want everyone to have the opportunity to attend, Mr. Noven and Ms. Houch will be giving the presentation twice. We will have our KCCAA Chapter Business Meeting in between the two presentations. Choose either the 11:30 am presentation and the chapter business meeting afterwards OR the chapter business meeting at 12:30 pm and the 1:15 pm presentation afterwards. You do not need to register prior to Sept 24, and we realize that not everyone can stay for the entire time.

 

Schedule:

11:10-11:30 am Registration

11:30-12:30 pm Martin Noven and Kristen Houch Presentation (including time for audience questions and discussion)

12:30-1:15 pm KCC SUAA Chapter Business Meeting (Registration continues)

1:15-2:15 pm Martin Noven and Kristen Houch Repeat Presentation (including time for audience questions and discussion)

 

It is perfectly okay to bring your lunch to eat during the presentation/chapter meeting. Coffee, tea, water, and cake for dessert will be provided. 

 

Employees, the 3% cap on salaries went back up to 6% for community colleges SOLELY because of SUAA's WORK this spring with legislators! If it were not for SUAA, you would have been excluded! (This cap is calculated for all KCC employees. Of course, SUAA opposes any cap, but 6% is much better than 3%.)

 

Bring a new member with you to this event, and you will BOTH be entered in this year's membership raffle! Membership applications and payroll deduction forms will be available. As always, maintaining and growing our membership is important to our influence in Springfield; and our ability to do so depends on you. Talk to your colleagues about joining SUAA; enroll your spouse or partner! They benefit from SUAA's efforts too.

 

RAFFLE PRIZES!

 

Dinner for Two ($50 gift card) at Brickstone Restaurant (2)

 

$25 Amazon Gift Card (2)

 

Drawing for all prizes will be held at the final SUAA event for the year in April 2020!  Bring new members to the Iroquois Room to join SUAA on September 24, and both you and the new member will be entered in the raffle. Recruit 2 members, get 2 raffle tickets, etc. Spouses and partners count too! Maximum of one prize per person.

 

Unfortunately, we can not video this presentation for later viewing, so please make your arrangements now to attend. 

 

See you in the Iroquois Room on September 24!
