item.title: Board Notes - Aug. 2019
item.description:
Article Description: Information from the latest Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Aug. 12, 2019


Information. The Board heard the following:
  • Dr. Jose da Silva shared results from the Student Satisfaction Inventory.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Recommendation to accept grant awards
  • Recommendation to approve the board meeting schedule
  • Recommendation to approve the FY20 budget 
  • Recommendation to approve engineering services for abatement in the library

President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • Van Fab, Inc. in Union Hill suffered a fire recently.  KCC, in collaboration with the Workforce Board and the Economic Alliance, has reached out to Van Fab to offer assistance.  KCC’s workforce services will be able to place many workers who may be displaced.  We have also offered a Job Fair to work on placing these people back into positions. 
  • NIMS Training – KCC’s leadership team reviewed our plan and command structure today. We’ll have more to offer later in the year, but please know that we have plans in place. 
  • Estate Plans - The college received a bequest from Janet V. Leonard, which is another pleasant surprise.  We hope the trend continues, and we’ve responded by putting together a Planned Giving Seminar on Oct. 10 facilitated by Mark Smith.  
  • Donor Stewardship - Also, Kelly and I have worked together to schedule a number of donor lunches, and these have provided an excellent opportunity for me to learn more about our community’s supporters.  
  • Leader Development - Over 20 of KCC’s staff and administrators attended the Global Leadership Summit hosted by Van Drunen Farms.
  • Legislator Education - The Governor’s budget allocated specific sums of money for each state official along with sole discretion for distribution of these funds.  I’ve sent communication to all of our elected officials with the aim of opening up conversation about these funds and how the community college may be the best way of maximizing the impact of these resources.  We still know very little about how and when these resources are available, but please know that we are doing all we can to encourage our local politicians to invest in KCC.
  • South Extension Center - Though we are near the conclusion of our current lease agreement with RMC for the SEC, the lease includes an option to extend.  We recently sent a letter to RMC informing them of our intent to extend the lease agreement.  
  • In the News – 17 student-athletes have received NJCAA honors for academic achievement during 2018/19 school year. Lady Cavaliers basketball team earned spot on the Women’s Basketball Coaches Association honor roll for two year colleges.
  • New Start - Perhaps the best news - we have arrived at the start of the 2019/20 fall semester.  Faculty Inservice – 8/14-15.  Students arrive on 8/19.
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next ICCTA meeting is Sept. 13-14 in Springfield. A key topic will be cannabis programs on campuses. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said …
  • The Summer Bash was a success. SAC raised $138 through concession sales.
  • Eight TRiO students attended planned cultural activities. 
  • Upcoming events include Club Rush and Snack ‘N Chat.

item.title: New campus master plan guides future projects
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The Campus Facilities Master Plan was approved by the Board of Trustees at their July meeting. The purpose of the plan is to address existing concerns, provide for current needs, and accommodate future needs at the Riverfront campus. 

The process to develop the plan began in late 2018 with an inventory and assessment of existing facilities. Input was then gathered from a broad spectrum of faculty, staff, and students through 13 focus groups that were conducted with the architectural firm. Given existing conditions and with the input of the institution’s constituents, several iterations of plans were considered to address current and future needs. The culmination of the process resulted in the Campus Master Plan.

The plan will serve as a guide for potential future facilities projects. Whether or when particular projects are actually executed will be dependent on institutional priorities, available resources, and Board approval to proceed.

Author: Dr. Vicki Gardner, vice president for Finance and Administration

Expires: 7/26/2019

item.title: Coming Soon! VidGrid video platform
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Coming Soon!

KCC will be licensing the VidGrid video platform which will be available directly in Canvas.  Video is a powerful medium to connect with and engage students online.  VidGrid provides exciting new ways to enhance content delivery, interaction, and feedback in all of our courses.

Key features include:

  • Screencast and webcam video creation
  • Basic video editing
  • Unlimited collection storage
  • Track video views by student
  • In-video questions and comments
  • Auto-captioning

What's happening next…

  • Two new course navigation links will be added to ALL Canvas course shells the week of August 5th.
    1. VidGrid Recording – this link is visible only to teachers in Canvas
    2. VidGrid Login – this link is visible to teachers and students
  • All faculty will see a new VidGrid course on their Canvas Dashboard with information that includes:
    • Getting Started
    • Best Practices
    • Upcoming Training Dates

More information will be sent out once VidGrid has been deployed and made available in all courses.

item.title: New 3-year strategic plan approved
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​I'm happy to share with you that the Board of Trustees approved a new Strategic Plan on Monday, July 8.  

Collaboration on this plan started in the fall of 2017, and represents input from community leaders, employees, and students.

The new plan, which is in effect from July 2019 through June 2022, includes 5 strategic goals:

  1. Improve student success through increased enrollment, retention, transfer, and completion rates.
  2. Create diverse, inclusive, and equitable teaching, learning, and work environments.
  3. Improve physical and virtual teaching and learning spaces.
  4. Increase visibility and value in the community.
  5. Provide development opportunities to enhance KCC employee skills and knowledge.

Each goal is detailed in the attached document. Action plans for each goal are being worked on now, and will be 1-year in length.  Progress on the action plans and goals will be shared on the portal on a monthly basis starting August 30th, and the Strategic Planning Oversight Committee will continue to oversee the implementation.  

Anyone with questions regarding the strategic plan is invited to contact me at prushi@kcc.edu.  

Thank you to everyone who contributed to this 3-year plan!

item.title: Board Notes - July 2019
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, July 7, 2019


Guests and Information. The Board heard the following:
  • Dr. Purva Rushi, director of Institutional Research, gave a brief presentation about the formation of the strategic plan and the resulting goals. 
  • Kelly Myers, executive director of the KCC Foundation, acknowledged a bequest of $332,662 from the Wertz Family. $76,768 will go towards the Student Success Center project. The remaining $255,894 will go towards student scholarships.
Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Tuition and course reimbursement
  • Recommendation to approve the FY20-FY22 strategic plan
  • Recommendation to approve the campus master plan and submit it to the Illinois Community College Board
  • Acceptance of the FY19 budget for public display

President’s Report. Dr. Boyd said…
  • KVSO Annual Fourth of July celebration at KCC was a success with more than 350 people in attendance. Thanks for the PPD staff and others who prepared for the event.
  • Congratulations to nursing faculty and recent nursing graduates for achieving a first time NCLEX-RN pass rate of 100% for 2019. The last two graduating classes (December & May) all passed on the first attempt.  Very few schools are able to achieve 100%.  
  • KCC’s respiratory program was one of a select group to receive the Distinguished RRT Credentialing Success Award from the Commission on Accreditation for Respiratory Care (COARC).
  • Clay Sterling was recognized at the Midwest Renewable Energy Association’s 30th Annual Energy Fair Benefit Dinner. In honor of his work, the MREA will plant a tree along their Avenue of Advocates which lines the driveway leading to their Renew the Earth Institute in Custer WI. The Avenue of Advocates recognizes those who have shown great leadership in advancing renewable energy and sustainable living.
  • The college learned recently that we have achieved LEED Gold Status for ATEC.
  • The college’s police department has had a positive impact on campus safety and security. Since its inception 5 years ago, instances on campus have dropped significantly. That drop is predicated on the proactive approach our 12 officers take, and team’s breadth of experience. 
  • The college has updated signage for our Workforce Development Center. Words on the doors indicated the WDC entry but recent updates with large lettering for the Welcome Center has resulted in some confusion. The new lettering makes it clear that the building is the WDC which also houses a Welcome Center. 
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • Reference materials from the ICCTA conference are available and worthwhile.
  • Kudos to the KCC staff for their work, particularly to those who worked on the campus master plan, strategic plan and security initiatives.
Student Trustee’s Report. Daisy Solorzano said …
  • The Student Advisory Council transition to a Student Government Association continues.
  • Ten TRiO students will attend planned cultural activities later this month. 
  • KCC’s Pep/Dance Club are practicing and will perform at basketball and soccer games this fall.

item.title: "The Defending Champs" defend their title
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Champion team members back row Michelle Hasik, Alex Thosen, Megan Ponton, Todd Post, Abigail Tilley; front row Meredith Purcell, Nick Sotello, Kendra Souligne, Adam White; not pictured Tierra Dixon-Sullivan

Article Content:

Congratulations to "The Defending Champs" who went 3-0 in Tournament play to maintain the "Traveling Championship Trophy" as well as bragging rights for another year. 


In the first round, "The Defending Champs" beat Marketing 6-0 while Accounting and ITS went scoreless after 3 full innings (it was quite a pitcher's duel).  As a result of a sudden death tiebreaker, Accounting advanced to the next round.    

In the second round, Marketing edged ITS 3-2, while "The Defending Champs" outscored Accounting 3-1. 

In the third round, Accounting nipped Marketing 1-0 setting up a rematch between "The Defending Champs and Accounting for the Championship.  "The Defending Champs" showed no mercy and wholloped the Accounting team 10-1, and selected Todd Post as the MVP for the tournament.  He wishes to share his "Traveling MVP Trophy" with the entire team so it truly will be traveling (reminiscent of the Stanley Cup). 

A huge shout out to the three referees who called a great tournament: Jamal Hawkins, Jose da Silva, and Rich Soderquist.  Special thanks to our photographer, Liz Becvar; the Food Committee of Janet Fager, Teresa Zach, Liz Becvar, and Felicia St. John; our timekeeper, Maggie Wolf; our scorekeeper, Beth Nunley; our "Field Readiness Crew" of  George Mateja & his staff, and Todd Post; and Chris Gibson, our Paramedic professor who was on standby and thankfully not needed. 

We also want to recognize the Culture of Caring committee for all of their planning efforts leading up to the tournament:  Sheila Pfaff, Kendra Souligne, Liz Becvar, Janet Fager, Beth Nunley, Teresa Zach, Josh Gregoire, Katie Henry, Jessica White, and Maggie Wolf, with guidance and consultation from Chief Rich Soderquist!

We also want to thank those who were unable to play because they were in training, or who couldn't get away because they were providing office coverage. 

It was a great time shared by all and we greatly appreciate having the opportunity "to have some fun" while at work. 

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 6/20/2019
Expires: 7/1/2019
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: LGBT+ History Month
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:


June 28 marks the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall uprising in New York City, the catalyst for the modern day LGBT+ civil rights movement. The events at Stonewall Inn, now a National Historical Landmark, galvanized tributes a month later that over the years have been transformed into Pride celebrations every June. 

June has also been meaningful for the LGBT+ community in other ways: June 26th represents the sixth year anniversary of the landmark case for marriage equality, United States v Windsor. The Supreme Court of the United States held in that seminal civil rights case that the Defense of Marriage Act was unconstitutional as a "deprivation of the equal liberty of persons as protected by the Fifth Amendment". In June 2020 the Supreme Court will hand down decisions on three cases that will determine whether Title VII, the part of the Civil Rights Act prohibiting discrimination in the workplace, specifically protects LGBT+ employees. A decision in favor will ensure federal protections nationwide.

No civil rights movement can survive without the support and encouragement of allies. A large part of being an effective LGBT+ ally is participating in those difficult conversations and establishing a reputation for not tolerating offensive behaviors. Please click here for more information on how you can be an LGBT+ ally. 

Author: Francesca Catalano
Article Date: 6/24/2019

item.title: Outmigration and Community Colleges
item.description:
Article Description: Dr. Boyd's opinion piece about reversing Illinois' population drop was published in the Daily Journal Weekend Edition on June 8.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

In late 2018, the U.S. Census Bureau reported that 86 of Illinois' 102 counties experienced population decline. Closer to home, on June 1, 2019, The Daily Journal reported that most of the region's major municipalities experienced decline, including a 3% population drop in Kankakee County since the 2010 census. We should have concerns about negative population trends beyond the potential loss of home-rule status. Population decline in Illinois corresponds to the rising cost of college. Sources including an independent organization called Illinois Policy state that the cost of college in Illinois increased as much as 100% between 2006 and 2016. Illinois students and their parents face a difficult decision when they realize that out-of-state schools are more affordable than the public universities supported by their own tax dollars. Al Bowman, then executive director of the Illinois Board of Higher Education, was correct when he observed, "Illinois has become fertile ground for institutions around the Midwest to recruit" (Chicago Sun Times; Sept. 21, 2018 "Why Chicago-area high school students are leaving Illinois for college," Adam Thorp and Jane Recker).

An answer to this problem—and a way to reverse the trend of outmigration and shrinking populations—lies in the community college, a resource available in every community in Illinois. Specifically, dual credit programs establish close partnerships between local high schools and the community college. Dual credit means the high school student enrolls in a course—usually at their high school—and earns college credit, and it also counts toward high school graduation.

On June 5, 2019, a group of educators representing Illinois' high schools, community colleges and state agencies sent the Illinois Community College Board and the Illinois State Board of Education a proposal called "Model Partnership Agreement." It creates better guidance and structure for agreements between local school districts and community colleges to deliver dual credit. Prompted by recent legislative amendments to Illinois' Dual Credit Quality Act, the agreement has potential to change the way Illinois schools offer dual credit. Therefore, it can greatly increase access to high quality, rigorous college classes offered at reasonable costs.

The agreement includes provisions which, if implemented locally, will create opportunities for high school students to enroll in core college courses taught at their home high schools for a rate equal to 8% of the local community college's cost. At Kankakee Community College's current cost of $161 per credit for tuition and fees, the maximum cost to a dual credit student for a three-credit course would be $38.64.

That's right! A Kankakee and Iroquois-area high school student could enroll in a college-credit course for under $40. Where it is appropriate, the Model Partnership Agreement also encourages school districts to reduce the rate to students even further, making classes free or very low cost. 

Many community college students wish to transfer to public universities. Many of these dual credit courses which are a part of the general education core will transfer because they are part of the Illinois Articulation Initiative, a transfer agreement which includes all Illinois public colleges and universities (learn more at itransfer.org).

Every Illinois community college already has local agreements with school districts to offer dual credit classes. Successful implementation of the "Model Partnership Agreement" will expand access to every student who is ready for college-level work. But, successful implementation means supporting and encouraging students to enroll.

If we commit to reversing the outmigration trend in Illinois, and if we are not content to sit idly by and watch the populations in our villages, towns and cities dwindle away, it is vital that we take pride in our community colleges. It is time for us to leverage strong partnerships which can exist between school districts and community colleges. As parents, we can have frank conversations with our high school aged children about their college and career plans. We can speak openly with them about the very real burdens of college loan debt. As educators, we must be open and flexible in how we deliver instruction to meet the needs of the students whose success we enable. We must focus on the community college as a necessary first two years before entering the workforce or transferring to a university. As citizens, we need to champion our local community college so our students enroll with a sense of pride in their community and all the wonderful things it has to offer.

Author: Dr. Michael Boyd
Article Date: 6/6/2019
Expires: 8/2/2019
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: June is all about Integrity!
item.description:
Article Description: Integrity is a commitment to behaving ethically, to communicating in ways that are open, positive, and constructive, and to making decisions in a manner consistent with our core values and beliefs.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

June is all about INTEGRITY! Watch this short video for a quick real life reminder from some kids who read their parents' tweets.

 

As a Cavalier and part of our commitment to our core value of integrity, I will: · Do the right thing even when no one is watching. · Be aware that my personal and professional actions reflect on KCC. · Use resources responsibly and in alignment with the institutional mission and priorities. · Maintain the confidentiality and trust of our students and my co-workers. · Take ownership of my actions. · Give credit where credit is due. · Look for solutions in all situations instead of assigning blame or dodging responsibility.


There is no better test of a man's integrity than his behavior when he is wrong.  --  Marvin Williams

If you tell the truth you don't have to remember anything.  --  Mark Twain

Whoever is careless with the truth in small matters cannot be trusted with important matters. -- Albert Einstein

Integrity is making sure that the things you say and the things you do are in alignment. — Katrina Mayer


Author: Sheila Pfaff, Kendra Souligne, Teresa Zack (Cavaliers Care Committee)

item.title: 2019 Performance Appraisals
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

It is that time again -- time for annual performance appraisals of administrators, professional/technical and supportive staff.

Completed appraisals are to be submitted to the Human Resources Office by June 3rd  for non-supervisory staff (full and part-time) and June 17th  for supervisory personnel.

Evaluation process:

The process includes reflection on your accomplishments, how you met/exceeded last year's goals, and what specific goals/objectives await you in the coming fiscal year.

Please note below the new KCC Strategic goals, which are "pending board approval":

  • Improve student success through increased enrollment, retention, transfer, and completion rates.
  • Create diverse, inclusive, and equitable teaching, learning, and work environments.
  • Improve physical and virtual teaching and learning spaces.
  • Increase visibility and value in community.
  • Provide development opportunities to enhance KCC employee skills and knowledge. 

Other notes worth mentioning include a diversity/equity/inclusion factor has been added, and the training needs section has been revised to emphasise Professional Development.  This section should be completed jointly by the employee and the supervisor and should address what specific development opportunties would you like KCC to offer you within the next 12 months to enhance your skills and knowledge?   

You should consult with your immediate supervisor for his/her deadline which allows time for all levels of supervision to review evaluations before the appropriate Human Resources deadline.  Electronic evaluation forms are located on the HR Portal page under Documents.

As part of this process, if the position description is not accurate, your supervisor should make proposed revisions and submit them to Human Resources with the evaluation.  A copy of your current description may be obtained by contacting Janet in HR at ext. 8124.  A "Specific responsibilities" section should also be included.

The process will be as follows:

1.  Complete a self-evaluation.
2.  Submit it as a Word document to your immediate supervisor. Schedule a meeting with him/her to discuss performance, review the completed tasks, establish new goals through March 2020 and complete the final evaluation. Note: Input/support from department directors should be solicited prior to this meeting.
3.  Sign the completed evaluation, get your immediate supervisor's signature, plus the appropriate department director's.  Keep a copy (or save it electronically). Your supervisor should do the same (for use during next year's evaluation process).
4.  Deliver a paper copy to Human Resources by the appropriate due date.

Please contact David Cagle at dcagle@kcc.edu or 815-802-8128 if you have any questions regarding this process.

Author: Human Resources
Article Date: 5/30/2019
Expires: 6/21/2019
item.author: Janet Fager

item.title: Food Pantry Thank You
item.description:
Article Description: Thanks to St. George Middle School and KCC's PTK
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The KCC Food Pantry would like to send a huge thank you to St. George Middle School and KCC's PTA students.  For the second year in a row as a part of their spirit week St. George collected a truck load of food donations.  Once those items were on campus PTA students and Professor Jennifer Blanchette organized, sorted, inventoried and stocked the Food Pantry.  They also performed the spring cleaning and disposed of expired products.  In the Spring 2019 semester the KCC Food Pantry had over 600 unique student visits.  We thank everyone in the greater KCC community for their continued support.

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, May 14, 2019

A public hearing was held to receive comments on the proposal to sell $5.8 million Funding Bonds for the purpose of paying claims against the district. No oral or written comments were received from the board or the public.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Contract award for a server refresh.

Trustee's Report. Richard Frey ...

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said...

  • Eight students participated in Student Advisory Council's talent competition, KCC's Got Talent.

item.title: Main Campus Heating/Cooling Plant Renovation
item.description:
Article Description: Central Heating and Cooling Plant Project Details
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​

On Monday, May 13th the college will begin the second phase of our Central Heating and Cooling Plant renovation.  This summer we will be eliminating the remaining two steam boilers and installing two new high efficiency hot water boilers, which will now give us a total of four.  The areas affected by this work, which will be cool temperatures, includes the Activities building, WDC, Phase II of the L Building (from L355 east) and the East Addition. 

Monday (May 13th) there will be contractors in the Prairie bldg. and Vo-Tec removing the previously abandoned hot water boilers.  We anticipate this work being complete before the start of summer classes.  The new work will be isolated to the boiler room and Activities building mechanical room.  The boiler phase of this project is anticipated to be completed by the start of the fall semester. 

Following the completion of the heating plant we will begin the 1st phase of the cooling plant renovation.  This work is expected to begin mid-October when cooler temperatures persist.  This work will consist of shutting down the main cooling plant, removing the existing chillers and installing a brand new, high efficient cooling system.  This work will affect most of the main campus, excluding Prairie and Vo-Tec who will have to wait until next year.  The first phase of the cooling project is expected to be completed by the end of the calendar year.

If there are any questions or concerns, please contact Rob Kenney at ext. 8194 or Rich Soderquist at ext.8173.  Thank you!


Author: Summer Work to Begin
Article Date: 5/6/2019
Expires: 5/14/2019

item.title: Indoor garden established
item.description:
Article Description: View the indoor garden near Athletic Department.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

This new planter area -- next to the ramp between the Athletic Department and L Building -- was is designed using the principles of sustainable landscape design. Species were chosen for their low water/high propagation properties, aesthetic appeal and diversity.

The initial planting includes ornamental grasses, sweet potato vine, aloe and succulents. The display also includes a waterfall with recycled water system, a dry riverbed and other landscaping techniques.

Concept, specifications and construction completed by the Physical Plant Department Grounds Crew. Installation assistance provided by Horticulture Program students and faculty, and the baseball team.

item.title: Core Value of "Excellence"
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Over the past three months, the Culture of Caring committee has celebrated the core values of – Collaboration, Learning and Respect.  This month we celebrate "EXCELLENCE"!

 

As defined in the Cavaliers Care book…

"Excellence is an active commitment to meeting and exceeding the highest expectations, both those we set for ourselves, and of those we serve. We model excellence not only by striving for the highest quality in everything we do, but through our willingness to reflect honestly on past performance as a means of continuously improving.  As an organization, KCC's dedication to excellence is exemplified by setting the highest standards for performance and service, and for ensuring that all members of our community have access to the training, resources, and support needed to excel".

 

We often associate excellence with that BIG, one time, achievement or exceptional accomplishment either at work or at home.  This may be true, but what about the "day-to-day" little accomplishments?  Shouldn't we strive for excellence in everything we do?  Be the best we can be every day?  Yes, but how is this possible?  One way is by building a "habit of excellence." 

 

  • Aristotle said, "We are what we repeatedly do.  Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit". 
  • Colin Powell said, "If you are going to achieve excellence in big things, you develop the habit in little matters.  Excellence is not an exception it is a prevailing attitude." 
  • John Shivers said, "Giving that 100% to whatever task is assigned regardless of any accolades received.  By giving your all it will reflect not only on yourself, but our institution as a whole."
  • Jacob Fansler said, "Trying to do the best job possible on the tasks that I work on. Not taking shortcuts to save time. Doing a task the right way. I care about and take pride in the work that I do, so I enjoy doing it correctly."
  • Dr. Avendano and others say, "No one rises to low expectations."

 

Therefore, we all need to become "excellent" in the little matters too — at home, at work, at school.  Don't settle for mediocrity.  Make a commitment today to meet and exceed the highest expectations in our performance and service to our students, co-workers, family and the community!  Be proud and fulfilled by knowing that you excel in excellence!

 

How can you excel today?  Tomorrow?  Every day?

Author: Jessica White & Janet Fager
Article Date: 5/1/2019
Expires: 5/10/2019

item.title: Board notes: April 2019
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, April 8, 2019.

General meeting. The following presentations and information was shared:

  • Trustees Frey and Boicken were re-elected for six year terms on April 2.
  • Dr. Michael Boyd introduced faculty member Clay Sterling, who was approved for tenure, effective with Fall 2019.
  • Craig Keigher introduced Outstanding Full-Time Faculty Award winner Amy Porter. Outstanding Adjunct Faculty Award winner Claire Henneike was unable to attend; she is the first dual credit instructor to receive the award.
  • Dr. Jose da Silva introduced Daisy Solorzano as the 2019-20 Student Representative to the Board.
  • Phi Theta Kappa Officers and Advisors gave a presentation about the recent PTK International Catalyst Convention in Orlando, where the chapter won two awards.

Action items. The Board approved the following:

  • Approval of contract awards for computer switches. 
  • Phase II of the replacement of the central steam boiler plant.
  • Phase I of the replacement chiller plant; and the next steps in the bonding process.

President's report. Dr. Avendano said...

  • He will attend the Phi Theta Kappa Banquet April 9 in Springfield. The PTK Induction takes place April 12 at KCC.
  • He will meet with several community college presidents this week to discuss potential grant funding for the Illinois Green Economy Network (IGEN).
  • The ATEC Grand Opening is April 17. It is followed by The Daily Journal's Progress Awards, where KCC will receive the Innovator in Technology Award for ATEC. KCC will present the Innovator in Agriculture Award to Locavore Farms.
  • The trustees are invited and encouraged  to attend any and all events on campus in the upcoming months, including those during Law Week.
  • Recent Foundation gifts include a new scholarship and large gifts from two donors.
  • The American Bar Association came to campus for an accreditation visit for the paralegal program.

Trustee's report. Dick Frey said...

  • He and Dr. Avendano will meet with legislators as part of the Illinois Community College Trustees Association's Lobby Day, May 1 in Springfield.
  • Trustees are encouraged to attend the ICCTA annual convention and banquet in June, as well as any or all ICCTA meetings during the year.
  • The trustees received the ICCTA's 2019 Legislative Goals.

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said …

  • Student Advisory Committee will hold an employment workshop on April 10 and will host KCC's Got Talent, a talent competition.
  • A club recognition dinner will take place April 12.
  • Finals Relaxation Week will include massages, an oxygen bar, and a Zumba class.
  • She will attend Student Advocacy Day in Springfield on April 9, and give a brief speech about funding for community colleges before meeting with legislators.
  • Baccalaureate Scholars plan to hold a fundraiser to renovate the bus bench.

Author: Karen Slager
Article Date: 4/9/2019
Expires: 4/26/2019
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Porter and Henneike named as 2019 Outstanding Faculty Award recipients
item.description:
Article Description: Announcement of 2019 Outstanding Faculty Awards
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The Outstanding Full-Time Faculty Member recipient is Amy Porter, English professor in the Humanities and Social Sciences Division.

Amy Porter began her journey in teaching as a graduate assistant at Illinois State University after completing a B.S. in psychology. Although it was not her original plan, she took on the challenge of teaching English with no formal education on how to do so. She was surprised to find that teaching was the career that she had hoped for—uniting her expertise in psychology with leading a classroom. Over the years, she has taught rhetoric/composition at Joliet Junior College; Prairie State College; and Governors State University, where she also co-managed a writing center. In 2008, she began as an adjunct professor at Kankakee Community College, and was hired full-time in 2011. Porter has stayed current in her field by attending and presenting at a variety of conferences around the country, most recently at the 2018 Two-Year College English Association conference in Indianapolis for a panel discussion of how adverse childhood experiences affect the way college students learn. She looks forward to pursuing this research even further and continues to see great benefits in the classroom from the implementation of her findings.









The Outstanding Part-Time Faculty Member recipient is Claire Henneike, who teaches college-level dual credit English in the Humanities and Social Sciences Division.

Claire Henneike makes every effort to ensure that students in her dual-credit English classes feel supported in their transition into college. She considers herself a lifelong learner, which speaks to her love for teaching. In her years teaching at both Watseka High School and KCC, she has displayed a real commitment to the success of her students. Henneike has been instrumental in closing the gap between high school and college readiness for local high school students. With her assistance, KCC has made strides in better preparing students for transfer-level coursework. She has also encouraged civic responsibility in her students by having them complete a project aimed at bettering their local community. Claire's energies demonstrate concern for her students that extends well beyond the confines of her classroom.

Porter and Henneike will be KCC's nominees for the annual Illinois Community College Trustees Association outstanding faculty awards presented in June.

item.title: Core Value of Respect
item.description:
Article Description: Respect is the Core Value for the month of April.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

Core Value of Respect 

 

The Merriam Webster definition of respect as a noun is an act of giving particular attention (consideration), high or special regard (esteem), expressions of high or special regard (paid our respects); as a verb is to consider worthy of high regard (esteem) or to refrain from interfering with such (please respect their privacy) 

Sesame Street puts a nice spin on respect 

How do you display respect?

Tips for Demonstrating Respect

  1. Treat people with courtesy, politeness, and kindness.
  2. Encourage coworkers to express opinions and ideas.
  3. Listen to what others have to say before expressing your viewpoint.
  4. Use people's ideas to change or improve work.
     

    Aretha Franklin sang about RESPECT
     

    The Cavalier Care Booklet offers this information on Respect: 

    Respect is the affirmation of human equality, the recognition that regardless of background, abilities, or beliefs, everyone deserves to be treated with dignity, civility, appreciation, and care. Respect is fundamental to creating and sustaining a sense of community at KCC. As an organization and as individuals, we enact this core value by behaving in ways that promote connection, understanding, consideration, and growth among students, colleagues, stakeholders, and district residents.
     

    In my commitment to our core value of respect, I will:

    Act with civility and professionalism

    Seek first to understand, then to be understood

    Consider others' feelings and recognize when my emotions are affecting my actions

    Be humble and compassionate; never be afraid to apologize

    Openly recognize and appreciate each person's strengths and contributions

    Embrace diversity and work toward creating a more inclusive environment

    Affirm that individuality and uniqueness enriches our campus

    Ask for help and feedback, and appreciate it when it is offered

    Be engaged when in meetings and respect everyone's time and efforts

    Assume the best and trust people to do their jobs
     

    Here is a short video on Respect in the Workplace

    6 Way to Build a Respectful Workplace
     

    If you're looking to improve your relationships, whether business or personal, try these five easy ways to show your gratitude and respect for others:
  1. Listen. I know it sounds easy, but listening–truly listening–can be one of the hardest skills to master
  2. Encourage
  3. Congratulate
  4. Be Helpful
  5. Say Thank You 

***We encourage you to say Thank You to a co-worker or student with a note or small treat.

Simple 'Thank You' cards have been distributed to each area and more are available from Marketing.

Create a Bucket Drop for exceptional customer service by a fellow employee (There is a goodie drawer by Janet in HR if you wish to include a treat.) 

Let's also remember to respect the earth on this year's Earth Day, Monday, April 22.

Reuse and Recycle whenever possible to maintain a good earthly environment for future generations.

The Horticulture Club will be handing out milkweed on Earth Day. Butterflies eat milkweed, so the club would like to encourage KCC students and staff to plant milkweed around their home. 

April 22 is also National Jelly Bean Day feel free to share jelly beans with co-workers, and students.

 


Author: Liz Becvar
Article Date: 4/1/2019
Expires: 4/30/2019
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: STTF wants to MTB
item.description:
Article Description: April 1 event kicks off new initiative
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​It's no secret that work time is busy, and valuable.

A new initiative from the STTF (Save Time Task Force) should MTB (make things better).

The first step to MTB, according to STTF is to AM (abbreviate more). Employees are encouraged to submit ARLs (abbreviation reference lists) with YFA (your favorite abbreviations).

There is a 4 minute 1 second time window to submit ARLs to STTF via IPD (in-person delivery). On Monday, April 1, it will MTB to have YFA on green paper for STTF between 4:01 p.m. and 4:05:01 p.m., which is 4 minutes and 1 second later. Bring the YFAs to the FFRD (first floor reception desk).

On-time arrivals will be given TATD (the attention they deserve). Late ARLs will be TA-S! (thrown away-sorry!).

The STTF thanks you for your efforts!

Author: Ellen Schmidt, STTF member
Article Date: 4/1/2019
Expires: 4/1/2019

item.title: UW campaign wraps up March 28
item.description:
Article Description: Still time for you to give to help KCC meet its goal
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

To date, KCC employees have pledged a total of $10,633.  There is only two days left in the local United Way campaign, which culminates at their annual dinner meeting on Thursday, March 28. 

KCC's goal going into the campaign was $14,000. As you can see, we are $3,367 shy of that goal, presently at 75.95% .  Last year, we actually exceeded our goal of $14,000 by raising a total of $14,963.  If you have already made a pledge in this year's campaign, THANK YOU.  If you have not, there is still time to do so! 

Embedded is a United Way Pledge form that can be completed and returned to my office.  Regardless of the amount, EVERY DONATION MATTERS!  Please see the UW video which highlights the work of the local United Way and their impact throughout our  community. Live United video

As always, I thank you for your past and current support of the local United Way!

item.title: High School Art Show Coming to a Close Tonight!
item.description:
Article Description: Stop by the Miner Memorial Library lower level before it is too late.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The 30th annual High School Art Exhibition is on display and coming to a close. More than 180 students have artwork on display from 12 area high schools.

The show runs through this Wednesday, March 20 in the lower level art gallery in the Harold and Jean Miner Memorial Library at KCC. Gallery hours are 7 a.m. - 8 p.m. Monday through Wednesday. Stop by the gallery and vote for your favorite piece (one vote per person please). The winner will receive a gift Wednesday night at the reception.

A closing reception, awards presentation and juror’s critique will be held this Wednesday, March 20, from 6-8 p.m. Awards in Painting, Color Drawing/Design, Black & White Drawing/Design, Photography/electronic imaging and 3-D Design will be revealed at 7:15 p.m. KCC art faculty are the jurors.

The schools represented are: Bishop McNamara, BBCHS, Central, Cissna Park, Grant Park, Herscher, Kankakee, Manteno, Momence, Pontiac, St. Anne, and Watseka.

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Please join Student Life and Criminal Justice Club for the Damsel in Defense workshop. This event is scheduled for Thursday, March 21st at 1:00 p.m. in the lower level of Miner Memorial Library. 

​Our Warrior Workshop is a fun, interactive workshop that teaches women that their lives are worth fighting for and provides them with the necessary training and education.  During this workshop you will learn strategies to help you be a hard target verses and easy one and how to always be prepared. You will also get out of your seat to practice striking techniques and proper pepper spray usage.  Women leave this workshop feeling empowered and understanding that they have the ability to protect themselves and their loved ones. Free and open to the public.

item.title: Board notes: March 2019
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, March 11, 2019

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Bid requests for a switch refresh and for phase two of the replacement of the central steam boiler plant and phase one of the replacement chiller plant.
  • Contract award for a College Drive roadway project.
  • Expanded computer lab in the Health Careers Division
  • Moving forward with the biannual funding bond process.

President’s report. Dr. Avendano said …

  • The new minimum wage increase will have a monetary impact on the college of approximately $300,000+ over seven years. 
  • There are five goals in KCC’s FY20-FY22 Strategic Plan, which he shared; along with thanks to Dr. Boyd and his team for their work on the Strategic Plan. 
  • With respect to a potential capital bill, he asked the Board to consider the cost of a lobbyist to procure funds for KCC. 
  • There will be a tour ATEC this week with Nucor representatives. 
  • The administration, responding to the Board’s desire for the college’s continued presence in Iroquois County, is working on short- and long-term solutions for relocating the South Extension Center. 
  • Thank you to the Board for their attendance at the Illinois State Scholars Dinner. He received several commitments, via email, that students plan to attend KCC.

Trustee's Report. Bill Orr said said…

  • He attended the March ICCTA meetings in Naperville. 
  • He participated in a roundtable discussion, which included the following: impact of the new minimum wage increase; on-campus time requirements for full-time faculty; ways to attract a broader student base; legalized marijuana; and e-sports clubs. 

Board Chair Patrick Martin thanked Trustee Orr for attending the meetings. 

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said …

  • Phi Theta Kappa students will attend the Catalyst Convention in April in Orlando. 
  • SAC is planning a “Herstory” display in honor of Women’s History Month. 
  • On March 27 the college will host guest lecturer Jean Sparrow, communication consultant, speaker and educator, who will talk about social media presence. 
  • Also on March 27, there will be a Heartland Blood Drive on campus, as well as the opportunity to view the movie “Oceans 8” to celebrate women in film. 
  • Students are invited to attend a Chicago Bulls game on March 20. 
  • ICCB/SAC met regarding how to appeal to legislators on Student Advocacy Day, April 8 in Springfield. 
  • The Criminal Justice Club will host a “Damsel in Defense” workshop.
Author: Karen Slager
Article Date: 3/18/2019
Expires: 3/29/2019

item.title: Core Value of Learning
item.description:
Article Description: Be a lifelong learner
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The Culture of Caring committee is inviting you to celebrate the core value of Learning during the month of March! As such, we would like to remind you to attend one of two "Days of Learning" sessions offered each day on March 4 and 5 (see Additional Info on Days of Learning post to learn all of the specifics).

Here is a quick quote on Learning that Dr. Vicki Gardner uses at the bottom of her emails that we found enlightening:  There is no end to education. It is not that you read a book, pass an examination, and finish with education. The whole of life, from the moment you are born to the moment you die, is a process of learning - Jiddu Krishnamurti

We have attached a six minute video on the six simple tips on the importance of Continuous Leaning, narrated by Jack Canfield.  He is an American author, motivational speaker, corporate trainer, and entrepreneur. He also co-authored the Chicken Soup for the Soul series, which has more than 250 titles and 500 million copies in print in over 40 languages.

His six tips are:

  1. Decrease your TV time (yes, he goes there)
  2. Study other successful people
  3. Learn how to read faster
  4. Attend as many conferences workshops, and other in-person events as you can
  5. Make a conscious commitment to yourself to engage in lifelong learning
  6. Be prepared

Here is the link to watch the video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R7qaCZexob8

Additionally, our KCC Cavaliers Care Book provides the following definition of Leaning for KCC employees:

Learning is the process by which we develop intellectually and emotionally. It is the acquisition of knowledge, skills, at­titudes, and behaviors that lead to personal and profession­al growth. As an institution of higher education, learning is at the heart of everything that we are and do at KCC. Indeed, our central mission is "Enhancing quality of life through learning." This charge applies not only to the students, stakeholders, and residents we serve, but to each of us as employees. This dedication to learning is exemplified through our institutional commitment to innovation, con­tinuous quality improvement, research, and data informed decision-making. But it is also demonstrated through an openness to feedback and new ideas, a spirit of humility (particularly the recognition that there can be many different ways to address any issue), curiosity, and maintaining a healthy sense of humor and perspective.

We can demonstrate learning with the following actions and beliefs:

  • Pursue growth and learning for personal, professional, and institutional improvement.
  • Be open to new ideas, procedures, methods, and feed-back.
  • Recognize that empathy and compassion are the foundation of emotional intelligence.
  • Cultivate and use emotional intelligence when working with others.
  • Challenge myself to think outside the box and support the creative efforts of others.
  • Research and explore evidence-based best practices for the purpose of continuous quality improvement.
  • Embrace, encourage, and drive innovative change.
  • Provide mentorship, support, and cross-training to my colleagues as they seek to acquire new knowledge and skills.
Author: Josh Gregoire and David Cagle
Article Date: 3/1/2019
Expires: 3/31/2019

item.title: "Green Book" Free Movie Showing
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

To culminate Black History Month please join SAC for this Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor, Best Original Screenplay and Best Film Editing Academy Award winning feature film. Dr. Don Shirley is a world-class African-American pianist, who is about to embark on a concert tour in the Deep South in 1962. In need of a driver and protection, Shirley recruits Tony Lip, a tough-talking bouncer from an Italian-American neighborhood in the Bronx. Despite their differences, the two men soon develop an unexpected bond while confronting racism and danger in an era of segregation.

This event is Free to KCC staff and students.

Event date: Thursday, Feb. 28th

Start time: 4:30 pm

Place: KCC Auditorium (L110)

Sponsored by: Student Advisory Council

 

Author: Linh Williams
Article Date: 2/25/2019
Expires: 2/28/2019

item.title: Plans underway for a Student Success Center
item.description:
Article Description: Renovations for Miner Memorial Library is one step closer.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
A renovation of the Miner Memorial Library into a Student Success Center is one step closer to reality. 
The KCC Board of Trustees has approved a proposal to hire Demonica Kemper Architects of Chicago to design and develop schematics for the space, assist with the bidding and construction processes and coordinate the furniture and equipment for the space. 
“The vision for the Student Success Center is the creation of an active, energetic learning hub for students, faculty and staff,” said Dr. John Avendano, KCC president. 
User groups met with Demonica Kemper in Fall 2018 to provide input. The preliminary plan includes centralizing tutoring services in the Student Success Center, creating technology-rich student collaboration rooms and individual study spaces, maintaining traditional quiet study areas, enhancing the entrance for visibility, and updating furniture and other furnishings. 
Funding for the $5 million project will come from a combination of KCC Foundation funds, equity and funding bonds. The project if preliminarily scheduled to begin in winter of 2020 with completion prior to fall 2021.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 2/20/2019
Expires: 3/1/2019
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Dr. A honored by the Illinois House of Representatives
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Dr. John Avendano, KCC’s president, received a resolution from the Illinois House of Representatives honoring his commitment and service to higher education. 
State Rep. Lindsay Parkhurst presented the resolution at the KCC Board of Trustees meeting on Feb. 11. It named many of Avendano’s accomplishments. The resolution mentions Avendano’s leadership through an unprecedented state budget impasse of two years, his advocacy for Monetary Assistance Program (MAP) funding for students and appropriations for community colleges, and his representation of KCC and Illinois Community Colleges to legislators in Springfield. 
At KCC, he added new academic programs, successfully implemented two strategic plans, and opened campus facilities. KCC also celebrated two national championships and the college’s 50th anniversary during his tenure. 
“It was truly an honor to have received such a thoughtful acknowledgement for my career,” said Avendano. “I’m so appreciative of everything that has come my way.”
Avendano is retiring from KCC at the end of June after serving as president for 10 years. 
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 2/19/2019
Expires: 3/1/2019
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: New Hospitality Operations certificate
item.description:
Article Description: Attention dreamers and innovators who are ready to tranform area attractions.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
A new Hospitality Operations certificate will be an option for KCC students beginning Fall 2019. 
The 18-credit hour certificate packages two existing KCC courses along with four newly developed courses. It prepares students to enter the hospitality profession in hotels, restaurants, banquet and entertainment venues or meeting, convention and event planning settings. Employment opportunities are in restaurants, chambers of commerce, tourism destinations, recreation businesses and hotels. 
“Entrepreneurship is the first class in the series because we see this program attracting entrepreneurs who are looking for the knowledge, skills and connections they need to develop an idea into a reality,” said Boyd. “We want this program to attract dreamers and innovators who have disruptive ideas that can transform the attractions of the area.”
Courses will be taught at KCC, with internship experiences at area facilities. 
“Local businesses are interested in our hospitality students as interns and future employees.” said Dr. Michael Boyd, vice president for Instruction and Student Success. “We held a discussion with industry leaders in collaboration with Kankakee County Convention and Visitors Bureau and we had an overwhelming response.”
“We are proud to be a voice representing the tourism and hospitality industry and grateful that Kankakee Community College recognizes the need for a formal Hospitality Management academic program,” said Staci Wilken, executive director of the Kankakee County Convention and Visitors Bureau. “We hope this program can prepare students to roll out the red carpet for our guests.” 
Students will be encouraged to earn Illinois Restaurant Association credentials in food handling, sanitation, alcohol and allergens. The hospitality classes also can be taken toward an associate degree, which can transfer to a hospitality program at a four-year college or university in Illinois to earn a bachelor’s degree. 
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 2/19/2019
Expires: 3/1/2019

item.title: Just in: SEC provides excellent teaching and learning environment
item.description:
Article Description: This week the HLC affirmed the South Extension Center as an additional site location.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Reviewers from the Higher Learning Commission conducted a site visit at KCC’s Harold and Jean Miner South Extension Center in Watseka on Dec. 13. This week, the HLC report affirmed that KCC delivers appropriate services, and the South Extension Center will continue to offer full associate degree programs for students.

A few highlights from the HLC report:

“It is important to note that the staff are former SEC alumni and know their community very well which makes them trustworthy and approachable contacts for students.  Students voiced their satisfaction with the registration, advising, career counseling and placement and library access at this Watseka location.”

“The students present praised the faculty, especially their “homegrown” English professor.”

And most important:
“In meetings with administrators, faculty, staff and students, it was confirmed that KCC delivers, supports and manages student services at this location and it is in frequent communication with the administrators and deans at the main campus.”

This is great news to hear, providing further evidence of what we know already- that you all provide and support an excellent teaching and learning environment for our students at the SEC. 

Purva Rushi
Accreditation Liasion Officer


Author: Dr. Purva Rushi
Article Date: 2/13/2019
Expires: 2/22/2019
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Food Pantry Anniversary
item.description:
Article Description: KCC's Food Pantry Celebrates 1 year in operation.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Thursday, February 14th  is the one year anniversary of the KCC Food Pantry!  During that time, we have had over 1900 unique student visits.  Our Food Pantry is fueled by the efforts of our volunteers; currently we are open five days a week for a total of 14 hours.  We are always looking for more volunteers to help with general operations or service learning opportunities, please encourage students to stop by.  We still hear from students when they use the facilities that they are just hearing about this service. 

Data from the KCC Food Pantry has been used in doctoral research as well as statewide and national studies assessing food insecurities.  I have presented our program at the ICCCA conference in Peoria, will be speaking at the League for Innovations in the Community College's Innovation Conference this month, and was asked specifically to present on our Food Pantry at the International Conference on Teaching and Leadership Excellence meeting this summer.  Thank you all for your continued support of our Food Pantry, without you none of this would be possible. 

For more information on the Food Pantry please email foodpantry@kcc.edu


Author: Francesca Catalano
Article Date: 2/13/2019
Expires: 2/28/2019

item.title: Board Notes - Feb. 2019
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees Meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Feb. 11, 2019

Guests and information. The Board heard from…
State Representative Lindsay Parkhurst presented Dr. Avendano with a resolution from the Illinois House of Representatives honoring his work.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Tuition and fee increase to $161 per credit hour for FY20 - $5 tuition and $2 activity fee
  • Architectural services for the Student Success Center.  
  • Hospitality Operations certificate program 
  • Grant awards from The Workforce Board
  • Request for bids for College Drive roadway project
  • Additions and revisions to course fees
  • Lease extension with Northeastern Illinois Area Agency on Aging

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • Donnie Denson and Paul O’Connor were recently named to the Illinois Basketball Coaches Association Hall of Fame. Donnie is KCC’s Women’s Basketball head coach and Paul O’Conner served as former chief financial officer and interim president, and coached women’s basketball 1986-2000.
  • Architects Demonica Kemper conducted focus groups with employees in preparation for the master facilities plan. 
  • Grand opening for the ATEC building is scheduled for April 17 from 4-6:30 p.m. The community will be invited to celebrate our newest facility. Click the link to add it to your calendar.
  • Don’t miss out on the Cavaliers Cash Bash on Feb. 16. Proceeds support KCC athletics.
  • As capital bills are advanced the college should consider how to access funding for renovations and facilities projects. 
  • The college is preparing for a potential minimum wage increase. The current $8.25 minimum wage has stood since 2010 and if passed by the House and signed into law by Gov. Pritzker, the minimum wage would increase to $9.25 on Jan. 1, 2020, $10 on Jan. 1, 2021 and then by a dollar each year after that until eventually reaching $15 by 2025.

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next ICCTA meeting will take place March 8-9. Speculation about Gov. Pritzker’s minimum wage and tax increases will be topics. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Melany Villagomez said …
  • Puppy Love fundraiser is scheduled for Feb. 12 hosted by One Pet One Vet. 
  • Student Advisory Council is hosting a paint night on Valentine’s Day. 
  • Student Advisory Council is preparing for Student Advocacy Day in April. Students around the state will advocate that community colleges receive a larger slice of higher education funding.
  • Phi Theta Kappa is preparing for its annual convention in April. 
  • Baccalaureate Scholars determined its service projects, including assisting with high school recruitment, advocating for “Women in STEM” scholarships, replacing a campus bus bench and increasing the evening bus schedule.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 2/12/2019
Expires: 2/22/2019

item.title: Little Sci/Fi/Fant Lending Library
item.description:
Article Description: Available in R300 hallway
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​From the current TV hit The Passage to time tested favorites like The Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones (back April 14th!!) science fiction/fantasy books have not only inspired scientists, engineers and mathematicians, they have also inspired science itself.  Emboldened by our common affection for the genre as well as a desire to share some of our favorite books with our students, the faculty and staff of MSE have created the "Little Sci/Fi/Fant Lending Library" in a nook of the third floor R building, near the Food Pantry.  The library is founded on a generous donation from Angry Robot Publishing (100 books on route!) and contains many of our favorites and other classic gems.  Please stop by and take one or leave one – new and used donations of science fiction/fantasy are greatly appreciated.

item.title: Teaching Squares sign up
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Teaching Squares is an exciting professional development opportunity offered only once a year

This voluntary program attempts to improve teaching and build community through a structured, non-evaluative process of classroom visits and shared reflection. Your Teaching Squares experience offers you the opportunity to improve your own teaching by visiting your Square Partners in an actual classroom situation. There is also an online option to learn about Square Partners online teaching strategies and course design through guided tours and discussion.

A Teaching Square consists of four faculty participants (preferably from different disciplines) who:

  • Visit at least one class taught by each Square Partner (three class visits); or, for the online version, receive a guided tour.
  • Reflect on each class experience and methods demonstrated.
  • Share reflections with Square Partners
  • Share Square observations with Project participants as a whole

The Teaching Squares program will require about one hour per week for seven weeks.


(you will receive a calendar appointment for the initial meeting date)

The Kickoff will be Thursday, February 7th at 3:00pm in room L315.

Author: Craig Keigher
Article Date: 1/22/2019
Expires: 2/2/2019
item.author: Craig Keigher

item.title: Faculty Book Study
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Faculty Book Study

The Faculty Development and Embracing Diversity committees are pleased to announce a spring book study opportunity.  To participate, please respond to this email by January 31st.  An initial meeting will be held on February 6th at 3pm in room L131 (staff dining room).  All subsequent book study dates will be determined at this meeting, so please bring your calendar availability for the spring term.  If you are unable to attend the initial meeting, but would still like to participate, please sign-up to be included.  Limited copies of the book will be available at the Miner Memorial Library in Faculty Reserve.  The book  is also available at Amazon or other retailers.

White Kids: Growing Up with Privilege in a Racially Divided America (Critical Perspectives on Youth)  is a clear-eyed and sometimes shocking account of how white kids learn about race. this book explores questions such as, "How do white kids learn about race when they grow up in families that do not talk openly about race or acknowledge its impact?" and "What about children growing up in families with parents who consider themselves to be 'anti-racist'?"

 

(you will receive a calendar appointment for the initial meeting date)


Contact Craig (ckeigher@kcc.edu) for more information.


Author: Faculty Development and Embracing Diversity committees
Article Date: 1/16/2019
Expires: 1/31/2019
item.author: Craig Keigher

item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Jan. 14, 2019

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Capital Renewal grant funds to repair the main campus building shell in the library
  • Adoption of the personnel policy revisions
  • Bid award for computers
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Avendano said…

  • The Board toured the ATEC building prior to their meeting. ATEC is now open for classes. The new building may become another front door because of its quick entry from the parking lot.
  • Enrollment is down 1% in headcount and 2% in credit hours as of the first day of school. But, enrollment activity is still happening between now and census day.
  • KCC police officer Vern Turner and Top Notch put together a basketball classic for high school teams, along with health awareness, over the weekend.
  • Two trustees, Richard Frey and Cathy Boicken, are candidates for re-election to the KCC Board of Trustees. The election is on April 2, 2019.
  • Today is Gov. J.B. Pritzker's inauguration day. It is expected that the State of Illinois will put forth a capital bill. The college should consider how to access funding for renovations and facilities projects.
  • Thank you to the Board for their time with the presidential search process. The Board's decision will become final at a special meeting on Wednesday, Jan. 16 at noon.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • The next ICCTA meeting will take place in March. Speculation about Gov. Pritzker's increased education funding will be a topic.

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said …

  • Phi Theta Kappa is preparing for its annual convention in April.
  • Club Rush is happening this week.
  • Student Advisory Council is preparing for Student Advocacy Day in April. Students around the state will advocate for community colleges to receive a larger slice of higher education funding.
  • Baccalaureate Scholars are determining what service projects to pursue this semester.
  • Chew 'n Chat is scheduled for Thursday, Jan. 17 from noon-1 p.m. to give students a chance to talk with her as Student Trustee.

item.title: Thank you!
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​Dear KCC College Community,

I’m writing to express my sincere gratitude for inviting me to Kankakee Community College to interview for the position of President. I appreciate the warm welcome I received upon arriving, and this reception was extended throughout the day.  

I hope that everyone on campus feels the same sense of enthusiasm, anticipation, and excitement about KCC’s future as I do. KCC deserves the very best President who can take the College forward to the next level of achievement and excellence. I’m not only confident that I meet the desired characteristics and requirements you’ve described, but I’m also confident that I can lead KCC to even greater achievements on behalf of the students we serve. This is an historic moment for the College because our community’s expectations for our performance have never been higher. If we are to meet these expectations, we must build upon the success of our current initiatives, boldly confront the challenges we face, and act decisively to implement innovative programs.

I hope that KCC sees in my candidacy someone who is ready to lead us to the next level of excellence and achievement. 

Thank you,

MB

Author: Michael Boyd, Ph.D., vice president for instructional and student success
Article Date: 1/15/2019
Expires: 2/1/2019
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: New application is online
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Upon arriving at KCC this past November, I was informed that we have been working on changing our online admissions application to a new software system for the past year. 

Thanks to the great work that has taken place by many of our employees from IT, Admissions, Recruitment, and other areas of the college, I am happy to share that we are ready to Go Live with the new online admissions application. 

Understanding the impact that a new online admissions application can have to our enrollment, we waited until we were done with the rush from the beginning of the Spring semester to do a soft roll-out of the new online admissions application. Our Go Live date is Jan. 14, 2019 at 6 a.m. As you are either submitting an new student application for yourself or assisting a student to submit an online admissions application, if any issues arise, please feel free to utilize the Live Chat function of the software or call ext. 8500 for assistance. 

If you have any questions regarding this change, please do not hesitate to reach out.

Author: Jose E. da Silva, Ph.D., vice president for student development and services

As a reminder, follow these steps to receive your 2018 tax forms in the most expedient manner:

item.title: Final Reminder: Illinois Assessment Fair Feb. 15
item.description:
Article Description: All faculty and staff are welcome to attend
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

This is a final reminder for the upcoming Illinois Assessment Fair which is now just a month away!  Registration is still open, we have plenty of room.  All faculty and staff are welcome to attend at no charge, but we do require registration for attendance and meal planning.  Several people have asked if they could attend parts of the fair, but not all of it due to schedule conflicts: YES, but please do register in advance using the form below.

Employee Registration form

Note: external individuals may register here with $100 fee

Date: Friday, February 15, 2019
Time: 8:00 a.m. – 3:45 p.m.
Place: Kankakee Community College (main campus: Welcome Center)

Also, if you are still considering submission of a presentation proposal, the deadline is January 23rd.  Tracks will include: 1) Administrative and Student Services Assessment, 2) Assessment and Accreditation, 3) Assessment and Community Engagement, 4) Assessment Best Practices, 5) Faculty Development and Assessment, 6) General Education Assessment.

We are excited to have Dr. Gavin Henning deliver the keynote address this year.  Gavin is Professor of Higher Education at New England College in New Hampshire where he directs the Master of Science in Higher Education Administration and Doctorate of Education programs. A national leader in higher education, Gavin serves as President of the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and is a past president of ACPA – College Student Educators International. He has over 20 years' experience in higher education assessment and institutional research and frequently consults and presents regionally, nationally, and internationally on the topic. His scholarship includes over 80 peer-reviewed presentations and over 80 invited presentations and keynotes regarding assessment. In addition, he has published articles and books on assessment including Student Affairs Assessment: Theory and Practice (2016, Stylus) with Darby Roberts that serves as the foundational text for assessment courses in many higher education graduate programs. Gavin earned his Ph.D. in Leadership and Policy Studies from the University of New Hampshire.

Dr. Henning will host both a follow-up discussion to his keynote, and an additional breakout topic later in the day.

Questions: Craig Keigher, Director of Instructional Technology and Faculty Development, at (815) 802-8402 or ckeigher@kcc.edu.


Author: Craig Keigher
Article Date: 1/14/2019
Expires: 1/31/2019
item.author: Craig Keigher

item.title: Jan. 22/23: Master Plan Focus Groups
item.description:
Article Description: Please give input for interior renovations.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​One part of the master planning process is the interior renovation of older parts of the facilities.

To aid in that plan, Demonica Kemper Architects is leading focus groups on Tuesday and Wednesday, Jan. 22 and 23. They will take place in Room L253.

All employees are invited to the appropriate session (see schedule, below). There is no limit to the number of team members at the meeting. Note: As always, please be sure work areas are covered.

Following these meetings, input will be reviewed and prioritized. The steering committee and architects will use the information to create the master plan. It's anticipated that a final master plan will be brought to the board in June.

Focus group tips/topics to consider

  • Keep the discussion facilities-focused.
  • Are you located in the right area of the college?
  • Is your space adequate for your programming?
  • What new initiatives require space?
  • Are there collaborations across departments that make proximity important?

Schedule and groups

Tuesday, Jan. 22 – Room L253

9-10 a.m.: President's Office, Foundation, Marketing and Public Relations, Institutional Research, Grant Development

10-11 a.m.: Adult & Community Education, Continuing Education & Career Services

11 a.m. - noon: Instructional Technology, Library

1-2 p.m.: Health Careers Division

2-3 p.m.: Humanities & Social Sciences Division

3-4 p.m.: Business/Technology Division, Perkins

Wednesday, Jan. 23 – Room L253

9-10 a.m.: Business Office, Financial Affairs, Human Resources, Bookstore

10-11 a.m.: Facilities & Campus Security

11 a.m. - noon: Information Technology Services

1-2 p.m.: Math, Science & Engineering Division

2-3 p.m.: Admissions & Registration Services, Financial Aid Services, Advising Services

3-4 p.m.: Support Services, Upward Bound/Talent Search Programs & Athletics

Article Content:

Accuplacer Next Gen. will launch this month. While students and staff may not notice a difference in content or how the exam is given, a new three-digit score will be used to decipher reading placement.

Accuplacer currently used for placement utilizes a two-digit score. These two-digit scores will be termed "classic" and may still be used for placement (expire 4 years from date taken). New cut scores reflecting this change will be updated on-line and available as handouts in Student Services.
