item.title: Money Purchase factor changes effective 7/2/19
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image Caption:

 

Article Content:

When SURS calculates a retirement benefit, all eligible calculation types are performed and the annuity is based on the calculation that provides the highest benefit. For most defined-benefit members (not SMP), this is a comparison between the General Formula and the Money Purchase calculation. The Money Purchase factors used to determine monthly annuity benefits will change July 2, 2019, based upon the most recent experience study conducted by SURS actuaries. The new factors will result in a lower monthly benefit payment for those retiring on or after the July 2, 2019, effective date, if their benefit is calculated to be highest using the Money Purchase calculation. It is estimated that the monthly benefit paid from the Money Purchase will be reduced on average by 5 percent to 6 percent, if retirement is deferred until after the new factors take effect. SURS estimates that active participants can recover this monthly reduction by delaying retirement for approximately six to seven months, due to the additional contributions and interest that would be added.

To learn more about these changes and how this might impact your decision to retire, please click on the following link: https://my.kcc.edu/employees/hr/Documents/MoneyPurchaseFactors.pdf

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 12/18/2018
Expires: 1/11/2019
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Status Update - Help me get home!
item.description:
Article Description: Little Big Santa STILL needs your help...
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Just a quick update on my status.  My captors are nice, although a bit kooky.  Thirty more bucks and I can make it home in time to help my Pa get ready for his big night on the 24th!!!  

~LBS

~~~~~~~~

​Hello - 

Let me introduce myself. I'm Little Big Santa. My most recent home was Adult Ed. But I've been taken from there. 

My captors say there is a way for me to get home to my dear Adult Ed friends.

You see, I'm hungry! Others are hungry, too!

So, they want donations made to the Food Pantry.

Will you help out?

Here's how: Please bring a monetary donation to the Food Pantry (Enter in Room R308, or take to L355) and let them know it's to help me (Little Big Santa) get back home to Adult Ed!

If $100 is raised for the food pantry I will be returned; safe and sound!

Ho Ho Ho and thanks for helping!

-LBS

Author: Little Big Santa

item.title: Last call to sign up for Holiday Tournaments
item.description:
Article Description: Deadline to sign up is 2 pm Dec 14
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

  

Let the games begin!

Bragging rights and prizes will be on the line during three KCC holiday tournaments: ping pong, air hockey and bags.

Details

  • All KCC employees and student workers are invited to participate.

  • Register by 2 p.m., Friday, Dec 14 at the first floor reception desk.

  • Matches will begin Monday, Dec 17 and will continue until champions are crowned shortly before noon on Dec. 20.

  • Brackets will be posted on the Human Resources portal site, and at the tournament site – Cavalier Corner/lower level of the College Center.

  • Entry fee in each sport is a donation to KCC's Food Pantry (on your honor).

The sports

  • Ping pong: Each game will be played to 21, and the winner must win by 2. The match is best 2 of 3. Participants can use their own paddles if they choose. Scoring will use the honor system. The top two players will receive gift cards.

  • Air hockey: Each game will be played to 7. The match is best 2 of 3. Common sense rules apply, such as players not being able to touch the puck with their hands and not crossing over the middle line. The top two players will receive gift cards.

  • Bags: Partners/teams will be randomly drawn and paired. Each game will be played to 21. The match is best 2 of 3. The top two teams will receive gift cards.

For more information, contact David Cagle at 815-802-8128 or email dcagle@kcc.edu or Ellen Schmidt at 815-802-8279 or email eschmidt@kcc.edu.

Author: David Cagle & Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 12/14/2018
Expires: 12/14/2018
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Tidings of Cheer! Here are Holiday Buffet details: 12/20/18
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Holiday Buffet details for 12/20/18

Article Content:

​It’s time to gather in the grand tradition of an all employee (faculty & staff, full- & part-time, student workers) holiday party beginning at 12:15 p.m. on Thursday, Dec. 20 in the College Center.

KCC will cease operations at noon on Dec. 20. This will allow employees to gather for the celebration. Following the luncheon and party, all employees are invited to use the remaining afternoon hours to take down holiday decorations and prepare for the new year before adjourning for winter break.

Luncheon details
If you are eating lunch, please bring a dish to share so there can be enough food for everyone. Bring your covered dish to the Cavalier Room by noon.

To ensure variety, if your last name begins with…
• A-R, please bring a side dish (e.g. hot dish, salad or appetizer)
• S-Z, please bring a dessert

Other procedures/info:
• The meat, plates, napkins, plastic ware, bread and condiments will be provided.
• Bring a drink, too; beverages will not be provided.
• The room will be cleaned immediately afterward, so please pick up your dishes before leaving.
• We will eat in the College Center to accommodate more people.
• No need to line up early. Sit at numbered tables in the College Center. At 12:10 p.m., a random drawing will determine the order of tables to go through the line.
• Food tables will have selections on both sides to speed up the line.
• Everyone is ENCOURAGED to dress in FESTIVE (yet appropriate) HOLIDAY ATTIRE, such as Fuzzy Slippers, Crazy socks & hats, and of course your Favorite Holiday Sweater (ugly or not).  There will be an opportunity to showcase your wardrobe in a Holiday group picture.

The luncheon will conclude with comments from KCC President Dr. Avendano.

Author: Human Resources
Article Date: 12/13/2018
Expires: 12/21/2018
item.author: Janet Fager

item.title: Board Notes - Dec. 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Dec. 11, 2018

 

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Renewal of the property, casualty, liability insurance programs
  • Resolutions honoring full-time retirees
  • First reading of the personnel policy revisions
  • Bid award for a 25 passenger bus
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Avendano said…

  • An update report from the KCC Foundation is included in the board materials, and noted how much assistance was given to students. Ruth Hopper and Warren and Sharon Owenga gave especially thoughtful donations for students. 
  • We are on target for hitting employee giving goals.
  • The board is advancing two finalists for the president's position. Campus interviews will happen in January.
  • Condolences to Judge Michael Kick on the loss of his wife, Lisa. Judge Kick is a KCC alumnus and friend of the college.
  • Two trustees are candidates for re-election to the KCC Board of Trustees. The election is on April 2, 2019.

Trustee's Report. Todd Widholm said…

  • Todd Widholm attended the ICCTA meeting, and participated in roundtable discussions with the other trustees. Todd recognized Dick Frey for his ongoing commitment to attending those meetings as the board's representative.

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said …

  • Dr. Vicki Gardner gave a presentation about her trip to Russia for the Global Awareness Club. The students thought it was informative and well received.
  • Basketball fundraiser raised $700, and the donations were split between the Veteran's Resource Center and Student Advisory Council.
  • The Club Recognition Dinner happened on Nov. 30.
  • During finals relaxation week the office of Student Life hosted an "Express Your Stress" art event, One Vet One Pet puppy therapy, yoga and massage.
  • Seven PTK members attended the sleep out, and they made it through the night. They raised funds for Fortitude Community Outreach.
  • Baccalaureate Scholars students finished 18 backpacks for their blessings-in-a-backpack drive to help local homeless. The student nursing association is distribute them.

 


Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 12/12/2018
Expires: 12/20/2018

item.title: Benchmark reports are now available
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​KCC's Office of Institutional Research has results from the 2018 National Community College Benchmark Project (NCCBP).

The Executive Summary: NCCBP Strengths and Opportunities 2018 Report shows the college's top strengths and opportunities. This report was compiled by the KCC Office of Institutional Research, and includes graphs comparing KCC to other Illinois community colleges which submitted data.

This report shows that KCC has a national rank at or above the 80% percentile in 18 categories.

The NCCBP Executive Report 2018 includes key national benchmarks. It was compiled by the NCCBP.

For further information, contact Dr. Purva Rushi, director of institutional research and grants development.

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Congratulations to Kendra Souligne who was recognized at the Kankakee County Chamber's 40 Under Forty event held on 11/15/18. The event is held to recognize people who are under the age of 40 and excel at their profession, give back to the community, and are passionate about Kankakee County.

Beyond that honor, Kendra was also chosen as the recipient of a scholarship to pay for her to complete her Masters in Organizational Leadership degree at Olivet Nazarene University. One scholarship is handed out every two years by the Kankakee County Chamber of Commerce.

Way to go, Kendra! We can't wait to see what the future holds for you.

item.title: Board Notes - Nov. 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, Nov. 13, 2018

Guests and information. The Board heard from…

Representatives from Groskreutz, Abraham, Eshleman & Gerretse presented the college's financial audit.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Resolution for estimated tax levy amounts
  • The FY2018 financial audit
  • WIOA on-the-job training contract with Plochman, Inc. in Manteno
  • Protection, health and safety funds to replace the central heating and cooling plant
  • Capital Renewal Project to replace the lift in the Miner Memorial Library
  • Grant awards from the Workforce Board
  • Solicitation of bids for a 25 passenger bus
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President's Report. Dr. Avendano said…

  • Appreciation to Kelly Myers and the Foundation for organizing a well-done scholarship recognition event on our campus. Also, thanks to Rich Soderquist and the PPD team for helping with the set-up.
  • Kudos to Dr. Cari Stevenson and Kendra Souligne on another successful Veteran's Recognition Ceremony.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • Mr. Frey was not in attendance, but represented the college at the Regional Trustees Meeting.

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said …

  • Homelessness awareness is focus for two KCC student organizations. As part of the an Honors in Action project, Phi Theta Kappa is hosting a Sleep Out on Friday, Nov. 16 at KCC's picnic pavilion to raise funds for Fortitude Community Outreach. And, the Baccalaureate Scholars are coordinating a "blessings in a backpack" drive to help local homeless.
  • Student Advisory Council organized this year's Halloween Spooktacular, and more than 300 community members attended. It featured a haunted house organized by the STEM Club. Clubs also hosted a Day of the Dead celebration.
  • Melany announced that she was selected as the lead organizer for the state-wide Student Advocacy Day in March.  
  • The Global Awareness Club hosted a showing of the documentary "We Still Live Here" to bring awareness to Native American issues.

item.title: Hunger & Homelessness Awareness Week - Nov 12 - 16
item.description:
Article Description: Activities Planned
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

November 12 – 16 is Hunger and Homelessness Awareness Week.  The KCC Food Pantry has had 869 visits from students this semester (end of Week 11 of 16). Our Food Pantry is supported through the volunteer efforts and donations of faculty, staff and community members.  How can you help?

 

  • The KCC Criminal Justice Club is hosting a STUFF-THE-SQUAD-FOOD-DRIVE to benefit the KCC Food Pantry.  Non-perishable donations and hygiene products can be dropped off at the Student Center on 11/7 or 11/13 from 10 – 1 PM or to room W102 anytime up until 11/15.
  • The Food Pantry is also in need of canvas, reusable bags. 
  • We could also use plastic containers; large ones for storage as well as smaller ones for displaying food items.

 

Thank you for supporting us!  Please email FoodPantry@kcc.edu with any questions.

item.description:
Article Description: Criminal Justice students network with Law Enforcement professionals.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​The Criminal Justice Program held a Speed Networking event at KCC for all criminal justice students November 8th.  Participants included Trooper Alyssa Bufford - Illinois State Police K-9, Master Sergeant Chris Koerner - KAMEG Director, Officer Evan Gregg - Kankakee County Probation Department, Officer Melvina Calvin-Edwards - Kankakee City Police Department, Deputy Tobe Fulford - Kankakee County Sheriff's Department, Lieutenant Phillip Trudeau - Bradley Police Department. 

Students had the opportunity to engage in six - 20 minute "speed networking" sessions, rotating between tables for each session.  Students asked participants questions about careers in law enforcement.

item.title: Registration is now open! Illinois Assessment Fair Feb. 15
item.description:
Article Description: All faculty and staff are welcome to attend
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Registration is now OPEN for the 23rd Annual Community College Assessment Fair hosted this year by Kankakee Community College.  All faculty and staff are welcome to attend at no charge, but we do require registration for attendance and meal planning.  Please do consult with your immediate supervisor if you plan to attend.

Employee Registration form

Note: external individuals may register here with $100 fee

Date: Friday, February 15, 2019
Time: 8:00 a.m. – 3:45 p.m.
Place: Kankakee Community College (main campus: Welcome Center)

Presentation proposals on any assessment-related topic are also ENCOURAGED at this time.  Tracks will include: 1) Administrative and Student Services Assessment, 2) Assessment and Accreditation, 3) Assessment and Community Engagement, 4) Assessment Best Practices, 5) Faculty Development and Assessment, 6) General Education Assessment.

We are excited to have Dr. Gavin Henning deliver the keynote address this year.  Gavin is Professor of Higher Education at New England College in New Hampshire where he directs the Master of Science in Higher Education Administration and Doctorate of Education programs. A national leader in higher education, Gavin serves as President of the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and is a past president of ACPA – College Student Educators International. He has over 20 years' experience in higher education assessment and institutional research and frequently consults and presents regionally, nationally, and internationally on the topic. His scholarship includes over 80 peer-reviewed presentations and over 80 invited presentations and keynotes regarding assessment. In addition, he has published articles and books on assessment including Student Affairs Assessment: Theory and Practice (2016, Stylus) with Darby Roberts that serves as the foundational text for assessment courses in many higher education graduate programs. Gavin earned his Ph.D. in Leadership and Policy Studies from the University of New Hampshire.

Dr. Henning will host both a follow-up discussion to his keynote, and an additional breakout topic later in the day.

Questions: Craig Keigher, Director of Instructional Technology and Faculty Development, at (815) 802-8402 or ckeigher@kcc.edu.

item.title: And The Votes Are In!!
item.description:
Article Description: The votes have been tallied and the winners are determined.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​We had another great year of Halloween fun! Thank you to everyone who dressed up individually or in a group theme. And thanks to everyone who participated by voting.

The voting was very close this year.  L355 Academic Office won (finally after all these years), but Marketing /Media was right on our tails.  Next was BA/HR/Accounting, then Welcome Center/Corp & ConEd, and finally Bookstore.

As for the individual votes, we had a tie for first. Sheldon Walcher and TJ Hoekstra each received 7 votes. Ken Crite was next with 3 votes. The following people received 2 votes each--Liz Becvar, Belle in the Bookstore, Michele Buikema, David Cagle, Janet Fager, Kristen Larson, and Kari Nugent. And finally, receiving one vote each--Sam Jordan, Vanessa Lopez, Beth Nunley, Sarah Reyling, Janet Rosenbrock, and Cari Stevenson.

item.title: GSU Center for Performing Arts - Alice in Wonderland
item.description:
Article Description: The following event is not sponsored by KCC. This information is being posted as a service to the community.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The following event is not sponsored by KCC. This information is being posted as a service to the community.

​GSU asked if we could spread the word about their upcoming performance of Alice in Wonderland on Nov. 1st and 2nd (Nov. 3rd already sold out).  This is an experimental version which is rooted in the lens of Alice and many other characters as sexual assault survivors.  Although the script will remain in its original writing, the director uses soft insinuations through vocal inflections, staging, and set design to tell this unique interpretation.

To support their cause and social project, CASA of Will County and Guardian Angels of Will County will be on site to provide materials and support. Student tickets can be purchased at $10 each up to two tickets per student with a valid student I.D.

For more detailed information regarding the performances, go to www.centertickets.net and click on the Alice in Wonderland picture.

MATURE CONTENT/ON STAGE SEATING

Article Image:
Article Content:

Thursday 10 am - 2 pm  

Near Deputy Chief Springer's office

KCC in conjunction with KAMEG will host a Drug Take Back event on October 25.  Take this opportunity to safely and anonymously turn in expired, unwanted, or unused prescription or over the counter drugs as part of efforts by the DEA to prevent drug addiction and overdose deaths. Remove label or use a permanent marker to blackout your personal information.

*No liquids, illegal drugs, bio-hazardous materials or sharps/needles.

For more information on the DEA National Drug Take Back program, visit their website at:

https://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/drug_disposal/takeback/

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The 11th Annual KCC Halloween Competition is just around the corner!

I hope everyone is ready for some fall fun!

The annual Halloween contest will be on Wednesday, Oct. 31. This will be the eleventh year that areas of the college have competed against each other for the best Halloween costumes and department theme.  I would love to see more departments join in on the fun.

"It is hard to believe that we have been holding this fantastic annual competition on the main campus for 11 years now,” said Sheila Pfaff, one of the competition organizers. “I can’t wait to see what caldron of fun everyone has come up with this year!"

Each area's theme must be kept under wraps to keep the competition from borrowing ideas. As an incentive, the winning department will keep the “Fabulous” Traveling Tacky Trophy and will be able to show it off until the 2019 competition.

There also will be a Traveling Tacky Trophy for best costume. The winner of the best costume does not have to be part of one of the office/area themes. Those who are part of a department theme cannot vote for best theme, but should definitely vote for best individual costume.

If your department or staff in your area would like to get into the spirit of the day, please contact Sheila Pfaff, spfaff@kcc.edu or 815-802-8700 by Wednesday, Oct. 24.

Author: Sheila Pfaff
Article Date: 10/16/2018
Expires: 10/31/2018

item.title: Board Notes - Oct. 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Oct. 9, 2018

Special Guests. The Board were introduced to…
New full-time assistant professors that recently joined KCC:

  • Nimbus Couzin, physics/physical science

  • Jaclyn Cruz, director of the Respiratory Therapist program

  • Christopher Gibson, director of the Paramedic program

  • Sarah Gowler, coordinator of the Child Development program

  • Nathanael Karch, Asst. Prof. Nursing

  • Rebecca Murphy, Clinical Coordinator for Radiography

  • Mark Schnoor, economics/statistics

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Bid awards for ATEC technology equipment and PacketShaper replacement
  • Master plan for interior renovations 
  • Academic continuity plan for brief campus closures
  • Supplemental tax provision 
  • 2019-20 academic calendar
  • Tuition and course reimbursements
President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • Appreciation to Dr. Mike Boyd, Kari Nugent and their teams for planning and preparing Great Expectations.
  • There will be a public hearing on Oct. 16 about the solar array. It’s planned for installation on the south area of the Riverfront Campus. A portion of the energy generated will power the college. It will save the college as much as $40,000 per year for the first ten years, and over $100,000 per year in the decades after.
  • ICCB selected a new Executive Director, Dr. Brian Durham. He replaces Karen Hunter-Anderson who retires in November.
  • Kudos to professors Dr. Kris Condon, Steve Depasquale and the LEX Honors Society for hosting the Town Hall Meeting, where candidates for the Illinois House of Representatives 79th District debated issues.
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next ICCTA meeting will be held in Lisle on Nov 9-10. 
  • Michael Monaghan, ICCTA’s Executive Director, announced his retirement. Plans are underway to search for his successor. 
Student Trustee’s Report. Melany Villagomez said …
  • Eight KCC Phi Theta Kappa attended the Honors in Action Conference. The theme is Youth and Homelessness, and as a result KCC’s PTK members are planning a homelessness awareness event on campus.
  • Student Advisory Council is organizing this year’s Halloween Spooktacular, featuring a haunted house. 
  • STEM Club hosted a Telescope Cookout and Mars viewing.

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Image Caption:

Active Shooter Training

​

Article Content:

​

“The KCC Police Dept. will host two presentations related to Active Shooter Training. Two identical sessions will be held on Wednesday October 10th, running from 11:00 am to 12:30 pm and again from 2:00 pm to 3:30 pm in the college auditorium room L110. Both sessions are identical and are open to all students, faculty, and staff to be able to accommodate busy class and work schedules. The sessions will be presented by Sgt. John Raimondo and other members of the Kankakee County Tactical Response Team, and will include two video presentations, a discussion on the Tactical Response Team, and civilian active shooter response, and will end with a question and answer session.” There will be two sign in sheets, one for both faculty and staff and one for students, so please be sure to sign in. It's important we capture the number of participants for each session.

item.title: Get ready for Great Expectations
item.description:
Article Description: Learn about the day, and let us know if you're joining us for lunch.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Great Expectations is two weeks away. 
It’s a morning dedicated to strategic planning, and the college community is invited to share their creative ideas about the college’s future direction. Be sure to accept the calendar appointment we have an accurate count for lunch. 

Everyone is encouraged to participate.
This includes all employee groups. Administrators know that some people may have to come and go to ensure office coverage in our service areas.


The activities are centered on the five strategic priorities.
  • Excellence & Innovation
  • Access & Value
  • Partnerships & Collaboration
  • Institutional Culture & Diversity
  • Success

How were these priorities created?

The priorities were developed after college employees participated in the Strategic Planning Forum last October. The Strategic Planning Oversight Committee (SPOC) hosted the forum, and afterward used the ideas to determine the future priorities. The photos in the article depict some of the SPOC team's work. Then, President’s Cabinet reviewed and refined them. Finally, the priorities were shared with faculty and staff, and action teams were organized for each priority. The action teams’ work ended earlier this year, and now we’re using the priorities to build the next strategic plan.



How should I prepare?
Take a look at the data book, but there is no other preparation needed. Prefer a printed data book instead? Just let me know. 


Agenda for Great Expectations on Oct. 5

8 a.m. – Iroquois Room
Social time! Refreshments: coffee bar and light fare
8:30 a.m. - Auditorium
Introductions, music and welcome remarks
9-11:30 a.m. – College Center
IdeaFest 2018: Envisioning Our Future
Creative idea sessions featuring the strategic priorities
Noon - 1 p.m. - Iroquois Room
Lunch and recap from the morning
Menu: Urban Grub (pulled pork, baked potato bar) or Farmer’s Fare (Chopped salad with homemade dressing, warm bread, chicken noodle and cheesy broccoli soup)
1-4 p.m. – Iroquois Room
Small group (30 max.) strategy mapping with Dr. Jane Salisbury


Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 9/21/2018
Expires: 10/5/2018

item.title: Congratulations on promotion
item.description:
Article Description: Celebrate with Gregg Beglau on Friday, Sept. 21
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Gregg Beglau, KCC’s coordinator of Student Support and Transition in the Adult Education department, was recently promoted to Chief Petty Officer in the U.S. Naval Reserves.

Gregg served active duty in the U.S. Navy from 1993 to 1998, then was mobilized following the Sept. 11 attacks, serving in a Law Enforcement Physical Security unit for a year in Spain. 

He has been with the Naval Reserves since 2011. 

Everyone is invited to celebrate at a casual gathering on Friday, Sept. 21 at 2 p.m. in the Adult Education department. Cake will be served.

 

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 9/17/2018
Expires: 9/28/2018

item.title: You're invited to vision the future
item.description:
Article Description: Great Expectations is approaching fast. Let us know if you can participate.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Great Expectations is fast approaching. 
It’s a day dedicated to strategic planning. If you haven’t already, please accept or decline the calendar appointment on Oct. 5. That will help us with materials, food and refreshments. Bring your appetite. Even the menu is designed to inspire.

You’re in for an exciting day! 
It starts with a chance to mix and mingle, followed by a morning filled with creative idea generation around our five priorities. The agenda is below, and it’s sure to tap into our collective wisdom. In the afternoon, a small group will put our ideas in motion with Dr. Jane Salisbury, a strategy mapping expert. 

Teams are already hard at work.
Some are leading focus groups with community and business leaders, others are receiving training as facilitators, and a few are making sure the environment sparks creativity, passion and energy.  

There’s a little pre-work for you, too. 
Prior to Oct. 5, take some time to read the data book. It’s filled with important information to inform our work. Prefer a printed book instead? Just let me know. 

Please reach out to me or Dr. Mike Boyd with questions.
In the meantime, check out this quick video and our agenda below.


Great Expectations Agenda, Oct. 5, 2018:
8 am – Iroquois Room
Social time! Refreshments: coffee bar and light fare

8:30 am - Auditorium
Introductions, music and welcome remarks 

9-11:30 am – College Center
IdeaFest 2018: Envisioning Our Future
Creative idea sessions featuring the strategic priorities

Noon-1pm - Iroquois Room
Lunch and recap from the morning
Menu: Urban Grub (pulled pork, baked potato bar) or Farmer’s Fare (Chopped salad with homemade dressing, warm bread, chicken noodle and cream of broccoli soup) 

1-4 pm – Iroquois Room
Small group (30 max.) strategy mapping with Dr. Jane Salisbury
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 9/17/2018
Expires: 10/4/2018
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Board Notes - Sept. 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Sept. 10, 2018

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Resolutions honoring Professor Kari Livesey, Dr. Christine Young and Dean Julia Waskosky
  • Adoption of the FY19 budget 
  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Solicit bids for ATEC technology equipment and PacketShaper replacement
  • Award bids for ATEC furniture

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • KCC is hosting Great Expectations – a series of strategic planning events designed to capture input from the community, students and employees. The KCC Board of Trustees and the KCC Foundation board will receive surveys to provide their input.
  • KCC’s Miner South Extension Center offers 50%+ of an associate degree at its location through the new Fast Path program. The Higher Learning Commission will conduct a site visit there on Sept. 24 so it can formally become an additional campus location.
  • KCC Foundation hosted Swine, Wine and Dine on Aug. 25 and after all expenses they raised $68,872. Thanks to everyone who attended!
  • The Women’s Giving Circle fall appeal will be mailed in September to all WGC donors. 
  • The Foundation has assisted 11 students since the start of semester with the Cavalier Fund, Compassion Fund and the Betty Meents laptop scholarship. Students received assistance with books, digital codes, and background checks for their academic program, bus passes and an Arena food card. 
  • The KCC Foundation is hosting a Financial Officers luncheon later this fall.
  • Diefenbach family provided a substantial gift to the college through their trust.
  • On Thursday, Oct. 4, KCC will host its annual Job Fair, 9-noon, in the College Center. A special area will be designated for local manufacturers to celebrate National Manufacturing Month. 
  • Solar array may be installed on South end of campus before December. A portion of the energy generated will power the college. It will save the college as much as $40,000 per year for the first ten years, and over $100,000 per year in the decades after.
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next ICCTA meeting will be held in East Peoria on Sept. 14 and 15. 
  • ICCB executive director Karen Hunter-Anderson announced her retirement effective Nov. 30. 
  • ICCTA shared interesting articles about the characteristics of community college students in America. More than 40% of college students in the United States are community college students. Also, Illinois now leads the nation in bachelor’s degree completion rates among community college students. In fact, 53.8 percent of new Illinois community college students in 2010 (both full- and part-time) who transferred to a four-year college completed a bachelor’s degree within six years.

Student Trustee’s Report. Melany Villagomez said …
  • Eight KCC Phi Theta Kappa will attend the Honors in Action Conference. The theme is Youth and Homelessness.
  • Student Advisory Council is planning a number of events, including a Red Cross Blood Drive.
  • Student Life, in conjunction with the Alumni Association, is planning a Movie on the River event on Sept. 14.
  • Club Rush week was a success. Clubs recruited new members and planning is underway for their fall 2018 programming.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 9/14/2018
Expires: 9/21/2018
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Yoga Class
item.description:
Article Description: Increase your strength and flexibility
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Want to increase your strength and flexibility while decreasing the stress in your life?  How about joining a yoga class? 

Lamanda Garcia, Assistant Professor of MLT/Phlebotomy Coordinator, has graciously volunteered to lead a class that will meet on Mondays and Wednesdays, from 11-11:50 am in room G107.  Whether you are a beginner or advanced, all levels are welcome.  All you need is comfortable clothing, a yoga mat, and a block.  Why a block?  Most beginners are actually doing poses incorrectly.  The block will help with proper alignment and can be used until greater flexibility and stability is realized.  The classes are non-credit and are free to our employees.  The first class will begin this Monday, August 27.  Locker rooms are available directly across the hall – just bring a lock to secure your personal belongings.  If interested, please discuss this first with your supervisor to ensure adequate staffing in your work areas and to adjust your hours to still work a 40-hr week. 

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 8/22/2018
Expires: 8/31/2018
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Do you have a student in need?
item.description:
Article Description: Food Pantry Fall Information
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture defines food insecurity as the lack of "consistent, dependable access to enough food for active, healthy living."1 A recent report surveying community college students indicated that 56% experienced food insecurity.  At KCC, between Feb 15 - May 10, 2018, 504 students used our food pantry. 

Can you help me get the word out to everyone about the food pantry?  Please share our hours and location with students: Room R312.  Monday – Friday: 11 – 1 PM; T and Wednesday: 4 – 5 PM.

Faculty, please consider posting a version of the following in your syllabi or Canvas shells:

"Any student who faces challenges securing their food and believes this may affect their performance in the course is urged to contact the Food Pantry (foodpantry@kcc.edu Room R312) for support. Furthermore, please notify the professor if you are comfortable in doing so.  This will enable him/her to provide any other resources that s/he may possess." *

*Modified from language by Sara Goldrick-Rab, Ph.D. Professor of Higher Education and Sociology, Temple University

Please see attached PDF for information on services the Foundation can provide to support our students in need.

Thank you!

Author: Francesca Catalano
Article Date: 8/17/2018
Expires: 8/31/2018
item.author: Alison Nakaerts

item.title: Board Notes - Aug. 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Aug. 13, 2018

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Grant awards from the Workforce Board
  • Acceptance of the FY19 budget for public display
  • Board meeting schedule for 2019

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • For the 11th year in a row, 100% of the Radiography Class of 2018 passed their national competency exam on the first attempt.
  • Frances R. Wertz, a retired Bradley school teacher, passed away and left a portion of her estate to Kankakee Community College to be used for scholarships.
  • Enrollment numbers were tracking above last year on Monday. Up to date enrollment stats are visible in the portal.
  • Inservice begins on Wednesday with a joint session for Back to School. The college’s Faculty Development Committee always puts together a solid agenda of presentations.
  • KCC will host a Town Hall meeting for the two candidates for state representative to state their case for the position.
  • Classes begin Monday. This year marks the college’s 50th anniversary for opening our doors.
  • Swine, Wine & Dine is set for Saturday, August 25.

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next ICCTA meeting will be held in East Peoria on Sept. 14 and 15. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Melany Villagomez said …
  • KCC Phi Theta Kappa members will elect officers on Aug. 14.
  • Student Life is planning a Movie on the River event on Sept. 7.
  • Planning is underway with student clubs for their fall 2018 programming.

item.title: Come to the SUAA annual meeting
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Come to the KCC SUAA Chapter Annual Meeting on Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, 5:30-7:30 pm, at Aurelio's Pizzeria, 1600 N. Convent St., Bourbonnais. 

All KCC employees, chapter members and their guests are invited to attend! New members are welcome!

Representative Lindsey Parkhurst and former Representative Lisa Dugan have been invited to speak. Rep. Parkhurst will provide answers to our questions in writing. Former Rep. Dugan will speak at the meeting. 

In addition, SUAA Executive Director Linda Brookhart will provide an update on what is--and is not--happening in the state legislature and will be available to answer questions before and after the meeting. 

Cost is the same as last year, $15 per person. Menu includes garden salad, pizza buffet (cheese, vegetarian, sausage, pepperoni, etc), unlimited soft drinks, coffee, or tea (tax and gratuity included).

Registration with payment must be received by Tuesday, Aug. 21! No payments will be taken at the meeting itself. To register, send your $15 payment to Mary Posing in Continuing Education and Career Services or mail your payment to Barbara Arseneau, 20 Emery Drive, Bourbonnais, IL 60914. Checks should be made out to KCC SUAA Chapter.

Please send a list of questions that you would like Rep. Parkhurst and former Rep. Dugan to answer to l.guinn1@aol.com by Friday, Aug. 17!

Don’t miss this opportunity to find out these candidates’ positions on issues that matter to you as well as to get the latest news on what is happening in Springfield!

Author: Linda Guinn, KCC SUAA chapter president
Article Date: 8/14/2018
Expires: 8/21/2018
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Additional Readings on Emotional Intelligence: Flexible Leadership
item.description:
Article Description: How can you be a more effective team leader? Try mixing up your styles!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
How can you be a more effective team leader?  Try mixing up your styles! 
Research indicates that there are six different leadership styles: visionary, participative, coaching, affiliative, pacesetting and directive. 
A strong leader should be adaptive; not everyone responds to one style and over time the needs of the team may change.  For more information see this article.

Author: Dr. Francesca Catalano
Article Date: 8/2/2018
Expires: 8/10/2018

item.title: KCC passes VA audit
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​KCC’s veteran’s services team has passed a Veteran’s Affairs audit with flying colors.
The Federal VA audit resulted in no issues, with no findings.
The college expects to receive an official letter to confirm the results within the next month.
“This is a team effort, as many of us work with the veterans; completing vouchers, registering them, approving degree audits, certifying, payments, etc.,” said Deanna Liacone, director of financial aid. Liacone made special mention of contributions made by Kendra Souligne, coordinator in the Financial Aid Office; Michele Buikema, administrative assistant for the Information/Finance Office; and Vanessa Lopez, specialist II in the Financial Aid Office.
KCC offers a number of services for veterans, including a Veterans Resource Center.

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 7/19/2018
Expires: 8/9/2018
item.author: Katie Henry

item.title: Streak continues for X-ray program
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

For the 11th consecutive year, Kankakee Community College graduates have a 100 percent pass rate on the American Registry of Radiologic Technologists National Certification Examination.

The 14 graduates in the class of 2018 took the test between May and July. National comparison information will be available in January. Since 2013, the national pass rates have ranged from 87.2 percent to 93.3 percent.

Those who pass the test carry the credentials of Registered Radiologic Technologist.

Candidates were required to earn a minimum mean scaled score of 75 to pass, and KCC's graduates had scores ranging from 75 to 93, said Darla Jepson, director of KCC's Radiography Program.

KCC offers a two-year associate degree in radiography, which trains students for careers in radiologic technology. In addition to being eligible for the AART certification exam, graduates are also automatically eligible for a license with the Illinois Emergency Management Agency, Division of Nuclear Safety.

For more information about KCC's Radiography Program, contact Jepson at djepson@kcc.edu or 815-802-8832.

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 7/19/2018
Expires: 8/9/2018
item.author: Katie Henry

item.title: 3 present at state conference
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Three KCC employees recently made a presentation at EllucianIL, a one-day conference for Illinois' higher education institutions.

The three—(shown left-right) Meredith Purcell, Josh Gregoire and David Hermann—presented "Goodbye WebAdvisor, Hello Student Planning" at the June 2018 conference. They highlighted KCC's implementation and current uses of Colleague Student Planning, related technical and process challenges, and plans to expand its use in the future.

EllucianIL is for leaders to connect with peers and see presentations about trending topics and new features on the technology roadmap for Ellucian products and services. At KCC, Ellucian provides technology for Colleague and Self-Service (online registration).

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, July 9, 2018

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
Tuition and course reimbursement
Grant award for the Highway Construction Careers Training Program
Recommendation to solicit furniture bids for ATEC
WIOA On-the-Job Training Contract

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said...
Welcome to Alex Thorson, KCC’s new Head Men’s Basketball Coach.
KCC has been named the top community college in Illinois for helping students land a job after graduation according to Zippia, a career advice website. Ten years after graduation 87.1% of KCC grads are employed.
KCC earned a mention on NBC News Chicago last week for our participation in the new community bike share program. The program, called Bike 609, offers bike rentals around the community, and five bikes will soon be available for rent from the North Extension Center.
The Kankakee Valley Symphony Orchestra Association extends its gratitude to KCC and the Board of Trustees for our continued support of the July 4th event.
KCC received grant fund extensions for the ATEC construction from DCEO and ICECF
Two dates to remember: Faculty In-Service begins Monday, Aug. 13, and KCC is hosting a strategic planning forum called Great Expectations on Friday, Oct. 5. 

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
The 3% vs 6% salary cap remains a discussion item with ICCTA members. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Melany Villagomez said …
KCC Phi Theta Kappa members held a convention recap meeting June 21, and also attended Susan Lamore’s retirement event.
Student Life is planning a Movie on the River event this August.

​“Take me out to the Ballpark”

On July 12th, KCC “kicks” off with summer fun. 

At 12:30 pm the first annual kick ball tournament begins on the north lawn. Teams from all over the campus will compete for the tournament trophy, with the championship game at 2:30 pm.

A ballpark lunch of a hot dog, chips, and a soda will be available for all employees at the pavilion during the tournament. Spectators are encouraged to come out to the ballpark and cheer on their favorite team.

item.title: 'CRM' software implementation makes progress
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The TargetX customer relationship management (CRM) software implementation team has completed Phase 1 of the process to have strategies, plans, programs, and communication maps functional by July.

Beginning July 2, 2018, the CRM software will give KCC the capacity to:

  1. Electronically and immediately interact with any prospective student who completes an inquiry form or registers for a recruitment event.

  2. Respond to prospects with information about their program interests as determined by the information they provide.

  3. Prompt prospective students to complete the next step to enroll with messaging/interactions that foster personal connections in new ways that are seamless for the prospect.

  4. Provide just-in-time prospect student activity data, dashboards and reports that will inform recruitment staff which prospects are most likely to enroll for target marketing.

  5. Allow prospective students to register online for recruitment events.

Beginning September 2018, Phase 2 of the implementation process includes the launch of CRM capability for the online application, UChat, texting and social media which will:

  1. Provide prospective students automated guidance and timely prompts to complete an application and take the next steps to enroll.

  2. Schedule advisor appointments, send reminders and follow-up for canceled or missed appointments.

  3. Deliver robust communication options and interaction with staff through UChat and texting.

  4. Use social media in ways that support group affiliation among prospective students and connects them socially to KCC.

  5. Inform recruitment staff about prospective student communication activity for target marketing and outreach.

As the CRM software implementation evolves, additional KCC staff will be trained to use it for student interaction and outreach. CRM data and reports will be available to staff through the IR office. Reports will capture prospective student data, including but not limited to, demographic information and program interests. Reports will inform processes and actions to complete the recruitment process.

Implementation team members include: Co-leads Michael O’Connor, Kim Harpin, and David Hermann; Michelle Argento, Laura Gardner, Adam White, Francesca Catalano, Purva Rushi, Sean Hogan, Jacob Fansler, Josh Gregoire, Ellen Schmidt, and project ambassador Julia Waskosky.

Author: CRM implementation team
Article Date: 6/28/2018
Expires: 7/13/2018
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

Article Content:

​When requesting event services to be provided by the Physical Plant department, please use the R-25 event request program. In text format, please describe the event layout in terms of tables, chairs, and any other PPD specialty items or services needed. Please identify a KCC event manager's name and phone number for contact by PPD. When entering the reservation, please allow one hour before and after the event for room set up and take down. Individuals that do not have access to the R-25 system, should contact their department appointed requester and give them the required information to be submitted for entry into R-25. In order to assure that the event will be set up and ready for the date and time specified, please submit your request at least two weeks in advance of the event. If you have any questions or needs related to your event, please contact April Frye at 8179, or Carol Hubert at 8192. Thank you.

Author: PPD
Article Date: 6/19/2018
Expires: 7/10/2018
item.author: Jessica Braddy

item.title: Board Notes - June 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Highlights from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC's Board of Trustees meeting, June 11, 2018 


Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • The Dept. of Labor prevailing wage ordinance
  • Recommendation to operate within the budget draft
  • Adoption of personnel policy revisions
  • A letter of intent to consider a solar array installation

 President's Report. Dr. Avendano said…

  • Gov. Rauner signed a bill into law that shifts pension costs to colleges for any salary increases over 3% annually for participants in specific SURS programs. The intent is to stop end-of-career salary increases, but affects vested SURS employees regardless of years of service if the salary increase over 3% occurs in the calculation period for final earnings on which a pension is based.
  • KCC expects $350,000 less state budget support this year. The state funding formula is based on enrollment figures from two years prior.  
  • KCC is participating in the bike share program in our region managed by Zagster. A bike station for the program will be installed at the NEC later this summer.
  • GED Commencement was a wonderful event. Thanks to Maggie Wolf and her team for coordinating another meaningful ceremony.
  • The KCC Foundation provided a summary report for the board. Highlights:
    • Of the 402 KCC graduates this year, 4 grads received Women's Giving Circle grants and 52 grads were scholarship recipients.
    • More alumni programming is happening to engage our local alums.
    • Three bequest gifts were recently received.

Trustee's Report. Dick Frey said…

  • The ICCTA convention took place and the ICCTA awards were announced, and Dr. John Avendano received the Advocacy Award.
  • New ICCTA board leadership was selected.
  • The 3% salary cap was a hot discussion item at the ICCTA convention.

Student Trustee's Report. Melany Villagomez said …

  • Phi Theta Kappa's Illinois Regional Convention happened June 1-3, and a recap meeting for PTK is happening June 21.
  • KCC's strategic planning event Great Expectations is happening Oct. 5, and planning has begun for the day.
  • Student Advisory Council leadership conference is happening later this year in Orlando.
  • Student Life is planning a Movie on the River event this summer.
  • Planning is underway with student clubs for their fall 2018 programming.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 6/13/2018
Expires: 6/22/2018

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Ethical Reasoning is next up in the general education outcome assessment rotation! Faculty members teaching courses with this outcome will be contacted at the beginning of the fall semester. Later in the term those faculty members will receive a randomized list of a sample of their students; then all they will have to do is submit artifacts demonstrating those students' ethical reasoning abilities. Identifying information will be removed from the artifacts, and a small team of faculty will assess those items as part of a short-term summer 2019 research project.

Details regarding how to submit artifacts will be provided at the beginning of the fall semester. For now, feel free to familiarize yourself with the Ethical Reasoning rubric.

item.title: Board Notes - May 2018
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, May 14, 2018

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Tuition and course reimbursements
  • Grant awards
  • Memorandum of understanding for WIOA’s Livingston County satellite office
  • First reading of personnel policy revisions
  • Resolutions honoring six retirees for their service to the college – Nicki DePatis, Kim Garretson, Jean Janssen, Susan LaMore, Nancy Ozee, and Elise Schultz.
  • Resolution honoring Justin Hasselbring for his service as Student Representative to the Board of Trustees.

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • KCC’s Food Pantry was recognized as Innovator in Social Service at the Daily Journal Progress Awards, and Meijer is donating $1000 in gift cards to our pantry at its opening on May 17.
  • Appreciation to Dr. Kris Condon and her team for coordinating Law Week. KCC raised more than $2,000 during Trivia Night, and proceeds benefit Prairie State Legal Services. Former Board of Trustees member Dennis Marek and Walter “Wally” Pieszka hosted another notable Law Week night when they candidly talked about Wally’s experiences during World War II. Wally is the subject of Dennis’ book The Ultimate Survivor.
  • Celebration season is in full swing, and the commencement ceremony is a reminder of what brings us the most joy at KCC. Appreciation to the graduation task force for their hard work. Our GED graduation ceremony is happening Thursday, June 7, and that event ends our series of pinnings, graduations and celebrations. 

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The ICCTA convention is June 1-2 in Springfield. The ICCTA awards will be announced during the convention. 
  • GED graduation is a special and meaningful event – everyone should experience it. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Justin Hasselbring said …
  • The PTK convention was a memorable experience. Ten KCC students went, but in all about 4000 students from around the world attended. 
  • Student Life hosted the soccer bleacher dedication, and it was a successful event. 
  • Thanks to the board for their support during a brief farewell speech.

item.title: Thank you for a successful Law Week!
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:
Law Week 2018 is another one for the books, and it could not have happened without a whole KCC team to make it happen.  We estimate 200 people were on campus across all four evenings to recognize the “Separation of Powers:  Framework for Freedom.”
  • To those offices and agencies participating in Thursday night’s Civics Fair, thank you for your roles in engaging the next generation of civically literate students!
  • To Dr. Avendano, thank you for your introductions of our campus guests on Tuesday and Thursday night and for your support of 2018 Law Week!
  • To Prairie State Legal Services, thank you for the continued partnership and for the opportunity to raise money for (and awareness of) the good work you do in our community.
  • To our poster contest judges—Professor Jean Janssen, Judge Imani Drew, and Janet Glazar, thank you for your time, your critical eyes, and your judging capabilities!
  • To our Monday night panelists—Sheriff Downey, Chief Judge Kramer, Auditor Lee, Vice-Chair Liehr, and State’s Attorney Rowe—You were a powerhouse panel that should be required listening for every citizen in our community.  Thank you for your public service and for your commitment to our week’s events.
  • To our Tuesday night author, Dennis Marek, and his special guest, Wally Pieszka, your recollections and your writing were living history for everyone in attendance.  It was an honor to host you on our campus.  Thank you.
  • To Rich Soderquist, Eric Springer, and the KCC Police Department, thank you for helping with the logistics for the entire week.
  • To KCC’s Physical Plant Team, including April Frye, Carol Hubert, Brian Yeoman, and the entire PPD staff, thank you for your good humor, your follow-through, and your infinite patience!  We appreciate all you do for us every day!
  • To our student volunteers and participants, thank you for being such excellent ambassadors for YOUR college and program!  You made us all proud!
  • To the leadership of the Kankakee County Bar Association and the Society of Women in Law, thank you for always making a place at the table for our students’ participation in Law Week activities.
  • To the 2018 Law Week Committee, thank you for your time, your ideas, your talents, and your commitment to making a week-long event such a success!  
Author: Dr. Kristine Condon
Article Date: 5/14/2018
Expires: 5/25/2018

item.title: Summer PPD projects
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

I want to bring everyone up to speed on projects that happening on the Riverfront Campus this summer, and their impact on the college.

Thank you for your patience and cooperation while we complete these projects to improve the physical environment of our campus.

Replacing boiling and water cooling

The college is taking a phased approach to replace the antiquated steam boiler heating plant and the chilled water cooling systems on Riverfront Campus. We will be changing over from steam boilers to high efficient hot water boilers and the chillers will be replaced with new high efficient chillers and cooling towers. The first phase, which has started, will remove one of the three main steam boilers, heat exchangers, and all associated piping. We will then install the first two of four hot water boilers along with new distribution piping. The work during the first phase will be in the boiler room, mechanical room in front of the main reception desk, north side and south corridor of the Health Careers Center for Excellence Building, Prairie Building, and the Technology Building. This is a large project encompassing multiple student and faculty areas. We are working with the contractors to work around the college’s academic schedule in a way that will limit disruptions. The biggest impact of the project--affecting the entire Riverfront Campus--will be the lack of heat.  Beginning May 14, we will shut down the boiler plant to begin the demo phase of the project.  This could become an issue because we currently use heat to temper the air during the cooling season. Without heat, we cannot control the temperature of air  supplied to each area. 

The good news: Physical Plant Department has a control strategy in place to help mitigate any excessive cooling. If temperatures get too chilly, please call to PPD at ext. 8170 or ext. 8174 to share the cold area and we will make further adjustments to the system that will allow the space to warm back up. The bulk of the work begins May 14 and will be complete before the start of fall semester.

Remodel bathroom

Beginning May 14, we will begin to remodel the third floor women’s east restroom near Adult Education offices. The restroom will be closed from May 14 to mid-July. Upon completion, it will look very similar to the women’s restroom near Financial Aid.

Foundation moving

Beginning May 14, we will be converting Room D211 into the new Foundation offices. This work will be completed by June 30.

Author: Rob Kenney, coordinator of facility construction & building maintenance
Article Date: 5/1/2018
Expires: 6/4/2018

Thirty-three TRIO students and 17 KCC employees were recipients of STAR Awards at a reception in their honor on April 3 in the Iroquois Room. 

Student awards are presented to students who have maintained a cumulative GPA of 3.25 or higher, are currently enrolled at KCC and have completed at least 12 credit hours during the past 12 months.

Employees were nominated by the student award recipients because they have made a difference in the life of the student.

Student recipients: Karen Avalos, Elan Benge, Lauren Chouinard, Berenice Cintora-Villagomez, Haley Corbett, Sarah Doris, Jasmine Elliott, Piaget Felix, Jeffery Gifford, Brooke Graveline, Timothy Grazulis, Elyse Gustafson, Jonathan Hernandez, Jerrica Jarrett, Rachael Kamp, Brittany Lafond, Jenna Lanoue, Kenzie Lindgren, Allison LoCascio, Mianna Malone, Candace Martell, Destiny May, Tessa Mullin, Erica Paulissen, Shaila Ruiz, Pedro Santos, Abigail Sievert, Kari Snyder, Melany Villagomez, Jacob Virklan, Katelyn Windebank, Joshua Wisniewski and Alisha Wright.

item.title: Med Lab Professionals Week: 4/22-28
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

National Medical Laboratory Professionals Week will be April 22-28, 2018. 

This week recognizes the contributions of professionals whose work in the medical/clinical laboratory helps give our nation the best possible health care. These medical laboratory personnel play an increasingly vital role in the diagnosis and prevention of disease; and often their dedicated efforts are unseen as they work behind the scenes.

Every day, nurses, physicians, and other healthcare workers depend on laboratory professionals to perform tests on blood and other body fluids, interpret the results, and help provide a complete picture of a patient’s health. Using modern biomedical equipment and complicated analysis, laboratorians can detect the presence of cancer, identify infectious viruses and bacteria, and measure glucose, cholesterol, or drug levels in blood. Without this precise and valuable information, medicine would simply become guesswork.

From April 22- 28, 2018, please join these dedicated professionals in celebrating Medical Laboratory Professionals Week and their vital role in protecting and promoting your health.

First year KCC Medical Laboratory Technology (MLT) students will be in attendance for their program course labs (M139) Thursday, April 26 from 8 a.m. - 5:30 p.m. All staff and other students are invited to stop by and “see them in action”  - performing some medical laboratory tests.

To view a video about KCC's program, go to https://youtu.be/8OYl6N7w2ZA.

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:

Article Content:

​The Student Learning Committee is looking for faculty interested in participating in the Summer Gen Ed Assessment Project!

Faculty will spend two days norm training, assessing student writing samples, and making recommendations for improvement. Participants will earn a $500 stipend, and breakfast, lunch, and caffeine will be provided both days.

Priorities for selection include availability and cross-divisional representation; if there are not enough full-time applicants with matching availability, adjunct faculty members will be considered.

If interested, please fill out the Gen Ed Summer Team Interest Form before April 30th. The team will be announced before final exam week.

Questions? Contact Denise Caparula or any member of the Student Learning Committee.

item.title: Jepson and Gocken named as 2018 Outstanding Faculty Award recipients
item.description:
Article Description: Announcement of 2018 Outstanding Faculty Awards
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content: ​

The Outstanding Full-Time Faculty Member recipient is Darla Jepson, director and professor in the Radiography Program.

For Darla, her success lies in setting high standards for her program and students, then helping them succeed. It has paid off for the KCC Radiography program, which has a 100% pass rate on the national certification exam for 10 straight years. Part of the quality education Darla strives to provide is in keeping up with the ever-changing profession of medical imaging. She works tirelessly to gain financial support for upgrades to the radiography lab so students can be trained on the most current technology.

A proud alumna of KCC, Darla has formed deep connections with students and the community. She is chairperson of KCC's Career Pathways Committee, providing leadership in collaborating with local employers and stakeholders to create programs and occupational opportunities to meet employers' needs. She also is a Certified Workplace Excellence Facilitator, which included extensive training to help students develop workplace skills which are sought by employers.

 

The Outstanding Part-Time Faculty Member recipient is Amber Gocken, who teaches computer graphic design in the Business/Technology Division.

Amber exhibits many qualities and values that make an instructor truly exceptional.

She has been instrumental in implementing new software and associated coursework to keep students current with industry standards. Her students complete projects with real world relevance and value to benefit the community. Examples include designing children's books which are donated to the KCC Child Development Center, and designing new branded graphics for River Valley Metro Bus Service.

A 2011 graduate of KCC's Graphic Design Program, Amber will complete a master's degree in independent film and digital imaging this spring.

In the spring of 2016, Gocken was the founding advisor for the KCC Arts & Technology Society which, "promotes a creative forum for all mediums of art and technology." She also volunteers in the community.

  

Jepson and Gocken will be KCC's nominees for the annual Illinois Community College Trustees Association outstanding faculty awards presented in June.

item.title: Board Notes - April 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Summary of topics from the KCC Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, April 9, 2018

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Bid awards for computer servers and switches, restroom renovations, and phase one of the central steam boiler plant equipment replacement.
Presentations. Honored and distinguished guests…
  • Dr. Mike Boyd, vice president for Instructional and Student Success presented the new tenured faculty Bridget Bertrand-Essington, professor of Law Enforcement/Criminal Justice and Lamanda Garcia, professor of Medical Laboratory Technology.
  • Craig Keigher, director of Instructional Technology and Faculty Development presented the KCC Outstanding Faculty of the Year award recipients Darla Jepson, professor of Radiography and Amber Gocken, professor of Computer Graphic Design.
  • Phi Theta Kappa advisors Susan Lamore and Frances Hebert introduced this year’s PTK student officers: Kenzie Lindgren and Erica Paulissen, co-presidents; Rylie Karvunis and Victoria Sikma, co-vice presidents; and Justin Hasselbring, membership chair.
  • Julia Waskosky, dean of Student Development introduced Melany Villagomez as the 2019 Student Board of Trustee member who will be seated at the June meeting. 
  • Faculty Association President Steve DePasquale and Board Chairman Jerry Hoekstra formally signed the faculty contract.
President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • ATEC is quickly progressing. Steel has been erected and geo-thermal field has gone in.
  • KCC is creating a talent pipeline for CSL Behring and Nucor Steel, two of the area’s largest employers. Both are preparing for large-scale expansions at their local facilities. 
  • Donna Mann, GED program instructor, received the Illinois Adult and Continuing Educators Association Arthur J. Stejskal Teacher of the Year Award.
  • Dr. Mike Boyd was honored by the Higher Learning Commission as a “Mighty Mentor” for his exemplary volunteer service to peer reviewers.
  • KCC’s Food Pantry will be recognized as Innovator in Social Service at the Daily Journal Progress Awards.
  • Several activities are planned for Law Week April 30-May 4. Including an event with former Board of Trustees member Denny Marek. He is talking with Walter Pieszka, the subject of his book The Ultimate Survivor, May 1 from 6:30-8 p.m. in the Auditorium.
  • KCC is collaborating on a solar farm proposal with our South Metropolitan Higher Education Consortium (SMHEC) partners.
  • Appreciation to Ken Crite, coordinator of Career Services, and the team who organized the Spring Job Fair. Seventy-seven employers participated in the event. 
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • Lobby Day is happening on April 18, and he is talking with legislators on behalf of KCC.
Student Trustee’s Report. Justin Hasselbring said …
  • Recent fundraising events raised more than $450 for student activities, and the next fundraiser is a silent auction on April 25.
  • PTK recently inducted 43 new members. 
  • Student Advocacy day is April 12 and the agenda revolves around MAP grants.
  • Upcoming events: SAC is hosting a talent show this Wednesday, April 11, a Battle of the Sexes on April 23, and a three-on-three basketball tournament on May 2.






Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 4/10/2018
Expires: 4/20/2018
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Congratulations on award
item.description:
Article Description: Dr. Michael Boyd honored by HLC
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Dr. Michael Boyd, KCC vice president for instruction and student success, was honored last week by the Higher Learning Commission for his exemplary volunteer service! 

"He was nominated by multiple staff and other peer reviewers as a 'Mighty Mentor' for his tireless development and support of other peer reviewers," said Dr. Francesca Catalano, who attendied the Peer Corps Recognition Luncheon.

According to the Higher Learning Commission: Mighty Mentors selflessly share their knowledge and wisdom, and lend a guiding hand to other reviewers whenever they can. Others know to come to them with questions, concerns, or simply for words of encouragement. Simply said, they are tops at tutelage.

"Congratulations Dr. Boyd for the wonderful recognition," said Dr. John Avendano, KCC's president. "To receive the recognition by the HLC is a great honor, and to be nominated by several people speaks to your commitment and belief in the process."

Only two such awards were given from the 19- state HLC region.

Mike is shown here with the other award recipient, Jill Carlson, director of assessment and accreditation at Santa Fe Community College.

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 4/9/2018
Expires: 4/23/2018
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: New KCC event calendar adds features
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

On Tuesday, April 10, a new events calendar will premiere on the portal.

This calendar, driven by Tockify software, includes a number of features (also shown on the photos, below):

  • Add individual events to your personal calendar
  • Quickly share events on social media
  • View as a list or on a calendar
  • Search future events
  • Search events by date
  • Add a new calendar with all events in your Outlook
  • Thumbnail pictures to distinguish events at a glance



The calendar will roll out on the portal to start. It will be visible to employees (below Update) and students (at the top, above KCC News).

After a few months, it also will appear on a newly redesigned KCC news and events page.

At this time, there is no change to the procedure for having an event added to the calendar.

 Anyone with questions or comments is invited to contact Kari Nugent, director of marketing and public relations.

Article Content:

A new system of communication with prospective students is being developed, with training and priority initiatives scheduled to be in place before July 1. 

The “Customer Relationship Management” technology, also called a CRM, will not only bring together numerous processes that are currently completed separately, it will also engage prospective students through the recruitment process. 

To learn more about the chosen software, the steps in the process for implementing it, and who is on the implementation team, read the attached CRM Question & Answer sheet.

The implementation team is excited about the capability of the CRM and the impact it will have on the way a prospective student experiences KCC. With the support of the Board and Dr. Avendano, the team is working diligently to maximize the potential of the CRM and benefits to KCC’s future students. 

Anyone with further questions is invited to contact Julia Waskosky at ext. 8215.

item.title: Board Notes - March 2018
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, March 12, 2018

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Request to bid computer servers and switches and phase one of the central steam boiler plant equipment replacement
  • Bid awards to upgrade digital radiography equipment 
  • Audit proposal for fiscal years 2018 and 2019
President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • Thanks to Rep. Lindsay Parkhurst. She delivered a signed resolution from the Illinois House of Representatives that honors KCC for its gold star AASHE rating and national rank for sustainability. 
  • Congratulations to Coach Donnie Denson and the KCC Women’s Basketball team. They won the Region IX tournament, and Coach Denson was named Coach of the Year for Region IX.
  • ATEC is moving forward and construction gets started again in early April.
  • The board toured our new food pantry, which was honored with the Daily Journal Progress award for Innovator in Social Services. KCC will receive the award at a ceremony on April 12.
  • Thanks to Days of Learning presentation teams for their work to bring emotional intelligence and customer care to the forefront.
  • The KCC Foundation provided a summary report for the board. Highlights included a partnership with Nucor Steel, expanded Women’s Giving Circle support and Arena Food Services sponsorships for the new food pantry. The Foundation also received 304 scholarship applications this year – nearly 100 more applications than last year. 
  • The Illinois Council of Community College Presidents recently met. Discussions included elections, budget predictions, current legislation, and the state’s investment in higher education. 
  • Immigration experience is the topic for several upcoming events on campus. Book and panel discussions, movies and more are planned starting Wednesday, March 14. Events are coordinated and sponsored by the Humanities and Social Sciences Division and the Miner Memorial Library. 
Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The Illinois Community College Trustees Association members met and discussed pending legislation, board member training, and the role of community college foundations. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Justin Hasselbring said …
  • Summer registration began today.
  • PTK hosted a scavenger hunt and ice cream social to benefit the food pantry. 
  • The ICCB SAC meeting in Lisle was productive and the group discussed Student Advocacy Day. 
  • Students, faculty, staff and community members are invited to Buffalo Wild Wings on March 14 to support KCC Student Life. Mention the fundraiser when you order and 15% of the profit will be shared with us.
  • Four new benches are on campus thanks to the Cav Cap Challenge.
  • You’re invited to participate in upcoming campus events:
    • National Ag Day on March 20
    • Book discussion for Women’s History Month - Girl Interrupted
    • Pack the Park on March 22
    • Blood drive on March 28

A bipartisan group of former Congresswomen discuss their paths to public service, the challenges they faced, and the obstacles they still need to overcome. Live streaming of the event can be found here from 6 – 7:30 PM on March 2nd.  For more information on this series, see this link from the National Archives.  This event is presented in partnership with the U.S. Association of Former Members of Congress and commemorates the 100th anniversary of Jeannette Rankin becoming the first congresswoman.

item.title: Criminal Justice Program celebrates Black History Month
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​The Law Enforcement / Criminal Justice Program celebrated Black History Month by presenting students with speakers from local and state law enforcement agencies.  The speaker series began on February 6th and concluded on February 27th.  Speakers included Lieutenant Donell Austin from Kankakee Police Department, Sergeant William Berry from the Bradley Police Department and Captain Marcus Gipson from the Illinois State Police.  Officers spoke on topics such as department demographics, the positive impacts of diversity within a police department, personal experiences of being the first minority officer within a department.  Other topics included police accountability, the competitive nature of a police career, and the importance of personal and academic preparation for a criminal justice career.  

Author: Karen Richards
