item.title: Employee Satisfaction Survey deadline extended
item.description:
Article Description: Please take the survey before it ends at 11:59 pm, Friday, March 2
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

Your feedback is valued!

Article Content:

To date, 163 employees have taken the employee satisfaction survey.  If you haven't already done so, please complete before it ends at 11:59 pm, Friday, March 2.  Here is the link:  http://new.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_8lf8HBbVT606bK5

It should take about 20 minutes to complete. Ruffalo Noel Levitz is administering the survey and--as a third-party--helps assure that answers will be confidential. Information pertaining to individual identities will not be shared.

KCC is encouraging all full-time employees, current adjunct instructors, and part-time employees averaging 16 hours or more of work per week to complete the employee satisfaction survey.

This will be the seventh year we have used Noel Levitz to administer the survey. It allows for comparison between years to see how we are doing, as well as a comparison to approximately 30 other community colleges across the nation. We hope to have the survey results compiled and distributed sometime in April. 

Here are questions and answers related to the survey, which have been asked before:

   Q: Can the survey be saved and restarted if I am interrupted?

    A: Yes, as long as you use the same computer when returning to the survey.    

    Q: Can we offer some type of incentives to employees for completing the survey in order to increase participation?

    A: KCC is offering an incentive for the completion of THIS survey only (not to be precedent setting for other surveys). Upon completion of the survey, you will be given the opportunity to print off a coupon for a medium size coffee or 20 ounce pop (Approx. $2.00 value) redeemable in the Hammes Café.  Additionally, if you put your name on the bottom of the coupon, you will be entered into a second incentive where we will draw four names with each person winning a $25 Wal-Mart gift certificate.  

    As always, thank you in advance for your cooperation and honest/constructive feedback.

item.description:
Article Description: Construction could resume as early as April 2.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
The general contractor has submitted a schedule with an anticipated site startup date of April 2, sub-contractors are beginning the process of re-mobilization anticipating the April 2 date.
  • Product and material submittals are being re-submitted for approval by the architects and engineers.
  • Drawings and specs are being reviewed for any building/mechanical code changes.

item.title: Board Notes - Feb. 2018
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Feb. 12, 2018.

Action Items
The Board approved the following:
  • Request to bid restroom renovations and digital radiography equipment
  • Course fees
  • Tuition and fee increase for FY19 to $154
  • Tuition/course reimbursement

President’s Report. 
Dr. Avendano said…
  • Thanks to Katelynn Ohrt, director of the Horticulture and Agriculture programs. She shared photos and information with the board.
  • Credit division headcount was up 5.1% over last spring, but credit hours dipped 2.4% over last year. 
  • State Senate Bill 2597 is one to watch. It proposes consolidation of Illinois Board of Higher of Education, Illinois Community College Board and the Illinois Student Assistance Commission. 
  • Ed Emerson will be the 2018 commencement speaker. Ed graduated from KCC in 1978, and is now a political strategist. His career in behind-the-scenes politics has taken him to the White House, where he worked for 7 years. Most recently, Ed served as lead advance for a presidential candidate. 
  • KCC invited representatives of the regional Top 25 employers to lend a voice on program advisory committees when appropriate. The Economic Alliance 2018 Market Profile brochure showcases the good work happening with employers across the region. IDES reported that Kankakee County’s 2017 unemployment rate dropped 1.2 percent over 2016, and there are 1300 more jobs in 2017 than the previous year. 
  • The Cash Bash is happening Saturday, Feb. 17 at the Quality Inn in Bradley. Tickets are still available. Proceeds benefit KCC athletics.
  • The college is hosting a reception to announce our new food pantry on Wednesday, Feb. 14 at 2 p.m. in Room R307. Students, faculty and staff are invited to attend.
  • Activities are planned to celebrate Black History Month. Everyone is invited to attend the lunch and learn on Wednesday, Feb. 14 and lecture on Tuesday, Feb. 20. 

Trustee’s Report
Dick Frey said…
  • He is closely watching legislative fluctuations, and is working to educate new legislators about community college needs.
  • The next Illinois Community College Trustees Association meeting will take place in March, and Lobby Day is in April.

Student Trustee’s Report
Justin Hasselbring said …
  • Club Rush activities were a success.
  • New ways to advertise student events was discussed during the ICCB-SAC conference call this month. 
  • Students, faculty, staff and community members are invited to Chipotle on Tuesday, Feb. 13 to support Student Life. Mention the fundraiser when you order and 50% of the profit will be shared with us.
  • Students came to Meet the Student Trustee on Jan. 22 and 23 in the College Center, and Justin was able to get good feedback.
  • Basketball Pack the Place happened Jan. 25, and cheerleaders from Bishop McNamara High School performed at half time.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 2/13/2018
Expires: 2/23/2018

item.title: MSE division hosts several events
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

It is a busy time for the Math, Science and Engineering Division! 

On Monday (Feb. 5), we host administrators, teachers and guidance counselors from 11 partner high schools for a Math Summit moderated by Kathleen Almy from Northern Illinois University. 

Teams will work to develop fourth year, transitional math courses that will better bridge students to college-level math and will meet the requirements of the Postsecondary & Workforce Readiness Act. 

On Tuesday (Feb. 6), we welcome 192 students from 12 area high schools competing in the WYSE (Worldwide Youth in Science & Engineering) Academic Challenge.  

Also on Tuesday, students from Milford High School will tour the campus and the gross anatomy lab with Dr. JP Cohen. 

Thank you to all team members who worked hard to make these visits possible!

item.description:

Article Content:

Input related to KCC from employees, students and the community is always welcome. 

One way to provide feedback is to utilize the Candid Comments form. The form is available electronically and on paper. The electronic form is on the college website.

The paper forms are located: 

  • In the College Center, near the Workforce Development Center hallway 
  • 3rd floor intersection of L and R buildings. 
  • Inside the entrance to the Library, on the south wall. 

Feedback icon also an indicator that input is welcome
Update is a natural tool to use to gather feedback, comments and opinions on topics affecting the college community.

 When you see the feedback icon (at left) it's an indication that the article writer is seeking your input.

Please take the time to share your thoughts on the topics of the article. An email link or phone number is provided at the end of the article. Please use this tool as we build a culture of communication at KCC.

item.title: Eat your heart out Valentine’s Day food pantry kick-off
item.description:
Article Description: ​Students, faculty and staff are invited to a grand opening celebration for KCC’s food pantry on Wednesday, Feb. 14, at 2 p.m. in Room 307 on the Riverfront Campus
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Students, faculty and staff are invited to a grand opening celebration for KCC’s food pantry on Wednesday, Feb. 14, at 2 p.m. in Room 307 on the Riverfront Campus. Ribbon cutting and remarks are scheduled for 2:30 p.m. Refreshments—including Valentine’s candy—will be available.

“It’s tough to concentrate in class when you’re hungry, or if you’re worrying how you’ll afford a meal for your family that night,” said Francesca Catalano, KCC’s associate dean for math, science and engineering, who is coordinating the pantry. “That’s why we’re promoting it as ‘Food for Thought,’ as you’ll see from the signage on the door and around campus. We know our pantry will help the most vulnerable among us.”

The pantry is in the Arts and Sciences Building, Room R312 and it is for KCC students. Donations are being accepted for non-perishable food in the white bins near the First Floor Information Desk. Monetary donations to the pantry can be made to the KCC Foundation.

Author: Kari Nugent

Expires: 2/15/2018

item.title: New advising process this semester
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

In the past, Student Services required all students to make appointments with an advisor for most of the year.

More than 60 percent of appointments did not show up. There were some times with up to a three-week wait to meet with an advisor. 

This semester, we have implemented an open advising schedule for continuing students. Continuing students can meet with advisors on a first-come/first-serve basis or request an appointment. This allows students flexibility to meet with their advisor when they want.

New students are still required to schedule an appointment so important academic information and goals can be reviewed.

New students can make their appointments online after completing the application. Applicants are informed of this option in a personalized "welcome and next steps" email.

We hope these changes will provide students with the best customer service and flexibility.

For more information, please contact Meredith Purcell at mpurcell@kcc.edu or ext. 8514.

Author: Meredith Purcell

item.description:
Article Description: Basketball Pack the Place is Jan. 25.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

**Note** The Lady Cavaliers game vs. Kennedy-King College Jan. 25 has been canceled. The following information reflects this change.

​

Fans are invited to wear scarlet and navy for “Pack the Place” basketball activities on Thursday, Jan. 25 at Kankakee Community College.

The Cavaliers men's team plays Kennedy-King College at 7:30 p.m. Admission is free and there will be free refreshments while supplies last.

Cheerleaders from Bishop McNamara Catholic High School will perform during half-time. A DJ will also provide music throughout the game.

“We want the community to feel school spirit on game days for Cavaliers sports, and the campus should be alive with excitement and enthusiasm,” said Linh Williams, coordinator of student life. “To spread a sense of pride and competition, KCC Spirit T-shirts will be available for purchase for $5 during the game.”

For more information about Pack the Place, contact Williams at ltwilliams@kcc.edu.


It is a casual day for employees who follow the casual day guidelines. View those guidelines here.

item.title: Foundation offices are moving
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The KCC Foundation offices are on the move!

The entire operation will be moving to Room D211 following the Spring 2018 semester.

Reasons for the move include:

  • Donor access – parking and an elevator will be closer.
  • Confidentiality – Meeting Room L253 is adjacent to the current Foundation offices. The frequent activity in that room, and people waiting outside the door for their meeting to begin, result in a compromise of confidentiality that Foundation staff can have in donor conversations.
  • Increased utilization of meeting rooms – The Foundation will have easier access to Room D300 for Foundation Board and committee meetings.
  • More L253 for everyone else - Other groups desiring to use Room L253 will have expanded access to it.

Patience and adaptability are appreciated by all as the institution makes this forward move to improve Foundation access and interactions with donors.

Author: Vicki Gardner
Article Date: 1/18/2018
Expires: 2/2/2018

item.title: Board Notes - Jan. 2018
item.description:
Article Description: Summary of topics addressed at the Board of Trustee's January meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Jan. 8, 2018.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Request to purchase computers
  • WIOA office lease for its Livingston County location
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • Appreciation goes out the PPD team. They dealt with a water main break on Sunday and also shoveled and salted the campus in advance of our faculty, staff and student arrivals. 
  • ATEC funding has been approved by the Dept. of Commerce and Economic Opportunity and the Governor’s office. The college and its building partners are reassessing costs and the projected timeline.
  • Four CSL Behring employees have been selected for new Dept. of Labor Apprenticeships which begin this month. The employees will work at CSL three days per week in industrial, hands-on positions. Two days per week, they will be students in the KCC’s Industrial Electrical Technology program. 
  • Enrollment is always a focus. More students are registered, but they are taking fewer credit hours. Headcount is tracking 3.76% up over last spring, while credit hours are down 4.1%.
  • Dr. Boyd and KCC’s Business and Technology Division offered stats and information about its Associate of Applied Science programs.  
  • Kudos to Professor Clay Sterling. The North American Board of Certified Energy Practitioners (NABCEP) renewed KCC’s accreditation of four courses in its Solar Photovoltaic certificate.
  • Spring in-service took place last week, and collaboration was the theme. Accolades to the Faculty Development Group for their work. 
  • Beginning this May, Governors State University will offer its Masters in Educational Administration program at our North Extension Center.
  • Plans are in place to confer with Illinois State University President Larry Dietz about the Council of Presidents agenda. (Editor’s note: Dr. A is president of the Illinois Council of Community College Presidents, and Dietz holds a similar role among university presidents.)

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • The next Illinois Community College Trustees Association meeting will take place in March. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Justin Hasselbring said …
  • Spring classes began this week. Welcome Back week is in full swing with faculty and staff offering directions and support for new students.
  • Club Rush activities are planned. 
  • Students are invited to Meet the Student Trustee on Jan. 22 and 23 in the College Center.
  • Basketball Pack the Place is happening Jan. 25, and cheerleaders from Herscher and Bishop McNamara high schools will perform at half time.

item.title: ​KCC Employee Giving Message
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

With the beginning of the semester I wanted to share good news. We have met and exceeded our goal of $21,460 for the KCC Employee Giving Campaign. Your gifts will assist students in need through Compassion Fund, will help remove barriers to completion with your investment in Women’s Giving Circle, will provide funding for scholarships, will enable the Foundation to fund equipment needed for instruction and assist students who lack funding for books and supplies. 

Thank you for your generosity! 

As a reminder, those of you who have recurring gifts to the Employee Giving Fund, your recurring gift began with the Jan. 5, 2018 payroll. Recurring gifts are the gifts that keep on giving (if you indicate recurring on the Employee Giving Form your gift will continue--as is--year after year). 

If you have not given yet, there is still time. The campaign goes until the end of the fiscal year. Each dollar assists students in their success. You can give online or you can fill out the PDF form and return it to the Foundation Office.

Thank you for your caring support.

Author: Kelly Myers

KCC’s Food Pantry shelves are filling up – thanks to you! Check out the short video.

“Special thanks to all our faculty and staff who have donated goods,” said Francesca Catalano, associate dean of the Math, Science and Engineering Division, who is coordinating the pantry. “It’s tough to concentrate in class when you’re hungry, or if you’re worrying how you’ll afford a meal for your family that night. item.title: ATEC News!
item.description:
Article Description: KCC was reapproved for ATEC funds.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:
Greetings everyone -

We learned yesterday that Kankakee Community College was re-approved by the Governor’s office and the Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity to move forward with the Advanced Technology Education Center (ATEC). Rep. Lindsay Parkhurst delivered the news and plans a press release to announce the project moving forward. 

It is still unclear as to when the funds will be released, however, this is a great sign. It’s also exciting that this project will continue and ultimately offer programs that lead to good paying jobs.

As many of you know, ATEC construction began in 2015 on the Riverfront Campus. But, funds were halted at the state level and the project has been stagnant for the past 2+ years.  

We expect construction to resume as soon as the funds are released, however, we can begin engaging our construction partners for planning.  We will keep the college community informed when we have the timeline to share. 

ATEC is designed with classrooms, labs, offices, and support spaces. It will be the place for hands-on technical training in wind generation, solar thermal, solar photo-voltaic systems, and electrical (National Electric Code NEC) instruction. It’s been designed to meet or exceed requirements for the US Green Building Council's Leadership in Energy and Environment Design (LEED) Gold certification. 
Author: Dr. John Avendano
Article Date: 12/7/2017
Expires: 12/14/2017

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

Life insurance benefits more than $50,000 are taxable and must be included on the W-2 form.

The college is required to withhold SURS (State Universities Retirement System) funds on this amount. Due to this SURS withholding requirement, the SURS deduction will be taken out on the last paycheck of the year.

Employees will see a stipend payment with an offsetting benefit deduction on the Dec. 22 paycheck.

Please note that income taxes have been taken out automatically over the course of the year. Anyone with questions is invited to call, Jane Clark, at 815-802-8146.

item.description:
Article Description: Summary of topics from the Board of Trustees meeting.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image Caption:

Article Content:
Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Dec. 12, 2017.
Action Items. The Board approved the following:
  • Adoption of the tax levy
  • Purchase of customer relationship management software
  • Grant award from the Workforce Board
  • Updated board policy manual
  • Revised personnel policy regarding sexual harassment (section 1.4) 
  • Treasurer’s bond increase
  • Bid award for a commercial diesel mower
  • Tuition/course reimbursement
President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…
  • Thanks to Jill Christy for the wonderful Christmas cookies. Jill thanked the board for their service with a homemade tray of treats at the meeting.
  • KCC’s Health Careers division programs offered stats and information in the board book.  
  • The KCC Foundation’s report shares recent highlights for the board.
  • ATEC funding has been appropriated but not yet released by the Dept. of Commerce and Economic Opportunity and the Governor’s office. We are staying in close communication with Rep. Parkhurst’s office to get funds released. 
  • Thanks to the employee recognition event planning team for a wonderful evening.
  • Congratulations to Dr. Kristine Condon, Athena award recipient and student Kim Roggendorf, Women in Networking scholarship recipient. They were honored at the Leading Ladies Luncheon on Nov. 16. 
  • KCC ranks second in North America among associate degree colleges for sustainability practices.
  • Cash Bash is happening on Feb. 17 at 6:30 p.m. at the Quality Inn. Proceeds benefit KCC’s athletics teams.

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…
  • He enjoyed the board member education session led by guest speaker Jim Lanier. The session was hosted by the KCC Foundation. 

Student Trustee’s Report. Justin Hasselbring said …
  • PTK hosted a volleyball tournament on Nov. 20. Eight teams played and the KCC volleyball team set up the nets and officiated the games. 
  • Student Life organized a relaxation week that included an oxygen bar, massages, yoga, coloring stations and puppies to snuggle. 
  • Finals week is happening now, and snack stations are a hit.
  • He participated on the SPOC team working on the care initiative.

item.title: Players needed for Holiday ping pong tourney
item.description:
Article Description: Ping Pong Players Wanted
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Back by popular demand, the excitement of the greatest sport in the world will dawn at KCC on Friday, Dec. 15 when the opening rounds begin in the KCC Holiday Ping Pong Tournament. 

KCC employees and student workers are invited to join the tournament.   

Following are the details: 

Matches will begin Dec. 15, and will be held until a champion is crowned shortly before noon on Dec. 20. The top three players will receive gift cards. Entry fee is a donation to KCC's Food Pantry (on your honor).  

The registration deadline is noon Dec. 14. Sign up at the first floor reception desk. Brackets will be posted on HR's portal, and will also be on display at the tournament site (Cavalier Corner, in the lower level of the College Center). 

In brief, each match will be best two-out-of-three; and each game will be played to 21, but the winner must win by 2. Participants can use their own paddles if they choose. Scoring will use the honor system until the Dec. 20 matches – quarterfinals, semifinals, third place and finals – when a designated official will keep score. Complete rules are available for review at the first floor reception desk and will be posted during the tournament. 

For more information on the tournament, contact David Cagle at 815-802-8128 or email dcagle@kcc.edu or Ellen Schmidt at 815-802-8279 or email eschmidt@kcc.edu.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 12/8/2017
Expires: 12/21/2017
item.author: David Cagle

item.description:
Article Description: Air Hockey Players Wanted
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Another tournament will commence at KCC on Friday, Dec. 15 when the opening rounds begin in the KCC Holiday Air Hockey Tournament. 

KCC employees and student workers are invited to join the tournament.   

Following are the details: 

Matches will begin Dec. 15, and will be held until a champion is crowned shortly before noon on Dec. 20. The top three players will receive gift cards. Entry fee is a donation to KCC's Food Pantry (on your honor).  

The registration deadline is noon Dec. 14. Sign up at the first floor reception desk. Brackets will be posted on HR's portal, and will also be on display at the tournament site (Cavalier Corner, in the lower level of the College Center). 

In brief, each match will be best two-out-of-three; and each game will be played to 10. Scoring will use the honor system until the Dec. 20 matches – quarterfinals, semifinals, third place and finals – when a designated official will keep score. Common sense rules apply, such as players not being able to touch the puck with their hands and not crossing over the middle line. 

For more information on the tournament, contact Josh Gregoire at 815-802-8916 or email jgregoire@kcc.edu.

item.title: Historic Wright home has opportunity for volunteers
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

New volunteers are now being welcomed to work in various capacities at the Bradley House, a Frank Lloyd Wright-designed home in the Riverview neighborhood of Kankakee.

Training is provided for tour interpreters and gift shop volunteers. Volunteers can serve as few or as many hours as desired on any weekend, March to December. Hours on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays are noon - 4 p.m.

Other volunteer positions such as working on the landscaping and assisting at events also are available.

To learn more about becoming a volunteer at the historic Bradley House, go to the Wright House volunteer page or contact me at ext. 8208.

Students are welcome to serve as volunteers. If you know of a student whom you think would be interested, please share this information.

Author: Susan LaMore - member of Wright in Kankakee board of directors
Article Date: 12/12/2017
Expires: 1/5/2018

item.title: Tidings of Cheer! Here are Holiday Buffet Details: 12/20
item.description:
Article Description: Holiday Buffet Dec 20
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Tidings of Cheer! 

Article Content:

It's time to gather in the grand tradition of an all-employee (faculty & staff, full- & part-time, student workers) holiday party beginning at 12:15 p.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 20 in the College Center.

KCC will cease operations at noon on Dec. 20. This will allow employees to gather for the celebration. Following the luncheon and party, all employees are invited to use the remaining afternoon hours to take down holiday decorations and prepare for the new year before adjourning for winter break.

Luncheon details

If you are eating lunch, please bring a dish to share so there can be enough food for everyone. Bring your covered dish to the Cavalier Room before noon.

To ensure variety, if your last name begins with...

  • A-K, please bring a dessert
  • L-Z, please bring a side dish

    Other procedures/info:
  • The meat, plates, napkins, plastic ware, bread and condiments will be provided.
  • Bring a drink, too; beverages will not be provided.
  • The room will be cleaned immediately afterward, so please pick up your dishes before leaving.
  • We will eat in the College Center to accommodate more people.
  • No need to line up early. Sit at numbered tables in the College Center. At 12:10 p.m., a random drawing will determine the order of tables to go through the line.
  • Food tables will have selections on both sides to speed up the line.
  • Everyone is ENCOURAGED to dress in FESTIVE (yet appropriate) HOLIDAY ATTIRE, such as Fuzzy Slippers, Crazy socks & hats, and of course your Favorite Holiday Sweater (ugly or not).  There will be an opportunity to showcase your wardrobe in a Holiday group picture. 

The luncheon will conclude with comments from KCC President Dr. Avendano.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 12/8/2017
Expires: 12/21/2017
item.author: David Cagle

item.title: Tis the season to be jolly, and wear Denim, while supporting KCC Food Pantry
item.description:
Article Description: Wearing jeans to help support KCC's Food Pantry
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Wearing jeans to help support KCC's Food Pantry

Article Content:

If denim days was on your Christmas list, Santa has obliged.  Employees may wear denim on Friday, Dec 15, as well as Mon-Wed, Dec 18-20.  With your jeans, feel free to wear either KCC apparel, a business casual shirt, or perhaps another one of your favorite holiday sweaters while adhering to normal casual denim guidelines (click here to review: http://www.kcc.edu/FacultyStaff/update/Documents/CasualDenimGuidelines.pdf)

Wearing denim does come with one caveat, however.  For each day you wear jeans, you will need to bring in a food donation to stock up KCC's Food Pantry.  Suggested items include: non-perishable foods like canned soups, chili, oatmeal, granola bars, dried fruit/fruit cups, instant breakfast drinks, nuts, jerky or ready to microwave meals (mac and cheese cups for example). A barrel to place your donated food items in will be available at the front desk.  This will be on the honor system and if you forget to bring in a food item to donate, you can always make a cash donation to benefit KCC's Food Pantry.   

Other festivities will occur Dec 18-20 and will be communicated a bit later after all of the details are finalized.  

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 12/8/2017
Expires: 12/21/2017

item.title: Monday Update emails dip into sunset
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
The new year will also bring a new era for Update information.
The portal has made Update more accessible and visible. The portal also includes news and events relevant to all constituents: community, students and staff. 
So, beginning in 2018, full articles will no longer be sent in a weekly email. 
The Marketing Department will continue to send regular emails to employees with links and information about checking the portal. Those emails are planned for at least one time per week at times when new items are posted.
Retirees and friends of KCC who want to continue receiving KCC news are invited to view information on www.kcc.edu/news; follow KCC’s Twitter and Facebook pages; or sign up for RSS feeds.
Anyone with feedback about the portal version of Update is invited to contact Kari Nugent (knugent@kcc.edu) or Ellen Schmidt (eschmidt@kcc.edu) in the marketing office.
Author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Giving Tuesday
item.description:
Article Description: Blue bows show how giving impacts campus.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
The KCC Foundation is celebrating Giving Tuesday on Nov. 28 by highlighting donated items on campus with blue bows. 

“The bows help us recognize just how much philanthropy impacts our campus,” said Kelly Myers, executive director of the KCC Foundation. “The premise behind Giving Tuesday is simple, on the heels of Black Friday and Cyber Monday people around the world come together to celebrate generosity and to give.”

Blue bows are on the following items:

Television in the Workforce Development Center foyer
Bottle-filling water fountains
Equipment at the Manufacturing and Industrial Technology Center
Nursing Simulator
Donor Wall
Wall of Honor
Building signage
Athletics Computer Lab

Facilities
Hammes Café
Hammes Bookstore
Harold and Jean Miner Memorial Library
Governors Room
South Extension Center
North Extension Center

Artwork
Meridian IV 
Songs of Celan
Crow Series
Breeze Keeper

Giving Tuesday is a global day dedicated to giving back.

item.title: United Way/Employee Giving Campaign
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​The United Way/Employee Giving campaign is still underway.  So far, 68 employees have made a pledge raising $12,556 of the $14,000 UW goal.  87 employees have made a pledge to the Employee Giving campaign raising $19,749 of the $20,000 goal.  Both goals are within reach and if you haven't made a pledge as of yet, there is still time to do so.  Pledge forms for the KCC Foundation and the United Way can be found under the "more information" section of the Employee/Human Resources information page or by contacting HR. 

 

As an incentive, all those who make a contribution to one or both campaigns have their names entered into a drawing.  The lucky winners from our most recent drawing are Karen Richards and Kari Livesey.  Both won $25 Wal-Mart gift cards.  Three more drawings will be held before we wrap up the campaign on Dec 20. 

 

As always, we thank you for your continuous support to both worthwhile campaigns…..

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 11/22/2017
Expires: 12/20/2017
item.author: Janet Fager

item.title: 3 administrators present at statewide conference
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
Three administrators recently presented “Student Retention in Foundational Courses: Lessons from KCC” at the Illinois Council of Community College Administrators Conference.

The presenters were Dr. Purva DeVol, director of institutional research and grants development; Dr. Sheldon Walcher, associate dean of the Humanities and Social Sciences Division; and Dr. Francesca Catalano, associate dean of the Math, Science and Engineering Division.

The presentation description said "Longitudinal research on retention at KCC reveals that participation in developmental
English and math courses has dramatic positive impacts on student outcomes. This
presentation documents these findings and explores the teaching and learning
environment that has led to this success."

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 11/21/2017
Expires: 12/8/2017

item.title: Board Notes - Nov. 2017
item.description:
Article Description: Summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Following is a summary of topics addressed at KCC’s Board of Trustees meeting, Nov. 13, 2017.

Action Items. The Board approved the following:

  • Resolution for estimated tax levy amounts
  • Protection, health and safety funds to begin the 4-year project to replace the central heating and cooling plant
  • First reading of an updated board policy manual
  • Application for the Process Technology Solution certificate program
  • Solicitation of bids for a commercial diesel mower
  • Tuition/course reimbursements

Guests and information. The Board met or heard from…

  • Dr. Mike Boyd introduced new professors Pat Bukowski, Nursing and Dr. Meg Mahat, Chemistry.
  • Julia Waskosky shared Title IX information.

President’s Report. Dr. Avendano said…

  • KCC’s data trends show that about 300 students are enrolled in an Associate in Science (AS) degree each fall. The AS degree is one of our most sought-after degrees. It’s designed to transfer, and we guarantee that it does at any four-year college or university in Illinois.
  • The community college presidents’ retreat featured a speech from Comptroller Susana Mendoza. She provided insights about the state budget, bills, and stopped projects. The group also heard updates about the Bachelor’s Degree in Nursing.
  • The Veteran’s Day ceremony and art show was a lovely event, with special thanks to Dr. Cari Stevenson, Kendra Souligne and Jean Janssen.
  • The Bar admission ceremony was also a well-organized event, with special thanks to Dr. Kristine Condon and the Illinois Supreme Court.

Trustee’s Report. Dick Frey said…

  • Roundtable discussions at the Illinois Community College Trustees Association meeting centered on enrollment, marketing, recruiting in K-12 systems, and new program creation, including the Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree.
  • Legislation and trustee trainings were also topics at the meeting.

Student Trustee’s Report. Justin Hasselbring said …

  • More than 200 people attended the Halloween Spooktacular. Clubs provided kids activities and a local theatre company performed Michael Jackson’s Thriller.
  • The charity basketball game Vets vs. Police was a fun and competitive night.
  • The ICCB SAC meeting focused on MAP grants.
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 11/14/2017
Expires: 11/20/2017
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Retirement thanks
item.description:
Article Description: I would like to thank the College and colleagues for my lovely retirement reception.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Dear KCC Colleagues,

I would like to thank the College and colleagues for my lovely retirement reception. The flower arrangement was beautiful, and I appreciated the obvious care given to create a festive setting.

It meant a great deal to me to have so many of the community come by to wish me well, and I was touched by their kind words.

As my husband and I transition and settle into our new home near family in North Carolina, I will continue to be reminded of my friends at KCC by the keepsakes I received that day.

I am maintaining my KCC e-mail account and would look forward to your keeping in touch. If you are ever in the Raleigh area, I would love to get together.

Best wishes to all!
Elise Schultz

Academic Advisor / International Student Advisor
Retired, 9/30/2017

Author: Elise Schultz
Article Date: 11/9/2017

item.title: Recognition Event promises a 'Super' time
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​With some Bam!, a bit of Pop! and maybe even a dash of Zowie! the 2017 Recognition Event will celebrate the Every Day Superheroes of KCC.

The event is Friday, Nov. 17 at the Hilton Garden Inn, in Kankakee.

Forty employees will be honored at the event. Social hour will begin at 5 p.m. A dinner buffet and recognition program will follow, beginning at 6 p.m. Entertainment will follow the program.

Whether you've been there recently or not, you'll find a night of good food, fun, and comraderie.

This year's honorees are ... 

40 years: Barbara Loudy
30 years: Brenda Dressler
25 years: Grace Conway, Donnie Denson and Ellen Schmidt
20 years: Cindy Hebert, Darla Jepson, Stella Mausehund, Alison Nakaerts, Deborah Renville, Gisel Waide, Tim Wilhelm
15 years: Harold Dotson, Kari Livesey and Michael OConnor
10 years: JuTun Andrews King, Aaron Bretveld, David Cagle, Sheri Cagle, Charlie Cooke, Kim DeYoung, Glenda Forneris, Joshua Gregoire, Jamal Hawkins, Kelli Jandura, Akilah Stewart and James Wosz
5 years: George Mateja, Katelynn Ohrt, Deanna Liacone, Katryn Wachtor, Jennifer Blanchette, Ruth Fabbro, Michael Miller, Alia Lockett-Faulkner, Cindy Walters, Ralph Flores, Todd Jenkins and Mary Polka

Congratulations to all of the honorees!

Anyone with questions about the event can send a note to Kari Nugent, director of marketing and public relations, or phone 815-802-8256.

item.title: KCC hosts bar admission ceremony
item.description:
Article Description: Forty new lawyers will take the attorneys’ oath on Thursday, Nov. 9 at KCC.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
Forty new lawyers in the will take the attorneys’ oath on Thursday, Nov. 9 at KCC.  

The bar admission ceremony in the Third Judicial District will begin at 11:00 a.m. in the KCC Auditorium, followed by a reception hosted by the Illinois Bar Association in the Arts and Sciences Foyer. Justice Thomas L. Kilbride of the Illinois Supreme Court will preside over the ceremony, and his daughter Mary Colleen Kilbride is among the candidates to be sworn in. 

The group is amongst 1,335 individuals who will be sworn in and admitted to the practice of law in Illinois during bar admission ceremonies held in the state's five Supreme Court judicial districts. 

All of the candidates have passed the Illinois State Bar Examination and a required ethics examination and were certified by the Supreme Court Committee on Character and Fitness. 
The new attorneys sworn in at the Nov. 9 bar admission ceremonies will bring the total number of licensed attorneys in Illinois to approximately 98,000. In addition to Kankakee, ceremonies will be held Thursday in Chicago, Elgin, Springfield and Carbondale. 

The Third Judicial District includes the following counties: Bureau, Fulton, Grundy, Hancock, Henderson, Henry, Iroquois, Kankakee, Knox, LaSalle, Marshall, McDonough, Mercer, Peoria, Putnam, Rock Island, Stark, Tazewell, Warren, Whiteside and Will. 
Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 11/8/2017
Expires: 11/10/2017
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: Professor to talk about his experiences as a refugee
item.description:
Article Description: Elior Iseli, assistant professor for economics and math, will relate his experience as a refugee from Congo.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Elior Iseli, assistant professor for economics and math, will relate his experience as a refugee from Congo. "The Pursuit of Happiness", a presentation about refugees in the United States, is happening Wednesday, Nov. 15 at 2-3 p.m. in the Workforce Development Center Conference Hall (Room D140).

Elior will talk about why refugees come to the United States; how difficult it is to be a refugee in the US, and the struggles they face upon arrival during the presentation, along with other themes.

KCC's Phi Theta Kappa chapter is hosting the presentation, and it is the chapter's study topic this year.

Faculty who are willing to offer extra credit to classes for attending this presentation are asked to contact Frances Hebert with the course numbers and sections by Monday, Nov. 13, and she will provide a sign-up sheet for each course. Questions can be directed to Frances at ext. 8757 or fhebert@kcc.edu

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 11/3/2017
Expires: 11/16/2017
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: Professor recognized for dedicated service
item.description:
Article Description: Congratulations to Dr. Kristine Condon, recipient of the Will County Bar Association Community Service Award for Nonlaywers.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

​Left-right:  Bob Bodach, WCBA director and chair of the Community Service Awards Committee; Sean Brady, WCBA president and member of KCC's PLAS Advisory Committee; Dr. Kristine Condon; retired Will County Chief Judge Gerald Kinney, recipient of the Community Service Lawyer Award.

Article Content:

​Congratulations to Dr. Kristine Condon, recipient of the Will County Bar Association Community Service Award for Nonlaywers. She accepted the award at a reception in Joliet on Oct. 26. The award recognizes a non-lawyer member of the Will County legal community who, through community service, hard work, and dedication to their profession, has advanced the reputation of the legal community as a whole.

Kris is professor and program coordinator for the Paralegal/Legal Assistant Studies program.

Author: Kari Nugent
Article Date: 11/2/2017
Expires: 11/10/2017

item.title: Update is now exclusively on the Portal
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

The transition of the Update newsletter to the portal is moving along nicely.

New Update items are being placed on the portal exclusively.

Here is a summary of areas (webparts) on the portal with information for all staff:

Update Newsletter - Information and upcoming events exclusive to employees. Events include an event icon.

KCC News - Information and news releases for the community. The community includes students and/or residents of the college district; and usually includes KCC staff, too.

KCC Events - Events which students and/or residents of the college district are invited. Faculty and staff are usually invited as well.

Finding old Update articles

The Update page on KCC's website is now archival only - and you can search of the Update site on kcc.edu for articles going back to 2011.

For archives of Update on the Portal, go to "See All Update Articles" and use the search tool under the list of articles. 

Author: Ellen Schmidt
Article Date: 11/2/2017
Expires: 11/12/2017
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Halloween wrap-up
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​The costumes are hung up and the lights are back on in haunted houses.

With Halloween over, it is time to ring up the results of KCC's employee contests.

Selected for best individual costume was Alice "Tinker" Parker for her Portable Zoo. Second place went to "The Colonel," Roger Ehmpke. 

Others receiving costume votes were: Liz Becvar, Dawn Bennett, Mary Bilderback, Laura Gardner, Amber Gocken, Monica Johnson, Annie Kyrouac, Deanna Liacone, Travis Miller, Kari Nugent, Justin Panozzo, Sheila Pfaff, Karen Richards, James Ryder and Kendra Souligne.

In the department contest, the witches brew-tastic Hocus Pocus group from W102's Division Office won out.

In second, everything was awesome if you got to see the Legoland of Adul Education. Now wearing the bronze colored belt of third place are the WWF entertainers of the Financial Aid Office.

Other participating departments were The Welcome Center/"Con" Ed with Orange is the New Black, Advising and Registration with a retro diner, L355 Academic Office with Clue, and Marketing/media with product mascots.

Thank you to all participants! Get your ideas cooking now and see you next year!

Article Date: 11/1/2017
Expires: 11/17/2017

item.title: Nov 16 FT Employee Benefits Update
item.description:
Article Description: ​It’s almost time to renew your benefits!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​It’s almost time to renew your benefits!

Time is quickly approaching for the full-time employee’s open enrollment period which begins on November 16th and concludes on December 1st . During this period each full time employee will be required to re-enroll their benefits (including FLEX spending) and verify beneficiaries.

This year a representative from Blue Cross/Blue Shield will be on campus to discuss the features of MD Web Live and Blue Access for Members (BAM) on the BC/BS website. Any changes to the current health insurance program will also be explained at this time. Ample time will be available for questions.

All full-time employees are strongly encouraged to attend one of the two information sessions being offered on Thursday, November 16. 

Appointments will be sent to all full-time employees to choose from either the 10 a.m. or the 2 p.m. sessions.

Computer lab, D122, will be available after each session for those employees who wish to re-enroll that day.  HR staff will be available to assist with enrollment and answer any other benefit questions you may have.  Please bring your beneficiary information with you, e.g. SSN, DOB.

Author: Submitted by David Cagle, Director of HR
Article Date: 11/1/2017
Target Audiences: All site users
Expires: 11/17/2017

item.title: Strategic planning updates
item.description:
Article Description: Dr. Boyd shares updates from the Strategic Planning Oversight Committee
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:
Colleagues,
 
At the SPOC Open Forum on October 4th, a general plan was presented to the campus community.  The plan focuses on measureable goals each aligned with one of five Strategic Priorities:  Communication, Cost, Outreach & Marketing, Access, and Culture of Caring.  Five teams have met to begin drafting action plans to achieve these goals over the course of the next year.  At its next meeting, SPOC will review progress made on these Action Plans so that the college can move forward with this important work.

More specific information regarding these action plans will be available after SPOC’s meeting on November 14th.  If you have any questions, please feel free to contact one of the Team Chairs directly.
 
Communication – Dr. John Avendano
Cost – Vicki Gardner, Kelly Myers
Outreach & Marketing – Kari Nugent
Access – Dr. Michael Boyd
Culture of Caring – Julia Waskosky, David Cagle   
 
Thank you,

MB
Author: Dr. Mike Boyd, vice president for Instructional and Student Success
Article Date: 10/31/2017
Expires: 11/10/2017
item.author: Kari Nugent

item.title: SURS and the Social Security Windfall Provision - Video Presentation
item.description:
Article Description: Do you expect to get Social Security in addition to your SURS pension when you retire?
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Submitted by Linda Guinn, KCC SUAA President

  • Do you expect to get Social Security in addition to your SURS pension when you retire?
  • Did you know your Social Security benefits will be reduced because of your SURS pension?
  • Want to understand how Social Security and your SURS pension interact (the Windfall Provision)?

Come to the Workforce Development Center Conference Hall on Wednesday, Nov. 1 and get the answers.

The KCC SUAA Chapter will show a video featuring John Meyers of the  Springfield Social Security Office, who answered the above questions (and more) at the SUAA Foundation Meeting this past June.

After seeing his presentation, KCC employee Mary Posing commented “Mr. Meyers gave the best and clearest explanation of the windfall provision that I have heard.”

The 37-minute video will be shown twice on Wednesday, Nov. 1 -- 11:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m.

Bring a lunch to eat while you watch. Dessert will be provided.  All KCC employees are invited to attend one of the showings.

In addition, SUAA members will be given directions for downloading the new SUAA mobile app.

Article Date: 10/26/2017
Expires: 11/2/2017
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: New ITS Help Desk hours
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Effective Monday, Oct. 30, the Information Technology Services Help Desk will change its hours.

The new hours are

Mon.-Thurs.: 7:30 a.m. - 8 p.m.
Fri.: 7:30 a.m. - 5 p.m.
Sat. & Sun.: Closed

The change is designed to better meet the needs of constituents when demand is greatest. Over the last few years, ITS has seen declining demand on weekdays after 8 p.m. and on weekends. Thus, a reallocation of resources was necessary.

ITS still will make resources available during off-hours by special request.

Any questions or concerns can be addressed to Michael OConnor, director of ITS, at moconnor@kcc.edu or 815-802-8908.

Article Date: 10/18/2017
Expires: 11/10/2017

item.title: Donate blood in memory of Jace Lillis
item.description:
Article Description: The ninth annual blood drive in memory of Jace will be Saturday, Nov. 4 from 9 am-2 pm at the Bourbonnais Upper Grade Center.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

The ninth annual blood drive in memory of Jace Lillis will be Saturday, Nov. 4 from 9 a.m. - 2 p.m. at the Bourbonnais Upper Grade Center, 200 W John Casey Rd, Bourbonnais. For an appointment, text Lisa Lillis at 815-955-1383 or visit redcrossblood.org. Donors must bring photo ID and should eat a meal a couple of hours before donating.

Jace was a KCC graduate who died in 2003 after a drunk driver struck the motorcycle he was driving. Jace was actively involved in KCC’s clubs and organization, and his parents Thad and Lisa Lillis, have established a KCC scholarship in his name.

Article Date: 10/20/2017

item.title: Final chance to register for Halloween contest
item.description:
Article Description: The KCC Halloween Competition is coming up quickly!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The KCC Halloween Competition is coming up quickly!

The competition will be on Halloween, Monday, Oct. 31. Keep your theme under wraps until the event. The department with the winning theme will keep the "Fabulous" Traveling Tacky Trophy until the 2018 competition.

There also is a Traveling Tacky Trophy for best costume. The costume winner doesn't have to be part of one of the office/area themes.

To get into the spirit of the day and join in, please contact Sheila Pfaff, spfaff@kcc.edu or 815-802-8704, by end of the day Monday, Oct. 23.  Ballots will be prepared and printed the week before Halloween.

The following departments have joined the competition so far: Adult Ed, The Welcome Center, Marketing/Media, Financial Aid, L355, and for the 1st time W102.  Any department not on the list who plans to be in the competition, make sure Sheila is contacted by Monday.

item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Image Caption:

KCC Adjunct Professor Dr. Kris Condi has published a new book.

"N is for Noah" is her first children's book and fifth book overall. It is available at Amazon.com, barnesandnoble.com, Andersonbookshop.com and other locations online.

The ISBN is 9781480851344 or 9781480851337 depending on the website.

It is from Archway Publishing, the self-publishing arm of Simon & Shuster.

Kris teaches in the Business and Technology Division, and is teaching four classes this semester.

item.title: Found in the tree grove
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​A crew from Physical Plant Department recently found a marker for a "Student Grove."

They found it while clearing vegetation in the wooded area alongside College Drive, across from the golf course. The space around the stone is now pretty open, to show the grove was established in January 1977. The marker also says "To recognize those students who have served the College with distinction, this arbor grove is dedicated in their honor."

Near the marker were some tagged pin oaks with student names.

Anyone with more information about the grove is welcome to contact George Mateja, coordinator of grounds and horticulture management.

Note: The Student Grove is different from the "Student Trustee Grove."

Article Date: 10/13/2017
Expires: 10/27/2017

item.title: SURS and the Social Security Windfall Provision - Video Presentation
item.description:
Article Description: Do you expect to get Social Security in addition to your SURS pension when you retire?
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​​Submitted by Linda Guinn, KCC SUAA President

  • Do you expect to get Social Security in addition to your SURS pension when you retire?
  • Did you know your Social Security benefits will be reduced because of your SURS pension?
  • Want to understand how Social Security and your SURS pension interact (the Windfall Provision)?

Come to the Workforce Development Center Conference Hall on Wednesday, Oct. 25 and get the answers.

The KCC SUAA Chapter will show a video featuring John Meyers of the Springfield Social Security Office, who answered the above questions (and more) at the SUAA Foundation Meeting this past June.

After seeing his presentation, KCC employee Mary Posing commented “Mr. Meyers gave the best and clearest explanation of the windfall provision that I have heard.”

The 37-minute video will be shown twice on Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- 11:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m.

Bring a lunch to eat while you watch. Dessert will be provided.  All KCC employees are invited to attend one of the showings.

In addition, SUAA members will be given directions for downloading the new SUAA mobile app.

Expires: 10/26/2017

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​Starting in mid-October, mental health counselors will offer services on the Riverfront Campus for employees and students.

Clinical interns and psychologists with Transformative Growth Counseling will be in Student Services, and can help anyone experiencing stressors at work, school or life. The confidential services are affordable and insurance is accepted. No one will be turned away for inability to pay.

 Learn more or phone 630-423-6010 to schedule an appointment.

item.title: Cavaliers Baseball Ring Ceremony
item.description:
Article Description: You're invited to celebrate with the Cavaliers National Championship team as they receive their World Series rings on Saturday, Oct. 7 in the KCC Auditorium.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

You're invited to celebrate with the Cavaliers National Championship team as they receive their World Series rings on Saturday, Oct. 7 in the KCC Auditorium. Ceremony begins at 5 p.m. followed by a reception.

Refreshments will be served.

KCC's baseball team won the NJCAA Division II National Championship by defeating Mercer County (N.J.) on June 2. The Cavaliers finished with a record of 54 wins, 11 losses and one tie.

On their way to the championship, the Cavaliers accumulated a tournament-record 78 total runs in seven games, which included scoring in double-digits six times.

The Cavaliers are coached by Todd Post, and the assistant coach is Bryce Shafer.

 

Article Date: 10/3/2017
Expires: 10/8/2017

item.title: United Way and Foundation campaigns are underway
item.description:
Article Description: The United Way/Employee Giving kick-off on Sept. 27 got the campaigns off to a good start.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

The United Way/Employee Giving kick-off on Sept. 27 got the campaigns off to a good start. There were 53 United Way pledges, raising just over $10,000 of the $14,000 goal. For KCC Foundation, there were 64 employees have pledged $14,000 toward the $20,000 goal. 

Anyone who missed the kick-off and would like to make a pledge is invited to use the attached pledge forms – one is for KCC Foundation and the other is for United Way.
For incentives and inspiration to give, there is an incentives flier and 2 minute 6 second campaign video.

Following the kickoff, all those who donated to one or both campaigns were entered into a drawing for a $50 Walmart gift card. The lucky recipient is Sharon Hoogstraat. The campaigns will run through Nov. 22, and there will be five more drawings to win gift cards. 

Thank you for your supporting the KCC Foundation and United Way!

item.title: The 10th Annual KCC Halloween Competition is just around the corner!
item.description:
Article Description: We had our summer fun this year; now it is time for the start of some fall fun.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

We had our summer fun this year; now it is time for the start of some fall fun.

The annual Halloween contest will be on Tuesday, Oct. 31. This will be the 10th year that areas of the college have competed against each other for the best Halloween costumes and department theme.

"I can't believe we have been holding this fantastic annual competition on the main campus for 10 years now," said Sheila Pfaff, one of the competition organizers. "I hope those brain juices have been flowing over the past year and people aren't stuck in the Beetlejuice waiting room! I can't wait!"

Each area's theme must be kept under wraps to keep the competition from borrowing ideas. As an incentive, the winning department will keep the "Fabulous" Traveling Tacky Trophy and will be able to show it off until the 2018 competition.

There also will be a Traveling Tacky Trophy for best costume. The winner of the best costume does not have to be part of one of the office/area themes.

If your department or staff in your area would like to get into the spirit of the day, please contact Sheila Pfaff, spfaff@kcc.edu or 815-802-8700 by Friday, Oct. 20.

Article Date: 9/27/2017
Expires: 10/20/2017

item.title: KCC group presents at 'Forum for Excellence'
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

A group from KCC is presenting today (Sept. 20)  at the "Forum for Excellence Conference" at Illinois State University.

The panel of KCC presenters is Maggie Wolf, Gregg Beglau, Mary Posing, Dana Washington and Mark Anderson. They are holding a panel discussion on "Partnerships for Student Success." The discussion will share challenges and successes which resulted when the Adult Education Department collaborated with the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act on a project to offer students an industry recognized credential. 

The attached photo was taken of the group of presenters by Dr. Michael Boyd, who said ​"Proud of my team."

Mike, who is vice president for instructional and student success, also is a presenter at the conference. He is presenting "Illinois Essential Employability Skills Framework" along with two representatives of the Illinois Center for Specialized Professional Support.

item.title: Cavalier Cap Challenge is underway!
item.description:
Article Description: A new Cavalier Cap Challenge recycling competition is under way.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

A new Cavalier Cap Challenge recycling competition is under way.

It’s time to form teams – from student clubs/organizations, departments, sports teams, or any other group. Teams can register with the Office of Student Life until Friday, Sept. 29. Registrations are in person (Room L116, next to the auditorium) or by email to ltwilliams@kcc.edu.

The Office of Student Life will have a progress chart located near the Student Activities bulletin board. The competition goes through early March 2018. The team which collects the most caps will win a pizza party!

Teams should collect plastic bottle caps and save them in plastic bags. Clearly label the bags with the team name before putting it in a Cavalier Cap Challenge recycle bin (locations listed below). To participate individually, collect bottle caps and place them in any of the seven designated bins!

It takes 400 pounds of caps -- enough to fill approximately 10 55-gallon yard waste/trash bags -- to make a bench. It takes 500 pounds of caps to make a trash receptacle, and 1,000 pounds of caps to make a picnic table. 

The new benches, picnic tables and/or waste receptacles will be placed outside of the Riverfront Campus to offer a place to sit and enjoy the campus.

“We would like to continue what Abby Fisher, 2016-17 student trustee, started," said Linh Williams, coordinator of student life. "The college has a beautiful setting and we would like to see more students and community members enjoying our outdoor space."

Part of the Challenge this year will be to raise funds to help pay for the benches, trash receptacles and picnic tables. The cost of a bench is half price if we bring in the required weight in caps. Many student clubs have agreed to join the effort of raising funds and helping to sort the caps before they are taken to be recycled. If any team or individual would like to sponsor a bench, please talk to Linh Williams or Alison Nakaerts. If a bench or other cap-creation is sponsored, the group/individual will have a plaque on it.

“We hope to bring some fun, friendly competition to campus while also encouraging the habit of recycling to our students and staff. Thank you for your support and participation!” Williams said.

Cavalier Cap Challenge bin locations

  • First floor- front desk
  • College Center
  • Workforce Development Center
  • Gymnasium
  • Second floor- Student Services
  • Arts & Sciences Building
  • Third floor - near L355

This list of acceptable lids and caps is handy to save or print. Another tip : If it floats, donate it!

Thanks for participating!

Article Date: 9/20/2017
Expires: 10/13/2017

item.title: Tips and methods for reporting concerns
item.description:
Article Description: As the fall semester begins, the following information may be helpful to faculty and staff.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​As the fall semester begins, the following information may be helpful to faculty and staff. To report a potential or current concern, use the following contact options:

Situation: Violations to Code of Conduct (Section 17.0 of the current catalog)
Action: Email or phone David Hermann at dhermann@kcc.edu or phone 815-802-8524 or Julia Waskosky at jwaskosky@kcc.edu or phone 815-802-8510.

Situation: Student exhibits unusual behavior that may not be considered a violation to the Code of Conduct
Action: Email the Behavioral Intervention Team at bit@kcc.edu.

Situation: Criminal behavior
Action: phone the KCC Police Department at 815-802-8195 or complete the online anonymous report: http://www.kcc.edu/reportacrime.
If you or someone else is in immediate danger, call 911 then notify college security at 815-802-8190 or utilize security phones in the parking lot.

Situation: Sexual harassment, gender discrimination or sexual violence
Action: Please reach out right away – Fill out the online complaint form: www.kcc.edu/titleix or file in person with the Title IX Coordinator, Julia Waskosky, at 815-802-8510 or jwaskosky@kcc.edu. We are here to help. All concerns and reports are confidential.

Article Date: 9/19/2017
Expires: 9/30/2017
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: In development: New cohort A.A. transfer program
item.description:
Article Description: ​A new cohort-based Associate in Arts degree is in development. Tentatively titled Fast Path, the program will allow students who might ordinarily only be able to attend classes part-time to complete the A.A
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:
A new cohort-based Associate in Arts degree is in development. Tentatively titled Fast Path, the program will allow students who might ordinarily only be able to attend classes part-time to complete the A.A. in two years. Students will take two classes at a time in eight-week sessions, meeting twice a week for three hours. Other features include:
  • Each cohort will be limited to 20 students.
  • Students will complete all courses together as a group, creating rich opportunities for collaboration, friendship, and support.
  • Classes will be delivered in both blended and online formats.
  • A dedicated faculty mentor will assist students as they progress throughout the program.
  • Offered at two locations: Riverfront Campus and Miner South Extension Center.
  • Textbooks and a laptop may be bundled into the cost.
  • The program will culminate with students completing a capstone project supervised by their faculty mentor.

TheAssociate in Arts is a transfer degree approved by the Illinois Articulation Initiative, a statewide transfer agreement with more than 100  participating four-year colleges and universities in Illinois. It also is transferrable to many out-of-state colleges.

For more information, contact Dr. Sheldon Walcher, associate dean of the Humanities and Social Science Division or Dr. Francesca Catalano, associate dean of the Math, Science and Engineering Division.

Article Date: 9/19/2017
Expires: 9/30/2017

item.title: Look to the ‘writing on the wall’ for more ideas
item.description:
Article Description: The Strategic Planning Oversight Committee wants to know what students think.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​The Strategic Planning Oversight Committee wants to know what students think. So, beginning the week of Sept. 18, banners will be on walls around campus asking students how we can improve their KCC experience.

A virtual wall will be available in Canvas, too. Please encourage students to participate.

Student feedback will help formulate the college’s next strategic plan. The current plan runs until 2018.

“Enrollment is a challenge right now, so the SPOC committee is channeling efforts to improve it,” said Dr. Mike Boyd, vice president for instructional and student success. “We gathered input from our faculty and staff at the open forum last week, and we’re also asking students for their input.”

The banners will be up until Sept. 22. Employee feedback with ideas about enrollment can be shared with Mike at mboyd@kcc.edu.

Article Content:

Congratulations to Dr. Kristine Condon on her nomination for the Will County Bar Association’s Service to the Community Award for Nonlawyers. 

The award recognizes “a non-lawyer member of the Will County legal community who, through community service, hard work, and dedication to their profession, has advanced the reputation of the legal community as a whole.” The recipient will be announced Oct. 26.

“Our students have had a big impact in Will County,” said Kris. “I’m happy that the nomination put KCC on the regional legal map!”

Kris is a professor and coordinator of the Paralegal/Legal Assistant Studies Program.

item.title: New Early Alert Form
item.description:
Article Description: The KCC Early Alert Program is now taking referrals.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​

The KCC Early Alert Program is now taking referrals. This program allows instructors to identify students who may be struggling in their class(es) and may be at risk of unsuccessful completion. The main goals of Early Alert & Intervention are:

 

  • Identify issues with students in the classroom before it is too late to impact the student's success.
  • Improve student retention and persistence at KCC. 

 

This year, we have updated the process by creating a JotForm to expedite services.  If you are concerned about a student's academic performance, please submit a completed JotForm located through the link below:

 

https://form.jotform.com/71515809914966

 

Upon completion, the information collected on the JotForm will be forwarded on to his/her assigned advisor for intervention.

 

Instances where you may refer a student:

  • Consistently late homework assignments
  • Below-average scores on homework or exams
  • Time management issues
  • Consistently absent from class
  • Difficulty with directions or classroom guidelines
  • Reluctance to seek outside help to improve classroom performance

 

We look forward to working with you in helping our students be successful at KCC.


Article Date: 9/12/2017
Expires: 1/2/2018
item.author: Aindrea Hogan

item.title: ​Prepare for the forum
item.description:
Article Description: An infographic is being shared to help you prepare for the strategic planning open forum.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content: An infographic is being shared to help you prepare for the strategic planning open forum.

The graphic summarizes outcomes from the current plan, key data trends, and ongoing enrollment efforts. The audience will be asked to help generate ideas for future enrollment activities.

The open forum will focus on enrollment and takes place tomorrow, Sept. 6 from 3-5 p.m. in the Auditorium. Faculty and staff are all invited to attend.

“Our current institutional strategic plan concludes in 2018, and enrollment is the biggest strategic challenge right now,” said Dr. Michael Boyd, vice president for Instructional and Student Success. “Instead of working on another long-range strategic plan, let’s design an alternate strategy, with an intense and specific action plan, aimed at increasing enrollment.”

The Strategic Planning Oversight Committee (SPOC) is hosting the forum. Afterward, SPOC will use the ideas generated to determine future strategic priorities. Action teams will be organized for each of the strategic priorities. The teams will develop measurements, action steps, and accountability plans to ensure progress and results.

"We all have an important role to play as we face challenges related to current enrollment trends,” Mike said. “We hope you’ll join us at the forum.”

Article Date: 9/5/2017
Expires: 9/6/2017
item.author: Ellen Schmidt

item.title: Grief counseling services available
item.description:
Article Description: ​The recent deaths of local community students is tragic and heartbreaking.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​The recent deaths of local community students is tragic and heartbreaking.

To help KCC students and staff cope with this loss, the college will offer grief counseling with a licensed counselor and social worker. They will provide counseling and education materials about suicide prevention:

  • Monday, Aug. 28 from 1-2:30 p.m. in Room L110, the Auditorium.
  • Tuesday, Aug. 29 from 1-3 p.m. in Room L110, the Auditorium.

Immediate counseling is available from trained staff at nearby certified crisis centers:

  • www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org – includes chat option
  • 1-800-273-TALK
  • 1-815-935-1600

If you are thinking of harming yourself, or are grieving and want someone to talk to, please seek help. Thank you.

item.title: Hybrid Design and Development Group
item.description:
Article Description: Throughout fall semester, participating faculty will meet regularly to collaborate and share the goal of developing their own full courses in hybrid format.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Throughout fall semester, participating faculty will meet regularly to collaborate and share the goal of developing their own full courses in hybrid format. The Teaching and Learning Center will provide support and guidance with instructional design concepts and technical skill development important for this modality. There will be numerous resources provided, discussions, and sharing with and among the group as we develop hybrid courses aligned with best-known practices.

An initial kickoff meeting has been scheduled for Thursday, Sept. 7 at 2 p.m. in Room D327. At this first event, we will establish goals and objectives for the group and determine subsequent meeting dates and frequency. Please note that prior completion, or concurrent enrollment, in the Canvas Challenge is a requirement.

item.title: Fall Canvas Challenge
item.description:
Article Description: We cordially invite all faculty to participate in our Fall Canvas Challenge course starting the first week of September.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content: We cordially invite all faculty to participate in our Fall Canvas Challenge course starting the first week of September. We learn best by doing, and that’s the idea behind this course in which participants complete a series of authentic core Canvas tasks in their own practice sandbox.

When done, you’ll earn the Canvas Challenge completion badge that you can proudly display. Each week a cohort of participants will be asked to complete one challenge and associated activities.  All activities can be completed online at your own convenience during the week.

Join the more than 40 KCC faculty and staff who have already taken on the Canvas Challenge!

“I learned something that could be used to improve my own course almost every week.”

“Taking this course has helped me so much this year! It has made me realize what students are experiencing working in Canvas.”

“I also appreciated seeing so many examples from live courses. It has helped me to rethink some of my own presentation.”

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Faculty and staff are invited to attend a strategic planning forum focused on enrollment on Wednesday, Sept. 6 from 3-5 p.m. in the Auditorium. Calendar appointments will be sent.

Outcomes from the current strategic plan and enrollment efforts will be presented. The audience also will be asked to help generate ideas for future enrollment activities.

“Our current institutional strategic plan concludes in 2018, and enrollment is the biggest strategic challenge right now,” said Dr. Michael Boyd, vice president for Instructional and Student Success. “Instead of working on another long-range strategic plan, let’s design an alternate strategy, with an intense and specific action plan, aimed at increasing enrollment.”

The Strategic Planning Oversight Committee (SPOC) is hosting the forum. Afterward, SPOC will use the ideas generated to determine future strategic priorities. Action teams will be organized for each of the strategic priorities. The teams will develop measurements, action steps, and accountability plans to ensure progress and results.

“We all have an important role to play as we face challenges related to current enrollment trends,” said Mike. “We hope you’ll join us at the forum.”

Author: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)

Expires: 9/6/2017

item.title: Thanks-a-gram: ITS
item.description:
Article Description: Employees are encouraged to use Thanks-a-Grams as a way of recognizing each other.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Employees are encouraged to use Thanks-a-Grams as a way of recognizing each other.

There are two steps.

First, present a "Thanks-a-Gram" to a deserving co-worker. Thanks-a-Grams are online and in print in marketing and public relations.

Second, the person giving it can give a copy or email it to the human resources department. Human resources will ask the recipient(s) if it is OK to be published in Update and posted on the "You Rock" wall north of Physical Plant Department.

Thanks-a-gram 

TO: ITS
FROM: KCC Foundation staff
RE: Online link

After sending out invites to an event, we realized that we had not included an online payment option.  We brought our SOS to IT and they helped create an appropriate link to email to invitees.  Mike O'Connor and his crew were very helpful and made it happen quickly-We are so grateful!
