item.title: ​State Sen. Daniel Biss to Speak at Upcoming KCC SUAA Meeting
item.description:
Article Description: The KCC State University Annuitants Association Chapter will hold its annual meeting on Monday, Sept. 18 from 5:30-7:30 p.m., at Aurelio's Pizza, 1600 N. Convent St., Bourbonnais
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

Submitted by Linda Guinn, KCC Annuitants Association president

The KCC State University Annuitants Association Chapter will hold its annual meeting on Monday, Sept. 18 from 5:30-7:30 p.m., at Aurelio's Pizza, 1600 N. Convent St., Bourbonnais. The cost is $15 per person, which includes garden salad; pizza buffet (cheese, vegetarian, sausage, pepperoni, and "the combination"); soft drink, coffee or tea; tax and gratuity.

State Sen. Daniel Biss is the featured speaker for the evening. An advocate for higher education, Senator Biss will answer questions on higher education funding, pensions and pension debt, the state budget, etc. In addition, SUAA Executive Director Linda Brookhart will be available to talk with people before and after the meeting.

There is limited seating, and registration is open exclusively to chapter members (including new members) and their guests through Aug. 25. After Aug. 25, if seats are still available, all KCC employees are invited to register.

Registration with payment must be received by Sept. 8. No payments will be taken at the meeting. Register by sending your payment to Mary Posing in Continuing Education and Career Services. Checks should be made out to KCC SUAA Chapter.

Tentative agenda
5:30-5:45 p.m.  -  Check in
5:45-6:15 p.m. - Eat salad and pizza
6:15 - approx. 6:35 p.m. - Chapter Business Meeting
Approx. 6:35-7:30 p.m. - Senator Biss: Question/Answer Format
7:30 p.m. - Adjournment

For more information, contact any KCCAA Board member: Mary Posing, Cindy Walters, Steve DePasquale, Liz Becvar, Kari Livesey, or Barbara Arseneau; or email Linda Guinn at l.guinn1@aol.com.

Article Date: 8/14/2017
Expires: 9/8/2017

item.title: Gearing up for fall
item.description:
Article Description: Learn about the marketing initiatives we've been working on to drive fall enrollment.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

It is hard to believe the fall semester starts in three short weeks. I wanted to share some of the marketing initiatives we’ve been working throughout the summer to drive additional students for fall. Nancy Schunke has coordinated similar efforts for the South Extension Center market. The entire campaign promotes register.kcc.edu, and we can see clicks and increased traffic to the page when ads run.

Newspaper

Running a series of ads in the Daily Journal, Herald and local community newspapers.
Press release sent out to encourage fall enrollment and promote the special Saturday registration date.

Radio

KCC ads are running on area stations, coupled with on-air interviews promoting registration.

Outdoor

Billboards featuring KCC are in five community locations.

Direct Mail

A postcard encouraging registration went to most homes in our district area.

High school juniors and seniors received customized communications throughout the year.

Text messages

Current students received messages encouraging them to register.

Email

Current students received email messages promoting registration.

Geofencing

Technology targeting specific audiences was used to send ads to their cell phones. Engagement was high with these segments. The most recent results reported that 607 people who received the ads visited campus after seeing them.

Facebook

We have been running Facebook ads on KCC’s page, and we can count the number of people who click on our ads. If any of you have a personal Facebook page we encourage you to follow the KCC pages and share the information on your personal page. Sharing maximizes our exposure for no additional cost. Social media is a great tool to get our messages out with little virtually no cost to the college. https://www.facebook.com/KankakeeCommunityCollege/

Branding

In addition to driving registration, we coordinate ways to tell our story. Check our college’s social media pages on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. We also highlight alumni and student success stories with our ad campaigns, Fabulous Fifty Alumni awards, and stories on our News and Events web page.

Today, our enrollment is tracking 10.27% down in credit hours from this time last year. What can you do to move the meter? Here are a few tips:
Repost KCC’s Facebook ads
Talk about KCC with your family and friends
Take an interest in students or prospective students, because one caring adult can make a difference for students.

Author: Kari Nugent, director of Marketing and Public Relations
Article Date: 8/2/2017
Expires: 8/18/2017

item.title: Casual Day 7/7
item.description:
Article Description: ​Because it is a Friday when classes are not being held, on July 7, employees will have the option to following the casual day guidelines:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​​Because it is a Friday when classes are not being held, on July 7, employees will have the option to following the casual day guidelines:
-- Participation is optional.
-- Jeans may be worn if accompanied by a collared shirt with "Kankakee Community College" on it or if accompanied by a business casual shirt and a KCC name badge or staff ID. KCC shirts are sold at the Hammes Bookstore and a limited selection is available in marketing and public relations. Prices vary at both locations. Visit the bookstore or Linda Chouinard for more information.
-- Staff are asked to use their good judgment in choosing appropriate jeans. Inappropriate jeans include those with patches, fraying, excessive length, low-rise cut and/or very faded.
-- Those who choose not to wear jeans should wear their normal work attire; or they can choose to wear a KCC collared shirt along with their normal attire.
-- All employee groups can participate.
-- Please use good judgment in choosing whether to wear jeans. Depending on what is scheduled for a particular day, jeans may or may not be appropriate. Professional appearance is important, and all employees share the responsibility of representing the college.
 
Questions regarding casual days should be directed to David Cagle, director of human resources.

Author: The Shadow
Article Date: 6/15/2017
Expires: 7/7/2017
item.author: James Wosz
